QUITTELL--Dr. Glenn S.,We couldn't love you more, and we will miss you. Love, Jeanne, Robin, Aron, Jordana, Ric, Lynne, Eric & Alexandra.

QUITTELL--Dr. Glenn S.,68, on November 12. Devoted husband to Jeanne; loving father to Robin and father-in-law of Aron; doting grandfather of Jordana; loyal big brother of Ric and Lynne; and uncle to Alexandra. Graveside service at Rose Hills Memorial Park, Putnam Valley, NY, on Thursday at 1:30pm. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Lustgarten Foundation.

PTASZEK--Dr. Barbara Alper. The congregation of Westchester Reform Temple mourns the death of its devoted member and extends sympathy to her bereaved family. Helene K. Gray, President Jonathan E. Blake, Rabbi Jill Abramson, Cantor Sara Abrams, Rabbi

PLATTEN--Margaret Wyckoff 95, died at her home in Stamford, CT on Tuesday, November 5 surrounded by her family. The daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William W. Wyckoff of East Orange, NJ and a direct descendant of Pieter Claesen Wyckoff, she was a graduate of Wellesley College. Her husband, Donald C. Platten, former Chairman of Chemical Bank, predeceased her in 1991 after 51 years of marriage. A resident of Darien for 46 years, she was a Trustee and Board member of: League of Women Voters, Mid-Fairfield Child Guidance Center, Darien Community Association, Wellesley College Durant Society, Noroton Presbyterian Church (where she led a children's choir for 17 years), and New-York Historical Society. Her descendants are Katherine Platten Tyson (John), Peter Wyckoff Platten (Mary June), Alison Platten Vanderbilt (Alfred), seven grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11am on Saturday, November 23rd at Noroton Presbyterian Church in Darien, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Horton Scholarship Fund at Noroton Presbyterian Church or the College Scholarship Fund at the Darien Community Association.

PAYNE--Orville Smith, 97, after suffering severe complications from a devastating fall, passed away, at New York Presbyterian Hospital on November 6, 2013. She was the daughter of Dr. Robert E. Smith and Ruth Lofton Smith. She is survived by her sons, Judge Kibbie F. Payne (Ret.) and Attorney Kirby F. Payne, and her daughters Carolyn Payne-Dean Fairley, Ed. M., and Yvonne P. Daniel, Ph.D, four grandsons, ten great- grandchildren, and many other relatives and friends.

MILLER--Samuel C. World Monuments Fund regrets the passing of Sam Miller, 15-year trustee and ardent advocate for heritage preservation. With his wife Rosetta, a tireless promoter of Angkor's preservation, sponsor of the Rosetta garuda. A thoughtful advisor, cognoscente, and raconteur, Sam will be missed.

LUTZ--Frank X.,65, of Hazlet, NJ, on November 9, 2013. Beloved companion of Ann McIlmurray and brother of Lavinia Mancuso and Elizabeth Minor. He will be greatly missed by his family and his many friends. Gathering at Shore Points Funeral Home, Hazlet, Friday 4-8pm Funeral at Holy Family Church, Hazlet, Saturday 9:30am Memorial donations to www.everyonereading.org

KAGAN--Saul. The American Gathering of Jewish Holocaust Survivors and Their Descendants mourns the passing of our former executive vice president Saul Kagan. Holocaust survivors are grateful for his untiring efforts on their behalf. May his memory be for a blessing to all.

KAGAN--Saul. The Board of Trustees and staff of The Jewish Foundation for the Righteous deeply mourns the passing of Saul Kagan a devoted friend. Saul's kindness, caring, and humility will be missed. Saul made a difference in the lives of Holocaust survivors and Righteous Gentiles. We extend our heartfelt sympathies to Eleanor and the entire family. Harvey Schulweis, Chairman Roman Kent, President Stanlee J. Stahl, Executive Vice President

KAGAN--Saul. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum mourns the passing of our great friend and partner Saul Kagan. He tirelessly devoted his long life to securing restitution for Holocaust survivors and to honoring the memory of the victims. Undeterred by any obstacles, his historic efforts have improved the lives of survivors and advanced Holocaust memory and education worldwide. He leaves an extraordinary legacy. The Museum extends its sincere condolences to his wife Eleanor and his entire family. Tom A. Bernstein, Chairman Joshua B. Bolten, Vice Chairman Sara J. Bloomfield, Director The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum

JURITH--EDWARD H. Passed peacefully November 9, 2013 at home in NW Washington, D.C. surrounded by family and friends. Survived by Kathleen M. Healy, his wife of 29 years, sons, Theodore E. and William C. of D.C., sister, Carolyn Huber Clarke (Anthony) NY. Visitation Thurs, 6-8pm; Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 11am, both at Shrine of The Most Blessed Sacrament, 3630 Quesada St., NW, DC. In lieu of flowers family requests donations to Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School, 357 Clermont Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11238.

HRUZA--Judita M.,MD, died October 28th, 2013. Beloved wife of Zdenek, mother of Eva (Mark), George (Carrie) and adored grandmother of David, Audrey, Stephanie, Paul, Hope and Rose. A revered physician, she had a long and fulfilling career at Manhattan Psychiatric Center. A Holocaust survivor without bitterness, Judita made it her mission to extend the lessons of her anguish through intimate talks with young people throughout the world. Donations in her memory can be directed to the Holocaust Museum and Learning Center, St. Louis, MO. www.hmlc.org

HORVITZ--Dvora, age 68, of New York City, passed away November 12, 2013, following a courageous battle with cancer. Loving and beloved partner of Yossi Segal and mother of Asaf Segal. For more than 40 years, a creative force behind the exquisite jewelry designs of Tambetti Inc. She will be sorely missed by all who knew her. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Beth Israel Medical Center In Memory Of Dvora Horvitz, 555 W. 57th St. 18th Floor. New York, NY 10019.

GOTIMER--Msgr. James E.,on November 11, 2013. Former Pastor of Saint Bartholomew RC Church in Elmhurst, NY. Reposing Gerard J. Neufeld Inc. Funeral Home 88-04 43rd Ave, Elmhurst, NY, Friday 1pm-6pm. Vigil Mass Saint Bartholomew RC Church, Friday at 7:30pm. Funeral Mass, Saturday at Saint Bartholomew RC Church at 10:30am. Interment at Holy Cross Cemetery.

VOLPER--Ronald J.,67, of Larchmont, NY, passed away November 11, 2013. Cherished husband of Hillary, adored father of Erik and Amanda (Sandy Krohn), beloved brother of Adrienne Schere (Alan), Steven (Joyce), Vicki (Mark Goldstein). Missed terribly by loving family, devoted friends. Admired for his kindness, wisdom, generosity, loyalty, business acumen, and delightful sense of humor. An irreplaceable mensch among men. Funeral Friday, November 15, 10am, Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, NY.

STEIN--Martin Frederick (Fritz), Jr.,M.D., of Bronxville N.Y., died November 11, 2013 after a sudden stroke. He was 77 years old. A native New Yorker and graduate of Columbia University, he received his medical degree from Albany Medical College in 1962. He devoted his career to the care of patients with kidney disease and served as Medical Director of St. Joseph's Hospital in Yonkers, NY. He was a wonderful husband, father, grandfather, friend and humanitarian. He took great pride in his military career as a Colonel in the US Army Reserves. He is preceded in death by his wife Sheila S. Stein and survived by his sister, Gayle Bishop of Texas, six children and fourteen grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held Saturday, November 16th at 11am at the Reformed Church of Bronxville. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Wounded Warriors Project at www.woundedwarriorsproject.org or the Alzheimer's Association of Hudson Valley at 2900 Westchester Avenue, Suite 306, Purchase, NY 10577-2552.

SULLIVAN--John J.,of Middlebury, VT formerly of Sleepy Hollow NY, died peacefully Saturday November 9th. Born in 1931, he graduated from Cathedral College in 1951 and The University of Notre Dame in 1953. In 1955, John married Madeline Connelly. He joined Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company's executive training program in 1956, becoming Senior VP and deputy GM, and the officer-in-charge of the North American Division's National Corporate Group, retiring in 1987. That same year he joined the Long Term Credit Bank of Japan, Ltd as a Joint GM of the New York Branch and Executive VP of LTCB Trust Company, truly retiring in 1999. John had memberships at Sleepy Hollow CC and the former Sky Club in New York City, and volunteered on Boards at Marymount Preparatory School and The Church of the Magdalene. He is survived by his wife, daughters Jeanne Sullivan, and Madeline Sullivan-Drake of VT and eight grandchildren. He is predeceased by his daughter Joanne, and son John. Visitation is Friday, November 15th from 2pm-4pm and 7pm-9pm at Coffey Funeral Home, Tarrytown, NY. Funeral Mass is Saturday at 11am at Church of the Magdalene. Burial at Sleepy Hollow Cemetery. Donations to: www.cookiesforkidscancer.org

SLABE--Elaine Werner, born November 2, 1938, died on November 12, 2013 at the age of 75. She was the daughter of Edwin Monroe Werner and Anna Navarro Werner. She died from intestinal cancer at a hospice in Manhattan. Born in New York City, Elaine spent 50 years living in the New Jersey municipalities of Elizabeth, Westfield, and Mountainside until returning to her home town of Manhattan in 2006. She made profound contributions civically in both New Jersey and New York. Active in the volunteer community, she served on both the Westfield YMCA and The Education Fund of Westfield board of directors as a member, primarily in fundraising capacities. She chaired local fund raisers and various community outreach programs benefiting both businesses and residents alike. She is survived by James Frank Slabe, her husband of 40 years, and two children, Teena Marie Louise Hogan, age 57 of San Diego, California and Michael Edwin Lozada, age 55, of Manalapan, New Jersey. She was preceded in death by her parents and her three siblings: Robert Werner, James Werner and Geraldine Werner. Cremation services were privately held in New York.

SCHWARTZ--Samuel Robert, 76, passed away November 12, 2013 in Boca Raton, FL. He was the first son of Robert B. and Estelle Schwartz of Hewlett, NY. Sam was a loving husband to Barbara Gallers Schwartz. Proud father of Melissa, Robert and Betsy. Devoted stepfather of Lainie, David, Michael and Angele. Delighted grandfather of Matthew, Jon Ross, Caroline, Henry, Claire, and Simon. A pillar of the Five Towns New York community, Sam will be remembered for his philanthropy and generosity. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the American Diabetes Association.

ROSNER--Arnold L. Loved brother of Irene Rosner David, son of the late Lillian and David Rosner, brother-in-law of Raphael David, died on his 68th birthday. A prolific composer, music professor, life-master bridge player. He was a man of great depth, creativity and intensity who marched to his own rhythm there was only one 'Arnie'. Services Friday 11:15am at "The Riverside," 76th St. and Amsterdam Ave.

ROSENSTOCK--Lisa Wahl. The Board and staff of the S.L.E. Lupus Foundation and Lupus Research Institute express our deepest sympathies to the family of Lisa Wahl Rosenstock, an early pioneer and true champion in the fight against lupus. We extend our condolences to Lisa's mother Rita, sister Susan, husband Michael, daughter Debra, and we honor in memory, Lisa's late father and our beloved Board member, Irving Wahl.

PORAT--Mark Moshe, Engineer, died November 13, 2013, at age 87. Survived by wife Muriel Ressler, three children: Judy, David, Andrew: three grandchildren. Burial Friday, 2pm, Mount Hope Cemetery in Hastings, NY. Donations to Technion Israel.

POLLAK--Martin Marshall, was born in New York City on July 31, 1927 and he served in the United States Navy as a medic during WWll. He graduated from Syracuse University In 1950 and from St. John's Law School in 1953. After practicing law in New York City for several years, he founded National Patent Development Corporation in 1959 along with his law partner, Jerry Feldman. National Patent brought patents from the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe to the United States, most notably the patents for the first soft contact lens. After licensing the contact lens process to Bausch and Lomb, National Patent founded its own soft contact lens company, International Hydron Corporation, which became a public company in 1983. Hydron was later sold to SmithKline Beckman. After serving as a senior executive and major shareholder of National Patent and its affiliates for more than 40 years, Martin retired from National Patent in 2003. Martin served as a trustee of the Worcester Foundation for many years, and as chair of the U.S.-Czech Chamber of Commerce, and was active in other charitable endeavors. He was married to Ellen Pollak for almost 63 years, and together they had four children. He is survived by his wife, three children, eight grandchildren and his brother, Stephen. A memorial service will be held at a future date. The family asks that, in lieu of flowers, donations be made to the Alzheimer's Foundation.

PAYNE--Orville Smith, 97, after suffering severe complications from a devastating fall, passed away, at New York Presbyterian Hospital on November 6, 2013. She was the daughter of Dr. Robert E. Smith and Ruth Lofton Smith. She is survived by her sons, Judge Kibbie F. Payne (Ret.) and Attorney Kirby F. Payne, and her daughters Carolyn Payne-Dean Fairley, Ed. M., and Yvonne P. Daniel, Ph.D, four grandsons, ten great- grandchildren, and many other relatives and friends.

MILLER--Samuel C. World Monuments Fund regrets the passing of Sam Miller, 15-year trustee and ardent advocate for heritage preservation. With his wife Rosetta, a tireless promoter of Angkor's preservation, sponsor of the Rosetta garuda. A thoughtful advisor, cognoscente, and raconteur, Sam will be missed.

LUTZ--Frank X.,65, of Hazlet, NJ, on November 9, 2013. Beloved companion of Ann McIlmurray and brother of Lavinia Mancuso and Elizabeth Minor. He will be greatly missed by his family and his many friends. Gathering at Shore Points Funeral Home, Hazlet, Friday 4-8pm Funeral at Holy Family Church, Hazlet, Saturday 9:30am Memorial donations to www.everyonereading.org

LLOYD--Sally Hill, 64, of New York, NY, Bridgehampton, NY, and Vero Beach, FL died peacefully in her home on November 11 after a valiant battle with cancer. Mrs. Lloyd is survived by her husband of 37 years, Charles Ewing Green Lloyd Jr.; siblings, Serge Jerome Hill Jr., Robert Foote Hill and Priscilla Hill Alexandre; her three children, Jennifer Lloyd Dance, Ewing McAllister Lloyd and Stewart Lathrop Lloyd. She is an alumna of Miss Porters School and Bennett College. She was a member of the Short Hills Club, Baltusrol Golf Club, Riomar Country Club and Bridgehampton Club. Mrs. Lloyd joined Smith Barney Harris Upham in 1968, where she had a long and distinguished career as an equity sales trader in the institutional securities division. She was a pioneer for women in Wall Street, named one of the first female managing director's at the firm in 1986, retiring in 1994. She will be remembered for her razor sharp intellect, generous heart, quick wit and fun loving spirit. Her greatest love in life was spending time with her family, especially her four grandchildren, Mack, Sally, Cordia and Campbell to whom she was affectionately known as "DeDe". She was truly the "anchor" of the family and will be deeply missed by all. A Memorial service will be held at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue at 11am on Thursday, November 21. In lieu of flowers, charitable donations can be made to The American Cancer Society.

LIGON--T. Juanita, died peacefully on Wednesday, November 13th, 2013 at the age of 88. She was born in Indianapolis on January 27th, 1925 to Mary Elsie and Samuel W. Ernest. She is survived by her husband of 67 years Earl D. Ligon, daughters Stephanie Ligon Olmsted (Robert M.), Jan Brown (Michael A.) and Karen McCormick (Patrick J.), grandchildren Courtney and Hilary Brown and Nicholas and Alison McCormick and sister Margaret Ellingwood Griffin. Juanita graduated from Washington High School in 1943 and married Earl in 1946. Her career as a legal secretary continued throughout her life. She enjoyed gardening, traveling and antiquing. She was a member of the Indianapolis Museum of Art, the Indianapolis Zoo and the Eiteljorg Museum. In New York City she was a member of the Museum of Natural History and the American Folk Art Museum. Her great love of animals led to a lifelong involvement with the Home for Friendless Animals and the Humane Society of Indianapolis. Visitation will be Friday November 15th at Leppert Mortuary Nora from 11:00am until 12:30. A private service to celebrate Juanita's life will follow with burial at Washington Park East in Indianapolis.

KAGAN--Saul. The American Gathering of Jewish Holocaust Survivors and Their Descendants mourns the passing of our former executive vice president Saul Kagan. Holocaust survivors are grateful for his untiring efforts on their behalf. May his memory be for a blessing to all.

JURITH--EDWARD H. Passed peacefully November 9, 2013 at home in NW Washington, D.C. surrounded by family and friends. Survived by Kathleen M. Healy, his wife of 29 years, sons, Theodore E. and William C. of D.C., sister, Carolyn Huber Clarke (Anthony) NY. Visitation Thurs, 6-8pm; Mass of Christian Burial Friday, 11am, both at Shrine of The Most Blessed Sacrament, 3630 Quesada St., NW, DC. In lieu of flowers family requests donations to Bishop Loughlin Memorial High School, 357 Clermont Ave., Brooklyn, NY 11238.

FRIEDMAN--Robert, passed away on November 7, 2013 surrounded by his loving family and his dedicated caregiver Maria Lucia Whitehead, at the Lawlis Family Hospice. Beloved husband for 55 years of Carole (nee Raison) Friedman. Loving father of Daniel (Mary) of Fairfield, CT; Ellen (Joe) Ruble of Greenwood Village, CO; and Michael of San Francisco, CA. Proud grandfather of Matthew, Rachel and Joseph Friedman and Thomas, Eric, Genevieve and Joie Ruble. Robert was born in Brooklyn in 1931, the son of the late George and Diana Friedman. He received a BS degree from City College of New York. Robert began his retail career at the Boston Store in Milwaukee, where he met his wife, Carole. Friedman's retail career included 20 years at the May Co. where he retired as President and CEO of Famous Barr in St Louis in 1991. A Memorial Service honoring Bob's life will be held on Sunday, November 17 at 1:30pm at Congregation Emanu-El, 2020 West Brown Deer Road, River Hills. In lieu of flowers, the family is requesting donations be made to the American Diabetes Association.

FISHMAN--Nathan. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Nathan Fishman. He leaves behind a loving family that carries on a tradition of exceptional philanthropy. We extend our condolences to Nathan's wife, Ruth; his children, Robert, Clifford (Carole), Mitchell (Lois), Joan (Gregg); his grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

EVARTS--William M. Jr.,The Board and Staff of The New York Community Trust mourn the death of our Chairman Emeritus. For 30 years, Bill's gentle and courtly manner coupled with his intelligence, attention to detail, and wise counsel helped The Trust more than double its grantmaking to serve the City he loved. Bill will be sorely missed. Our deepest sympathies to his wife Helen and the family. Charlynn W. Goins, Chairman Lorie A. Slutsky, President

EVARTS--William Maxwell, Jr, 88, of Manhattan, Garrison, NY and Vinalhaven, Maine, died on Monday November 11 of complications following a fall. He is survived by his wife of 65 years, Helen Coleman Evarts; his daughters Holly Evarts Bartow, Kate Landon Evarts, and Alice Conover Evarts; his sons-in-law Clarence W. Bartow and William A. Allen; his grandchildren Iain Prescott Gordon, William Evarts Bartow, and Emily Vaux Bartow. Mr. Evarts was a graduate of the Buckley School, St. Paul's School 1943, Harvard College 1949, and Harvard Law School 1952. Mr. Evarts served in the US Army with the 94th Infantry Division, 1943-1945, in France and Germany. He was wounded in the Battle of the Bulge and was awarded the Croix de Guerre avec Palme for his service with the Forces Francaises de l'Interieur, the formal name for the Resistance fighters in France. Mr. Evarts joined the law firm Winthrop, Stimson, Putnam, and Roberts in 1954. Specializing in general corporate work, he served as managing partner for over 20 years. He became of counsel to the firm in 1997. Along with his family and his professional career, his major interests were his church, his community and the environment. Descended from a long line of legal and church leaders, Mr. Evarts served on the vestry of St. Philip's Church in Garrison, NY. He was chairman of the New York Community Trust, and served on the boards of the United Hospital Fund, and the Clark Foundation. He also served on a number of environmental boards including the Trust for Public Land, Scenic Hudson, the National Audubon Society, the Nature Conservancy of New York, and the Hudson Highlands Land Trust. He was an enthusiastic mountaineer, hockey player, rower, sailor, and backpacker in the mountains of the West. He took great pleasure in music, especially in playing classical piano. We celebrate the life of this good man on Saturday, November 23, at 2pm at St Philip's Church, Garrison, NY Contributions in his memory may be given to St. Philip's Church, Box 158, Garrison, NY 10524.

EVARTS--William M.,Jr. The board and staff of United Hospital Fund are deeply saddened by the death of our long-time board member and wonderful friend. Bill joined the Fund's board in 1983 and provided wise leadership, serving as a vice chairman and member of the executive committee for many years and as an active member of the finance and nominating committees. His enthusiasm for the Fund's mission of health care improvement, careful and caring attention to relationships and responsibilities, and unwavering loyalty and good humor will be greatly missed. We extend our sincere condolences to his wife Helen and daughters. J. Barclay Collins II Chairman James R. Tallon, Jr. President

DUBLIRER--Michael P.,on November 10, 2013. Devoted son of the late Harold and Edna Dublirer, beloved husband of Kathleen Barry Dublirer, loving brother of Robert Dublirer and Jane Kosminsky. Service: 2pm, Thursday, November 14, 2013 at Trinity Mausoleum. Donations in his memory may be made to research of Parkinson's Disease.

Bresnick--Richard (Dick), born May 31, 1931 in Brooklyn, NY to Molly and Irving Bresnick, passed away November 12, 2013. He is survived by his beloved wife, Roberta; daughter, Linda; son, Ed; granddaughters, Sarah and Chloe and grandson, Noah. He was a US Army, Korean War veteran. Many friends and family have always supported and loved Dick for being the most stand up, straight forward, and reliable person you will ever know and will be missed by many. To write a condolence and read the full obituary, please go to www.gpanochfunerals.com. Gary Panoch Funeral Home 561-997-8580.

DENARO--Jeannie. The NYU Cardiovascular Clinical Research Center mourns the untimely loss of Jeannie Denaro. As project director, she coordinated the ISCHEMIA trial team at over 200 sites worldwide. Her joie de vivre and talents will be missed. Our heartfelt condolences go out to her family.
MAYER--Bertram. We cherish the memory of the love and devotion you showed us in so many ways. We miss you and time will never dim our love for you. Your Family

Jon Lewis shot thousands of archetypical civil rights photographs in the late 1960s: a picket line snaking along the horizon, children playing in squalor, activists huddled in a strategy session. What makes these photographs different is their location and the subjects. Taken in central California and not in the Jim Crow South, they depict farm laborers of Mexican and Filipino descent, the vanguard of the historic Delano grape strike.

DEAN--Andy Chen, M.D.,Ph.D. 3/26/60 - 11/15/06. We remember you with love and respect. Your Family

WRIGHT--Jane Cooke M.D. Memorial service for Jane Cooke Wright , M.D., will be held at the New York Society for Ethical Culture located at 2 West 64th St., NY, NY on November 30, 2013. The service will begin at 4:30pm.

WATSON--William R.,died peacefully on November 9, 2013, age 57. Son of the late Katherine and William Watson, beloved brother and uncle, and father to daughter Lauren. A Buckley boy, a professional librarian, a skilled sailor and brilliant athlete. He was a wonderful friend. We miss you Bill and we love you forever.

VOLPER--Ronald J.,67, of Larchmont, NY, passed away November 11, 2013. Cherished husband of Hillary, adored father of Erik and Amanda (Sandy Krohn), beloved brother of Adrienne Schere (Alan), Steven (Joyce), Vicki (Mark Goldstein). Missed terribly by loving family, devoted friends. Admired for his kindness, wisdom, generosity, loyalty, business acumen, and delightful sense of humor. An irreplaceable mensch among men. Funeral Friday, November 15, 10am, Larchmont Temple, Larchmont, NY.

STEIN--Martin Frederick (Fritz), Jr.,M.D., of Bronxville N.Y., died November 11, 2013 after a sudden stroke. He was 77 years old. A native New Yorker and graduate of Columbia University, he received his medical degree from Albany Medical College in 1962. He devoted his career to the care of patients with kidney disease and served as Medical Director of St. Joseph's Hospital in Yonkers, NY. He was a wonderful husband, father, grandfather, friend and humanitarian. He took great pride in his military career as a Colonel in the US Army Reserves. He is preceded in death by his wife Sheila S. Stein and survived by his sister, Gayle Bishop of Texas, six children and fourteen grandchildren. A Memorial Service will be held Saturday, November 16th at 11am at the Reformed Church of Bronxville. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to: Wounded Warriors Project at www.woundedwarriorsproject.org or the Alzheimer's Association of Hudson Valley at 2900 Westchester Avenue, Suite 306, Purchase, NY 10577-2552.

SIEGEL--Betty June, 86, of Babylon, NY died Wednesday, November 13, 2013 at the Bellingham Retirement Community in West Chester, PA. Born in Bronx, NY she was the daughter of the late Reuben Cohen and the late Beatrice Friedman Cohen. Betty had worked as an English and History teacher in NY and spent many years as a Guidance Counselor for Bay Shore High School. Betty was a founding member and past president of the Livingston Senior Center in Babylon, NY, founder and past president of the Bay Shore Retired Teachers Association, recipient of the Nathaniel Conklin Award for Volunteerism, active in Pilot International and contributor to many other civic causes. She is survived by her son, Richard Siegel and his wife Lily of Chester Springs, brother, Alan Cohen, and grandchildren, Jill and Jamie Siegel. She was preceded in death by her daughter Loren Siegel and brother Frederick Cohen. Relatives and Friends are invited to her Graveside, 11am Sunday, November 17, 2013 at the Hillside Cemetery 742 Rutherford Ave. Lyndhurst, NJ. Contributions may be made in her memory to the James A. Baker Institute for Animal Health, College of Veterinary Medicine, Cornell University, Ithaca, NY 14853. Services by DellaVecchia, Reilly, Smith & Boyd Funeral Home, Inc. of West Chester, PA 610-696-1181; www.DellaFH.com.

RUSSO--Theresa, we are very saddened by the passing of the mother of our esteemed partner, Dennis Russo. Our spirits are brightened, however, in the knowledge that her children, Susan and Dennis know that their mom lived a happy and fruitful life. Our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to Dennis, his wife, Susan, their son, Christopher, Dennis' sister, Susan, and her family and the other members of the Russo family. Herrick, Feinstein LLP

RUSSELL--The Rev. William H.,85, on November 12, 2013 in Sun City Center, FL. He is survived by his loving wife, Elizabeth Truslow Russell; his son, James Truslow Russell; his daughter-in-law, Monika H. Russell; his grandson Tyler H. M. Russell and his sister, Aimee R. Corsini. His sisters, Marie H. Russell and Joan R. Low predeceased him. He was delighted to have ten nephews, ten nieces, 16 grandnephews and 14 grandnieces. He graduated from Brooks School, North Andover, MA (1947) and The University of Virginia, Charlottesville (1951), and then served four years in the Air Force, with a year in Korea. He was president of Bellinger-Davis Travel and Inverness Travel both in New York City. He continued in travel while pursuing his true calling at the George Mercer, Jr. Memorial School of Theology of the Diocese of Long Island. He served as a deacon at St. Margaret's Church, Plainview and at Holy Trinity, Hicksville. He also served as the Assistant Priest at St. John's Huntington and the Rector of St. Paul's Episcopal Church, Patchogue. He celebrated his 25th anniversary of ordination to the priesthood this past June. He will be remembered for his infectious laugh and delightful sense of humor as well as his caring concern for others. He has earned his wings and flown HOME. He will be deeply missed.

ROBINSON--Nan Senior, 81, died peacefully in her home in New York City on November 14, 2013. Born in Salt Lake City, UT to Clair Marcil Senior and Lillian (Worlton) Senior Davis, she is survived by her loving husband of 59 years, David Z. Robinson, her sons, Marc (Elizabeth Briody) and Eric (Sally), her grandchildren, Andrew (Angela), Daniel, David (Dana Levin-Robinson), Emily, Kathleen and Anton, her sisters, Noel Brusman and Renee Senior, and her brother, Edwin Senior. Nan received her BA from Mills College in 1952, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and her MA in American History from Harvard University in 1953. Nan researched civil rights issues for journalists Robert Spivak and Ben Bagdikian in Washington, D.C. from 1962 1966. She was a Special Assistant to the Undersecretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development in Washington, D.C. from 1966 1969. She served as Assistant to the President and as Vice President for Planning at the University of Massachusetts in Boston, MA from 1970 1978, where she played a key role in landing the JFK Presidential Library on the Boston campus of the University of Massachusetts. She then served as Deputy Commissioner of Higher Education for the State of Connecticut in Hartford, CT from 1978 1981 and as Vice President for Administration of the Rockefeller Foundation in New York City from 1981 1989. She was named to the Centennial Honor List of 100 Women by Barnard College in 1989, and named Woman of the Year by the YWCA of Greater Hartford in 1980. Private services will be held. A memorial celebration of her life is being planned for January 11, 2014, the 82nd anniversary of her birth, in New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to CCNY/CWE/Quest, a community for lifelong learning, or to the Alzheimer's Association.

PARSA--Gretchen W.,age 73, passed away November 12, 2013, after a brief, but brave and resolute battle with cancer. A resident of Bronxville, NY, her devotions included support of hospital volunteer programs, animal humane organizations, and alumni administrative support of her undergraduate sorority. She was particularly fond of her newer role as grandmother. She lost her husband in 2004 to cancer as well. She is survived by her son, Cyrus and his wife Suzanne, and her grandsons Aiden, Hayes, and Andrew. A family service is planned in Chicago. The family appreciates the support and compassion demonstrated by her friends and extended family during her illness. May she rest in peace.

MORRIS--Robert E. 80, Devoted husband, father, businessman, philanthropist, and friend, passed away on November 13. Born to Adele Groden Morris and Norman M. Morris in New York. He resided in NYC, Greenwich, CT, and of late, Boca Raton, FL with Sandi, his wife of 43 years. He was the father of Jeffrey (Lauren) Morris of Boca Raton, FL & Deborah Morris Daum (John) of Rye Brook, NY, and Leland, David, and the late Richard Morris of a previous marriage. Also survived by 13 grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. Private burial will be held Friday morning.

MANN--Veronika (Borsiczky), 68, of Newburyport, MA, loving wife of H. Thompson Mann, M.D., died unexpectedly in her home November 8, 2013. Born in Budapest, Hungary and raised in New York City, Veronika attended Barnard College where she studied English. An accomplished writer, Veronika had a long career in journalism, both as a freelancer and working for Rolling Stone during its' early years in San Francisco. In recent years after raising her family, she had become a skilled photographer and started a small photography business in Newburyport. In addition to her husband she is survived by a daughter Alexandra Mann of New York, NY; twin sons Edward Mann of Richmond, VA and James Mann of San Diego, CA; a brother, Sandor Borsiczky of Montreal, and a stepfather Bartholomew Hargitay of White Plains, NY. She will be greatly missed. Her funeral service will be held Friday, November 15 in the Whittier-Porter Funeral Home in Ipswich, MA followed by interment in the Evergreen Cemetery, Newbury, MA. In lieu of flowers memorial contributions in her name may be made to the Greater Newburyport YWCA, 13 Market Street, Newburyport, MA 01950. To leave a condolence please visit www.whittier-porter.com.

LUTZ--Frank X.,65, of Hazlet, NJ, on November 9, 2013. Beloved companion of Ann McIlmurray and brother of Lavinia Mancuso and Elizabeth Minor. He will be greatly missed by his family and his many friends. Gathering at Shore Points Funeral Home, Hazlet, Friday 4-8pm Funeral at Holy Family Church, Hazlet, Saturday 9:30am Memorial donations to www.everyonereading.org

LLOYD--Sally Hill. We will miss your keen mind, your wise and non-judgmental counsel, your devotion, fierce loyalty, and your joie de vivre. There was never a dance party Sally did not love. We mourn for and with her family, Lusty, JenJen, Ewing and Stewie. Dance on, Sal Pal. With love, The Curtins Annie and Tom Hayden, Todd and Whitney

LLOYD--Sally Hill, 64, of New York, NY, Bridgehampton, NY, and Vero Beach, FL died peacefully in her home on November 11 after a valiant battle with cancer. Mrs. Lloyd is survived by her husband of 37 years, Charles Ewing Green Lloyd Jr.; siblings, Serge Jerome Hill Jr., Robert Foote Hill and Priscilla Hill Alexandre; her three children, Jennifer Lloyd Dance, Ewing McAllister Lloyd and Stewart Lathrop Lloyd. She is an alumna of Miss Porters School and Bennett College. She was a member of the Short Hills Club, Baltusrol Golf Club, Riomar Country Club and Bridgehampton Club. Mrs. Lloyd joined Smith Barney Harris Upham in 1968, where she had a long and distinguished career as an equity sales trader in the institutional securities division. She was a pioneer for women in Wall Street, named one of the first female managing director's at the firm in 1986, retiring in 1994. She will be remembered for her razor sharp intellect, generous heart, quick wit and fun loving spirit. Her greatest love in life was spending time with her family, especially her four grandchildren, Mack, Sally, Cordia and Campbell to whom she was affectionately known as "DeDe". She was truly the "anchor" of the family and will be deeply missed by all. A Memorial service will be held at St. James Church, 865 Madison Avenue at 11am on Thursday, November 21. In lieu of flowers, charitable donations can be made to The American Cancer Society.

HORVITZ--Dvora, age 68, of New York City, passed away November 12, 2013, following a courageous battle with cancer. Loving and beloved partner of Yossi Segal and mother of Asaf Segal. For more than 40 years, a creative force behind the exquisite jewelry designs of Tambetti Inc. She will be sorely missed by all who knew her. A memorial service will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Beth Israel Medical Center In Memory Of Dvora Horvitz, 555 W. 57th St. 18th Floor. New York, NY 10019.

HAZARD--Susan Lawrence, 100, of New York City, died October 30, 2013. Born in Cambridge, MA September 21, 1913. Married to Professor John N. Hazard, Sovietologist, who preceded her in death. Mother of four children, six grandchildren and six great-grandchildren. Memorial service at St. George's Episcopal Church, 209 East 16th Street, at 12pm, Saturday, December 28, 2013. Donations to St. George's Church.

GREEN--William, on November 13, 2013. Professor of English and Shakespearean Scholar for 52 years at Queens College - CUNY. Beloved father of Jonathan Green and Natalie Green Giles, dear father-in-law of Hilary Thomas and Douglas Giles, adored grandfather of Gabrielle, Alexandra and Devon, loving brother of Betty Ajces. Service Friday, November 15, 2013, 9:45am at "The Riverside," 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave. Donations in his memory may be made to Queens College-CUNY, QCCommunity.QC.CUNY.edu
GOTIMER--Msgr. James E. The members of The Lotos Club mourn the loss of their distinguished colleague and longtime friend, James Gotimer, and send condolences to his family.

EVARTS--William M. Jr.,The Board and Staff of The New York Community Trust mourn the death of our Chairman Emeritus. For 30 years, Bill's gentle and courtly manner coupled with his intelligence, attention to detail, and wise counsel helped The Trust more than double its grantmaking to serve the City he loved. Bill will be sorely missed. Our deepest sympathies to his wife Helen and the family. Charlynn W. Goins, Chairman Lorie A. Slutsky, President

EVARTS--William M. Jr, Scenic Hudson is saddened at the loss of a great champion for the Hudson Valley. Bill contributed powerfully to preserving the beauty and health of the Hudson River and the land along its shores. The analytic and strategic mind that shaped his distinguished legal career helped guide our mission for two decades. His giving spirit, wit and charming disposition will be deeply missed. Our thoughts are with his family.

DENARO--Jeannie. The NYU Cardiovascular Clinical Research Center mourns the untimely loss of Jeannie Denaro. As project director, she coordinated the ISCHEMIA trial team at over 200 sites worldwide. Her joie de vivre and talents will be missed. Our heartfelt condolences go out to her family.

DAVIS--Lawrence. With great sadness, we mourn the loss of our Executive Director of 22 years. His talents and generosity knew no bounds, and his passion, devotion, creativity, and spirit will reside at the school forever. Thousands benefited from Lawrence's vision to bring music to all. He will be greatly missed. The Bloomingdale School of Music Board of Directors www.bsmny.org

BANCHIK--Donald, of Nanuet, NY on November 12, age 77. Born in The Bronx January 4, 1936 to Joseph and Hilda (Edelman) Banchik he had seven siblings. Donald attended college on a basketball scholarship and served in the ARMY. Donald has lived in Nanuet for 16 years, prior in Eldred, NY, where he had been Superintendent of Schools until his retirement. He also lived in Bennington, VT where he was Principal of Mt. Anthony Union High School, and had also been an Assistant Principal at Spring Valley High School, Spring Valley, NY. Donald's first wife Barbara (Young) predeceased him in 1997. He is survived by his wife Lorraine Brooks Banchik and his children, Steven and his husband Emmanuel along with Michael and his wife Ruthie, their children Barbara and Benjamin. He is also survived by his step children Maxine Brooks, her son Jason; Jeff Brooks, his wife Sue and their sons, Stan and Jimmy. Donald was known for his sense of humor as well as kindness and easy going attitude. Education was a perfect career, as he loved children of all ages and really cared. He was a supportive nurturing father, a loving and devoted husband as well as a very proud grandfather. He will be missed by all. A graveside funeral service was held at Sons of Israel Cemetery, Monsey, NY. Contributions to Feeding America's Children www.feedingac.org, are preferred and appreciated. Visit WarnerAndWozniak.com to share condolences.

The latest issue of T takes us to many destinations in many different ways. In our cover story, we provide a relaxed, versatile wardrobe with clean lines that are tailor-made for travel. Sometimes travel can simply be a state of mind; lovely interiors can transport a home. The designer Faye Toogood brings the English countryside to her London house, with her unexpected arrangements of objects. These days, travel envy happens with a few clicks. Instagram offers a fresh means to peek into others’ carefully curated lifestyles all around the world. Next, we travel to France by way of Miami; the designer Charlotte Perriand, who created furnishings, interiors and buildings with Le Corbusier, is being recognized at Design Miami this December for her ahead-of-the-curve sensibility. Sometimes it’s all about the journey — Alexander Payne shares his love for the wholesomeness of hometown Nebraska in a road trip with the novelist Kurt Andersen. In Montana, the investment banker-turned-hunter Georgia Pellegrini offers a weekend retreat for urban women like herself to get in touch with their primitive selves. Last but not least, Lawrence Osborne travels to Myanmar to search for the inspirations behind George Orwell’s books. See all stories from the issue >>

Harley-Davidson’s Lost Photographs, 1915-1916, Milwaukee More than 50 black-and-white photographs documenting the early years of the Harley-Davidson Motor Company are on display through Jan. 1, in Milwaukee at the Harley-Davidson Museum. The photos, printed from a collection of more than 400 fragile glass-plate negatives, provide a glimpse back nearly 100 years ago and include employee portraits, depictions of the company’s 1916 racing team and images used for marketing.

SCHNEIDER--Seymour, passed on November 15, 2013. Best friend and loving husband of Francine Broock Schneider for 64 years. Doting father of Ellen (David) Fox and Joan Bernstein. Adoring poppy to Michael, Adam, Lauren, Jason and Debra. Seymour was a dedicated teacher at Andrew Jackson High School and a World War II Veteran. He will always remain in our hearts and be greatly missed. Funeral Services: Sunday, 10am at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre.

ROSENBLATT--Leon B.,darling son of Jean and George. Adored husband of Sandy and loving father to Geri, Steven, and Alisa (Seth) Gershman; special "Poppy" to Josh and Charlie, loving brother of the late Eleanor Weinhouse, passed away peacefully after battling multiple illnesses. Leon always strived for excellence in everything he did. He fought all his battles with grace and dignity. He will always be remembered for his creativity and charm and love for his family and friends. Service 10:30 Sunday, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

RACHLES--Seymour. The Board of Governors and Members of the Elberon Bathing Club mourn the recent passing of our long time Member and very dear friend, Seymour Rachles. Seymour was one of those people who always made you feel good when you saw him. His infectious smile and upbeat manner were so warm and caring and his jokes so funny that running into him would lift your spirits and make your day. Losing someone like Seymour, who would give you the shirt off his back if you asked and who was truly a dear and sweet soul is particularly painful to all of us who have valued his friendship for so many years. He was and remains the embodiment of what the words "nice guy" really mean. Our heartfelt condolences go out to Gloria, Robyn and Vivien in this most difficult time. Seeing him leisurely stroll into EBC is a memory that will stay with us forever. He is already sorely missed by all who knew him. Robert Fagenson, President Douglas Schwartz, Secretary

OSWALD--Gerald A.,Sr, of Mineola, NY on November 14, 2013. Loving husband of the late Peggy. Beloved father of Peggy Oswald Manning, Thomas, Gerald A. Jr., and the late William. Cherished grandfather of eight grandchildren. Gerry was a professional baseball player and a scout for the St. Louis Cardinals. He was also a proud WWII veteran. Family will receive friends at Donohue-Cecere Funeral Home located at 290 Post Avenue, Westbury, NY (516) 333-0615 on Saturday from 7-9pm and Sunday from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial Monday 11am at St. Brigid's RC Church, 50 Post Ave., Westbury. Interment with military honors to follow at Holy Rood Cemetery, Westbury. In lieu of flowers, the family would appreciate contributions to: St. Thomas Aquinas College, C/O Gerry Oswald Sr. Scholarship Fund, 125 Route 340, Sparkhill, NY 10976. www.donohue-cecere.com

OSBORNE--Bernard, on November 14, 2013. Beloved husband of Angela. Loving father of Rachel and Alicia. Cherished grandfather of Eden, Ellis, Tyler and Kaylee. Devoted brother of Robert, Sandra and Patricia. He was a retired director of finance and operations for ABC TV News, who will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call on Monday, November 18, 2-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian burial Tuesday, November 19, 10:30am at St. Mary's RC Church, Rutherford, NJ. In lieu of flowers, contributions in his memory may be made to Visiting Nurse Service of New York Hospice 212-609-1526.

MORRIS--Robert E. The owners and employees of Roma Industries mourn the loss of their dear friend and company co-founder Robert Morris. His enthusiasm and good will were his hallmarks. His thoughtfulness and care and his loyalty to his friends and colleagues will always be remembered fondly. Our recollections will always be accompanied with smiles. Paul Horowitz, Joel Jacobs, Paul Aglietti and all of his friends at Roma Industries.

BANDON--William E.,Jr., 84, died peacefully at home in Somers, NY, of natural causes. Bill is survived by his wife, Lila (nee Arida); children: William E. Bandon III (Patricia), Victoria Noonan (Laurence), and Alexandra Bandon; grandchildren: Matthew and Christian Noonan, John and Isabel Bandon, and sister Margaret Kohler. He is predeceased by his brother, John Bandon, and his sister Sheila Coogan. He was born in Manhattan and attended Cardinal Hayes High School (1946), Iona College (1953), and St. John's Law School (1958), with two tours of duty in the U.S. Army. He served as Secretary and Counsel to the New York State Liquor Authority, and had an accomplished 35-year private practice in family law. Visitation on Saturday and Sunday at Clark Associates Funeral Home, Katonah, NY. Funeral Mass will be celebrated Monday, 10:00am, at St. Patrick's Old Stone Church in Yorktown Heights, NY.

If part of your Sunday morning routine is to sit down to solve the crossword over a cup of tea, you might have a hint to one of today’s clues right under your nose. English breakfast tea, a blend, includes Assam’s offerings. The region comes up today at 42 Down, one of several clues about Indian geography.

VARIETY PUZZLE — It’s curious that two of the most memorable villains in fiction share a fondness for Marcus Aurelius. In Richard Connell’s 1924 short story “The Most Dangerous Game,” General Zaroff, the unhinged sophisticate who hunts humans on his island, unwinds at the end of the night with a bottle of chambertin and the writings of Aurelius. In “The Silence of the Lambs,” Hannibal Lecter quotes from The Meditations during a cellblock interrogation: “First principles, Clarice. Simplicity. Read Marcus Aurelius. Of each particular thing ask: what is it in itself? What is its nature? What does he do, this man you seek?”

Seating charts often lead to awkward dinner pairings. But when the artist Enoc Perez found himself sitting next to Gilles Mendel, the French-born creative director of J. Mendel, at a benefit for the Dia Foundation in New York last year, the two, in fact, hit it off quite well. “I could immediately relate to him because my wife is French, and she is a big fan of his work,” Perez said. “He’s also architectural in terms of his lines, and I do a lot of paintings of architecture, so we had ground in common.” First, a friendship developed — and soon after, a collaboration. “I thought maybe I could do a portrait of him, but it would be about looking at his work through my eyes,” Perez explained. Mendel was into it and allowed Perez into his workroom, where the artist shot pictures of everything he saw — scraps of fabric, dresses on forms, fur garments being constructed — and then created a series of collages for his new book, “Gilles Mendel by Enoc Perez.”

KLEINER--Sam. May, 18 1942 - November, 18 2003 Always in Our Hearts. Love, Darlene, Ken, Chris, Jeremy, Benjy, David z'l & Grandkids.
ISRAELTON--Harvey S. November 17, 2011 A lover of the arts and a scholar. We've all come together in missing you. You will always be remembered . Love, your family and friends

WESELEY--Stanley DDS, of Lantana, Florida on November 12, 2013. He passed away at the age of 95. He was preceded by Beatrice, his devoted wife of 66 years. Survived by his loving daughter Elaine and son Paul. Cherished grandfather of Lisa and Linda. He practiced dentistry in Brooklyn for over 47 years. He retired to Florida and will be remembered most by family, friends and patients as a lover of books and learning. Graveside services Thursday 11:45am, November 21, at Beth Israel Cemetery.

DOERFLER--Ronald J. A memorial service to remember and celebrate the life of Ronald J. Doerfler will be held on Friday, November 22 at 2pm at The First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York (12 W. 12th St. at 5th Ave., New York, NY 10011, 212-675-6150, www.fpcnyc.org). Doerfler, a Hearst Corporation director, trustee and senior vice president, finance and administration, passed away October 11. He was 72. Doerfler, whose career at Hearst Corporation spanned 15 years, had responsibility for Hearst's finance and accounting activities, and also oversaw Hearst's New York real estate holdings. He was elected to Hearst's Board of Directors in June 2002 and was a testamentary trustee under the will of William Randolph Hearst since 2008. Doerfler represented Hearst on the board of directors of A+E Networks during virtually his entire tenure at Hearst. He was also instrumental in the planning and construction of Hearst Corporation's award-winning Hearst Tower, which opened in 2006. Earlier in his career, he played a major role in Capital Cities' acquisition of ABC, Inc., in 1986 and again in the 1996 Capital Cities/ABC merger with The Walt Disney Company. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Fairleigh Dickinson University and The First Presbyterian Church in the City of New York.

TENNEY--Charles H. Jr.,72, on November 4th at Johns Hopkins Hospital, Baltimore, MD. Born and raised in New York City, he lived in Elizabethtown, NY. A graduate of the Buckley School, Trinity Pawling and Lafayette College. Beloved husband of Karen and proud and loving father of Heather. A passionate fisherman, avid reader, chef and retired owner of Riverrun Restaurant, he is survived by his wife Karen, daughter Heather and his sisters Pat Tenney, Joan Davidson (William), Marguerite Embry (Talton), and Anne Unger (Toby). Charlie was a dear husband, father, brother, uncle and cousin. He will be remembered by all who knew him for his love of the outdoors, his kindness, his sense of humor and his love of family as well as his innate ability with food and his insatiable appetite for books. A family memorial will take place in the spring.

SLABE--Elaine Werner, born November 2, 1938, died on November 12, 2013 at the age of 75. She was the daughter of Edwin Monroe Werner and Anna Navarro Werner. She died from intestinal cancer at a hospice in Manhattan. Born in New York City, Elaine spent 50 years living in the New Jersey municipalities of Elizabeth, Westfield, and Mountainside until returning to her home town of Manhattan in 2006. She made profound contributions civically in both New Jersey and New York. Active in the volunteer community, she served on both the Westfield YMCA and The Education Fund of Westfield board of directors as a member, primarily in fundraising capacities. She chaired local fund raisers and various community outreach programs benefiting both businesses and residents alike. She is survived by James Frank Slabe, her husband of 40 years, and two children, Teena Marie Louise Hogan, age 57 of San Diego, California and Michael Edwin Lozada, age 55, of Manalapan, New Jersey. She was preceded in death by her parents and her three siblings: Robert Werner, James Werner and Geraldine Werner. Cremation services were privately held in New York.

SFERRA--George W. Sr.,D.D.S., November 6, 2013 at the age of 97. Longtime resident of Haworth, New Jersey before retiring to Gulfport, FL. Practiced dentistry in New York City for over 50 years. Pre-deceased by his loving wife Edith, of 63 years. Loving father of Dr. George W. Sferra Jr. and his wife Barbara, Mary Sferra Facciolla and her husband Tom, James Sferra and his wife Cynthia Allen and John Sferra and his wife Ivana. Cherished grandfather of George, Christopher, Amy, Adam, Alicia and John Paul.

SCHWARTZ--Samuel Robert, 76, passed away November 12, 2013 in Boca Raton, FL. He was the first son of Robert B. and Estelle Schwartz of Hewlett, NY. Sam was a loving husband to Barbara Gallers Schwartz. Proud father of Melissa, Robert and Betsy. Devoted stepfather of Lainie, David, Michael and Angele. Delighted grandfather of Matthew, Jon Ross, Caroline, Henry, Claire, and Simon. A pillar of the Five Towns New York community, Sam will be remembered for his philanthropy and generosity. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the American Diabetes Association.

SCHNEIER--H. Robin. Joyce and Fred Schneier note the passing in New York on November 8, and mourn the loss of our loving daughter Robin. We are joined by her sister, Diane Schneier Perrin, brother-in-law Bryce and nephew Alec in our sorrow. Robin's attributes and talents were recognized early and applauded throughout her 56 years. Encouraged in her love of art, science and literature and growing accomplishments in painting, she was respected and loved by extended family, friends and neighbors. Missing her deeply is a widely shared certainty.

SCHNEIDER--Seymour, passed on November 15, 2013. Best friend and loving husband of Francine Broock Schneider for 64 years. Doting father of Ellen (David) Fox and Joan Bernstein. Adoring poppy to Michael, Adam, Lauren, Jason and Debra. Seymour was a dedicated teacher at Andrew Jackson High School and a World War II Veteran. He will always remain in our hearts and be greatly missed. Funeral Services: Sunday, 10am at Gutterman's, Rockville Centre.

SCHLINGER--Israel "Izzy", November 6, 2013. World War II Veteran. Born in the Bronx, NY and graduated in 1942 from Townsend Harris High School, NYC. Son of the late "Pepe" and Alex Schlinger, Husband of Shirley Elfman Schlinger, Brother of Sol Schlinger, Father of Ken and Kathy Schlinger and Dayle and Arthur Carosi, Grandfather of Michael Carosi, Dr. Jennifer Schlinger, Amy Schlinger and Molly Schlinger as well as many dear cousins. Survivor of D-Day plus 30 and Battle of the Bulge. Retired after 48 years with Bache & Co. President and Board member for 33 years of Palmer Terrace Cooperative. Member of Knights of Pythias, Masons, Kiwanis, Combat Infantrymen's Assoc. and Mamaroneck-Larchmont Athletic Old Timers Assoc. Inducted into the Mamaroneck High School Athletic Hall of Fame. Besides his family and friends, he loved Mamaroneck, NY. He was 89 years young. Donations may be made to the Wounded Warrior Project, Cystic Fibrosis Foundation or a charity of your choice.

ROSNER--Arnold L. Loved brother of Irene Rosner David, son of the late Lillian and David Rosner, brother-in-law of Raphael David, died on his 68th birthday. A prolific composer, music professor, life-master bridge player. He was a man of great depth, creativity and intensity who marched to his own rhythm there was only one 'Arnie'.

ROSENBLATT--Leon B.,darling son of Jean and George. Adored husband of Sandy and loving father to Geri, Steven, and Alisa (Seth) Gershman; special "Poppy" to Josh and Charlie, loving brother of the late Eleanor Weinhouse, passed away peacefully after battling multiple illnesses. Leon always strived for excellence in everything he did. He fought all his battles with grace and dignity. He will always be remembered for his creativity and charm and love for his family and friends. Service 10:30 Sunday, Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 91 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

ROBINSON--Nan Senior, 81, died peacefully in her home in New York City on November 14, 2013. Born in Salt Lake City, UT to Clair Marcil Senior and Lillian (Worlton) Senior Davis, she is survived by her loving husband of 59 years, David Z. Robinson, her sons, Marc (Elizabeth Briody) and Eric (Sally), her grandchildren, Andrew (Angela), Daniel, David (Dana Levin-Robinson), Emily, Kathleen and Anton, her sisters, Noel Brusman and Renee Senior, and her brother, Edwin Senior. Nan received her BA from Mills College in 1952, where she was elected to Phi Beta Kappa, and her MA in American History from Harvard University in 1953. Nan researched civil rights issues for journalists Robert Spivak and Ben Bagdikian in Washington, D.C. from 1962 1966. She was a Special Assistant to the Undersecretary of the Department of Housing and Urban Development in Washington, D.C. from 1966 1969. She served as Assistant to the President and as Vice President for Planning at the University of Massachusetts in Boston, MA from 1970 1978, where she played a key role in landing the JFK Presidential Library on the Boston campus of the University of Massachusetts. She then served as Deputy Commissioner of Higher Education for the State of Connecticut in Hartford, CT from 1978 1981 and as Vice President for Administration of the Rockefeller Foundation in New York City from 1981 1989. She was named to the Centennial Honor List of 100 Women by Barnard College in 1989, and named Woman of the Year by the YWCA of Greater Hartford in 1980. Private services will be held. A memorial celebration of her life is being planned for January 11, 2014, the 82nd anniversary of her birth, in New York City. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made in her memory to CCNY/CWE/Quest, a community for lifelong learning, or to the Alzheimer's Association.

RICHMOND--Fredda, beloved mother, aunt, grandmother and friend, died peacefully in August surrounded by family. A Brooklyn native, she and her sister Marion were first generation college graduates committed to public education. Fredda and her husband Murray opened their home to all. They shared a strong moral compass and deep compassion. Fredda, with her indomitable spirit, warmth and spunk, will be deeply missed. A memorial will be held for her today at 2:00 pm at the Society for the Advancement of Judaism 15 W. 86th Street NYC.

REED--Toby, beloved mother of Lou Reed and Merrill Weiner. Toby was born on August 31st, 1920, and passed away November 7th at 93. A beauty queen at 19, a devoted wife to Sidney, a doting grandparent to Jill Opell, Lesley Weiner and Jeffrey Weiner, loving great grandparent to Reed Opell and Shayna Opell. Toby endured a ravaging, devastating illness and passed 10 days after her son. May their spirits live on.

PETTUS--Susan Fouke, of Seabrook Island, SC, and New York City died November 8, 2013, after a brave battle with ovarian cancer. Known as Susie, she was born December 15, 1943, and grew up in St. Louis, MO. The daughter of the late John Truman Fouke and Virginia Brown Fouke, she attended Mary Institute in St. Louis, graduated from Mt. Vernon Seminary and later Mt. Vernon Junior College. After graduating she moved to New York City and attended Pace School to study art. In 1968 she married Thruston W. Pettus and was a devoted wife for 45 years as well as a loving mother of Katherine Pettus Wujcik (Mark) and Thruston W. Pettus, Jr. She is also survived by her beloved brother, John T. Fouke, Jr. (Sharon), a niece, Penny Fouke Brobyn and a nephew, John T. Fouke III (Kelly). Susie dedicated the better part of her life to her immediate family, but she also held a special place in her heart for those cousins she grew up with in St. Louis, particularly the late Claude Fouke Benoist (Walter), Lucien R. Fouke (Becky) and Thomas C. Fouke (Linda). Susie was indefinable; shy yet playful, private yet approachable, quiet yet profound, demanding yet forgiving. She did not suffer fools and was quick to express her opinions, politically correct or not. Although she spent the later part of her life in Seabrook Island, her heart never left New York City where the theaters, museums and human diversity provided her with a steady diet of enlightenment and joy. Susie was an accomplished artist who painted for the pleasure it brought her, not the recognition. She was a collector of contemporary art and antiques, and her artistic skills and color sense carried over into interior decorating and designing elaborate holiday centerpieces. Susie adored animals, domestic and wild, and pity the person she caught stepping on a palmetto bug or harming an animal. She loved to travel and being blessed by a sacred elephant in India and kissed by a giraffe in Kenya were typical of her joyous abandon. Her family and friends know they have lost a truly unique person whose love, dignity, beauty and compassion will be irreplaceable. Services in St. Louis will be private. Arrangements made by J. Henry Stuhr West Ashley Chapel, 3360 Glenn McConnell Parkway, Charleston, SC. In lieu of flowers contributions can be made to the International Crane Foundation, NW 6469, P.O. Box 1450, Minneapolis, MN 55485-6469 or the Central Park Conservancy, 14 E. 60th Street, New York, NY 10020, in her memory.

PARSA--Gretchen W.,age 73, passed away November 12, 2013, after a brief, but brave and resolute battle with cancer. A resident of Bronxville, NY, her devotions included support of hospital volunteer programs, animal humane organizations, and alumni administrative support of her undergraduate sorority. She was particularly fond of her newer role as grandmother. She lost her husband in 2004 to cancer as well. She is survived by her son, Cyrus and his wife Suzanne, and her grandsons Aiden, Hayes, and Andrew. A family service is planned in Chicago. The family appreciates the support and compassion demonstrated by her friends and extended family during her illness. May she rest in peace.

NOONAN--Irene Gruber, a resident of Manhattan and East Hampton passed away on Thursday, at the age of 86. NELKIN--Morton, born in Brooklyn February 5, 1915, died November 12, 2013, with his loving family surrounding him. He was a son of Sarah (Kurta) and William Nelkin, and was predeceased by his brother, Sidney and sister, Julia. He is survived by his wife of 66 years, Edna Rubenstein Nelkin; sons James Nelkin and his wife, Andrea, and David Nelkin and his wife Linda; their two children Matthew and Sara. He leaves his brother, Sam Nelkin, his wife, Inge, and a loving extended family. After earning a B.S. degree, Mort graduated from Columbia University with a Doctor of Optometry, and following that he served in the Army Air Corps as an optometrist during World War II. Mort's modest demeanor belied his talents. He had a combination of humility, humor, intelligence, practicality, and excellent judgment regarding people. A man of exceptional character, Mort had a thirst for knowledge and was a voracious reader. He and Edna were world travelers and eternal students. Mort believed strongly in equal rights, separation of church and state, eradication of hunger, saving our planet's resources, and followed his ethical Judaic beliefs of justice in both his personal and public life. His knowledge was all encompassing and he was a true Renaissance man, well loved and respected by friends and family.

MASON--Charles D.,Research Chemist, Inventor and World War II Veteran. Charles Driscoll Mason, 93, of Chatham, NJ, passed away on November 14th. A Funeral Mass will be celebrated at Corpus Christi Church, 234 Southern Blvd., Chatham, on Wednesday, November 20th at 9:30am. Relatives and friends are invited to visit at Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, 345 Main St, Chatham on Tuesday from 4pm to 8pm. For further information or to send a condolence, please go to: bradleyfuneralhomes.com. Charles was born and raised in New York City and has lived in Chatham Township since 1974. He graduated from All Hallows High School and earned his doctorate in organic chemistry from Fordham University. A veteran of the U.S. Navy during WWII, he served from 1939 to 1945. Charles was in many of the major battles in the Pacific theatre. Professionally, Dr. Mason (known simply as "Mason") developed and held over thirty patents at Allied Signal in Morristown, NJ where he worked for over thirty years. He was an active member of the American Chemical Society. He retired in 1990. Always highly active, Charles enjoyed music, puzzles, golf and spending time with his family on Cape Cod. He will be fondly remembered for his kindness, intellect, larger than life sense of humor and quick wit. He inspired all that knew him to imagine, to challenge and to discover. Charles was the beloved husband of 48 years to the late Mary (nee McQuillan). He was the loving father of Catherine M. Wilson, Peter M. Mason, Barbara M. Mason, Elizabeth M. Mason, Pauline M. Mason, and Mary Ann M. Mason. He is also survived by his seven cherished grandchildren. He is preceded in passing by his brothers Jack and Gerald Mason. In lieu of flowers, donations in Charles' memory may be made to either the Maryknoll Lay Missioners or the Chatham Emergency Squad.

MACKLER--Scott, M.D. The Yeshiva University family is profoundly grieved by the passing of Scott Mackler, M.D. after his heroic battle with ALS for some 15 years during which he steadfastly continued his medical research as a Professor at the University of Pennsylvania, despite the almost complete paralysis of his limbs, by use of his computer and hi-tech machinery directed by his eyes and was even able to produce scientific research papers. His indomitable perseverance and spiritual strength was enabled and enhanced by his loving family. His beloved wife Dr. Lynn and their sons Alexander (and Laura) and Noah, his doting parents, the late Alfred Mackler who predeceased his cherished wife, Helen Mackler, of blessed memory who spent half of every week with him and his family, his adoring brother Harvey (and Karen) Mackler, and deeply caring sister Randi (and Bob) Windheim, his many nieces and nephews represented by Alexander Mackler, on the Joseph Alexander Foundation Board, and a host of devoted friends and colleagues. Yeshiva University has benefitted over the past four decades from the leadership of Dr. Scott Mackler's family who serve on the Joseph Alexander Foundation Inc., which Helen Mackler's brother, Joseph Alexander established, who they named as a Yeshiva University Benefactor, have established significant academic research in its undergraduate and graduate schools with members of the Mackler family, Helen Mackler and Harvey Mackler serving on the Board of Overseers of Yeshiva College and Stern College for Women respectively, and they named the Joseph Alexander Library of the Marsha Stern Yeshiva University High School. May the entire Mackler family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President
LOCKER--Aaron. You were a dear, sweet man. We will miss you always. Cindy, Andy and Levine family

LOCKER--Aaron, 86, died peacefully at home in Palm Beach Gardens, FL on November 15, 2013. He was also a long time resident of Manhasset and Westhampton Beach, NY He is survived by his beloved wife of 62 years, Renee, sons Frederick (Lori), Jeffrey, Keith (Stacey), grandchildren Alexandra, Sydney, Daniel and Samantha and sister Elinore Lambert. He served in the Armed Forces in World War II, graduated CCNY and NYU Law School. A charming, intelligent and rational counsel and advocate for his clients, including the Toy Industry Association, the Juvenile Products Manufacturers Association, various other Trade Associations and many of their members. He also served as a director of several global companies. A highly respected pioneer in Consumer Product Safety Legislation and Member of the United States Chamber of Commerce (Chair of their Committee on Product Safety) and frequent contributor of congressional testimony on such subject. In 1993 he was honored and inducted into the Toy Industry Hall of Fame, which noted that he guided the Association through the perils of government regulation. His forceful and articulate advocacy of members' interest helped to establish the American Toy Industry's leadership role worldwide. He was a prodigious reader and history buff. A dashing and articulate figure, his life-long passions revolved around the sea and the mountains. He loved the ocean and nothing gave him greater pleasure than fishing, boating, swimming and sailing along its shores. He had an enthusiastic passion for skiing. He enjoyed sharing these adventures with his family. Although measured in thought and speech he loved to drive, boat and ski fast. He was worldly, adventurous and lived life on his own terms. His wry wit, thoughtful counsel and zest for life will be sorely missed by everyone who knew him. A private service will be held for him in Florida with a memorial in New York at a later date. Any donations in his memory can be made to the Toy Industry Foundation (Toyindustryfoundation.org) and Hospice of Palm Beach County (hpbcf.org).

LLOYD--Sally Hill. We will miss your keen mind, your wise and non-judgmental counsel, your devotion, fierce loyalty, and your joie de vivre. There was never a dance party Sally did not love. DIMOND--E. Grey, a physician, medical educator, and an "original" door-opener to modern China died Sunday, November 3, 2013 at his home, Diastole, on Hospital Hill, in Kansas City, Missouri. He was 94. In 1970 the American journalist, Edgar Snow, wrote three articles for Norman Cousins' Saturday Review of Literature, describing his observations in his 1970 trip to the People's Republic of China. These articles dealt with birth control efforts in China, limb re-implantation, and acupuncture anesthesia. The information was original and prompted correspondence from critics declaring that Snow was not a proper observer, was not medically trained, and had apparently been either hoodwinked or was brain-washed by the Chinese. Snow asked his physician friend, Dimond, to go to China, make his observations and report on them. He arranged for an invitation to Dimond from Zhou Enlai. Dimond realized that the acceptance of his findings would be enhanced if his teacher, Paul Dudley White, then 85, could accompany him and bear witness, too. The Dimonds and the Whites arrived in China on September 15, 1971. In their party were the Dr. Sam Rosens and Dr. Victor Sidel of New York City. The four men were the first American physicians in China for 25 years. Their visit antedated Nixon's 1972 diplomatic opening to Communist China. Dimond wrote two articles for the Journal of The American Medical Association (JAMA) fully confirming Snow's findings. Dimond went on to bring the first Chinese physician delegation to the United States in 1972. Over the rest of his lifetime, he took physician and lay groups to China and found study places for Chinese physicians who began coming in numbers. Dimond made 40 trips to Asia, became an honorary professor of medicine at several Chinese medical schools, was for five years consultant to the national heart hospital, Beijing, and negotiated the publication of the Chinese edition of JAMA. He wrote two books, "More than Herbs and Acupuncture" (1975) and "Inside China Today" (1983), W.W Norton, describing his China observations. The first book covered his original trip in 1971, and the second was a biography of the American physician who became a Chinese citizen: George Hatem, (Ma Haide). Dimond's friendships in China gave him unusual access to events there. They included the former foreign minister, Huang Hua; the physician to the leadership, Wu Wei-jan; Rewi Alley, the New Zealander who made his life in China; and Ma Haide, who had joined the communists when they were still at Yenan. In 1980 Dimond and his wife, Mary Dwight Clark, adopted a Chinese daughter, an event that gave them pleasure and pride for the rest of their lives. His wife founded The Edgar Snow Memorial Fund and upon her death, Dimond took on the presidency for 20 years. The University of Missouri-Kansas City houses the Fund's large collection of papers and memorabilia of Edgar Snow. Dimond's observations in China convinced him that China was successfully returning to its historical role as a great nation. He believed that communism was a transitory happening and that the ancient civilization that is China would quietly become the modern China. He never wavered in this observation and often said, "I enjoy the criticisms of contemporaries who are so buried in their hostility towards communism that they could not see the 'return' of China." Dimond was the founder of the unique medical school at the University of Missouri-Kansas City. The School opened the same day Dimond entered China in 1971. Dimond's home, Diastole, was built near the School to honor his wife, Mary Clark Dimond, daughter of Grenville Clark. He gave the home to a private foundation and endowed it to advance the University of Missouri-Kansas City. He also gave the university his major collection of the Rubaiyat of Omar Khayyam. For ten years, beginning in 1950, he was at the University of Kansas School of Medicine and served there as the youngest chairman of medicine at any American medical school. After that he was director of the Institute for Cardiopulmonary Diseases at the Scripps Clinic in La Jolla, California. For a year and half he was special consultant on medical education to the Department of Health, Education and Welfare, Washington, D.C. Dimond is survived by his daughters, Sherri Grey Byrer of Terre Haute, Indiana; Lark Grey Dimond of Rancho Santa Fe, California; and Lea Grey Dimond of San Francisco, California; an adopted Chinese daughter, Dr. Joan Wu-Chang, three grandchildren, eight great-grandchildren, and six great-great grandchildren. He was an only child, born in St. Louis, Missouri, December 8, 1918, on his mother's birthday. His father, Edmunds Grey Dimond, was a pharmaceutical chemist and a representative of Eli Lilly and Company. On both sides his American roots went back to Virginia, 130 years before the founding of the country. Dimond grew up during the Great Depression and obtained an education only by having a football scholarship to Purdue University. Dimond was active for years in the American College of Cardiology and at the time of his death was the oldest living president of the organization. At the University of Missouri he was UMKC Provost for the Health Sciences and statewide Distinguished Professor of Medicine. His ashes will be returned to the family cemetery in Winona, Mississippi. A memorial is to be held in Kansas City, on the campus of UMKC, on December 8, 1:00pm. Memorial contributions may be made to the E. Grey Dimond Memorial Fund c/o Diastole, 2501 Holmes Street, Kansas City, Missouri 64108.

BANCHIK--Donald, of Nanuet, NY on November 12, age 77. Born in The Bronx January 4, 1936 to Joseph and Hilda (Edelman) Banchik he had seven siblings. Anthony Union High School, and had also been an Assistant Principal at Spring Valley High School, Spring Valley, NY. Donald's first wife Barbara (Young) predeceased him in 1997. He is survived by his wife Lorraine Brooks Banchik and his children, Steven and his husband Emmanuel along with Michael and his wife Ruthie, their children Barbara and Benjamin. He is also survived by his step children Maxine Brooks, her son Jason; Jeff Brooks, his wife Sue and their sons, Stan and Jimmy. Donald was known for his sense of humor as well as kindness and easy going attitude. Education was a perfect career, as he loved children of all ages and really cared. He was a supportive nurturing father, a loving and devoted husband as well as a very proud grandfather. He will be missed by all. A graveside funeral service was held at Sons of Israel Cemetery, Monsey, NY. Contributions to Feeding America's Children www.feedingac.org, are preferred and appreciated.
