STRUHL--Dr. Bernard. 13 years, We are still missing you and loving you. Your Family
SEIDEMAN--Abby Rachel. Missing you on your 39th birthday. Love always, Mom, Dad and Wendy
WURZEL--Leonard. He saw beyond tomorrow. We mourn our loss. Audrey and Daniel Scheyer

WURZEL--Leonard, On November 16, 2013, at the age of 95, after a short battle with lung cancer, he passed away at home in his beloved Sands Point. He was the proud Mayor of Sands Point for 22 years. Born in Philadelphia in 1918 he graduated from Washington and Jefferson College in 1939 and earned an MBA from Harvard University in 1941. He was drafted into the United States Army as a Private on September 18, 1941 and was discharged in 1946 as a Captain. He was awarded the Bronze Star Medal for meritorious service in connection with military operations from January 17, 1944 to May 8, 1945. On May 10, 2013 he was bestowed the Insignia of Chevalier of the Legion of Honor by the Consulate General of France. In 1949 he married Elaine Cohen and after four years in Manhattan, in 1953, they moved to Sands Point with their young sons Mark and Larry. Leonard was employed by Loft Candy Corporation from 1946, serving as president from 1957 to 1964. Leonard founded Calico Cottage Candies in 1964, from which he retired in 1992. He was thrilled that his sons now run the business. Leonard has been president of Retail Confectioners International and the Association of Manufacturers of Confectionery and Chocolate. Leonard and Elaine have been members of the Community Synagogue since 1953 and have often been recognized for their devotion and involvement over the years. Leonard served on the Sands Point Board of Zoning Appeals in 1974 and became its Chairman in 1976. He was elected to the Board of Trustees in 1981. On April 17, 1989 he was appointed Mayor of Sands Point and served as elected Mayor until his retirement in June 2011. In 1994, he successfully negotiated the acquisition of the IBM country club by the Village of Sands Point, saving the waterfront property from developers. He is considered the Founder and Mentor of the Village Club of Sands Point. Leonard is survived by his wife, Elaine Cohen Wurzel, his two sons and daughters-in-law, Mark and Ellen Wurzel and Larry Wurzel and Elaine Gnessin. Grandchildren, Jill Wurzel Lekstutis and her husband Carmine Lekstutis, Max Wurzel, and Greg Wurzel and Greg's Mother, Martha Wurzel, and two great-grandchildren, Alex and Chloe Lekstutis. Funeral Services will be held at The Community Synagogue, 160 Middle Neck Rd, Sands Point, NY 11050 at 1:30pm on Tuesday, November 19, 2013. Telephone: (516) 883-3144, Web: commsyn.org. Burial will take place at Beth Moses Cemetery, Wellwood Avenue, West Babylon, NY 11704. Telephone: (631) 249-2290. After burial, on Tuesday, Shiva will take place at Leonard and Elaine Wurzel's home, until 8pm, with services at 7pm. On Wednesday and Thursday Shiva will take place from 3pm to 8pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Community Synagogue.

WOLF--Dawn, beloved mother of Billie Greenfield, daughter of George and Marie Wolf, sister of Marie Wolf and Wendy Blasland (James). Aunt to Jan, Vanessa and Zoe Greenfield, Christopher, Laura and Brendan Goren, and Jimmy, Billy and Emily Blasland. Died unexpectedly in her home on November 11. She was a registered nurse and ingratiated all with her love. Wake: Viewing from 2-6pm on Monday, November 18, 2013 at The Riverdale Funeral Home; 5044 Broadway at the corner of 214th Street. Funeral Mass will be celebrated on Tuesday, November 19, 2013 at 10am at the Church of The Visitation, 160 Van Cortlandt Park So., Bronx, NY 10463. Interment will follow in The Woodlawn Cemetery at the Corner of 233 street and Webster Avenue, Bronx, NY 10740.

SIEGEL--Jeanne Yvette, died peacefully at home on November 16, 2013. Survived by daughters Carol Siegel and Elizabeth Carpenter (David), and grandson Adam Gould. Our mother was a writer, essayist, art critic and educator. Associated with WBAI in the late 1960s, the New School, and for many happy years the School of Visual Arts, where she was Chair Emeritus of the Fine Arts Department.

SFERRA--George W. DDS. With extreme sadness, the Fellows of the New York Academy of Dentistry mourn the passing of Dr. George W. Sferra, Sr. Dr. Sferra was a long time member of the Academy and a Past President. His wise and generous guidance will be missed. Our deepest sympathy is extended to the entire Sferra family. The New York Academy of Dentistry

SFERRA--George W. Sr.,D.D.S., November 6, 2013 at the age of 97. Longtime resident of Haworth, New Jersey before retiring to Gulfport, FL. Practiced dentistry in New York City for over 50 years. Pre-deceased by his loving wife Edith, of 63 years. Loving father of Dr. George W. Sferra Jr. and his wife Barbara, Mary Sferra Facciolla and her husband Tom, James Sferra and his wife Cynthia Allen and John Sferra and his wife Ivana. Cherished grandfather of George, Christopher, Amy, Adam, Alicia and John Paul.

SASSOON--Andre G.,of New York City, on November 16, 2013, age 77, after a long battle with cancer. Born on April 13, 1936 in Cairo, Egypt, Sassoon was loved by friends and family. Sassoon spent much of his life as a tireless friend to the nation of Israel and its causes. A service will be held on Monday, November 18, at 9:30am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel 630 Amsterdam Ave., NY.

MACKLER--Scott.The Western Wall Heritage Foundation mourns the passing of Scott Mackler loving son of Al and Helen Mackler z"l, whose life was an inspiration to all who knew him. His dedication to his family and his love for Jerusalem permeated to all who surrounded him. We extend our deep condolences to our very dear friends: his wife Lynn; their sons Alexander (Laura) and Noah; his brother Harvey (Karen) and sister Randi (Bob); and to all of his nephews and nieces.

MORRELL--C. Bruce, on November 13, 2013. Beloved husband of Helene. Loving brother of the late Ruth Patrk. Devoted uncle of Deborah and Susan. Former husband of Ann Morrell. A Veteran of the United States Navy who graduated from Yale and New York University. He later became a Senior Vice President at Smith Barney and Morgan Stanley. He will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call Tuesday, November 19, 5-8pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian Burial Wednesday, November 20, 1:30pm at St. Vincent Ferrer Church, Lexington Ave. at 66th Street.

GARDNER--Hilde, (September 15, 1911-November 14, 2013), remarkable wife (Ralph), mother (Howard, Marion), grandmother (Andrew, Benjamin, Daniel, Jay, Kerith), great-grandmother (Aggie, Oscar), beloved by scores of relatives and friends all over the world. In face of life-altering disruptions by the rise of Nazi Germany and the death of her first son Eric, she fashioned a new life for herself and her family in the United States, volunteered and accepted leadership roles in many organizations, was a realist who chose to see the positive options and inspired countless others to do the same. Burial private. Donations can be made in Hilde Gardner's name to the Boston Symphony Orchestra and the Harvard Graduate School of Education. Online guestbook at www.brezniakrodman.com

CONNOLLY--Sister Agnes, S.C.,(formerly Sr. Agnes Miriam) died on November 17, 2013 at 95 years of age. Sr. Agnes graduated from St. Vincent Hospital School of Nursing, and later ministered there as Assistant Director. Sr. Agnes also ministered at St. Vincent Hospital, NYC and at St. Joseph Hospital, Yonkers as a Nurse, Nursing Supervisor and Director of Nursing. She held various leadership positions in the Sisters of Charity as Council Member and as President of the Congregation and was Director for Mission of the Alliance for Catholic Health Care and a Trustee on numerous boards of the Sisters of Charity and the Archdiocese of New York. Sr. Agnes is survived by two sisters, Catherine Harris and Mary Dwyer of NYC and several nieces and nephews. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Sisters of Charity Development Fund, Mount St. Vincent, 6301 Riverdale Avenue, Bronx, NY 10471. Wake at Mount St. Vincent Convent, Tuesday, November 19th from 3pm to 8pm, with a Vigil Service at 6:30pm. Funeral Mass: Chapel of the Immaculate Conception at Mt. St. Vincent, Wednesday, November 20th at 10am. Burial at the Sisters Cemetery. flynnmemorialhome.com

Bush Moukarzel’s first line in the one-man play “Souvenir,” now playing at the Abrons Arts Center in New York, is, “For a long time, I went to bed early.” It’s also the very famous first line of Marcel Proust’s “Remembrance of Things Past,” published a century ago this year. Moukarzel’s hourlong piece, which was a sold-out hit in Dublin and London for the theater company Dead Centre, aims not so much to relive Proust’s epic, seven-volume story of social climbing, desire and memory as to distill its yearning, nostalgic essence into fragments of narrative and images. When the show begins, Moukarzel is running on a treadmill, his back to us, instantly conjuring images of being borne back ceaselessly into the past (or, stuck in the present). A giant diptych of Proust hangs overhead. Everywhere, there’s a clutter of half-opened packing boxes, marked cheekily with labels like “Mum,” “Apologies, “Bacon,” “Broken Glass” and (inevitably) “Madeleines.”

WURZEL--Leonard. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Leonard Wurzel. He leaves behind a legacy of exceptional philanthropy. We extend our condolences to Leonard's wife, Elaine; his children, Mark (Ellen) and Larry (Elaine); his grandchildren; his great-grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

WURZEL--Leonard, On November 16, 2013, at the age of 95, after a short battle with lung cancer, he passed away at home in his beloved Sands Point. He was the proud Mayor of Sands Point for 22 years. Born in Philadelphia in 1918 he graduated from Washington and Jefferson College in 1939 and earned an MBA from Harvard University in 1941. He was drafted into the United States Army as a Private on September 18, 1941 and was discharged in 1946 as a Captain. He was awarded the Bronze Star Medal for meritorious service in connection with military operations from January 17, 1944 to May 8, 1945. On May 10, 2013 he was bestowed the Insignia of Chevalier of the Legion of Honor by the Consulate General of France. In 1949 he married Elaine Cohen and after four years in Manhattan, in 1953, they moved to Sands Point with their young sons Mark and Larry. Leonard was employed by Loft Candy Corporation from 1946, serving as president from 1957 to 1964. Leonard founded Calico Cottage Candies in 1964, from which he retired in 1992. He was thrilled that his sons now run the business. Leonard has been president of Retail Confectioners International and the Association of Manufacturers of Confectionery and Chocolate. Leonard and Elaine have been members of the Community Synagogue since 1953 and have often been recognized for their devotion and involvement over the years. Leonard served on the Sands Point Board of Zoning Appeals in 1974 and became its Chairman in 1976. He was elected to the Board of Trustees in 1981. On April 17, 1989 he was appointed Mayor of Sands Point and served as elected Mayor until his retirement in June 2011. In 1994, he successfully negotiated the acquisition of the IBM country club by the Village of Sands Point, saving the waterfront property from developers. He is considered the Founder and Mentor of the Village Club of Sands Point. Leonard is survived by his wife, Elaine Cohen Wurzel, his two sons and daughters-in-law, Mark and Ellen Wurzel and Larry Wurzel and Elaine Gnessin. Grandchildren, Jill Wurzel Lekstutis and her husband Carmine Lekstutis, Max Wurzel, and Greg Wurzel and Greg's Mother, Martha Wurzel, and two great-grandchildren, Alex and Chloe Lekstutis. Funeral Services will be held at The Community Synagogue, 160 Middle Neck Rd, Sands Point, NY 11050 at 1:30pm on Tuesday, November 19, 2013. Telephone: (516) 883-3144, Web: commsyn.org. Burial will take place at Beth Moses Cemetery, Wellwood Avenue, West Babylon, NY 11704. Telephone: (631) 249-2290. After burial, on Tuesday, Shiva will take place at Leonard and Elaine Wurzel's home, until 8pm, with services at 7pm. On Wednesday and Thursday Shiva will take place from 3pm to 8pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the Community Synagogue.

REES--Thomas D.,MD. Thomas D. Rees, MD, FACS, 86, a distinguished and widely-honored plastic surgeon who also devoted much of his life to providing his skills and extensive medical care to the people of East Africa, passed away peacefully at his home in Santa Fe, NM, in the early evening hours of Thursday, November 14th, 2013. He follows his beloved wife, Nan, who passed away in May of 2012, his son David M. Rees, and is survived by his son Thomas D. Rees, Jr., daughter S. Elizabeth Rees, brother J. Richard Rees, MD, and numerous nieces and nephews. Dr. Rees was born in Nephi and raised in Salt Lake City, UT, the son of University of Utah professor Don M. Rees, PhD, and Norma A. Rees, and was a second generation descendent of Mormon pioneers from the south of Wales. He graduated from the University of Utah with a BA in 1946, and an MD in 1948, and from which he received an honorary Doctor of Science degree in 2013. He enlisted in the U.S. Navy in 1945, also served from 1957-1958, and was honorably discharged a Lt. Commander. Dr. Rees trained in general and plastic surgery at the Genesee Hospital in Rochester, NY, and The New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in New York City, followed by a prestigious fellowship in plastic surgery at the Queen Victoria Hospital in East Grinstead, in Sussex, England. He was privileged to work under Sir Archibald McIndoe, a pioneering New Zealand plastic surgeon who was famous for his work on the RAF pilots largely credited with saving England in the Battle of Britain in WWII. During his fellowship, Dr. Rees was invited by Sir Archibald to visit his ranch in Kenya. While enjoying "sundowners" together with Sir Michael Wood (another fellow under Sir Archibald and a transplant to Kenya), the three surgeons founded the Flying Doctors of East Africa in 1957. The three founders flew into the bush to set up clinics in rural areas of East Africa to enable advanced medical care ranging from vaccinations to operating on and treating local patients with congenital deformities and other conditions requiring extensive surgery and reconstruction. Radio and TV personality Arthur Godfrey donated their first plane, and through worldwide fundraising and government aid, the three surgeons created the organization now known as AMREF (African Medical & Research Foundation), which has grown into Africa's largest health development NGO. Based in Nairobi, Kenya, AMREF has offices in 11 countries in North America and Europe. AMREF now employs more than 1,000 health professionals and experts, 97% African, with 90% living in the communities in which they work. Over the past five decades, AMREF has received numerous awards for its contributions to African health development. Most recent include the Gates Award for Global Health, recognizing organizations that have made an outstanding contribution to improving global health, especially in resource-poor settings, and the Conrad N. Hilton Humanitarian Award, the world's largest humanitarian prize given to an organization that is significantly alleviating human suffering. Dr. Rees traveled to Africa annually and wrote a memoir about his experiences entitled "Daktari: A Surgeon's Adventures with the Flying Doctors of East Africa." Dr. Rees' contributions to the areas of plastic surgery techniques, education, and credibility cannot be overstated. He established his plastic and cosmetic surgery practice in New York City in 1957, at a time when there were only a handful of practicing plastic surgeons. With few exceptions, the field of plastic surgery was very insular in that most surgeons were fiercely protective of their techniques. Dr. Rees was only happy to open up his operating room to students, and he loved teaching and writing. He mentored thousands of fledgling plastic surgeons throughout his career; in his capacity as the Chairman of the Department of Plastic Surgery at Manhattan Eye, Ear & Throat Hospital from 1975-1992; directing the MEETH Aesthetic Surgery Fellowship; and teaching at the Institute of Reconstructive Plastic Surgery of the NYU Langone Medical Center. For over 25 years, Dr. Rees organized and co-chaired an annual Symposium on Aesthetic Plastic Surgery in New York City. These symposia feature a faculty composed of surgeons of different disciplines and nationalities, and are attended by surgeons from all over the world. Dr. Rees was a Clinical Professor of Plastic Surgery at the New York University School of Medicine, Chairman Emeritus of the Department of Plastic Surgery at MEETH, as well as a past president of the American Society of Aesthetic Plastic Surgery, and a former director and vice-chairman of the American Board of Plastic Surgery. He was a frequent lecturer at medical institutions, symposia and forums all over the world, and the author of more than 140 medical articles and six medical texts, including the two-volume Aesthetic Plastic Surgery, long the bible for surgeons in training. Dr. Thomas Rees had many talents and interests that extended beyond medicine. He was a philanthropist, an avid fly fisherman in the west and saltwater and deep-sea fisherman in the east, a skier, at home on horseback, a jazz saxophonist who sat in with some of the best of his era. Upon retirement, he became an acclaimed sculptor in Santa Fe whose work reflected his experiences and feelings for the people, animals, and environment of Africa and his work was exhibited in 2009 at the Gerald Peters Gallery in Santa Fe. Dr. Rees' transformative surgical skills touched celebrities, political figures, heads of state and their families and the people of East Africa. In all of this, he was accompanied, encouraged, and supported by his adored wife Nan. His ashes will be joined with his wife's and scattered in their beloved East Africa. A memorial service will be announced and take place within the coming months. In his memory, contributions may be made to those organizations to which he committed so much of himself.

MILLER--Leonore (Lee), died Sunday, November 17, in her home in Forest Hills, NY. Born in the Bronx in 1925 to Mary and Benjamin Paguer, Lee graduated from Hunter College, attended law school and had careers as a social worker, guidance counselor, and advocate in the area of self-help for women with breast and ovarian cancer. A founding member of SHARE, she has served the organization with passion since 1976. She was also known for her love of purple, chocolate, jellybeans and make-up. Lee is pre-deceased by her husband Edward, and survived by her children David Daniel, Mitchell, Jory and Celeste, eight grandchildren and four great-grandchildren, as well as countless friends, colleagues and the many others touched by her warmth and her work. Viewing will be held Tuesday, November 19 at 7pm, services Wednesday, November 20 at 10am, both at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 98-60 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY. For Shiva details, contact barbara@klipper.us. Donations can be made to SHARE Development Dept., 1501 Broadway, Ste 704A, New York, NY 10036

HUBBARD--Hugh Johnston, known affectionately as Butch by his family and friends, passed away Friday morning, November 15, 2013. Butch, age 70, son of the late Otis L. Hubbard and Ethel J. Hubbard, was born near the family home in Camden, Maine and raised in Lake Forest, Illinois. Like his father and older brother, Otis L. Hubbard, Jr., he attended the Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Connecticut and then graduated from Yale University. Butch thrived in New York City in the 1970's and 1980's turning his attention to the bright lights of Broadway. He acted as co-producer of several musical productions, culminating with a 1992 Tony Award for the revival of Guys And Dolls. He was an inveterate reader and passionate traveler, but more than anything, Butch loved to be surrounded by family and friends and typically was the instigator and center of conversation. He was the consummate story teller and captivated his nieces and nephews with tales of the good times in the city that never sleeps. Butch's engaging humor, robust laughter and perpetual smile will be missed by his many admirers. Preceded in death by his sister, Barbara Hubbard Campbell, and brother, Otis Livingston Hubbard, he leaves behind six nieces and nephews, Otis L. Hubbard III, Laura H. Lucia, John K. Hubbard, James O. Campbell, Nick M. Campbell, Turia C. Gumpert. A private memorial service will be held on Friday, November 22, 2013. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to the Chicago Symphony Orchestra (220 S. Michigan Ave., Chicago, IL 60604) and the Lyric Opera of Chicago (20 N. Wacker Drive, Chicago, IL 60606). Information Wenban Funeral Home, Lake Forest, IL www.wenbanfh.com or (847) 234-0022.

WALSH--William Desmond. William (Bill) Walsh, Esq., a man of singular generosity and outstanding leadership in business died at Stanford University Hospital on Saturday, November 16, 2013. Born in New York on August 4, 1930, Bill was a graduate of Fordham University (1951) and Harvard Law School (1955). He began his career as an Assistant US Attorney for the Southern District of New York where his arguments led to the prosecution of many organized crime figures of the 1950s including crime boss Vito Genovese. After six years he entered the private sector, first at McKinsey and Company and then heading to the west coast to join Arcata Corporation ending as President and CEO, later founding Sequoia Associates, LLC. There he forged partnerships and envisioned investment possibilities in corporate America which brought inestimable benefit to the country's economy and institutions. Bill took a deep interest in political, religious and educational matters in his country and the country of his heritage, Ireland. A committed and thoughtful philanthropist, he set standards that summoned up the best in others, and countless institutions have benefited from his generosity and leadership. Fordham University acquired a world class library (The William D. Walsh Family Library) and a classic antiquities museum, Harvard Law School built new state of the art classrooms, the Neuroscience Institute was given a new home for important study, the American Ireland Fund launched ground breaking programs in peace and reconciliation for the new generation, the government of Bolivia was a recipient of much needed medical supplies through his service as a Knight of Malta and served on the Board of Overseers at the Hoover Institution. Bill and his cherished wife Jane hosted Vintage Affaire, the annual fundraiser for the Vista Center, for many years at their home in Atherton. Sonoma Developmental Center which looked after his daughter, Caroline was another of his philanthropies. It was not simply financial support that he offered and inspired in others. Believing that time and talent should be given in equal measure with treasure, he served on the boards of these institutions, tirelessly offering his advice and inspiration. Bill had a great sense of fun and festivity, while being utterly committed to his friends and family. His greatest pride with Jane were his children: Deborah Hirsch (Peter), Michael Walsh (Barbara), Suzanne Tinsley (Ken), Tara Jane Arnold (Mark) and Peter Walsh (Melanie) and his 12 grandchildren: Timothy and Rebecca Hirsch, Patrick, Riley, Kevin, Brian, Megan, Sean, and Molly Tinsley, Spencer and Maxwell Arnold and Liam Walsh. Mr. Walsh is predeceased by his wife of 57 years and his daughter Caroline and is survived by his brother Donald G. Walsh of New Haven, Connecticut. A Memorial Mass will be held on Friday, November 22 at 11am at St. Raymond Catholic Church, 1100 Santa Cruz Avenue, Menlo Park, CA. The family requests that in lieu of flowers, contributions be made in Bill Walsh's memory to Parents Hospital Association in support of Sonoma Developmental Center, P.O. Box 237, Eldridge, CA 95431.

STUART--Stephen, (originally Slobodkin, aka "Nikdobols"), award winning professional photographer, who turned to scrimshaw and writing to satisfy his creative forces when the photographers went digital, died this last weekend after a brave battle against cancer. His life is celebrated by his wife, Mary Ann Smania; his brother and sister-in-law, Marc and Carol Stuart; his nephews, Brian and Neil and Neil's wife, Julie: and their beloved boys, Daniel and Matthew. Steve's son (by a former marriage), Jamie Stuart, has found his creative talents best expressed in the venue of independent film making where he has also received recognition as a force in the field. And not to be left out of the celebration of Steve's life are those who were Steve's "Chosen People" (aka friends): the Erenberg's; Bobbie and Stuart; the Malfa's; the Grande's; the Panico's; the Jasnow's; the Sterns; the Minnick's; the Weinraub's; Jimmy and Michelle; all the "Knife Guys" too numerous to mention; Steve's "guys", Marv, Irwin, Mike, and Pete; and all those who came into Steve's life by way of Mary Ann (except for the lawyers). Although from Florida, final arrangements for Steve are being made by the Ballard-Durand Funeral Home in White Plains, New York. Check their web site for details. In lieu of flowers, which always irritated Steve's nose, please make donations to the American Cancer Society.

STEIN--Bella Skutel, died peacefully at home, November 16, 2013, age 95. Beloved daughter of Samuel and Lena, dear sister of George and Harold, devoted wife of Manuel W. Stein, and loving mother of Ellen, she was also an adored cousin, aunt, and loyal friend.

SCHLECKER--Lucille, beloved wife of Dr. Austin Schlecker for 62 years. Loving mother of Jane (Jeffrey) Vorsanger, Burton (Elyse), David (Susan) and Lauren (George) Cohen. Proud grandmother of Matthew, Andrew, Rachel, Sarah, Evan, Nikki, Carly, Mark, Rose, Emma, Linda and Henry. Dear sister of Barbara Courtian. A devoted special education teacher in Brooklyn for over 30 years. Services: 12 Noon, Thursday, November 21 at Sherman's Flatbush Memorial Chapel, 1283 Coney Island Avenue (Ave. J), Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to your favorite Jewish charity.

SFERRA--George W.,DDS. The Officers and Board of Directors of the New York County Dental Society note with sorrow the passing of its esteemed past president who served the profession with great leadership. Our condolences to the family.

REES--Dr. Thomas D. The faculty and staff of the Institute of Reconstructive Plastic Surgery mourn the passing of their esteemed colleague, Dr. Thomas D. Rees. A longtime member of the Institute faculty, he was a Clinical Professor of Plastic Surgery at the NYU School of Medicine. He mentored many plastic surgery residents and fellows and was beloved by all. His writings and courses established aesthetic surgery as a vital component of plastic surgery. He was also distinguished for his international health initiatives. We extend our condolences to his daughter Liz and son Tom. Eduardo D. Rodriguez, MD, DDS. Director, Institute of Reconstructive Plastic Surgery; Joseph G. McCarthy, MD Director Emeritus, Institute of Reconstructive Plastic Surgery
PHILLIPS--Robert Warner, of Brooklyn Heights and Cornwall Vermont died on November 14, 2013, age 86. Memorial Service at St. Luke's in the Fields Episcopal Church on November 23 at 2pm.

O'DONOGHUE--Victoria Velie, of Princeton, NJ passed away November 16, 2013. Mother of Pierce McKellar and Nicholas McKellar, she was the daughter of Fleury Velie Mackie and the late Jack Terhune Valdes, and sister to Stacy Lorenceau, Midge Valdes and Kelly Valdes. A vivacious, beautiful woman, Vickie was involved in many aspects of the arts and lived for a time in New York City. Fond memories of Vickie may be shared at: vickie.memories@gmail.com.

MILLER--Leonore (Lee), died Sunday, November 17, in her home in Forest Hills, NY. Born in the Bronx in 1925 to Mary and Benjamin Paguer, Lee graduated from Hunter College, attended law school and had careers as a social worker, guidance counselor, and advocate in the area of self-help for women with breast and ovarian cancer. A founding member of SHARE, she has served the organization with passion since 1976. She was also known for her love of purple, chocolate, jellybeans and make-up. Lee is pre-deceased by her husband Edward, and survived by her children David Daniel, Mitchell, Jory and Celeste, eight grandchildren and four great-grandchildren, as well as countless friends, colleagues and the many others touched by her warmth and her work. Viewing will be held Tuesday, November 19 at 7pm, services Wednesday, November 20 at 10am, both at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 98-60 Queens Blvd., Forest Hills, NY. For Shiva details, contact barbara@klipper.us. Donations can be made to SHARE Development Dept., 1501 Broadway, Ste 704A, New York, NY 10036

MASLON--Gerald Edward, of Greenport, NY died on November 15th, 2013, at Mather Hospital in Port Jefferson, NY. He was eighty-nine years old. The death was due to complications from surgery. Gerry Maslon practiced law in New York City for forty years. He spent the last twelve at the City University of New York, specializing in real estate, supervising millions of dollars worth of building. In addition, he held most of the offices on the board of the Center for Development Disability in Woodbury, serving as President for two terms. He left in 2002 to become a founding member of Peconic Landing, a retirement community on the North Shore of Long Island. There he taught seven courses in Lifetime Learning, in constitutional law, music, art and literature. Born in the Bronx and educated in New York City public schools, Gerry graduated from Townsend Harris High School. A member of the Harvard Class of 1945, he completed his education at Harvard Law School. His interests in Cambridge included theater craft and The Harvard Crimson. On graduation he joined the Army and was sent to Yale to study Japanese in a total immersion course. He served as an analyst for the Counter Intelligence Corps and was stationed in Japan with the Army's occupation forces. Returning to New York he joined his father's legal practice. In 1950 Gerry married Elinor Front, a graduate of Barnard College and a member of the WAVES. She died at Peconic Landing in 2003. They had two sons, Henry, a staff member at Adelphi College library, and Laurence, an arts professor at New York University and author of several books on popular culture and the musical theater. Gerry also leaves a daughter-in-law, Genevieve Elam, an actress, as well as a beloved grandchild, Miles Maslon. In 2009 Gerry married Anne Tolstoi Wallach, an advertising woman turned novelist with "Women's Work." The best-selling book earned the highest advance in publishing history for an unknown author, and was translated into seventeen languages. With her, Gerry acquired three stepchildren, eight stepgrandchildren and a step great grandchild. Gerry Maslon took his family, his faith and his friends seriously; himself, never. He will be widely missed.

MACKLER--Dr. Scott. JBI International (the Jewish Braille Institute) deeply mourns the passing of Dr. Scott Mackler, the son of Alfred and Helen Mackler of blessed memory, who were long time and devoted JBI trustees. The compassionate and generous support of the Mackler family, through the Joseph Alexander Foundation, continues to brighten the lives of thousands of blind and visually impaired individuals. Our deepest condolences go to the entire family. May his memory serve as a blessing. Judy E. Tenney, Chairman of 2the Board Dr. Ellen Isler, President & CEO Israel A. Taub, Vice President & CFO

LOWE--Morton. It is with extreme sadness we mourn the death of our uncle, Morty Lowe, adored and adoring husband of Elizabeth, father of Jan, Jeffrey and Pamela Edith, and brother of Marcelle Lowell. We extend our deepest, heartfelt condolences to them and to his grandchildren. His warm, distinct personality and joy in life will be sorely missed. His likes will not be found again. Richard H. M. and Gail Lowe Maidman

LOWE--Morton E.,on November 18, 2013. Beloved and devoted husband of Dr. Elizabeth Lowe for 27 years, loving father of Jan, Jeff and Pamela, also survived by his sister Marcelle Lowell. Service Wednesday, November 20, 2013, 11:45am at "The Riverside," 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

LONDON--Jill, on November 18. Beloved mother of Lauren. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Service: Thursday, November 21, 10:30am at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street.

LAMBERT--Dr. Bruno, born October 2, 1910 in Andernach, Rhineland, Germany, died peacefully in his sleep, at his home, on November 14, 2013, age 103. Beloved husband of Margaret Bergman Lambert for more than 75 years; loving father of Glenn and Gary Lambert; devoted father-in-law of Martha Cronin Lambert; adoring grandfather of Molly and Ben Lambert. Cherished brother of the late Alfred and Hannah Lambert. Also survived by sister-in-law Elfriede Lambert, and nieces and nephews from both the Lambert and Bergman families. Services will take place Sunday, November 24 at 12:00pm at Schwartz Brothers-Jeffer funeral home, 114-03 Queens Blvd, Forest Hills. Contributions in his memory may be made to Doctors Without Borders, https://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/donate/tribute.cfm.

KIERNAN--Judith E.,of Westport, CT, passed away on November 15, 2013. She was the devoted wife of Charles E. Kiernan (Retired President/ COO of Duracell Int'l, Inc.); loving mother of Kathleen Kiernan Bailey, and her husband, Kenneth, and Christopher Kiernan. Calling hours will be held on Wednesday from 4:30-7:30pm in the Lesko & Polke Funeral Home, Fairfield, CT, with prayer services at 7:30pm. Interment will be private. KELLER--Ruth 85, of Great Neck, NY, died peacefully November 12, 2013. Holocaust survivor. Beloved wife of the late Paul Keller, mother of Michael Keller and the late Joseph Keller, mother-in-law of Cheryl Keller. Please consider donations to the Museum of Jewish Heritage-A Living Memorial to the Holocaust, 36 Battery Place, New York, NY 10280 and Friends & Alumni of OSE-USA, P.O. Box 2184, Livingston, NJ 07039.

HUBBARD--Hugh Johnston, known affectionately as Butch by his family and friends, passed away Friday morning, November 15, 2013. Butch, age 70, son of the late Otis L. Hubbard and Ethel J. Hubbard, was born near the family home in Camden, Maine and raised in Lake Forest, Illinois. Like his father and older brother, Otis L. Hubbard, Jr., he attended the Hotchkiss School in Lakeville, Connecticut and then graduated from Yale University. Butch thrived in New York City in the 1970's and 1980's turning his attention to the bright lights of Broadway. He acted as co-producer of several musical productions, culminating with a 1992 Tony Award for the revival of Guys And Dolls. He was an inveterate reader and passionate traveler, but more than anything, Butch loved to be surrounded by family and friends and typically was the instigator and center of conversation. He was the consummate story teller and captivated his nieces and nephews with tales of the good times in the city that never sleeps. Butch's engaging humor, robust laughter and perpetual smile will be missed by his many admirers. Preceded in death by his sister, Barbara Hubbard Campbell, and brother, Otis Livingston Hubbard, he leaves behind six nieces and nephews, Otis L. Hubbard III, Laura H. Lucia, John K. Hubbard, James O. Campbell, Nick M. Campbell, Turia C. Gumpert. A private memorial service will be held on Friday, November 22, 2013. In lieu of flowers, please consider donations to the Chicago Symphony Orchestra (220 S. Michigan Ave., Chicago, IL 60604) and the Lyric Opera of Chicago (20 N. Wacker Drive, Chicago, IL 60606). Information Wenban Funeral Home, Lake Forest, IL www.wenbanfh.com or (847) 234-0022.

GUDAS--Albert J.,The members of the Department of Pharmacology at Weill Cornell Medical College express their sorrow at the death of Albert J Gudas, beloved father of our chairman, Dr. Lorraine Gudas. We send our heartfelt condolences to Dr. Gudas, her mother, her sister Celeste, and his grandchildren.

GREENBERG--Rabbi David, passed away November 18, 2013. Married to the late Marilyn Kosofsky Greenberg. Survived by children Rachel, Ruth, Ethan, Adam and Susannah, as well as nine grandchildren. He served as US Navy Chaplin and was ordained at HUC-JIR. Rabbi for many years at the Scarsdale Synagogue, he later was Rabbi at the Jewish Center of the Hamptons. Burial will be private. Shiva at the home of Susannah Greenberg.
GOLDSCHMIDT--Richard. We mourn the death of Richard, son of Annabelle and Kurt. Brother of Jeffrey and Carin. His life had difficult challenges which have now been met. Sleep well.

BUTTER--Sandra Ruiz. VIP Community Services, Inc.,its Board of Directors and staff mourn the loss of Sandra Ruiz Butter, VIP's Director from 1993 to 2010, who passed away on Monday, November 11th following a long illness. Under Sandra's leadership and guidance, VIP grew from a small organization to become a vital and indispensable part of the fabric of the South Bronx providing recovery services, housing, health care, and vocational support. Sandra Ruiz Butter was a formidable presence as a leader in the Bronx and made a significant impact on the lives of VIP clients, staff and the Bronx community. Her guidance of the organization helped to build it to what it is today, and VIP continues to thrive on the foundation she laid. VIP extends it sympathies to Sandra's husband Bob and to her daughter Alicia. Contributions in memory of Sandra Ruiz Butter can be made to VIP Community Services, Inc., C/O Jepi Rivera, 1910 Arthur Avenue, Bronx, NY 10457. Charles Burgess, Chairman of the Board of Directors Debra de Jesus Vizzi, President

BERENBEIM--Sarah Katherine. Age 30, died suddenly in New York City on November 18, 2013. Daughter of Ronald and Jane Berenbeim, sister of Jessica, granddaughter of Joan Axelrod and the late Leonard Berenbeim, and of the late Sylvia and Murray Rosen; niece of Laura Rosen Reiter, Linda Berenbeim Nathan, and the late David Berenbeim; cousin of Joshua Nathan, Marnie Nathan Kloster, Alexander Berenbeim, and the late Samuel Berenbeim. BELL--John Annison, 71, of New York City died peacefully November 13, 2013. Services November 21, 2013 at 11am to be held at Roy L. Gilmore's Funeral Home, 191-02 Linden Blvd, St. Albans, NY 11412. Burial following at Calverton National Cemetery.

ASCH--Adrienne. Dr. Adrienne Asch, Director of the Center for Ethics at Yeshiva University and the Edward and Robin Milstein Professor of Bioethics, passed away on the morning of November 19. Dr. Asch taught courses at Wurzweiler School of Social Work, Cardozo School of Law, and Albert Einstein College of Medicine on bioethics, reproductive rights, professional ethics, and disability. She was a prolific scholar and engaged activist. Her sharp mind and her love of ideas will be sorely missed by her colleagues at Yeshiva University. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Dr. Carmen Ortiz Hendricks, Dorothy and David Schachne Dean, Wurzweiler School of Social Work

ASCH--Adrienne, peacefully at home on November 19, 2013. WECHSLER--Robert L. American Friends of The Hebrew University (AFHU) and The Hebrew University of Jerusalem mourn the loss of our esteemed friend, Robert Wechsler, a member of AFHU's national Board of Regents. Robert's commitment to civil rights, Israel and higher education constituted a beautiful family legacy. We extend our deepest sympathies to Robert's loving family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Hebrew University of Jerusalem Professor Menahem Ben-Sasson, President American Friends of The Hebrew University Michael S. Kurtz, Chairman Daniel I. Schlessinger, President Peter T. Willner, National Executive Director

WALSH--William D. Fordham University mourns the loss of our alumnus, colleague, and dear friend, William D. Walsh. A graduate of Fordham College, he was a valued member of the Fordham Board and its Executive Committee for many years and later served as a Trustee Emeritus. In recognition of his deep commitment and exemplary service to his alma mater, Fordham was proud to honor him with the Insignis Medal, one of the inaugural Fordham Founder's Awards, and an honorary Doctorate of Laws degree. He will be remembered by generations of Fordham students and faculty for his major contribution to and belief in the importance of the construction of the William D. Walsh Family Library at Fordham which opened in 1997 as one of the most technologically advanced academic libraries in the country. A decade later, the Fordham Museum of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Art, made possible by a generous donation of the Walsh Family's private collection of antiquities, opened in the William D. Walsh Family Library. Our thoughts and prayers are with his children, Deborah, Michael, Suzanne, Tara, and Peter; his brother Donald; and their families. Robert D. Daleo Chair of the Board of Trustees Joseph M. McShane, S.J. President

STOLLAR--Jeannette Gillespie, of Manhattan and Montgomery, NY. She leaves behind a family deeply saddened by her loss, including stepson Mark and wife Sandra, and daughter Jessica and husband Quentin. Services Sunday November 24, 11:30am at Millspaugh Funeral Home, Walden, NY. millspaughfuneralhome.com. Suggested donations to the Lou Stollar Scholarship Fund at FIT, Call 212-217-3370.

SMITH--Ophelia Marie, Cherished sister of Amelia Kaye Byer and Claude Byer, devoted aunt of Ernestine and David Byer-Tyre, LaVonne and Aaron Brown, Claudia, Constance and Janiya Byer-Tyre; loving cousin of Valerie Gresham; and beloved colleague of the board and staff of Win (Women In Need, Inc.). Born in New Bern North Carolina, Ophelia held a Ph.D. in Clinical Psychology from Columbia University as well as a BA in German and BM in Piano Performance from Oberlin College and Conservatory. After an early multidisciplinary career in recording, publishing and corporate divisions at CBS, she shifted gears to helping New York's most in need, becoming the Director of the Continuing Care Clinic at Fordham-Tremont Community Mental Health Clinic. In 1996, she came to Win as Vice President for Client Services where she led all program services overseeing administrative and organizational development activities for the more than 200 division staff employees who serve more than 10,000 women and children each year in Win's transitional family homeless shelters, supportive housing and alcohol and substance abuse clinic. She worked tirelessly to help homeless and distressed women and their families achieve independence and lead more fulfilling lives by guiding innovative holistic programming. Under her direction, Win opened seven family homeless shelters and one women's shelter in New York City. Most recently Dr. Smith led the team that conceptualized and developed Win Academy. She has helped well over 100,000 clients during her tenure at Win. A Celebration of Life will be held at The Church of the Holy Apostles, 296 Ninth Ave, New York, NY (at 28th St) on Saturday, November 23rd at 10:00am. The family asks that in lieu of flowers donations be made to Win (Women In Need) 115 West 31st St. NYC 10001 or Abhyasa Ashram Yoga and Meditation Center, 505 Hooper Drive, Ft. Walton Beach, FL 32548.

SALIGMAN--Harvey N. at the age of 75 in St. Louis, MO on Friday, November 15, 2013. Beloved husband for 34 years of Linda Powell Saligman; loving father of Martin, Lilli, Todd, Adam and Brian; dear grandfather of Max and Sam; brother of the late Rita Cooper and Lynn Saligman, uncle, great-uncle, cousin and friend of many. Former President and CEO of Interco, a long time trustee of Washington University and former trustee of Mercantile Bank and Ameren UE. He was a passionate supporter and collector of American Art. He loved the ocean and was a part time resident of Nantucket, where he will miss being on his boat "Triple Trouble," with his sons. His tremendous spirit and sense of humor made everyone around him happier and healthier. He will be remembered by those who knew him for his humility, kindness, grace, dignity and service to others. Services: A Memorial Service will be conducted at Graham Chapel on the campus of Washington University in St. Louis, MO on Sunday, November 24, 2013 at 1pm. Parking available by entering on Wallace Drive off of Forsyth Blvd., at Danforth University Center. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to the Harvey and Linda Saligman Multiple Myeloma Research Fund, attn: David Blasingame, Washington University Campus, Box 1101, 1 Brookings Dr, St. Louis, MO 63130-4899. No visitation. Condolences online at www.luptonchapel.com

O'DAY--Arthur Francis, passed away on November 15, 2013, from complications from heart disease. Art was born May 29, 1931 in Brockton, Massachusetts. He grew up in Stoughton Massachusetts, where as a teenager he achieved the rank of Eagle Scout. Art graduated from Stoughton High School in 1949 and Brown University in 1953. At Brown on September 18, 1950 he met and immediately fell for Sally Wilcox of Rockland, MA and in June of 2013 they celebrated 60 years of marriage. The family lived in Scituate, MA, where Art served as President of the Planning Board. In 1964, they moved to Chappaqua, NY and then in 1977 to Manhattan where he took full advantage of the arts. Art loved his family and they loved him, he is survived by his wife Sally, his five daughters Gail O'Day (Tom Frank) of Winston-Salem, NC, Wendy O'Day of Greenwood, NC, Linda O'Day Kennedy (Robert Kennedy) of Colonie, NY, Susan O'Day of Pasadena, CA, Brooke O'Day of Decatur, TN and two grandchildren Matthew Kennedy of Oak Island, NC and Amanda Kennedy (Roman Dubiel) of Albany, NY and a great-granddaughter Justice Kennedy, he is also survived by many nieces and nephews. Following graduation from Brown, Art proudly served in the US Army - 51st Signal Battalion in Iuncheon, Korea. Upon his discharge Art joined The Nordblom Company, a well-known Boston commercial real estate company. He then joined Berenson Company and in 1964 was hired to do real estate development for Associated Dry Goods, a job he totally thrived on and excelled at until the company was sold in 1986 to The May Company. Following his work at ADG he joined The Limited and then The O'Connor Company. While living in NYC, Art became Chairman of the Board of Brooklyn based Family Dynamics, which provides vital children's services. In 1989 Art and Sally retired to Jonathan's Landings in Jupiter, FL where they have spent the last 24 years. In 1953 Art took up golf in support of his wife's interests and has continued to enjoy and play all his life, first as a member at Scituate Country Club, then Mt. Kisco Country Club where he served as President and currently in addition to Scituate Country Club, Jonathan's Landing Golf Club, making many golf friends along the way. Art was a huge sports fan, loved his pets, particularly his pal Yogi, enjoyed bridge and The New York Times crossword puzzles. In retirement Art actively volunteered in many organizations including taking on the job of President of Jonathan's Landing Property Owners. He later became President of Jonathan's Landing Cares, which encourages and coordinated volunteer involvement within the Jupiter community. Additionally one of Art's favorite volunteer activities was being a weekly tutor at Jupiter Elementary School. There will be a memorial service for family and friends to celebrate Arts' life at 11:00am on Monday, November 25, 2013 at First Trinitarian Congregational Church of Scituate, 381 County Way, Scituate, Massachusetts 02066. In lieu of flowers donations should be directed to JL Cares or your favorite charity. To express your condolences you may visit: www.taylorandmodeen.com

MULLEN--Kevin F.,80, of Matawan, NJ, passed away on Sunday November 17, 2013 at JFK Medical Center in Edison, NJ. He was born in Navan, County Meath, Ireland, and came to the United States on Memorial Day 1953. A veteran of the United States Army, he was stationed in Germany from 1954 to 1956. He lived in New York until moving to Matawan in 1964. Before retiring, he had a long career in the restaurant business in New York. He loved to travel, and enjoyed many trips to Ireland. He was predeceased by his parents, James and Winifred Mullen, as well as six siblings. He is survived by his wife Philomena, son James Mullen, daughter Lisa Mullen, son-in-law Charles Hauer, grandson Michael Hauer, brother Patrick A. Mullen and sister, Sr. Therese Mullen, as well as many nieces, nephews, and cousins. Funeral and cremation services are under the guidance of Waitt Funeral Home and Cremation Service, 501 Hwy 79, Morganville, NJ 07751. Relatives and friends will be received at the funeral home on Friday, November 22, 2013, from 2pm to 4pm and 7pm to 9pm, and also Saturday, November 23, 2013 at 10am. A funeral mass will be celebrated on Saturday, November 23, 2013 at 11am, at the Church of St. Clement, 172 Freneau Ave., Matawan, NJ 07747. A cremation service will be held privately. To share stories or photos, or to post an online tribute to Kevin, please visit www.waittfh.com

COCHRAN--G. Moffett. With great sadness, the directors, partners and employees of Silvercrest Asset Management mourn the loss of our Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder, and extend our deepest condolences to his family. Publicly, Moffett was a highly accomplished and innovative business leader with rigorous ethical standards. Those honored to work with him also knew him as a man who seamlessly combined a striking intelligence with elegance, kindness and generosity of spirit. He has left us with a truly precious legacy.

COCHRAN--G. Moffett, founder and CEO of Silvercrest Asset Management Group, died Monday, November 18. He was 63. Cochran founded Silvercrest in 2002 building it into a substantial investment management company which was taken public in June, 2013. Moffett was born in Staunton, VA, and was the son of Lee Stuart Cochran, a former member of the University of Virginia Board of Visitors and a former chairwoman of the Thomas Jefferson Memorial Foundation Board and the late George Moffett Cochran IV, a Virginia Supreme Court Justice and a state legislator. Moffett is survived by his loving wife of 39 years, DuPre Cates Cochran of New Canaan, CT and his cherished daughters Elisabeth Peyton Cochran and Lee Stuart Cochran, both of New York City, his brother H.C. Stuart Cochran and his wife Emily Cart Cochran of Staunton, VA and his devoted father and mother-in-law Macfarlane and Marguerite Cates of Spartanburg, SC. Moffett received both a B.A. and law degree from the University of Virginia. He was Chairman of the Board of Directors of UVA's Jefferson Scholars Foundation and served on the Board of Trustees of the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts, the Jamestown-Yorktown Foundation Inc. and the College of Charleston Foundation. After law school, Moffett began his career with J. P. Morgan, followed by Bessemer Trust where he was a member of the Management and Executive Committees. Subsequently he became Chairman and CEO of Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette Asset Management and then President of Credit Suisse Asset Management after Credit Suisse's acquisition of DLJ. Those that knew Moffett would all agree that he was a man of great integrity, leadership, charisma, wit, charm and above all, a man who maintained unwavering loyalty to his family, friends, and colleagues. He was an accomplished fisherman and hunter and loved traveling the world. A Funeral Service will be held on Saturday, November 23 at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan at 11am. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to St. Mark's Episcopal Church or to The Robert Fine Cancer Research Lab at the NYPH. Donations can be addressed to: Dr Robert Fine, NYPH-Columbia Univ Medical Center, 630 West 168th St., PH-8- Stem, Room 8-406, New York, NY 10032.

CAMM--Marvin A. "Fred," 85, born November 7, 1928, passed away on November 19, 2013 at 8am at JFK Hospice. He was married to Samuel A. Camm, "Tommy," for 60 years. Survived by several nieces and nephews too numerous to mention that loved and respected him and our marriage. A very successful businessman at a young age, he ran a vending business, popping popcorn for the Balaban and Katz theaters in Chicago. He ran beauty salons in New York, and an interior design business for more than 50 years. I will, and have always, loved him. Sleep well. Your adoring partner in life - Tommy (and Amanda our dog) who also loved you. There will be a cocktail party both in Florida and New York City to celebrate his life at a time to be announced.
CAMM--Fred. Our dearest friend for over 50 years. We will miss you. Irene and Hank

BUTTER--Sandra Ruiz. VIP Community Services, Inc.,its Board of Directors and staff mourn the loss of Sandra Ruiz Butter, VIP's Director from 1993 to 2010, who passed away on Monday, November 11th following a long illness. Under Sandra's leadership and guidance, VIP grew from a small organization to become a vital and indispensable part of the fabric of the South Bronx providing recovery services, housing, health care, and vocational support. Sandra Ruiz Butter was a formidable presence as a leader in the Bronx and made a significant impact on the lives of VIP clients, staff and the Bronx community. Her guidance of the organization helped to build it to what it is today, and VIP continues to thrive on the foundation she laid. VIP extends it sympathies to Sandra's husband Robert and to her daughter Alicia. Contributions in memory of Sandra Ruiz Butter can be made to VIP Community Services, Inc., C/O Jepi Rivera, 1910 Arthur Avenue, Bronx, NY 10457. Charles Burgess, Chairman of the Board of Directors Debra de Jesus Vizzi, President

Gray flannel, a fabric usually reserved for men — in a banker’s suit or a hunter’s henley — has been reimagined for the everyday woman. When combined with leather, it can transform an ordinary baseball cap into a chic topper for any outfit, a basic tablet case into a handsome clutch or a simple duffel into a prim carryall. A basic flannel skirt gets dressed up when paired with punklike jewelry in gray tones. Other gray materials can offer similar impact to flannel as well. Pony hair, as seen on these elegant Chanel loafers, is a feminine alternative that is well suited for ladies who lunch. The ombré effect on this neoprene knit sweater from Proenza Schouler offers a contemporary riff on the idea of gray flannel that looks as at home on the streets as it does surf-side.

WALSH--William D. Fordham University mourns the loss of our alumnus, colleague, and dear friend, William D. Walsh. A graduate of Fordham College, he was a valued member of the Fordham Board and its Executive Committee for many years and later served as a Trustee Emeritus. In recognition of his deep commitment and exemplary service to his alma mater, Fordham was proud to honor him with the Insignis Medal, one of the inaugural Fordham Founder's Awards, and an honorary Doctorate of Laws degree. He will be remembered by generations of Fordham students and faculty for his major contribution to and belief in the importance of the construction of the William D. Walsh Family Library at Fordham which opened in 1997 as one of the most technologically advanced academic libraries in the country. A decade later, the Fordham Museum of Greek, Etruscan and Roman Art, made possible by a generous donation of the Walsh Family's private collection of antiquities, opened in the William D. Walsh Family Library. Our thoughts and prayers are with his children, Deborah, Michael, Suzanne, Tara, and Peter; his brother Donald; and their families. Robert D. Daleo Chair of the Board of Trustees Joseph M. McShane, S.J. President

TROTTER--Mary Aileen, 89, of Cedar Crest Village in Pompton Plains, NJ, passed away on November 16, 2013. Loving wife of the late Joseph Trotter, sister to the late Robert Crochelt, Roy Crotchfeldt and Ann Nora Hepler; and favorite aunt of many Manning and Hepler nieces and nephews. Mary was an animal lover, proud pilot and member of the Ninety Nines. A funeral Mass will be held 2pm Saturday, November 23 at Cedar Crest Chapel, Pompton Plains, NJ. Visiting hours will be held prior to the Mass from 1pm to 2 pm at the chapel. Interment will take place Monday, November 25 at Immaculate Conception Cemetery, Montclair, NJ. www.scanlanfuneral.com

TOY--Marian Donnelly. Born March 31st, 1947, died suddenly November 18th, 2013. Beloved wife of Christopher Toy of New York. Daughter of the late Regina and James Donnelly, sister of Ann Donnelly, Jean Bean, Peg Donnelly, Jeff Donnelly, and Ken Donnelly. Memorial service on Friday, November 29th, 11am, at Church of the Holy Trinity 316 East 88th Street. Please make donations to American Cancer Society, ASPCA and New York Cares.

SMITH--Ophelia Marie, Cherished sister of Amelia Kaye Byer and Claude Byer, devoted aunt of Ernestine and David Byer-Tyre, LaVonne and Aaron Brown, Claudia, Constance and Janiya Byer-Tyre; loving cousin of Valerie Gresham; and beloved colleague of the board and staff of Win (Women In Need, Inc.). Born in New Bern North Carolina, Ophelia held a Ph.D. in Clinical Psychology from Columbia University as well as a BA in German and BM in Piano Performance from Oberlin College and Conservatory. After an early multidisciplinary career in recording, publishing and corporate divisions at CBS, she shifted gears to helping New York's most in need, becoming the Director of the Continuing Care Clinic at Fordham-Tremont Community Mental Health Clinic. In 1996, she came to Win as Vice President for Client Services where she led all program services overseeing administrative and organizational development activities for the more than 200 division staff employees who serve more than 10,000 women and children each year in Win's transitional family homeless shelters, supportive housing and alcohol and substance abuse clinic. She worked tirelessly to help homeless and distressed women and their families achieve independence and lead more fulfilling lives by guiding innovative holistic programming. Under her direction, Win opened seven family homeless shelters and one women's shelter in New York City. Most recently Dr. Smith led the team that conceptualized and developed Win Academy. She has helped well over 100,000 clients during her tenure at Win. A Celebration of Life will be held at The Church of the Holy Apostles, 296 Ninth Ave, New York, NY (at 28th St) on Saturday, November 23rd at 10:00am. The family asks that in lieu of flowers donations be made to Win (Women In Need) 115 West 31st St. NYC 10001 or Abhyasa Ashram Yoga and Meditation Center, 505 Hooper Drive, Ft. Walton Beach, FL 32548.

SMITH--Allan. died November 20, 2013 at age 87, after recurrence of lymphoma. Survivors include daughter, Laura Kalick; son, Andrew Smith; and sister, Ruth Abbott. Interment will be in Martinsville, IN.

REES--Dr. Thomas D. It is with great sadness that members of the faculty and staff at Manhattan Eye, Ear & Throat Hospital mourn the passing of our friend, colleague and mentor, Dr. Thomas D. Rees. Dr. Rees was Chairman of the Department of Plastic Surgery at Manhattan Eye, Ear & Throat Hospital from 1975 to 1992. Under Dr. Rees' direction the MEETH Plastic Surgery Department and the Aesthetic Surgery Fellowship, which he began, became the leading aesthetic surgery service in the world. He was one of the first to openly teach the art and science of aesthetic surgery, an area that had previously been shrouded in secrecy. His numerous textbooks, scientific publications and lectures had a profound impact on the specialty. He was respected and loved by all but especially the Residents and Fellows he generously engaged. Dr. Rees was known and respected all over the world as a great surgeon and humanitarian. His annual trips to Kenya where he started The Flying Doctors of East Africa and the African Medical Education Research Foundation were among his most cherished accomplishments. Thirty-three years ago, with Dr. Rees as the dominant force, we established the annual Cutting Edge Aesthetic Surgery Symposium in New York for the highly specialized teaching of aesthetic surgery. The 2013 meeting will take place in ten days and will be attended by plastic surgeons from all over the world. Dr. Rees, the honorary Chairman, will be honored with the first Thomas D. Rees Lecture, which was previously scheduled. We honor his legacy and the positive impact he made on so many lives. We extend our heartfelt sympathy and condolences to his daughter Liz and son Tom and other members of his family. Sherrell J. Aston, M.D. Director, Department of Plastic Surgery Manhattan Eye, Ear & Throat Hospital Director, Department of Plastic Surgery North Shore LIJ Lenox Hill Hospital Daniel C. Baker, M.D. Professor of Surgery at New York University

PAGE--Shelby H.,92, a resident of Hilton Head Island, SC, passed away at his home Friday, November 15, 2013. He was born in New York City to Frank C. and Anna H. Page. Growing up mostly in Lawrence, NY. He was a champion diver at the Lawrence Beach Club and started his lifelong love affair with golf at the Rockaway Hunting Club, where he won the Junior Boys Championship in 1939. He attended Milton Academy and then Harvard University, class of '43. At Harvard, he was manager of the football team, helping the coaches diagram plays from high atop the stadium. After Harvard, he joined the army, and on completion of basic training at Camp Hood, served at the Pentagon and then in Honolulu, and was honorably discharged as a second lieutenant. In 1949, he joined the then Hewitt Ogilvy Benson and Mather as Treasurer with 'twelve other optimistic souls in a ratty office on Madison Avenue.' As Ogilvy and Mather grew, he missed the unstructured confusion and easy camaraderie of a startup, but was proud of being a part of what he called, 'the best international advertising agency in the world.' In 1950, he met the wonderful Roberta Raworth, and they married in 1951. Their son Frank was born in 1957. During the 60's and 70's, he was a member of the board and treasurer of the Rockaway Hunting Club in Lawrence, NY and became President of the Lawrence Beach Club. Shelby retired from Ogilvy and Mather as Chief Financial Officer and Treasurer in 1983 after 34 years. At the time, a colleague wrote that he was a 'source of good fun, inspiration, and integrity for all of us' at Ogilvy and Mather. In 1987, Shelby and Robby moved to Hilton Head where Shelby continued to play golf as a member of the Bear Creek Golf Club and bridge with his buddies from Long Cove, Bear Creek, and Cyprus. He also enjoyed travel, cruising to six of the seven continents. In Hilton Head, he participated in Meals on Wheels and supported Volunteers in Medicine and the Deep Wells Project. Throughout his life, he continued to support his schools, Milton and Harvard, as well as quite a number of humanitarian and environmental charities. Shelby will be remembered for his judgment, courage, and his contempt for dishonest argument. An Ogilvy and Mather board of directors' resolution declared him 'a gentleman with brains.' His kindness, integrity, and friendship will be missed by all. He was preceded in death by his loving wife, Roberta Page and brother Allison Page. He is survived by his sister, Cecilia Bourget, son, Frank Page, daughter in law, Ingrid Page, and grandson, Walter Page. Services will be private. The Island Funeral Home and Crematory is in charge of services. theislandfuneralhome.com.

NEMIROVSKY--Shlomit, long time resident of Forest Hills, NY and more recently of Palo Alto, CA, passed away on November 17, 2013 at the age of 84. Shlomit was born in Botosani, Romania, the fifth of six children of Zeev and Pnina Frenkel. At an early age, she and her family moved to Bacau. The immediate family managed to survive WWII, as the children were smuggled, one by one, to Israel. She arrived in 1943, participated in the 1948 Israeli War of Independence while stationed in the Negev Desert, and later trained as a nurse and worked at Rambam Hospital in Haifa, specializing in pediatrics. She met Samuel Nemirovsky and they were married in 1954. In 1962, they moved to New York. Shlomit made a wonderful home for Sam and their two sons while running a travel agency. The couple moved to Palo Alto in 2012. Shlomit and Sam enjoyed travel, theater, ballet, museums, opera, playful disagreements, and spending time with their grandchildren. Among the charities which Shlomit supported were St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, North Shore Animal League America, and Paralyzed Veterans of America. For Shlomit, her family was her life. Everyone who knew her will miss her fiery spirit, candor, warmth, and mischievous sense of humor. We will cherish her memory. She is survived by her husband, Samuel, her sons, Ofer and Gady, their wives, Shelly and Diana, and her grandchildren, Genevieve, William, Eric, Daniela, and Zachary. A memorial service to celebrate Shlomit's life will be held at 2:30pm on November 30th, at the Moldaw Residences at 899 East Charleston Road in Palo Alto, CA. The service will be held in room F401 on the fourth floor of the Cultural Arts Hall. Donations in her honor may be made to Mission Hospice in San Mateo.

MITGANG--Herbert. Author, historian, newsman, playwright, and loving husband, father and grandfather, died at his Manhattan home on Thursday, November 21. He was 93. He had a distinguished 47 year career at The New York Times, including as a member of the editorial board. He received the George Polk Career Award for his journalistic accomplishments among many other honors. He wrote or edited 18 works of fiction and non-fiction and was a noted Lincoln historian. He was named a fellow of the Society of American Historians, and was a member of the Dramatists Guild and The Century Club. He was past President of both the Authors Guild and the Authors League Fund. During World War II, he was an Army correspondent and was a managing editor of The Stars and Stripes Oran-Casablanca and Sicily Mediterranean editions. He is survived by his wife of 68 years, Shirley, son Lee Mitgang, daughter-in-law Gina Mitgang, daughter Laura Mitgang, son-in-law David Goodman, and grandchildren Caroline, Celia and Noah and sisters Harriet Zweifach and Phyllis Ellstein He was also the father of Esther Mitgang who died in 2007. A funeral service will be held on Sunday, November 24 at 11am at Central Synagogue, 123 East 55th St at Lexington Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Authors League Fund, 30 East 32nd St, 7th Fl., NY, NY 10016.

JOACHIM--Laurence, on November 17, 2013. Very loving father of Marco. Stepfather Jodd, Readick and Leo Kazan. Beloved husband of the late Barbara. Services Sunday 11:30am at "The Riverside," W 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.
FREIDUS--Cora, on November 20, 2013 at 93 years young. Loving mother of Jeff (Roz), Elleri (Mike), and Marshall (Michele). Adoring grandmother and great-grandmother.

COCHRAN--G. Moffett. With great sadness, the directors, partners and employees of Silvercrest Asset Management mourn the loss of our Chairman, Chief Executive Officer and Co-founder, and extend our deepest condolences to his family. Publicly, Moffett was a highly accomplished and innovative business leader with rigorous ethical standards. Those honored to work with him also knew him as a man who seamlessly combined a striking intelligence with elegance, kindness and generosity of spirit. He has left us with a truly precious legacy.

COCHRAN--G. Moffett. The Council and the membership of The University Club mourn the passing of our dear colleague. Moffett was a member for 36 years, where he served on the Council, as Treasurer and Vice President of the Club. A devotee to the arts and literature, Moffett also cast a great shadow on the squash court. Ave atque vale!

BROUNSTEIN--Murray. Beloved husband of 61 years to Florence, father of Steven and Richard, grandfather of Genna, Sam, Maya, and Sylvie. A kind decent man who loved his family unconditionally. He was the best of men. Funeral will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel located at 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st St. on Sunday, November 24th at 12pm.

BERNHARD--Irene, 83, of New York City, died on November 16th. She was born in Brooklyn, NY and lived in Malvern and Manhattan. She is survived by her son Keith, three grandchildren Kat, Morgan and Brian and great-granddaughter Anna Rose. Irene was the long-time Executive Assistant to the Chairman of Pfizer. Visiting Sunday November 24th, 2-4 and 7-9pm at The Gannon Funeral Home, 152 E. 28th St., NY, NY. A 10:00 am Funeral Mass at Chapel of Sacred Hearts of Jesus & Mary on Monday November 25th. Private Cremation. Memorial Donations to Dana-Farber/Boston Children's Blood Disorders Center, 10 Brookline Place West, 6th Floor, Brookline, MA 02445-7226.

TROSSMAN--Michael Klaus, of Stuttgart Germany died November 10th in New York City of natural causes. He was 66. Michael was the dearly beloved widower of prominent New York literary figure Wendy E. Weil and son of Russian born soldier Nickolas Trossman and Austrian Nurse Freidle Loder. Michael lived a bohemian lifestyle as a stalwart New York City Illustrator who's works earned him residencies in distinguished publications such as Esquire, The New York Times, Rolling Stone, The New Yorker, The Village Voice, Vanity Fair, GQ and many more. He is survived by his two sons Joshua and Andrew and grandson Dane. In lieu of flowers please send donations c/o Michael Trossman to The Jewish Museum, 1109 5th Ave New York, NY 10128 ATT: Stacy Welkowitz (212)423-3269 swelkowitz@thejm.org

SILBERT--Ramie J. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS), and its Women's Division, mourn the loss of our beloved friend and leader Ramie J. Silbert of New York City. Mrs. Silbert's decades of remarkable service to our organization, and staunch support of the Technion have been great sources of inspiration. She was a longtime member of the ATS National Board of Directors; and a leading member of the Women's Division, having served in numerous roles, rising to become chairman of the board. Mrs. Silbert was a Life Trustee of the ATS Board of Regents, and an Honorary Life Member of the Technion International Board of Governors. She received a Technion Honorary Doctorate in 1996, and an Honorary Fellowship in 1988. Along with her late beloved husband, Gerald, Mrs. Silbert was a Technion Guardian, a designation reserved for those who have achieved the highest level of commitment. We extend our heartfelt condolences to her daughter, Terry Silbert, and to the entire Silbert family. Contributions in memory of Ramie Silbert may be made to the American Technion Society Women's Division, 55 East 59th Street, 14th Floor, New York, NY 10022, or at www.ats.org. American Society for Technion-Israel Institute of Technology Scott Leemaster, President Joel S. Rothman, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

SILBERT--Ramie J.,died peacefully surrounded by her loved ones. Inseparable in life, Ramie now joins her beloved Jerry for eternity. Happily married for 60 years, their childhood romance became a pattern they hoped all could follow. Pre-deceased by loving parents Bessie and Tobias Jasper and loving sister Rita P. Nelson. Ramie's life values of love, devotion and charity gave her life meaning. Technion Israeli Institute of Technology recognized Ramie's commitment by awarding an honorary Fellowship in 1998 and an honorary Doctorate in 1996. Ramie leaves behind her most cherished daughter, Terry, brother-in-law and sister-in-law Robert and Phyllis Silbert, and adored nieces, nephews and life-long friends. Shiva will be held at Robert Silbert's home: 175 Riverside Drive New York, NY, Sunday 3-6pm and Monday 2-6pm.

REES--Dr. Thomas D. AMREF USA, the board members and AMREF worldwide staff mourn the loss of our co-founder, Dr. Thomas D. Rees, remarkable visionary and renowned surgeon, who passed away at his home in Santa Fe, NM on Thursday, November 14. Dr. Rees was a Clinical Professor of Plastic Surgery at New York University School of Medicine, Chairman Emeritus of the Department of Plastic Surgery at Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital and served for many years as surgeon to the Institute of Reconstructive Plastic Surgery at New York University Medical Center. He was a past President of the American Society for Aesthetic Plastic Surgery and a former Director and vice-chairman of the American Board of Plastic Surgery. In the shadow of Mt. Kilimanjaro, Dr. Rees and two other surgeons, Dr. Archibald McIndoe and Dr. Michael Wood, had an inspired idea: to bring urgently needed clinical and surgical care to the people in East Africa's most remote and underserved regions. Their plan was to utilize small aircraft and radios to reach these inaccessible areas - and thus the Flying Doctors of East Africa was born in 1957. This initial plan expanded over the years to include health education, training, and public health programs for a wide spectrum of health challenges in remote areas of Africa, as well as urban slums. Today, that vision is AMREF, (the African Medical & Research Foundation), the largest African-led health development organization, working in more than 30 African countries. In the United States, Dr. Rees continued what would be a life-long commitment to Africa and its people. He worked tirelessly for AMREF and the continent in many ways: serving as the Chair of the Board of the US affiliate of AMREF, fundraising and by promoting AMREF's work at every opportunity. Almost every year, Dr. Rees and his wife Nan travelled back to the continent, because they cared so passionately about the African people. Dr. Rees' dedication and enthusiasm were contagious. We are terribly saddened by his passing and extend our deep condolences to his children Liz, a board member of AMREF USA, his son Thomas, Jr and his entire family.

MITGANG--Herbert, We note with sorrow the passing of our longtime member Herbert Mitgang and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein and President David B. Edelson, Central Synagogue of New York City

MITGANG--Herbert. Author, historian, newsman, playwright, and loving husband, father and grandfather, died at his Manhattan home on Thursday, November 21. He was 93. He had a distinguished 47 year career at The New York Times, including as a member of the editorial board. He received the George Polk Career Award for his journalistic accomplishments among many other honors. He wrote or edited 18 works of fiction and non-fiction and was a noted Lincoln historian. He was named a fellow of the Society of American Historians, and was a member of the Dramatists Guild and The Century Club. He was past President of both the Authors Guild and the Authors League Fund. During World War II, he was an Army correspondent and was a managing editor of The Stars and Stripes Oran-Casablanca and Sicily Mediterranean editions. He is survived by his wife of 68 years, Shirley, son Lee Mitgang, daughter-in-law Gina Mitgang, daughter Laura Mitgang, son-in-law David Goodman, and grandchildren Caroline, Celia and Noah and sisters Harriet Zweifach and Phyllis Ellstein He was also the father of Esther Mitgang who died in 2007. A funeral service will be held on Sunday, November 24 at 11am at Central Synagogue, 123 East 55th St at Lexington Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions can be made to the Authors League Fund, 30 East 32nd St, 7th Fl., NY, NY 10016.

MacLEOD--Michael, 71, died at his home in New York on Tuesday from complications from cancer. In 1987, he and Delbert Clark founded Public Interest Data, Inc., a technology firm supporting non-profit fundraising with an emphasis on exceptional client service. Michael further devoted his life to advancing humanitarian causes through his three decades of serving as trustee and advisor to organizations including Amnesty International, Oxfam, Center for Victims of Torture, The Harlem Link Charter School, the Advocacy Institute, and the Tahirih Justice Center. Michael earned the Bronze Star as a veteran of the Vietnam War, and in 1980 was honored to manage the Presidential campaign of John Anderson. A devoted husband, father and grandfather, Michael is survived by his wife, Whitney Burnett; his sister, Margaret Kennedy, and her two sons, Alex and Andy Cmil; his daughter, Kafi Blumenfield; and his two grandchildren, Nia and Obi; all of whom made Michael's world a much better place. Michael touched many lives and will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that you make contributions to Amnesty International. Funeral Services at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Ave at 12:00pm, Saturday November 23rd.

Q. and A. with Roman Polanski, producer of the documentary “Weekend of a Champion.’'

As the season ends with the Brazilian Grand Prix this weekend, a review of budgets for the current season shows that money alone can’t buy titles — but it helps.
Ukraine’s prime minister said his government’s decision to walk away from the pacts was based on fiscal imperatives, and ultimately prompted by the I.M.F.’s overly harsh terms for an aid package.
Thousands joined to honor President John F. Kennedy in a tribute leaders hoped would also help heal a city long stigmatized by his death.
The day President John F. Kennedy was shot changed our perception of certainty and safety.
In Switzerland, the land of farming and social modesty, another referendum targets excessive pay.
New requirements announced on Friday effectively leave the American contractor’s F-35A stealth jet as the only viable option.
If America truly wants the West Bank’s economy to grow, it must let us develop Zone C, free of Israeli control.
Torrential rain and a rapid alternation of chilly breezes and sweltering heat have contributed to outbreaks of pneumonia in areas hit by the typhoon.
