IGNATOW--Archie. Forever missed as the years go by. Remembered with love. Gene and 3 Generations
FITZGERALD--Geraldine, born 100 years ago today, your loving and admiring family will remember you forever.

BLUM--Stuart. November 27, 2012. Professor Emeritus, Brooklyn College; Ph.D. Columbia University; U.S.A.F. Veteran. Cherished husband of Bobbi for 49 years. The memories of his love, integrity, wisdom and humor live in the hearts of all who knew and loved him.
AMENDOLAGINE--Vita Gioia November 24, 2008 "If tears could build a stairway, And memories a lane , We could walk right up to Heaven, And bring you home again." Rest In Peace. From your loving family
WILLKIE--H. Frederick, died suddenly on November 9, 2013 in Costa Rica. Survived by wife, Ida Robichaub, siblings, Julia and Hall of NYC and niece, Julia Miranda. A most singular man.

TROSSMAN--Michael Klaus, of Stuttgart Germany died November 10th in New York City of natural causes. He was 66. Michael was the dearly beloved widower of prominent New York literary figure Wendy E. Weil and son of Russian born soldier Nickolas Trossman and Austrian Nurse Freidle Loder. Michael lived a bohemian lifestyle as a stalwart New York City Illustrator who's works earned him residencies in distinguished publications such as Esquire, The New York Times, Rolling Stone, The New Yorker, The Village Voice, Vanity Fair, GQ and many more. He is survived by his two sons Joshua and Andrew and grandson Dane. In lieu of flowers please send donations c/o Michael Trossman to The Jewish Museum, 1109 5th Ave New York, NY 10128 ATT: Stacy Welkowitz (212)423-3269 swelkowitz@thejm.org

STEINER--Robert L.,Economist, Businessman and World War II Navigator dies at 90. Robert L. Steiner, independent economist, former President of Kenner Products Company and Senior Staff Economist at the Federal Trade Commission, died on Saturday, October 26th in Washington, D.C. Raised in Cincinnati, Ohio, Steiner graduated Magna Cum Laude and Phi Beta Kappa from Dartmouth College. A member of the "Dartmouth Squadron", Steiner flew 35 missions over Germany, serving as Navigator and First Lieutenant on a B-17 bomber in the 8th Army Air Force during World War II. He was awarded the Air Medal and five clusters After receiving his MA in Economics from Columbia University in 1948, Steiner joined various family-owned manufacturing businesses in Cincinnati, the most successful of which was Kenner Products, Co., the toy manufacturer of which he became president. Steiner was an early pioneer in television advertising for children's toys in the 1950's, starting with Girdle and Panel Building Sets and later the Easy Bake Oven. Steiner's business experience was the impetus for developing a "dual stage" theory of economics, in which manufacturers and retailers competed both horizontally and vertically and the margins at the two stages were often inversely related. After a lecture at Harvard Business School, Steiner was appointed Senior Staff Economist at the Federal Trade Commission in Washington, D.C. in 1978. Steiner authored over 40 articles in scholarly journals in antitrust, economics, marketing and advertising. His books include Visions of Cable Vision, 1972. Steiner's last article, Management, Market and Antitrust will be published in the Antitrust Journal later this year. Steiner spoke at numerous economic symposia, most recently in the summer of 2012 at Oxford University in England, at age 89. Steiner's served on several boards, including: the American Antitrust institute, the Charter Committee of Great Cincinnati, The Robert Krohn Livingston Memorial Camp, WCET, and the American Council for Judaism. Mr. Steiner was an avid fly fisherman, tennis and squash player, enjoying all three sports throughout his life and into his 90th year. Mr. Steiner is survived by his wife of 53 years, Christine Steiner; four children, Therese Steiner, Carl Steiner, Lorraine Steiner Hendriksen and Robert C. Steiner; four grandchildren, Christopher Hendriksen, Jeremy Klar, Zoe Klar and Andrew Hendriksen; two sisters Marjorie Wolf and Judy Kuehne.

SPELFOGEL--Beverly Kolenberg, of Manhattan passed away peacefully at Memorial Sloan Kettering Hospital early Friday morning November 22, 2013 at the age of 78. Daughter of deceased Sarah and Isidore Kolenberg, sister of deceased brother Arthur Kolenberg, husband to Evan J. Spelfogel for nearly 55 years, mother of Scott and Douglas Spelfogel and Karen Spelfogel Raichoudhury, grandmother/nana to Sara and Danny, Michael and Alex, Sabrina and Ryan. Beverly also leaves behind her daughters-in-law and son-in-law Mamie, Wendy and Raj, her sister-in-law Patty Kolenberg Bellovin, her cousins Estelle Faier, Joan Faier Tannen, and John Faier, her niece and nephew Katherine Kolenberg Miracle and Wayne Miracle and their triplet daughters Danielle, Lauren and Sydney Miracle, and myriad's of other relatives and dear friends. Beverly devoted her life to education, the environment and the betterment of humankind. Born and raised on the lower East Side of New York City and in Brooklyn, Beverly attended Hunter High School and Brooklyn College, earned a Masters' degree in 17th century English literature from Columbia University (where she met and married Evan), and an additional Masters' degree from Queens College in reading. After several years teaching in Washington, D.C. and at Erasmus High School in Brooklyn, Beverly taught reading at Weber Junior High School in Port Washington, Long Island for ten years before deciding that she had more to offer to society. While teaching full time, she earned a law degree from St. John's University School of Law and thereafter served for 28 years with the United States Environmental Protection Agency where she was Assistant Regional Counsel at the time of her passing. During her service with the EPA she also served as Special Assistant U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York, interfaced with the U.S. Department of Justice, tried cases in the lower federal courts and argued several cases before the Second Circuit United States Court of Appeals. She specialized in Superfund site clean-up litigation and was a leader of the team that was instrumental in recently bringing to a close the ten year massive litigation following the 9/11 attack on the World Trade Center. Funeral/Remembrance Services will be held Monday, November 25th, 12:30pm at the Sutton Place Synagogue, 225 East 51st Street between 1st and 2nd Avenues, Manhattan. Burial following on Monday, 3:00pm/3:30pm at Locust Valley Cemetery on Long Island off Ryefield Road, Locust Valley, NY. Shiva to begin Monday after burial, until 9:00pm at daughter Karen Raichoudhury's home, 6 Wildwood Court, Locust Valley, NY 11560. Additional Shiva gathering on Tuesday, November 26th, 2:00pm to 9:00pm and Wednesday, November 27th, 2:00pm-7:00pm at son Doug Spelfogel's home at 53 Roxen Road, Rockville Center, NY 11570. In lieu of flowers, the family asks that contributions be made to the Spelfogel Family Scholarship Fund at the Boston Latin School in Boston, Massachusetts, 78 Avenue Louis Pasteur Avenue, Boston, MA 02115.

SMITH--Allan. died November 20, 2013 at age 87, after recurrence of lymphoma. Survivors include daughter, Laura Kalick; son, Andrew Smith; and sister, Ruth Abbott. Interment will be in Martinsville, IN.

SILBERT--Ramie J.,died peacefully surrounded by her loved ones. Inseparable in life, Ramie now joins her beloved Jerry for eternity. Happily married for 60 years, their childhood romance became a pattern they hoped all could follow. Pre-deceased by loving parents Bessie and Tobias Jasper and loving sister Rita P. Nelson. Ramie's life values of love, devotion and charity gave her life meaning. Technion Israeli Institute of Technology recognized Ramie's commitment by awarding an honorary Fellowship in 1998 and an honorary Doctorate in 1996. Ramie leaves behind her most cherished daughter, Terry, brother-in-law and sister-in-law Robert and Phyllis Silbert, and adored nieces, nephews and life-long friends. Shiva will be held at Robert Silbert's home: 175 Riverside Drive New York, NY, Sunday 3-6pm and Monday 2-6pm.

SIMON--Rosaline Stark, age 94, died peacefully in Aptos, CA (formerly of Middletown, NY), with her devoted son, Stuart Simon, and her family at her side. She leaves behind her son Bruce Simon of Jackson Hole, WY, her sister Harriet Lewis, grandson and granddaughter, nieces and nephews and the joy of her life, great-grandson, Shawn. A world traveler who crossed the Atlantic on the great ships 50 times, she studied French, Italian and Spanish throughout her life and was a voracious reader. She loved and cultivated large and small gardens wherever she lived. She will be missed.

SHERMAN--Harry, MD, 103, of New York City, passed away November 22, 2013. Husband of the late Ida Sherman. Predeceased by one daughter Alice Quine. Survived by two daughters Ellen Luger and Laura Sherman, two granddaughters, three great-grandchildren, brother as well as many nieces and nephews. Funeral services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel on Tuesday, November 26, 2013, at 11:30am.

SIEGEL--Jeanne Yvette, died peacefully at home on November 16, 2013. Survived by daughters Carol Siegel and Elizabeth Carpenter (David), and grandson Adam Gould. Our mother was a writer, essayist, art critic and educator. Associated with WBAI in the late 1960s, the New School, and for many happy years the School of Visual Arts, where she was Chair Emeritus of the Fine Arts Department.

ROWAN--Helen Rounds. Beloved wife of Roy Rowan for 61 years, and the loving mother of Dana Rowan of Boston, Douglas Rowan of Oxnard, CA, Nicholas Rowan of New York City, and Marcus Rowan of Dallas. She is also survived by daughter-in-law Janice Kelley-Rowan and grandson William Roy Rowan of Boston. Helen died peacefully in her home in Greenwich, CT on November 19. The couple met at Life Magazine where she was a picture editor and he was a foreign correspondent. An avid gardener and expert in the Art of the Painted Finish, she and her husband traveled widely and had friends throughout the world. She will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be announced at a later date. Recently her youngest son Marcus created the Helen Rowan Endowed Scholarship for the Arts at his alma mater Hartwick College in Oneonta, NY 13820. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to the scholarship fund.

ROSS--Herbert S.,died peacefully on Wednesday, November 20th. He was 94 years old, and for the past seven years had been living close to his son's family in Evanston, IL. Born in Montreal, Canada, on March 27, 1919, to Rachel Osmiansky and Jacob Rosenstein, he moved to New York City in 1943. He became a citizen and enlisted in the Army in WWII, where he was stationed in North Africa and South Asia. Herb was married to Phyllis Freedman from 1948 until her death in 1970, and they had three children. For almost fifty years, he worked for an automotive export firm, W.D. Blood and Company, becoming a vice president. He spoke French and Spanish and traveled frequently to Central and South America. A lifelong Mason, bridge player, and punster, he enjoyed attending plays and concerts in New York with his companion, Ruth Finley Lein. Herb was preceded in death by his wife, Phyllis, his siblings Hilda, Harold and Bunny, and his beloved childhood group of friends, the Flying Squad Athletic Club. He is survived by his children, Harry Ross of Evanston, IL, Josephine Ross of Washington, D.C., and Mary Ross of Oakland, CA; their life partners, Heather, Chris, and Marilyn; his grandchildren, Samuel, Madeleine, and Claire; and five nieces and nephews. There will be a private family service. Services by Chicago Jewish Funerals Skokie Chapel, 847-229-8822, www.cjfinfo.com

ROBBINS--Norbert. Bert was easy to love gentle, thoughtful, and innately good. He also had enormous inner strength and was deeply committed to what he cared about family, Judaism, art, music, and learning. For 92 years, he lived a rich, varied life: Director of Market Research at Seagram's; marketing professor at NYU, Pace, and St. Peter's College; docent at the Whitney Museum; self-taught collector of modern prints; founding member of Congregation Ohav Shalom in Merrick, NY; and devotee of opera and classical music. He was a great dancer, tireless walker, jazzy dresser, and true gentleman. A beautiful soul and wonderful role model, he leaves behind a legacy of love.

REES--Dr. Thomas D. AMREF USA, the board members and AMREF worldwide staff mourn the loss of our co-founder, Dr. Thomas D. Rees, remarkable visionary and renowned surgeon, who passed away at his home in Santa Fe, NM on Thursday, November 14. Dr. Rees was a Clinical Professor of Plastic Surgery at New York University School of Medicine, Chairman Emeritus of the Department of Plastic Surgery at Manhattan Eye, Ear and Throat Hospital and served for many years as surgeon to the Institute of Reconstructive Plastic Surgery at New York University Medical Center. He was a past President of the American Society for Aesthetic Plastic Surgery and a former Director and vice-chairman of the American Board of Plastic Surgery. In the shadow of Mt. Kilimanjaro, Dr. Rees and two other surgeons, Dr. Archibald McIndoe and Dr. Michael Wood, had an inspired idea: to bring urgently needed clinical and surgical care to the people in East Africa's most remote and underserved regions. Their plan was to utilize small aircraft and radios to reach these inaccessible areas - and thus the Flying Doctors of East Africa was born in 1957. This initial plan expanded over the years to include health education, training, and public health programs for a wide spectrum of health challenges in remote areas of Africa, as well as urban slums. Today, that vision is AMREF, (the African Medical & Research Foundation), the largest African-led health development organization, working in more than 30 African countries. In the United States, Dr. Rees continued what would be a life-long commitment to Africa and its people. He worked tirelessly for AMREF and the continent in many ways: serving as the Chair of the Board of the US affiliate of AMREF, fundraising and by promoting AMREF's work at every opportunity. Almost every year, Dr. Rees and his wife Nan travelled back to the continent, because they cared so passionately about the African people. Dr. Rees' dedication and enthusiasm were contagious. We are terribly saddened by his passing and extend our deep condolences to his children Liz, a board member of AMREF USA, his son Thomas, Jr and his entire family.

RAEDER--Myrna Sharon, 66, revered professor at Southwestern Law School, passionate advocate for women in both the criminal justice system and the legal profession, and beloved wife, mother, and friend, died November 16 at her home in Los Angeles after a courageous two-year battle with breast cancer. In addition to her work, Myrna was passionate about travel, sharing many memorable trips with her husband of 38 years, Terry Kelly. She is survived by Terry and their two sons, Tom and Mike, who will remember their mom for her warmth, sound advice, strength of character, and good humor. A memorial service will be held in Los Angeles in January. The family requests donations be made in her memory to the Myrna Raeder Scholarship Endowment Fund. Please contact Debra Leathers, dleathers@swlaw.edu, for information regarding the fund. Condolences and memories of Myrna may be sent to tokelly007@gmail.com.

PIRILLO--Jack Joseph, of Deer Park, NY at the age of 88 on November 8, 2013. Beloved husband of the late Angelina. Winter time resident of North Port, Florida. Born Jack Joseph Pirillo on May 29, 1925 in New York, New York, the son of the late Salvatore and Antoinette Pirillo. Loving father of Antoinette (Doug), Salvatore, Vincent, and Jacqueline. Cherished grandfather of Douglas, Alyssa, Nicholas and Neil Brennan.

NORSTRAND--Iris F.,November 21, 1915 to November 18, 2013. Distinguished neurologist, psychiatrist and PhD in biochemistry. Frequent contributor to medical and scholarly publications and a member of Who's Who of American Women. Born Iris Marie Fletcher to Violet Marie Anderson and Mathew Emerson Fletcher and the sister of the distinguished mystery writer Lucille Fletcher. Graduated from Brooklyn College (class of 1937) and Long Island College of Medicine (1941). She was one of only three female students in her graduating class of 1941. Devoted wife of the late Dr. Severin A. Norstrand and loving mother of Virginia Helene Villano (deceased), Dr. Lucille Norstrand Murphy and Thomas F. Norstrand.

NEMIROVSKY--Shlomit, long time resident of Forest Hills, NY and more recently of Palo Alto, CA, passed away on November 17, 2013 at the age of 84. Shlomit was born in Botosani, Romania, the fifth of six children of Zeev and Pnina Frenkel. At an early age, she and her family moved to Bacau. The immediate family managed to survive WWII, as the children were smuggled, one by one, to Israel. She arrived in 1943, participated in the 1948 Israeli War of Independence while stationed in the Negev Desert, and later trained as a nurse and worked at Rambam Hospital in Haifa, specializing in pediatrics. She met Samuel Nemirovsky and they were married in 1954. In 1962, they moved to New York. Shlomit made a wonderful home for Sam and their two sons while running a travel agency. The couple moved to Palo Alto in 2012. Shlomit and Sam enjoyed travel, theater, ballet, museums, opera, playful disagreements, and spending time with their grandchildren. Among the charities which Shlomit supported were St. Jude Children's Research Hospital, North Shore Animal League America, and Paralyzed Veterans of America. For Shlomit, her family was her life. Everyone who knew her will miss her fiery spirit, candor, warmth, and mischievous sense of humor. We will cherish her memory. She is survived by her husband, Samuel, her sons, Ofer and Gady, their wives, Shelly and Diana, and her grandchildren, Genevieve, William, Eric, Daniela, and Zachary. A memorial service to celebrate Shlomit's life will be held at 2:30pm on November 30th, at the Moldaw Residences at 899 East Charleston Road in Palo Alto, CA. The service will be held in room F401 on the fourth floor of the Cultural Arts Hall. Donations in her honor may be made to Mission Hospice in San Mateo.

McCONNELL--Rev. John, S.J.,on November 22, 2013. Loving brother of Vincent, Patrick and the late James and Bernard McConnell. Reposing at the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel, 515 East Fordham Rd., Bronx, NY on Monday, 3-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass in the Murray-Weigel Hall Chapel on Tuesday, 11:30am. Interment at the Jesuit Cemetery, Auriesville, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the NY Province, Society of Jesus, 39 East 83rd St., NY, NY 10028. For information contact Farenga Bros. Inc., Directors (718) 654-0500.

MASON--Claire Rosen, 92, of Manhattan and Atlantic Beach, died peacefully November 22, 2013. She was born February 20, 1921 on Delancey Street to Jacob and Nettie Rosen who operated a thriving millinery shop. Claire was married for 67 years to Eli Mason (deceased 2009), her college sweetheart. After a successful professional career, Claire dedicated much of her time to service and family. She was an active member of the National Council for Jewish Women, New York Section and was the recipient of the Hannah G. Solomon Award for her record of outstanding and meaningful service. Together with her husband, she established the Claire and Eli Mason Fund to Feed the Hungry which provides food twice weekly at the Council's Senior Center. In 2008 Claire inaugurated the Claire Mason Women of Distinction Lecture Series as her tribute to the female students at Baruch College, her alma mater, and to the strong women who are their role models. Claire and Eli, class of 1940, were active participants in many philanthropic and governing committees regarding Baruch College. Claire is survived by two daughters: Judith Ann (Gerald Berger) of Delmar, NY and Nina Mason (Max Hirshfeld) of Washington, DC, four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A private service was held by the immediate family. Donations in her memory can be made to the National Council of Jewish Women Hunger Program, New York Section, 241 W. 72nd St. New York, NY 10023. A beautiful sky, A lovely rose, A good wife, A happy song, A lasting poem, A full life.

MANUS--Janet Wilkens, Died peacefully in her sleep of natural causes on Thursday, November 21, 2013. Beloved wife of husband Justin A. Manus; beloved mother of three daughters, Mara Anne Manus and Elizabeth Manus of New York City, and Jillian Manus, of Atherton, California; and beloved grandmother of Nicklaus and Brock. Janet was born in Hartford, Connecticut, and after high school graduation there, she graduated with a degree in geology from the University of Arizona School of Mines. She then went on to take a Masters degree in Education at Columbia Teachers College while her future husband, Justin, attended Columbia Law School. They married in 1955. She worked at the Museum of Natural History in the gemology department and later established her own literary agency, which specialized in representing authors of "true crime" books. Following her retirement, one of her clients wrote her a note reading, "To Janet, a woman who shines so bright, she casts shadows..." An avid reader, she loved words and stories, and was a champion sender of text messages. She also enjoyed theater and travelling with her family in Europe and throughout the US. She will be missed for her wit, wisdom, and joie de vivre. A private funeral service will be held this week at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel; to be followed by a December memorial service to be announced.

MANISCHEWITZ--Esther H. (nee Ostrovsky), died in Teaneck, NJ, on November 15, 2013. The burial took place in Jerusalem. Beloved wife of William B. Manischewitz z"l. Cherished mother of Leora (Bob), Ofra (Steve), Sharon (Jeff), and much loved grandmother and great-grandmother. Born in Jerusalem. Came to America and pioneered the Orthodox Jewish community in Teaneck, NJ with the founding of Congregation Bnai Yeshurun. She will be greatly missed by her entire community, friends and family. May her memory be a blessing.

MacLEOD--Michael, 71, died at his home in New York on Tuesday from complications from cancer. In 1987, he and Delbert Clark founded Public Interest Data, Inc., a technology firm supporting non-profit fundraising with an emphasis on exceptional client service. Michael further devoted his life to advancing humanitarian causes through his three decades of serving as trustee and advisor to organizations including Amnesty International, Oxfam, Center for Victims of Torture, The Harlem Link Charter School, the Advocacy Institute, and the Tahirih Justice Center. Michael earned the Bronze Star as a veteran of the Vietnam War, and in 1980 was honored to manage the Presidential campaign of John Anderson. A devoted husband, father and grandfather, Michael is survived by his wife, Whitney Burnett; his sister, Margaret Kennedy, and her two sons, Alex and Andy Cmil; his daughter, Kafi Blumenfield; and his two grandchildren, Nia and Obi; all of whom made Michael's world a much better place. Michael touched many lives and will be greatly missed. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that you make contributions to Amnesty International. Funeral Services at St. Ignatius Loyola Church, 980 Park Ave at 12:00pm, Saturday November 23rd.

LOWE--Morton. It is with extreme sadness we mourn the death of our uncle, Morty Lowe, adored and adoring husband of Elizabeth, father of Jan, Jeffrey and Pamela Edith, and brother of Marcelle Lowell. We extend our deepest, heartfelt condolences to them and to his grandchildren. His warm, distinct personality and joy in life will be sorely missed. His likes will not be found again. Richard H. M. and Gail Lowe Maidman

KORNBLUH--Louis, passed away peacefully at 95. Adoring husband of his late wife Charlotte, loving father of Martin and Bonnie, devoted grandfather of Alison, Barry, Lauren, Russell, Julie, Paul, David, Anneliese, and 11 great-grandchildren. Lou was a founder of Engineers Country Club. Poppy will always be remembered for his love of golf, passion for politics and his sense of humor. We will love and miss him forever.

HENNINGSEN--Mark Dillon, 52, of White Plains, New York, suddenly of a ruptured aorta on November 20th. Much beloved son and brother. Mark was a huge-hearted, loving man. Born to Joan Regan and John T. Henningsen on December 9, 1960. An executive in the financial services, insurance and real estate industries for over 25 years. His family was the world to him and there was never any better son or brother. Interment private. Memorial service to be announced. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Carver Center, 400 Westchester Avenue, Port Chester, NY 10573 would be appreciated.

GLASSER--Helen. An irreplaceable grandmother to Lisa Basile, Perrie Samotin Rubinstein and Jenna Glasser Samotin. A loving great- grandmother to Ava and Anna Basile. We always looked forward to our weekly visits with you and loved how you always made each of us feel so special. Your generosity was beyond compare. Our memories are abundant and we will always cherish having such a strong woman in our lives. As heavy as our hearts are Grandma, we feel so lucky to have had you in our lives for so long. You are such a big part of who we are today and for that we will be forever grateful to you. We will love you, miss you and honor you every day.

GLASSER--Helen. 1919-2013. Loving wife to our late father and grandfather, Arthur. The most special mother, loving and caring to Karen Glasser and Jill Glasser Samotin. A true grandmother to Lisa Basile, Jenna Glasser Samotin, Perrie Samotin Rubinstein, and Adam Rubinstein. Great-grandmother to Ava and Anna Basile. Sister of Marilyn Wolosky Koltun. Loving aunt to many nieces and nephews. She was surrounded by all of us on her last few days. An incredibly strong, beautiful woman to the end. Our loss is immeasurable, our hearts are heavy. A touching funeral service and internment was attended by many friends and family from near and far. Rabbi Dennis Math joined all of us in eulogizing a very special class act. Forever in our hearts. We will love you and miss you always Mom. Karen and Jill

GITTERMAN--Juliet Forbes Fischl, passed away peacefully at her home on November 13th, two weeks before her 95th birthday. She is survived by her son, Eric Hess, daughter-in-law June Hess, daughter Safiya Bonaventura, grand-daughter Arden Rowland and family, grandsons Aram and Joachim Williams and families, granddaughters Fleur and Claire Williams, stepson Joseph Gitterman and family and numerous beloved extended family and friends. Early in life Juliet was an accomplished actress on Broadway and radio. She was also a prize-winning gardener, and sensitive watercolor artist. Those touched by her magic adored her and were inspired by her love of beauty, irrepressible humor, exuberant spirit and passionate aliveness. There is no service at this time but grow flowers, have champagne, live fully and love each other in her name. That is her lasting legacy. Donations in Juliet's honor may be sent to the Komansky Center for Children's Health or Mt. Sinai Pediatric Care in New York City.

GIBBINS--Robert L. (Bob), Bob Gibbins was a pre-eminent trial attorney with an international reputation as a master in the courtroom. Bob Gibbins was also a man of intense kindness and goodwill. He was born on February 27, 1936 in Seminole, Oklahoma and died peacefully and gracefully at his home in Vermont on November 19, 2013 at the age of 77. He attended high school in Oklahoma until he left to serve in the Army. After finishing his tour in Korea, he entered the University of Texas, earned his undergraduate degree and then attended the University of Texas School of Law--all of this accomplished in a mere four years. After obtaining his law degree, Bob relocated to Plainview, Texas where he began his stellar career. His courtroom skill was quickly recognized. Bob was one of those rare courtroom talents who mesmerized juries with his good looks, deep voice, wry humor, lightning-quick intelligence and his ability to communicate with them, not talk at them. Moving his first wife and four children to practice in Austin in the early 1970'+s was a difficult decision, but a fortuitous one. Here he was able to become a truly extraordinary trial lawyer. Years after moving to Austin, Bob met the love of his life, a successful attorney named Pam Reed. Theirs was a pairing of two powerful, ambitious, larger than life personalities. During his decades long career he served as President of the American Trial Lawyers Association, Director Emeritus of the Texas Trial Lawyers Association, and President of the Travis County Trial Lawyers Association. He was a Fellow of the International Society of Barristers, the International Academy of Trial Lawyers, and the Texas Bar Foundation. He founded the Travis County chapter of American Board of Trial Advocates. His many honors included The Annual War Horse Award from the Southern Trial Lawyers Association, and the Lifetime Achievement Award and the Champion of Justice Award from the Association of Trial Lawyers of America. Bob's life changed forever, beginning in 1996. He began an incredibly difficult yet amazingly graceful 17-year battle with temporal frontal lobe dementia. Gradually, the tough attorney facade gave way to the gentle man. He spent those years as the sweetest possible person, loving completely his partner and patient care-giver, Pam Reed. Theirs has been a love story both tragic and grand. In addition to Pam, Bob is survived by the other true loves of his life, his four children and their spouses, eleven grandchildren, four great-grandchildren, his sister, his mother- and father-in-law, his sister-in-law, her husband and her children, and his brother-in-law.

GARDNER--Hilde, (September 15, 1911-November 14, 2013), remarkable wife (Ralph), mother (Howard, Marion), grandmother (Andrew, Benjamin, Daniel, Jay, Kerith), great-grandmother (Aggie, Oscar), beloved by scores of relatives and friends all over the world. In face of life-altering disruptions by the rise of Nazi Germany and the death of her first son Eric, she fashioned a new life for herself and her family in the United States, volunteered and accepted leadership roles in many organizations, was a realist who chose to see the positive options and inspired countless others to do the same. Burial private. Donations can be made in Hilde Gardner's name to the Boston Symphony Orchestra and the Harvard Graduate School of Education. Online guestbook at www.brezniakrodman.com

FUTTERMAN--Stella (Esther) Of Sun City West, AZ. Formerly of Bronx, NY. Died November 13. Beloved wife of the late Bobby. Dearest Mom of Robin and Mitchell Kaphan and Alan and Lisa Futterman. Adored Grandma of Mark, Adam, and Alison Kaphan. Donations to Leukemia/Lymphoma Society (Team Mitch) or Beth El Synagogue, New Rochelle appreciated.

FONTAINE--William "Alan", a New York City musician, passed away on October 26th. He was 71. A memorial will be held at St. Peter's Church on Monday, November 25, 2013 from 6:00pm to 9:00pm. Alan played guitar in the original Broadway production of "Hair." He leaves behind his loving wife, Maxine Powell Fontaine, his children William, Paul, and Llise; his stepchildren Jesse and Lisa; and his grandchildren: Isabella, Michael, Joshua and Xan.

FIELDSTEEL--Joyce Wilner, age 89, adored wife for 68 years of Bob, beloved mother of John (Maggie) and Rob (Jan), grandmother of Sarah (Norman), Elizabeth, Kate and great-grandmother of Dahlia. She died on November 23 in Hanover, New Hampshire at her home at Kendal. She had been a longtime resident of Sands Point, Port Washington, New York. A service celebrating her life will take place at Kendal in Hanover on December 7.

FAY--Joseph E.,on November 21, 2013. Member of the Order Sons of Italy in America. Past Grand Venerable, New York State. Licensed Funeral Director. Beloved husband of the late Evelyn. Father of Allen, Bruce, Louise and the late Ronnie. Also survived by his grandchildren. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Ave. on Sunday, November 24, 2013 from 2pm to 5pm and 7pm to 9pm. Funeral Mass, Monday, November 25, 2013 at 11am Sacred Heart Church, Yonkers, NY. See Frank E. Campbell website for details on donations.

EIGENFELD--Stanley, In the hush of night on November 11, Stan Eigenfeld, 83, slipped away as gracefully as he had lived. Loved by his step-son Glenn (Jean), granddaughter Debbie (Dennis), great-grandsons Sean and Riley, and his "one and only love" of 60 years, Annie Fisher Eigenfeld.

DIAMANTE--Joseph, age 91, passed away peacefully on November 17, 2013. Violinist and beloved husband of Irene Diamante and stepfather to Susan Levine Ourada. Brother of the late Cesare Diamante, good friend to his fellow musicians. He will be missed greatly. Rest in peace, Joe.

CHRISTIANSON--Paul, of New York City and Haddam Neck, CT, died October 26. With his wife, Paul started a youth and student travel business in 1968, which became InterExchange in 1988. The Christiansons began with the mission of facilitating international understanding, friendship and cooperation between U.S. citizens and young people from countries around the world. Earlier, Paul served in the U.S. Navy and worked with defense contractors in Europe and Asia. He also worked as Administrative Director at Columbia University and held various jobs with government agencies and NGOs. Paul earned degrees from Fairleigh Dickinson and Columbia. He is survived by his wife, Uta, brother, Howard Christianson, and sisters Janet Johnson and Carol Harris. Donations can be made to the National Parkinson Foundation.

CAMM--Marvin A. "Fred," 85, born November 7, 1928, passed away on November 19, 2013 at 8pm at JFK Hospice. He was married to Samuel A. Camm, "Tommy," for 60 years. Survived by several nieces and nephews too numerous to mention that loved and respected him and our marriage. A very successful businessman at a young age, he ran a vending business, popping popcorn for the Balaban and Katz theaters in Chicago. He ran beauty salons in New York, and an interior design business for more than 50 years. I will, and have always, loved him. Sleep well. Your adoring partner in life - Tommy (and Amanda our dog) who also loved you. There will be a cocktail party both in Florida and New York City to celebrate his life at a time to be announced.

BUTNER--Eleanor, born August 24, 1934 in The Bronx, NY. Died November 22, 2013 after a lengthy illness. Loving wife, for 57 years, to the late Lawrence Butner. Devoted mother of David Butner, Robin (Butner) Weidy and Gary Weidy. Loving grandmother of Brian Weidy, Dora Butner and Sara Butner. Cherished sister of Sydney Schwartz, Jeffrey and Miriam Zuckerman and Barbara and Philip Pakula. Graduate of the Bronx High School of Science, she then received a bachelor's degree from Baruch College, an MA in Education from Manhattanville College and an ME from Teachers College, Columbia University. Teacher and Assistant Principal at the Mamaroneck Avenue School in Mamaroneck, New York. Principal at the Robert W. Carbonaro Elementary School in Valley Stream, New York. She then joined her husband as co-owner and Executive Vice President of Lawrence Butner Advertising, Inc. in New York City, a direct marketing company. Funeral service will be held at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY on Sunday, November 24th at 9:30am. In lieu of flowers, donations to "Manhattan Hematology Oncology Research Foundation" at 157 East 32nd Street, New York, NY 10016, would be appreciated.

BUTLER--Michael J.,A real estate financier and investor, who turned around real estate loans and distressed housing and commercial property portfolios for the State of New York under Governor Hugh Carey between 1978-1982 and throughout his career in private sector banks, including Chase Manhattan in New York and Credit Lyonnais in Chicago, died on November 14, 2013 in Chicago, IL. The cause was cancer, said his wife real estate developer and financier Karen Butler. In addition to his wife, Karen S Butler, Mr. Butler is survived by a son, Michael Butler of Redlands, CA, two brothers William Butler, Esq. (Hyannis Port, MA) and Dr. Christopher Butler (Pittsburgh, PA), seven nieces and nephews and their four children. He is also survived by his mother-in-law Grace B. Martin of Palm Beach, FL. He was predeceased by his father and mother, William F. Butler and Dawn Ludington Butler (Hyannis Port, MA), stepmother Edith Surprenant Butler (Osterville, MA) and a brother, Patrick M. Butler (Centreville, MA). Memorial Services will be celebrated at St. Bartholomew's Church, New York, NY on December 12, 2013 at 5pm and Women's Athletic Club, 626 N. Michigan Ave, Chicago, IL on December 3, 2013 at 5pm. Burial will be at St. Francis Xavier Cemetery, Centreville, MA. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Northwestern Medical Faculty Foundation (NMFF), 675 N. St Clair, Chicago, IL in honor of Michael Butler and Dr. Steven Newman, Hematology-Oncology. Services by Drake and Son Funeral Home, Chicago, IL for info call 773-561-6874.

BOSAND--Alfred E.,was born in Woodhaven, NY on October 5, 1924 and passed away on November 15, 2013 in Delray Beach, FL after an extended illness. He attended Pratt Institute on a scholarship before enlisting in the U.S. Navy during WWII where he received a Purple Heart for injuries received during battle in the South Pacific. Post war, he completed his studies at the Fashion Academy, NYC. Alfred designed for several fashion designers before opening his own showroom and workplace at 37 W. 57th. St., NYC. After more than 40 years in the couture fashion business, he closed his 57th Street salon in 1986 to retire, dividing his time between his homes in NYC and Southampton, NY. He was one of the city's last privately owned couture designers with his own label. Alfred's timeless custom made gowns were sold in stores such as Saks Fifth Avenue and Neiman Marcus as well as many smaller upscale women's store around the country including Martha's and Sara Fredrick's of Palm Beach and NYC. Alfred's clientele ranged from First Lady Patricia Nixon and Anne Landers to many NYC and Palm Beach socialites and numerous show biz personalities. He also did the wardrobes for 10 consecutive Miss America's thru the 1960's. Alfred was a true gentleman and a generous man who had a wonderful life and lived it to its fullest. He is survived by Jerry Yarnall, his life partner of 30 years and by his nephews Robert and John Powell and their families of Seaford, NY and niece Sandy Bosand Smith and her family of Chesterfield, VA. Donations: Volen Center, Delray Beach, FL 33445 or HSUS.

BETTERIDGE--William Woodruff, 89, of Chatham NJ, passed away November 20, 2013. He was pre-deceased by his wife of 55 years Jane, and is survived by his children James Betteridge, David Betteridge, Ann Wheeler, their spouses, nine grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A memorial service will be held November 30th at noon at Christ Church in Short Hills, NJ.

BERKOWITZ-STEINBERGER--Sandy, 81, of Long Island and Florida, passed away on November 21, 2013 after a courageous struggle with cancer. She is survived by her children Jill Glasser, David Forrest, and Glen Berkowitz, son-in-law Jay Glasser, and grandsons Max, Zachary, and Richard Glasser. Services will be held on November 24th at 11am at Temple Beth-El, Great Neck, NY.

ARDREY--Rushton Leigh, Jr. February 7, 1937 October 28, 2013. Leigh is remembered as an innovative financier, gifted athlete, intensely loyal friend, and devoted father. A graduate of The Hotchkiss School, Yale University, and Harvard Business School, Leigh spent his professional career at J.P. Morgan, retiring as a senior executive. He is the beloved husband of Eugenia, much loved father of Leigh (Catherine) and Stephanie (David), and doting grandfather who delighted in William, Katie, Jack and Schuyler. Leigh is also survived by his siblings Alice Guion Wirth, James S. Ardrey (Joan) and Elizabeth A. Wilson. A Memorial Service will be held on December 7, 2013 at Trinity Episcopal Church, Southport, CT at 11.00am.

WATERSTON--Nat, 95. Wordsmith; ballroom dancer; bridge and chess player; and all-around funny, thoughtful, and loving man. Nat was a former business administrator for Wells Rich Green and Doyle Dane Bernbach. He will be greatly missed.

WALKER--Doug, 1948-2013. Philadelphia banker and philanthropic activist Doug Walker of Newtown Square, Pennsylvania died at home on November 22 after a three-year illness. He was 65. Doug grew up in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, and attended Deerfield Academy and Princeton University. He began his banking career at Morgan Stanley, earned his MBA at Harvard, and in 1978 joined Brown Brothers Harriman. Doug was 29 when he took over Brown Brothers' then struggling Philadelphia office. He stayed for 32 years, becoming a partner and transforming the office into a significant factor in the company's success. He was an innovative manager, encouraging his team to collaborate across different lines of business--an approach that influenced firm-wide practices. Doug was especially happy about his role as mentor to generations of young bankers. His many friends and colleagues at Brown Brothers remember him as thoughtful, compassionate and fiercely loyal to both the people he managed and the interests of the firm's clients. Doug played a leading role in Philadelphia's philanthropic community for three decades. He served on the boards of more than 20 different non-profit organizations, primarily in the fields of land preservation and natural history research. Doug loved Africa. His support of girl's education in Kenya involved many trips to that country, and led to his induction as an Elder of the nomadic Samburu tribe. His care for the planet and its inhabitants also included his seven dogs. They loved and trusted him in return. Doug planned to devote his retirement to his African work, but his illness intervened. He retired in 2011 to spend his remaining time with his wife, Jane Walker, and his three children, Olivia, Colin and Madeline.

STEINER--Marilyn, age 87, of Westport, CT on Friday, November 22, 2013. Beloved wife of Monroe who passed away in 2009; devoted mother of Amy and Richard Schafrann, and Cindy and Leo Asen; adored sister of Helen and Robert Fried; grandmother of Dan (Rachel), Allie, Pam and Sara, and aunt of Patti Seymour and Pam Fox Joravsky. A devoted, gracious and stylish Nana who loved her "mountain," her family, Westport and Compo Beach. Donations may be made in her name to Norwalk Hospital Foundation Circle of Caring, www.norwalkhealth.org.

SHERMAN--Harry, MD, 103, of New York City, passed away November 22, 2013. Husband of the late Ida Sherman. Predeceased by one daughter Alice Quine. Survived by two daughters Ellen Luger and Laura Sherman, two granddaughters, three great-grandchildren, brother as well as many nieces and nephews. Funeral services at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel on Tuesday, November 26, 2013, at 11:30am.

SAR--Ruth Devora, nee Schwartz of NYC. Born January 11, 1921, New Brunswick, NJ. Died November 22, 2013. Predeceased by her beloved husband of 57 years, Dr. Eli Sar, her beloved son Melvin David Sar, cherished sister Pearl Margareten and beloved niece Roslyn Dubroff. Survived by brother Harold (Helen) Schwartz; son Dr. Alan M. (Deborah) Sar, daughter-in-law Cathy M. Sar; grandson Jonathan (Nathalie) Sar; granddaughters Amanda N. Sar and Sarah (Carlos) Sar-Neri; great-granddaughter Abigail F. Sar-Neri; Nieces: Jackie (Gordon) Smith; Carol (Robert) Sills; Susan (Steve) Routenberg; Tziporah (Shabtai) Wishky; and many grand-nieces and nephews. Ruth graduated NYU with a degree in Sociology and worked by her husband's side in his medical practice for many years. Active in numerous Jewish charities, most notably, Mizrachi/Amit Women. A patron of arts, literature and culture, devoted daughter to Sam and Anna Schwartz. A magnificent woman full of grace, elegance, kindness and generous of heart. A source of strength to her extended family and community. A true Aishet Chail, woman of valor. Funeral is Monday, November 25, 2013 at 9:45am, Plaza Chapel at 90th and Amsterdam. Shiva at 160 West End Ave, Apt 8D from 1pm to 8pm (212-595-4844). If desired, contributions may be made to Amit Women at 817 Broadway, NYC, NY 10003. Internment at Beth Israel, Woodbride, NJ.

MASON--Claire, NCJW NY Section mourns the passing of Claire Mason, longtime member of our Board of Directors and active volunteer. Claire's devotion and generosity were exceptional. For many years, the Claire and Eli Mason Fund to Feed the Hungry supported NY Section's Community Kitchens and Food Pantry. We will miss her intelligence, her kindness, and her dedication to NY Section. We offer our heartfelt sympathy to Judith, Nina and their families. Paula A. Moss and Karol Todrys, Co-Presidents Joan Shapiro Green, Executive Director

OURLICHT--Boris July 18, 1925 - November 9, 2013. Died at the age of 88. Son of David Ourlicht and Rose Himelberg, brother to Shulamith Miller and Leah Campenella, father to Laurie Ourlicht and husband to Libby Ourlicht all who predeceased him. He served in WWII on a destroyer escort in the US Coast Guard from 1943 to 1945. He was an ironworker, UWA worker at Ford River Rouge plant and received his Master in Education at Wayne State University. He returned to New York as a teacher for Mobilization for Youth, and then retired as a teacher in the Great Neck Schools. Boris was an amazing man and lived his entire life promoting for the human rights and dignity to all. Fierce in his convictions, steady in his cause and truly loved by his children, grandchildren and many friends. He had a keen eye for spotting social injustice and the wit, intellect, and desire to shine the light for equality. His life was lived out loud, and his interests varied from gardening, fishing, politics, to jazz and reading; a practitioner of Tai Chi and accomplished sculptor. He is severely missed and survived by his son David, daughter in-law Marybeth, grandchildren David, Christine and Sam and extended family and friends. A memorial service will take place at the Unitarian Universalist Congregation, at 48 Shelter Rock Road, Manhasset, New York on Saturday, November 30th, 2013 at noon. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Robert F. Kennedy Center for Justice and Human Rights, www.rfkcenter.org.

LAWRENCE--Alicia-Gayle, on November 23, 2013. Beloved daughter of Florence and the late Sherman S. Lawrence, Esq. Loving sister of Robert L. Lawrence, Esq. Adored aunt of Tara and Carly, and an incredibly devoted family member and friend to all who had the pleasure of knowing her. Her voice, her heart, and everything about her were beyond special, and she will be deeply missed by all, especially by Oceana. Service Tuesday, November 26, 11:45am at "The Riverside" West 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave. New York, NY.

HARTSTEIN--Stanley N.,died on November 23, 2013. Beloved husband of Marsha. Devoted father of Allyn and Stephanie and father-in-law of Gary Sandberg. Loving brother-in-law, uncle, great uncle and friend. Raconteur, charmer and Giants fan. Services to be held Tuesday, November 26, 2013, at 11:15am at "The Riverside" 180 West 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY 10023.

FIELDSTEEL--Joyce Wilner, age 89, adored wife for 68 years of Bob, beloved mother of John (Maggie) and Rob (Jan), grandmother of Sarah (Norman), Elizabeth, Kate and great-grandmother of Dahlia. She died on November 23 in Hanover, New Hampshire at her home at Kendal. She had been a longtime resident of Sands Point, Port Washington, New York. A service celebrating her life will take place at Kendal in Hanover on December 7.

BISSELL--Elliston Perot III. Pete passed away peacefully on the evening of November 19, 2013 in Chatham, New Jersey. Pete was well known and loved by many and lived a rich and rewarding life. The son of Elliston Perot Bissell, Jr. and Ann Packard Bissell, Pete was born In Jamaica Queens New York on May 26th, 1935. He spent his early years in Morristown, New Jersey and Haverford, Pennsylvania. He attended the Episcopal School in Philadelphia and graduated from St. Paul's School in Concord, New Hampshire in 1953. Pete attended Harvard College, where he majored in Biochemical Sciences. While at Harvard he was a member of the Hasty Pudding, Lampoon, and President of the Phoenix-S.K. After graduating from Harvard in 1957, Pete joined the US Navy as a junior lieutenant. He was married to Edith (Edie) Mabelle Roach of Newtown Square, Pennsylvania in March 1958. Pete and Edie spent the early years of their marriage in Japan while he was stationed at the Yokosuka Naval base attached to a naval intelligence unit. After his discharge from active duty in 1961, Pete continued to serve in the Naval Reserves for 30 years and retired with the rank of Commander. Following his return to Philadelphia in 1961, Pete went to work for Pennsylvania Bell. Pete had a long and distinguished career at AT&T and its predecessor companies including vice president of Diamond State Telephone Company, working in AT&T's international division, and finally serving in AT&T's global strategy group. His career took him to many interesting places including living in Egypt from 1982 to 1984. He also gained recognition through obtaining two patents for proprietary telecommunication devices. Pete retired in from AT&T in 1997. In addition to his work, Pete played a very active role in numerous community organizations including the Kiwanis in Norristown, Pennsylvania, the Rotary Club of Wilmington, Delaware (serving as President in 1981), the Opportunity Center, Inc (a group that seek to educate and help the disabled), and the Urban League of Wilmington. Pete will be remembered fondly by the many lives he touched. He was always willing to lend a helping hand or provide sage advice. Pete had many hobbies gardening, HO Gage trains, model building, furniture making, bridge, military history, fine wine collecting, and painting lead soldiers. An avid golfer, he was a member of the Merion Golf Club, Pine Valley Golf Club, and the Morris County Golf Club. He was also a member of the Morristown Club. Pete was well known as a bon-vivant and a humorous raconteur! After nearly 40 years of happy marriage, Edie passed away. Pete was very lucky and fortunate to fall in love with and in 1999 marry Elizabeth (Betty) Lee Cutler. Pete and Betty had a wonderful time together and spending time with their 13 grandchildren. For many years they spent their winters in Albufeira, Portugal and summers at Fossil Hill Farm in Morristown, New Jersey. In these years Pete and Betty continued to explore the four corners of the earth and hone their prodigious bridge skills. Pete is survived by Betty, his three children Elliston Perot Bissell IV, Rolin Plumb Bissell, and Ann Packard Bissell, and five grandchildren Elliston Perot Bissell V, Ulysses Duncan Lighthill Bissell, Samuel Randolph Bissell, Tilden Avery Bissell, and Helen Packard Bissell. A remembrance service and burial will be held at Old Saint David's Church 763 Valley Forge Rd, Wayne, PA on Saturday, November 30, 2012 at 11:00 am with a reception to follow at The Merion Golf Club 450 Ardmore Avenue, Ardmore. The family has asked that in lieu of flowers contributions be made to The Alzheimer's Foundation of America 822 Eighth Ave., 7th fl., New York, NY 10001. Services by Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, Chatham. For additional information or to leave the family a message of condolence, go to bradleyfuneralhomes.com.

New Orleans is an excellent destination for food and drink, but finding a stylish frock there can be like tracking down ripe tomatoes out of season. The newest Billy Reid shop, nestled among a cluster of antiques stores on a charming corner of Magazine Street, aims to fix that. “There’s a palpable energy in this town right now,” the fashion designer explained between sips of a bourbon cocktail and bites of duck liver pâté at the store’s opening party last weekend. “There are just a lot of positive vibes here.” The New Orleans store is his 10th to open in 9 years, joining locations in Nashville, Atlanta, Austin and New York.

GROSS--Sidney. Time can not steal you from us. Always in our hearts and memories. Zenith & Family

WECHSLER--Robert, on November 18. A Memorial service to celebrate his life will be held on Thursday, December 5 at 6pm in the recital hall at CUNY Graduate Center, 365 Fifth Avenue.

TYRRASCH--Ernest E. It is with great sorrow that on November 23, 2013 marks the end of a remarkable life. Born in 1924 in Breslau, Germany; he left Nazi Germany in 1939 and arrived in London on a Kindertransport, where he spent the War years. After the War, he was hired by the United States Army and served in the Civilian Censorship Division and was also at the Nuremberg trials as an interpreter. He came to the United States in 1949 with less than 100 dollars and became a self-made millionaire and contributed to many charities. He was pre-deceased by his beloved wife, Marianne and survived by his wife, Lucy, whom he loved very much; his daughter, Jenny; grandchildren, Natalie and Alan and great-grandsons, Justin and Michael. In lieu of flowers, please send donations in Ernest's name to Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts, Lincoln Center Institute or the Joint Distribution Committee. A private memorial service will be held at a later date with the invitations to follow.

SHERMAN--Jerry, passed peacefully at home surrounded by love on November 24, 2013. Jerry leaves behind his wife of 58 years Bobbi, his son David, daughter, Emily, son-in-law Julian, step-daughter Wendy, as well grandsons Holden, Jasper, Isamu, Arlo, Daniel and great-grandson Heizron, his sister Renee and many nieces, nephews and cousins. Jerry Sherman was a highly-respected financial writer and long-time public relations professional. He began his career in journalism in 1945 as a reporter for the New York Journal of Commerce, advancing to columnist, associate editor and foreign correspondent. He entered the public relations field in 1952, working for several agencies before starting his own New York consulting firm, Jerry Sherman Associates. He joined Gulf & Western Corp as the vice president of public relations in 1979 and took early retirement in 1990. He rejoined the company, then named Paramount Communications Inc., in 1992 as senior vice president, communications. He was an active member of the New York Financial Writers' Association, which honored him for distinguished service to financial journalism on the occasion of the group's 50th anniversary. Jerry was an avid sports fan fiercely devoted to the New York Giants, Knicks and Yankees. Services: Yorktown Funeral Home 914-962-0700, 10:00am, November 27.

PICOT--Jean-Paul, on November 24, 2013. Beloved husband of Monique. Loving father of Francois and Yves. Cherished brother of Robert. Dear grandfather of Xander, Oliver and Christian. Fond uncle of Fredric. Family will recieve friends at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. (81st St.) Tuesday 6-8pm.
LOWE--Morton. The world will never be the same without you. Love, Amy Chanos & family

LEWIS--Peter, deepest condolences to the entire Lewis family. He was known and loved as a man of "core values." He was fortunate to have the enduring love and devotion of his wife Janet. He was the epitome of the "American Dream!" Dr. Jerilyn Kronen
LEWIS--Peter, Deepest condolences to the Lewis family. He was a brilliant businessman, a generous spirit, and visionary. Igor Galynker M.D. Family Center

LEWIS--Peter B. The staff and Board of Directors of Human Rights Watch mourn the passing of Peter B. Lewis, steadfast supporter for more than a decade. We are grateful for his passion, principles and commitment to the cause of human rights. We extend our deep and sincere condolences to his loved ones.

LEWIS--Peter B.,The Board of Directors and staff of the American Civil Liberties Union are deeply saddened by the passing of Peter B. Lewis, one of the leading lights of the philanthropic world, and a dear friend and longtime supporter of the ACLU. As one of America's great patriots, Peter was single-mindedly committed to the values of equality, fairness and justice--values that guided his stewardship of Progressive Insurance as well as his personal giving. As a proud card-carrying member of the ACLU for close to four decades, Peter's generous support of our programs transformed America into a more perfect union. He was an outspoken opponent of the so-called War on Drugs, and pushed vigorously for the legalization of marijuana; the ACLU's drug policy work would not exist at the level it does today without his generous support and inspired vision. Peter's support extended to civil liberties efforts in state legislative battlegrounds across the country, furthering the fight for racial justice, immigration reform and marriage equality. His enormous generosity enabled the ACLU to purchase a building named The Peter B. Lewis Center for Civil Liberties for the organization's expanding Washington Legislative Office, and to conclude our endowment fund, even in difficult economic times. The ACLU is honored to be one of the philanthropies that measured up to Peter's high standards, and we honor his memory every day by continuing to fight for the more just and free society he envisioned. His belief in the underdog and his commitment to righting wrongs made him a benefactor to millions of Americans whom he never met but about whom he cared deeply. Peter Lewis epitomized the best of our country's values and we will miss him greatly. Anthony D. Romero, Executive Director

LEWIS--Peter B. The Staff and Trustees of the New Museum mourn the sudden passing of Peter B. Lewis, a maverick corporate leader, visionary thinker, and extraordinary philanthropist. As a supporter of the New Museum, Lewis also gave us invaluable advice about expansion planning and managing growth. The Museum was fortunate to enjoy a close relationship with him through our Trustee and Vice President Toby Devan Lewis. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family, to Toby, their three children Jonathan, Ivy, and Adam Joseph and their families, as well as his brother Daniel, and sister-in-law Jan. Lisa Phillips, Toby Devan Lewis Director Saul Dennison, Chairman James Keith Brown, President

LEWIS--Peter B. The Trustees and staff of the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation mourn the passing of Peter B. Lewis, a longtime member of its Board and former Chairman. Peter's devotion and generosity to the Guggenheim, particularly to the Frank Lloyd Wright building on Fifth Avenue, ensure its well being for generations to come. We offer our sincere condolences to the Lewis family. Peter Lawson-Johnston, Honorary Chairman William L. Mack, Chairman Jennifer Blei Stockman, President, Solomon. R. Guggenheim Foundation Richard Armstrong, Director, Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum and Foundation

LAWRENCE--Alicia-Gayle. There was no one with a more loving heart or giving nature. We will miss the beauty, laughter and music that was our Aunt Alicia. We will love and cherish you forever. Love, Your Family.

KOFSKY--Elaine, 84, of Roslyn, NY and Boca Raton, FL passed away on Monday, November 25, 2013. Wife of Mel Kofsky for 64 years, brother of Isadore Klebanow, beloved mother of David Kofsky, Debbie and Chuck Fisher, Nikki and Eddie Kofsky, grandmother of Amy and Matt Singer, Jessica and Eric Fisher, Marnie and Asher Kofsky, great-grandmother of Gabriel Fisher, Joey Singer and Brody Fisher as well as many nieces and nephews. We will miss her intelligence, honesty, kindness, integrity and her devotion to her family and friends. KAVLI--Fred. New York University mourns the loss of Fred Kavli, who recognized the vast promise of science and was a tireless supporter of its potential to benefit humanity. His commitment to innovation and unparalleled generosity provided a shining model of leadership that stretches beyond scientific inquiry. His loved ones are in our thoughts.

KALIKOW--Shirley J.,88, of Somers, NY, formerly of West Hempstead, NY, died Sunday, November 24, 2013. She is the loving mother of Joseph Kalikow, Hilary Popp and Karen Kalikow. Devoted grandmother of Sarah, Rebecca, Robert, Charles and Daniel. Loving sister of Zelda and the late Lillie. The burial service will be private. The family will be sitting Shiva at Shirley's home on Wednesday at 4pm, Friday and Saturday afternoon.

HLADEK--Olga, nee Chichira, on November 24, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Anthony Hladek. Loving mother of Linda, Anthony Jr., Christine and Thomas. Cherished grandmother of four and adored great-grandmother of five. Reposing at the Frederick Funeral Home of Flushing, Northern Blvd. at 193rd Street. HARTSTEIN--Stanley N.,died on November 23, 2013. Beloved husband of Marsha. Devoted father of Allyn and Stephanie and father-in-law of Gary Sandberg. Loving brother-in-law, uncle, great uncle and friend. Raconteur, charmer and Giants fan. Services to be held Tuesday, November 26, 2013, at 11:15am at "The Riverside" 180 West 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave., New York, NY 10023.

GREENBERG--Sema Ann Tanzer, died after a long illness on November 22, 2013. We will miss her warm generous spirit, passion for life, and above all, her unconditional love for her children - the late Josiah Greenberg, Sarah Greenberg, David Greenberg and Ezra Greenberg. Sema is also survived by her sister Miriam McKenzie and three grandchildren, Samuel Greenberg, Jessica Greenberg and Julia Greenberg. She cared deeply about Israel and the Jewish people, her first job being with an Israeli Shipping Company in New York City. Subsequently she worked for the Jewish Theological Seminary and American Jewish Committee. Her zeal for social causes was not just relegated to Zionism, and as a young woman growing up in segregated Wilmington, DE, she joined the NAACP. She married, in 1950, Jack Greenberg, a man who worked for the NAACP Legal Defense Fund, and fully encouraged him in his work. They had four children together. We will miss her deeply and always love and cherish her memory.

FRIEDMAN--Rae, 91, of Paterson and Passaic, NJ, passed away on Thursday, November 21, 2013. She was predeceased by her husband Sam. She leaves her loving sons Ira and Brian, and grandchildren Joshua, Stefanie, Kacie, Zachary, Andrew, Julia, and Daniel. Born in Brooklyn, NY, Rae moved with her family to Paterson, NJ, where they owned and operated the Eastside Bakery and where she rose to be the Chief Deputy County Clerk at the Passaic County Courthouse. Contributions in her memory may be made to the Jewish Home Assisted Living, 685 Westwood Avenue, River Vale, NJ 07675.

FRASER--James Howard, born April 30, 1934, died peacefully on November 25, 2013. Beloved husband of 56 years of Sibylle von Holstein Fraser and devoted father of Stephen H. Fraser (Illinois) and Caitlin F. James (New Jersey), he was also an involved grandfather of James, Katherine and Stuart Fraser and Katherine and Gemma James. James earned his Doctorate of Library Science from Columbia University and spent nearly 50 years working in and with academic and research libraries. As a consultant, James specialized in locating and collecting elusive materials and wrote on broadly diverse topics such as: international children's literature research; political ephemera; book arts; photography; posters, outdoor advertising; Nipponica; Baltica, etc. As Library Director at Fairleigh Dickinson University (Madison, NJ), editor of "Phaedrus," author and contributor to numerous books and articles, James' wide interests inspired students, scholars, artists, and an international community of friends. Service Saturday November 30, 2013, 11:00am at Dangler Funeral Home, 106 Main St. Madison, NJ. Contributions in his memory may be made to www.Wycliffe.org.

COOKE--Anne Elizabeth Ryan, passed from this world early on Saturday, November 23, 2013; she had been resting at her home in Williamsburg, VA since August. Anne, Senior Vice President of Emblem Health, a New York based Health insurance Company, had been living and working in NYC for a little over a year. After a successful career with AT&T, she retired in 1998 to pursue other interests, including a short period with Michigan Consolidate Gas and Gen Three in Boston. Anne then came to the Healthcare industry with leadership positions at WellPoint, where she was responsible for the rollout of their Medicare Part D product, then DaVita Inc. with their Home Healthcare Division and finally with Emblem Health where she was responsible for Operations and IT. Anne remained in NYC during Hurricane Sandy to help keep Emblem's IT systems operational as power was lost and backups restored. She is survived by her husband of 23 years, Bruce Cooke, daughter, Victoria Cooke, Williamsburg, VA and sisters, Mary Nell Ryan, Milwaukee, WI, and Jeanne Ryan, Duluth, MN. Anne grew up in the suburbs of Milwaukee, was a nationally ranked swimmer in high school, and then attended St. Catherine University, St. Paul, MN, graduating in 1980 with honors and member of Phi Beta Kappa. Anne felt her greatest work satisfaction came in the Health Industry; a colleague who worked with her at Emblem can best describe her in the quote below: "Anne was inspirational, honest, and genuine. In speaking with many other people about Anne they each felt important and full of purpose after meeting her and hearing her vigor for life and dedication to transforming our organization. And she did just that; transform it. She held others accountable and required nothing but the best from each of us. I am a better person and stronger leader because of her. God bless." The family will receive local friends and neighbors on Tuesday evening, November 26th, from 4-7pm at Nelsen Funeral Home, 3785 Strawberry Plains Rd., Williamsburg, VA 23188. A Celebration of Life will be scheduled at a later time. The family is requesting in lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Hospice House of Williamsburg, 4445 Powhatan Pkwy, Williamsburg, VA 23188 in honor of Anne Cooke. Online condolences may be offered at www.nelsecares.com.

The letters arrive almost daily, on official-looking letterhead from a supposed charity, or from the J.M.D. Major Cash Disbursement Office. More blatantly, letters sometimes come from an outfit called Mountains of Money. They announce that the 85-year-old man to whom they’re addressed has won a prize — the amount seems to hover around $11,000 — and explain that to claim it, he has to fill out a form, often complete with a “verification code,” and send it in with a check for $6 or $7.
