WEINTRAUB--Ethel, 92, November 26 2013. Adored and adoring wife of the late Leonard, sister of Bernard Aronson and Helen Green, cherished mother of Ellen Roxland and Iris Lachaud, dearest mother-in-law of Ira Roxland and Jean Lachaud, best friend and world's best Nanny to Amanda Roxland, Jon and Cara Roxland, Laure Lachaud, and Luc Lachaud. We are so grateful to her wonderful caregivers Biljana and Gina for their devotion. Service Sunday December 1st, 11:30am at "The Riverside" 76th at Amsterdam Ave. In lieu of flowers, contributions to Ethel's favorite charity www.Citymeals.org.

STEIN--Matilda, (nee Priceman), of Brooklyn, NY, died Monday, November 25, 2013. Matilda had love for everyone and selflessly gave to make her family and friends dreams a reality. Matilda is predeceased by her husband Jack and son Mark. She is survived by her son Allan and numerous grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Funeral services will be held Wednesday, November 27, 9:45am at Parkside Memorial Chapels, 2576 Flatbush Avenue, Brooklyn, NY 11234.

SCHWARTZ--Sidney, January 23, 1923 - November 26, 2013. Esteemed Special Deputy Comptroller for New York City Affairs and Inspector General of the MTA. A man of wit, charm, and intelligence. Loving husband, father and grandfather. Services at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, New York, Thursday 9:30am. In lieu of flowers contributions to United Cerebral Palsy of Nassau County.

SHERMAN--Jerry, passed peacefully at home surrounded by love on November 24, 2013. Jerry leaves behind his wife of 58 years Bobbi, his son David, daughter, Emily, son-in-law Julian, step-daughter Wendy, as well grandsons Holden, Jasper, Isamu, Arlo, Daniel and great-grandson Heizron, his sister Renee and many nieces, nephews and cousins. Jerry Sherman was a highly-respected financial writer and long-time public relations professional. He began his career in journalism in 1945 as a reporter for the New York Journal of Commerce, advancing to columnist, associate editor and foreign correspondent. He entered the public relations field in 1952, working for several agencies before starting his own New York consulting firm, Jerry Sherman Associates. He joined Gulf & Western Corp as the vice president of public relations in 1979 and took early retirement in 1990. He rejoined the company, then named Paramount Communications Inc., in 1992 as senior vice president, communications. He was an active member of the New York Financial Writers' Association, which honored him for distinguished service to financial journalism on the occasion of the group's 50th anniversary. Jerry was an avid sports fan fiercely devoted to the New York Giants, Knicks and Yankees. Services: Yorktown Funeral Home 914-962-0700, 10:00am, November 27.

POHL--Elinor, 88, of Larchmont, NY, passed away on November 24, 2013. Born in Larchmont, on September 21, 1925, Elinor graduated from Mamaroneck High School and continued on to earn an Associate's Degree from Boston University. She devoted her life to caring for her family and enjoying her many friends and other interests. Elinor traveled throughout the world, worked with a number of companies and organizations and loved playing bridge and Maj Jong. She was committed to volunteering with community organizations, including the Neuberger Museum of Art and Women In Self Help (WISH), Westchester, Inc., an organization dedicated to helping women with problems help themselves. Elinor was predeceased by her husband, Henry Pohl, to whom she was married for fifty years and for whom she lovingly cared for at home during his long bout with Alzheimer's disease. She is survived by her brother, Robert Englebardt, her son Jeffrey Pohl (Mara) and her daughters Cathy Lee (David) and Alice Bruhl (Christopher), and her six beloved grandchildren, Barbara Pohl, Emily Bruhl, Rachel Lee, Martin Pohl, Matthew Lee, and Sarah Bruhl. Her grandchildren were among her proudest accomplishments. Funeral Services will be for the immediate family. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to a charity of your choice.

RAFF--Ruth, passed away peacefully at 90 on November 14, 2013, only a few months after her husband of 65 years, Emanuel. Survived by her sons and daughters-in-law Joshua Raff and Michele Fillion and Hershel and Judy Raff and her grandchildren, Jonathan Raff, and Simone, Camille and Luc Fillion-Raff. Ruth was a scientist, an avid reader, an expert gardener and an accomplished conversationalist and story-teller. She particularly loved to describe her life growing up in the Bronx, with little money but with an adventuresome spirit. She and Manny were passionate about theater, dance, music and art and loved to travel together. Ruth had an inquiring mind and strongly-held beliefs. After graduating from Hunter College, she earned a graduate degree in microbiology from the University of Wisconsin. Ruth was for many years a biology teacher at West Hempstead High School. She was a long-time member and one of the founders of the local branch of the Workmen's Circle. After her retirement, she was an active and effective volunteer in the community, including for many years in a laboratory at Winthrop Hospital. Per her wishes, no services were held. She was an inspiration to many and will be greatly missed.

ORENTREICH--Roslyn, (nee Seidner), 87, peacefully at home on Monday, November 25th, 2013. Devoted daughter of the late Sol and Yetta Seidner. Roslyn was a loving and devoted sister of the late Abraham Seidner. She is survived by Norman, her adoring husband of 67 years, her three children Catherine, David, and Sari, as well as four cherished grandchildren Nicholas, Jeremy, Ariane, and Eric; and son-in-law Michael Mass. Roslyn graduated from City College with a degree in social work. Roslyn was a devoted wife and mother who always put the needs of her family before her own. Service: Wednesday, November 27, 2013, 12:45pm at "The Riverside," 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

ORENTREICH--Roslyn. We note with sorrow the passing of our member Roslyn Orentreich and extend sincerest condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein and President David B. Edelson, Central Synagogue of New York City

MERSZEI--Kevin Zoltan, age 29, died November 22, 2013 at his family home in Greenwich, CT. Born in Los Angeles January 6, 1984, he was the son of Aimee and Zoltan Merszei. Shortly thereafter, the family moved to Greenwich. Kevin attended Greenwich Country Day School and The Eaglebrook School. He graduated Greenwich High School in 2003 and Arizona State University in 2008. From childhood, Kevin was fascinated with aviation. His natural aptitude earned him his private pilots license at age 18. At the time of his death he held FAA certifications in the most complex commercial aircraft in use today. He had worked as co-pilot of a private jet in Nigeria, instructor in an advanced aircraft simulator, and specialized cargo transport. In 2013 Kevin moved to Miami to fly for Ameriflight, domestically and internationally. Kevin loved life's pleasures, particularly travel. Over the years, he visited some 30 European and Asian countries. Intrigued with foreign cuisines, he mastered many in the kitchen. His loyalty, generosity, infectious and wry sense of humor, and his love for those closest to him will be remembered and sorely missed. Kevin is survived by his parents, now of Palm Beach, Florida; his wife Cristina whom he married in June; his half-siblings Leslie (Kliew) of Thailand, Geoffrey (Mary Jane) of Switzerland, Karen (Richard Stern) of Washington, D.C., and his uncle Frederick Morner of Oakland, CA. A funeral mass will be held at St. Catherine of Sienna Church Riverside CT at 12:00 noon Friday November 29. In lieu of flowers, donate in Kevin's memory to Pediatrics at Memorial Sloan Kettering Cancer Center.

MASON--Claire Rosen, 92, of Manhattan and Atlantic Beach, died peacefully November 22, 2013. She was born February 20, 1921 on Delancey Street to Jacob and Nettie Rosen who operated a thriving millinery shop. Claire was married for 67 years to Eli Mason (deceased 2009), her college sweetheart. After a successful professional career, Claire dedicated much of her time to service and family. She was an active member of the National Council for Jewish Women, New York Section and was the recipient of the Hannah G. Solomon Award for her record of outstanding and meaningful service. Together with her husband, she established the Claire and Eli Mason Fund to Feed the Hungry which provides food twice weekly at the Council's Senior Center. In 2008 Claire inaugurated the Claire Mason Women of Distinction Lecture Series as her tribute to the female students at Baruch College, her alma mater, and to the strong women who are their role models. Claire and Eli, class of 1940, were active participants in many philanthropic and governing committees regarding Baruch College. Claire is survived by two daughters: Judith Ann (Gerald Berger) of Delmar, NY and Nina Mason (Max Hirshfeld) of Washington, DC, four grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A private service was held by the immediate family. Donations in her memory can be made to the National Council of Jewish Women Hunger Program, New York Section, 241 W. 72nd St. New York, NY 10023. A beautiful sky, A lovely rose, A good wife, A happy song, A lasting poem, A full life.

LIFSHEY--Frederick. Fred lost his valiant battle with cardiac disease and myelodysplasia on November 25, 2013. He was born in Brooklyn on August 25, 1948. He was a graduate of Stony Brook University and the NYU College of Dentistry. Fred completed his residency in Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery at the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn. He went on to private practice in New York City. He later joined the staff of Woodhull Medical Center in Brooklyn, and was an important part of our residency training program in OMS, A bright and beloved teacher of our residents, he was committed to providing the best care to his patients. An avid powder skier he lived every day to the limit. He was a dear friend to all who knew him. The Department of Dentistry/OMS at Woodhull remembers his unquenched spirit and love of his teaching. Our thoughts are with his magnificent wife, Fran, who shouldered the incredible burdens of his long illness with the utmost grace. Peter M. Sherman

LEWIS--Peter B.,The members, staff, and Board of Directors of Fountain House mourn the passing of our dear friend and benefactor Peter B. Lewis. His support of people living with serious mental illness and his far-sighted vision in creating a state of the art wellness center will have a lasting impact on our community for years to come. We offer our sincere condolences to his loved ones.

LEWIS--Peter B.,The Board of Directors and staff of the American Civil Liberties Union are deeply saddened by the passing of Peter B. Lewis, one of the leading lights of the philanthropic world, and a dear friend and longtime supporter of the ACLU. As one of America's great patriots, Peter was single-mindedly committed to the values of equality, fairness and justice--values that guided his stewardship of Progressive Insurance as well as his personal giving. As a proud card-carrying member of the ACLU for close to four decades, Peter's generous support of our programs transformed America into a more perfect union. He was an outspoken opponent of the so-called War on Drugs, and pushed vigorously for the legalization of marijuana; the ACLU's drug policy work would not exist at the level it does today without his generous support and inspired vision. Peter's support extended to civil liberties efforts in state legislative battlegrounds across the country, furthering the fight for racial justice, immigration reform and marriage equality. His enormous generosity enabled the ACLU to purchase a building named The Peter B. Lewis Center for Civil Liberties for the organization's expanding Washington Legislative Office, and to conclude our endowment fund, even in difficult economic times. The ACLU is honored to be one of the philanthropies that measured up to Peter's high standards, and we honor his memory every day by continuing to fight for the more just and free society he envisioned. His belief in the underdog and his commitment to righting wrongs made him a benefactor to millions of Americans whom he never met but about whom he cared deeply. Peter Lewis epitomized the best of our country's values and we will miss him greatly. Anthony D. Romero, Executive Director

LEWIS--Peter B. The Trustees, National Council, and staff of the Aspen Art Museum mourn the loss of Peter B. Lewis, an inspiring philanthropist, friend, donor to and supporter of the arts. His legacy will live on through the many organizations, institutions, and projects to which he lent his ideas, positive influence, and unfailing and loyal support. Our condolences to his family and to our own National Council Co-Chair Toby Devan Lewis for their loss. John Phelan and Paul Schorr, Co-Presidents of the Board of Trustees; Pam Alexander, Co-Chair of the National Council; Heidi Zuckerman Jacobson, Nancy and Bob Magoon, CEO and Director

LEVIDOW--David, passed suddenly Friday, November 22, 2013 of a stroke. He will be remembered as a dear friend to many and an uncle to Bjorn. Services will be Wednesday, November 27th, 10am at Plaza Community Chapel: 630 Amsterdam Ave. at 91st Street.

LAWRENCE--Alicia-Gayle, on November 23, 2013. Beloved daughter of Florence and the late Sherman S. Lawrence, Esq. Loving sister of Robert L. Lawrence, Esq. Adored aunt of Tara and Carly, and an incredibly devoted family member and friend to all who had the pleasure of knowing her. Her voice, her heart, and everything about her were beyond special, and she will be deeply missed by all, especially by Oceana. KOFSKY--Elaine, 84, of Roslyn, NY and Boca Raton, FL passed away on Monday, November 25, 2013. Wife of Mel Kofsky for 64 years, brother of Isadore Klebanow, beloved mother of David Kofsky, Debbie and Chuck Fisher, Nikki and Eddie Kofsky, grandmother of Amy and Matt Singer, Jessica and Eric Fisher, Marnie and Asher Kofsky, great-grandmother of Gabriel Fisher, Joey Singer and Brody Fisher as well as many nieces and nephews. We will miss her intelligence, honesty, kindness, integrity and her devotion to her family and friends. Funeral services will take place at Sinai Chapels located at 162-05 Horace Harding Blvd., Fresh Meadows, NY 11365. Phone: 1-800-446-0406 on Wednesday, November 27, 2013 at 12:45pm.

GRUNBLATT--Rabbi Joseph. The Queens Jewish Center mourns the loss of Rabbi Joseph Grunblatt on November 23rd at age 86. He served as Rabbi of the Center from 1967-2006 and at his death was Rabbi Emeritus. Rabbi Grunblatt was highly respected within the larger Jewish community and was regarded as a Rabbi's Rabbi. Prior to his coming to the Queens Jewish Center in Forest Hills, Rabbi Grunblatt served pulpits in Saratoga Springs and Montreal. A prominent lecturer and community activist, he has served as Vice President of the Rabbinical Council of America, President of the Vaad Harabonim of Queens and was active in the Orthodox Union, NCSY and as advisor to collegiates. He also taught at Yeshiva University and Touro College. He authored Exile and Redemption which was published in 1988. Rabbi Grunblatt leaves his wife Bella, children, grandchildren and great-grandchildren. May his family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Queens Jewish Center Administration

EIGENFELD--Stanley, In the hush of night on November 11, Stan Eigenfeld, 83, slipped away as gracefully as he had lived. Loved by his step-son Glenn (Jean), granddaughter Debbie (Dennis), great-grandsons Sean and Riley, and his "one and only love" of 60 years, Annie Fisher Eigenfeld.

DUNCAN--Dorothy, beloved mother of Shaun, Amy, and Jed died peacefully November 17. Memorial December 7, 11am at Sherman Church Fellowship Hall, 6 Church Rd, Sherman, CT. She filled us with love and laughter, and will be greatly missed.

BERG--Ceil "Gloria," of Tappan, NY passed away Thursday, October 10, 2013 at age 79. She was born November 27, 1933 in Brooklyn, NY to the late Joseph and Esther Grashow. She was a graduate of Midwood High School and City College of New York. She worked for the American Red Cross, as a school teacher for the New York City Board of Education in Brooklyn and later in her family's business, Quick Mount Mfg. Co., Inc. Gloria moved with her husband and children to Tappan, NY in 1969 where she raised her family and became an active participant in the community. She was a member of the Orangetown Jewish Center for more than 40 years. The warmth and generosity Gloria brought to her many remarkable friendships and family relationships endure. Gloria is survived by her beloved husband Melvin, cherished children Victor (Deborah) and William (Elizabeth), adoring grandchildren Joshua, Hannah, Noah and Eli, and her brother Stanley. Memorial contributions may be made in Gloria's memory to the Lustgarten Foundation (seeking a cure for pancreatic cancer) at Lustgarten.org or 1111 Stewart Ave., Bethpage, NY 11714; 866-789-1000.

Survived by his wife of 65 years, Lottie Tartell, and his sons Ross (daughter-in-law Karen) and Marc (daughter-in-law Barbara), and seven grandchildren. SHERMAN--Jerry, passed peacefully at home surrounded by love on November 24, 2013. Jerry leaves behind his wife of 58 years Bobbi, his son David, daughter, Emily, son-in-law Julian, step-daughter Wendy, as well grandsons Holden, Jasper, Isamu, Arlo, Daniel and great-grandson Heizron, his sister Renee and many nieces, nephews and cousins. Jerry Sherman was a highly-respected financial writer and long-time public relations professional. He began his career in journalism in 1945 as a reporter for the New York Journal of Commerce, advancing to columnist, associate editor and foreign correspondent. He entered the public relations field in 1952, working for several agencies before starting his own New York consulting firm, Jerry Sherman Associates. He joined Gulf & Western Corp as the vice president of public relations in 1979 and took early retirement in 1990. He rejoined the company, then named Paramount Communications Inc., in 1992 as senior vice president, communications. He was an active member of the New York Financial Writers' Association, which honored him for distinguished service to financial journalism on the occasion of the group's 50th anniversary. Jerry was an avid sports fan fiercely devoted to the New York Giants, Knicks and Yankees. Services: Yorktown Funeral Home 914-962-0700, 10:00am, November 27.

PHILPOT--John Clinton, on November 26, 2013, son of the late Daniel and Gertrude and brother of the late Agnes Bernice Zwanzig. He is survived by several cousins and nieces and nephews. He was a WWII Navy Veteran serving in the Pacific. John was one of two Senior Credit Policy Executives reporting to The Vice Chairman and Top Credit Executive of The Chase Manhattan Bank as well as Senior Vice President in New York when he retired. His distinguished career at the Bank covered a span 37 years. He joined the Bank as a clerk in the Letter of Credit Department in 1946 and worked his way into the credit training program and from there to a number of senior roles in Commodity Finance, the Asia Pacific Area and then to head of Credit Policy for all areas of the International Department as well as the Credit Policy staff and credit policy issues bank wide. Friends may call Friday, November 29, 2013, 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, November 30, 10am, Church of our Saviour, Park Avenue at 37th Street.

ORENTREICH--Roslyn, The Board of Directors and staff of 910 5th Avenue express their heartfelt condolences to Norman, and his entire family on the passing of Roslyn Orentreich. Roslyn, together with her husband Norman and their children Catherine and David, have had a long term, honored and supportive association with 910 5th Avenue.

NEDLIN--Leonard. A great pal is gone. He leaves wonderful memories of laughter and friendship and his unique ability to turn the outrageous into pure joy. Our hearts go out to Radie, David, Wendy and Joey. We'll miss you buddy. Howard and Judy Steinberg

MANSON--Florence Sando, A pioneering woman newscaster in radio and the early years of television journalism who hosted Pittsburgh's TV Show "The Florence Manson Show," died on November 25, 2013 at her home in Riverdale, New York at age 95 from complications related to dementia. Florence was born in 1918 and she graduated from Westminster College in 1939 and received her Master's Degree in Drama from Case Western Reserve the following year. Florence broke out of the usual confines of gossip and fashion coverage that women broadcasters were relegated to, spending 18 years as a popular on air Pittsburghbased personality. In her era when women broadcasters were usually expected to keep their shows light and frothy, Florence Sando tackled the leading hard news of the day in a career that ran from 1941 to 1959. Longtime viewers of Pittsburgh TV stations with signals that broadcast up and down the East Coast and into the Midwest would remember her for "The Florence Manson Show," which featured her as a host-interviewer, a pioneering use of that format. She interviewed well known public figures such as Eleanor Roosevelt (on radio) as well as celebrities on tv such as Danny Kaye and Louis Armstrong. Some of these interviews are available at the Museum of Broadcasting in New York. She also produced the earlier hard news breakthrough "Women's Angle" a 15 minute morning broadcast. Sando's "Women's Angle" spoke to women as adults, presenting news of the world, rather than the low-brow mix of fashion and decorating tips dished out to female audiences until then. "It was easy when the news was about Madame Chiang Kai-shek, or the ten bestdressed women, or Mrs. Roosevelt or Senator Margaret Chase Smith..." Sando told author and educator and former broadcaster Lynn Boyd Hinds in "Broadcasting the Local News- The Early Years of Pittsburgh's KDKA-TV." She was so popular with the Pittsburgh area audience that KDKA-TV asked her in 1957 to host "The Florence Manson Show," now using her married name after her wedding to film executive Arthur Manson. Her tv shows were always committed to public service as well as entertainment. She cooperated with government, civic, social and cultural agencies in support of the war effort during World War II and presented stories and interviews which contributed to Pittsburgh's post war development. The show had a successful run until Florence and Arthur moved to New York in 1959. Mrs. Manson remained active in theater and community affairs in New York City. She was a member of the Board of Ensemble Studio Theatre. She also served as a member of the Board of Riverdale Neighborhood House as well as serving as an Elder of the Riverdale Presbyterian Church. Florence is survived by her husband, Arthur, her daughter Cynthia Ann and son-in-law Jeffrey Faville, and their children James and Catherine and her son Anthony, her daughter-in-law Angela and their children, Daniel, William and Timothy. A memorial service will be held at the Riverdale Presbyterian Church on December 7th at 11:00am. Please send donations to The Riverdale Presbyterian Church at 4765 Henry Hudson Parkway West. Bronx, NY 10471.

LIFSHEY--Frederick. Fred lost his valiant battle with cardiac disease and myelodysplasia on November 25, 2013. He was born in Brooklyn on August 25, 1948. He was a graduate of Stony Brook University and the NYU College of Dentistry. Fred completed his residency in Oral and Maxillofacial Surgery at the Jewish Hospital and Medical Center of Brooklyn. He went on to private practice in New York City. He later joined the staff of Woodhull Medical Center in Brooklyn, and was an important part of our residency training program in OMS, A bright and beloved teacher of our residents, he was committed to providing the best care to his patients. An avid powder skier he lived every day to the limit. He was a dear friend to all who knew him. The Department of Dentistry/OMS at Woodhull remembers his unquenched spirit and love of his teaching. Our thoughts are with his magnificent wife, Fran, who shouldered the incredible burdens of his long illness with the utmost grace. Peter M. Sherman
LEWIS--Peter. I loved Peter's zest for life, love, and philanthropy. It was great to be his friend. Agnes Gund

CHERNIN--Albert, died in his sleep November 26. Former executive Vice Chairman of NJCRAC he drove Jewish efforts in civil rights, immigration reform, church-state separation, and Soviet Jewry. He had a deeply loving, 55 year partnership with his wife, Rheta, who passed away in 2005. He is survived and remembered with great love by his children, Dan and Anne, and grandchildren, Arielle, Julia and Jake. Funeral at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel, Boynton Beach, FL, November 29, 11am. Memorial contributions may be sent to New Israel Fund, the JCPA, or Taub Center for Altzheimers Research.

TARTELL--Robert, 87, West Hempstead, NY on November 27, 2013. Survived by his wife of 65 years, Lottie Tartell, and his sons Ross (daughter-in-law Karen) and Marc (daughter-in-law Barbara), and seven grandchildren. He was predeceased by his son, Dr. Adam Tartell (daughter-in-law Sharon). Dr. Tartell practiced dentistry in Valley Stream, NY for 40 years. He was a U.S. Army dentist during the Korean War. Dr. Tartell was passionate as a signer, marathon runner, long-time president of the Gilbert & Sullivan Yiddish Light Opera, and a perennial student of the Yiddish language. Funeral service will be held on Friday, November 29 at 11:30 am at Gutterman's Inc. 175 North Long Beach Road, Rockville Centre, NY.

STERN--Ralph Warner, on November 27, 2013, New York, NY. Dearest husband of the late Joan Strauss Stern; beloved companion of Arlene Stern, father to Laurie Stern-Kluger and her husband Michael Kluger, and Paul Stern and his wife Denise in Jacksonville, FL; stepfather to Roberta Stern. Born December 5, 1924 in Mannheim, Germany; immigrated to the US and fought for the Allies in WWII. Pioneer in the field of Point-of Purchase advertising, he was a partner in the Merchandising Display Corporation, then joined Henschel, Steinau, and was most recently an adjunct professor at the NYU Stern School of Business, retiring in June 2013. Loved by many, he will be missed. Services will be held Monday, December 2, 10am at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave.

PICOT--Jean-Paul, died suddenly on Sunday, November 24, 2013. He has been the owner and master chef of La Bonne Soupe on West 55th St. NYC for 38 years. The restaurant continues to serve the world's finest French Onion Soup. Rest in Peace. -Bernie Ilson

John was one of two Senior Credit Policy Executives reporting to The Vice Chairman and Top Credit Executive of The Chase Manhattan Bank as well as Senior Vice President in New York when he retired. His distinguished career at the Bank covered a span 37 years. He joined the Bank as a clerk in the Letter of Credit Department in 1946 and worked his way into the credit training program and from there to a number of senior roles in Commodity Finance, the Asia Pacific Area and then to head of Credit Policy for all areas of the International Department as well as the Credit Policy staff and credit policy issues bank wide. Friends may call Friday, November 29, 2013, 2-4pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street. Mass of Christian Burial Saturday, November 30, 10am, Church of our Saviour, Park Avenue at 37th Street.

NELSON--Otto E.,1908-2013. Otto Nelson, esteemed photographer of fine art, whose clients included the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Asia Society, Japan Society, the Sackler and Freer Museums, and the private collections of David Rockefeller, Mary Burke and Malcolm Forbes died peacefully on November 17, of natural causes. He was 105. Nelson was renowned for the intelligence and respect with which he captured the objects and people he recorded, and for the simple elegance of his photographs. Throughout his long career, his beloved wife Marguerite did the printing, and the feisty photographer and his ever-gracious, Alsatian partner charmed their clients, family and friends as both bohemian couple and team. Born in Freiburg, Germany in the tumultuous years preceding the first World War, Nelson's career was shaped by art school in Berlin and years in Paris, where he fled Hitler and met his wife, and by their narrow and difficult escape to Switzerland and emigration to the U.S. With the help of friends and relatives, they settled in New York and established Nelson's career as a professional photographer. Before cultivating his niche in Asian, Islamic, and Ancient western art, Nelson photographed for a number of private schools and labor unions. He also photographed contemporary art in the Sixties, working for the Betty Parsons, Emmerich and Sydney Janis galleries, and sustaining longer relationships with such artists as Karel Appel, Pierre Alechinsky, Wallase Ting and Nell Blaine. A lifelong dedicatee of classical music and opera, he also made a series of portraits of such luminaries as Nathan Milstein, Vladimir Horowitz, Toscanini, and the famed Spanish pianist, Alicia de la Rocha. A highlight of his career was an invitation in the late Sixties to photograph in the famed Topkapi palace, in a library untouched for hundreds of years. Nelson had no children. He is survived by his niece, Ruth Norden, her daughter, Linda, and grandchildren, Luke and Alec Joyner, and by extended family in the UK, France and Israel, all of whom will miss him dearly.

NEDLIN--Leonard. A great pal is gone. He leaves wonderful memories of laughter and friendship and his unique ability to turn the outrageous into pure joy. Our hearts go out to Radie, David, Wendy and Joey. We'll miss you buddy. Howard and Judy Steinberg

MARX--Nancy 66, of Old Brookville, NY passed away Nov 27 following a valiant fight against brain cancer. Loving and devoted wife to Harvey for 31 years. Daughter of the late Lila and Morton Savada. Sister-in-law to Joyce and the late Jeffrey Marx. Sister to Elias (Andrea) Savada and Alan (Will) Savada. Aunt to Danielle (Stephen), Eric, Samuel, Shira and Daniel. Great-aunt to Jorryn and Emery. Nancy was a wonderful woman and humanitarian. She was an accomplished equestrian and consummate animal lover. A competitive tennis, bridge and Mah Jongg player, and world traveler. She will be dearly missed by all the relatives, friends and animals she touched. Funeral services Sunday December 1, 2 PM, at I.J. Morris, 21 East Deer Park Rd, Dix Hills, NY 11746. Donations to the charity of your choice.

She is survived by her loving son Felipe Marrero of New York City and her beloved daughter Carmen Isabel Esposito and her grandchildren Joseph and Kenneth Esposito of Jackson, New Jersey.

CARDUCCI--Philip V.,85, of Brooklyn, NY. Proud Italian and modest man passed away peacefully in his family home on November 27th. ANTHONY--Mary Kathryn, "Polly" November 15, 1952 September 29, 2013. After a courageous fight, Polly lost her battle with pancreatic cancer. Polly passed away surrounded by her family and beloved French bulldogs, Reggie and Meg. Polly was born in Alexandria, Virginia and moved with her family to Dayton, Ohio, before spending her formative years on the Palos Verdes Peninsula, CA. Polly had a lifelong love affair with popular music. In 1974, she began a music industry career that spanned four decades. In Los Angeles, after working briefly at RCA Records and Management III, she joined what would become the Sony Music family at Epic Associated Labels as an assistant in 1978, moved to New York in 1988, and eventually became President of Epic Records in 1997, making her the first female in history to helm a major record label. She culminated her career at Sony in 2003, returning to Los Angeles to join the Universal Music Group as president of DreamWorks Records and later co-president of Geffen Records. In 2006, she became head of TV and film for UMG, transitioning into executive producer on film and TV projects. Since leaving UMG, she worked on TV, film and theatrical projects. Polly's love of and generosity toward her family, friends, relatives, colleagues and dogs was obvious to all who knew her. She possessed incredible style and talent, whether cooking and entertaining at her beautiful home, or in fashioning the perfect outfit for herself or others. She was an inspiration and a mentor to many; had tremendous curiosity and focus, and will be greatly missed. She was preceded in death by her father, Bernard J. Anthony, as well as her grandparents, William and Helen Anthony, and Theodore and Ethel Haley. She is survived by her mother, Patricia H. Anthony, of Rancho Palos Verdes, CA; sister, Carrie Kelley (Bobby) of Stevinson, CA; brother, Ted Anthony (Teresa) of Austin, TX; sister, Betsy Anthony-Brodey of Los Angeles; brother, B.J. Anthony (Elisa) of Hermosa Beach, CA; nieces and nephews, Danny and Alex Kelley, Lily and Quinn Brodey, and Delaney and Marley Anthony. A private Celebration of Life was recently held in Polly's honor. In lieu of flowers, her family requests that memorial donations be made for pancreatic cancer research to The Polly Anthony Memorial Fund at the City of Hope, 1500 E. Duarte Ave., Duarte, CA 91010 (www.cityofhope.org), 626-256-4673; and The Polly Anthony Memorial Fund at the Lustgarten Foundation, 1111 Stewart Ave., Bethpage, NY 11714 (www.lustgarten.org), 516-803-2304.cakelley360@yahoo.com

Beloved wife of Franklin Lookstein for 45 years, devoted mother of Robert and Thomas Lookstein, adoring mother-in-law of Danielle Bajakian and Jaimee Lookstein, and loving grandmother of Olivia, Charlotte, Jordan, and Emily Lookstein. Pioneer in Publicity and Public Relations. Founding Partner of Halston Inc: 1968. Public Relations Director Henri Bendel: 1970-1974. Owner and Manager, Joanne Creveling Public Relations: 1975 present. Clients included Angelo Donghia, Ralph Lauren, Winter Antiques Show, European Fine Art Fair, Grosvenor House Antiques Fair, Brunschwig & Fils, Gallerie Ariane Dandois, Chinese Porcelain Company, Vernay and Jussel, A La Veille Russie, Zandra Rhodes, Ossie Clark, Rizzoli, Christie's Auction House, Philips Auction House, British Khaki, Pinky and Diane, Mario Nievera, Newell Art Gallery, Ballyfin Demesne. The family summer cottage on Shelter Island was featured in numerous newspapers and magazines including The New York Times, British House & Garden, and House Beautiful. Service will be held Tuesday, December 3rd 3-7pm at Frank E Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in her memory to the Mount Sinai Dubin Breast Center. http://philanthropy.mountsinai.org/donate

LIFSHEY--Dr. Frederick Michael. To my most remarkable husband and best friend. Not enough time with you. I will love you always plus a day. And will continue, along with everyone whose lives you touched.. to dance down the mountain and walk through the sand with you, Fran. A Memorial Service will be held Wednesday, December 4th at 5pm at "The Riverside" 76th Street and Amsterdam Avenue.

KAMEN--Barbara, on November 28. Beloved wife of Harry P. Kamen. Mother of Hilary Leff, Karen Millman, and Robert Leff. Beloved grandmother and stepmother. Barbara was a retired Corporation Counsel of NYC working in the Queens Family Court, and an avid supporter of Democratic causes. After a private burial, the family will be sitting at home on Sunday and Monday evenings.

CHASAN--Evelyn Schulman, of New York City. A wonderful teacher by example of her daunting will, deep loyalty, great expectations. Much loved especially by Willie her husband of over seventy years, her children Joshua and Jonathan and their families and Amelia (Peaches) Sealey. Memorial service, Cedar Park, Paramus, Sunday, December 1, 10:30am. Contributions may be sent to Adult Learning Institute, Columbia-Greene Community College, Hudson, NY 12534.

BOSSINGER--Julia Irene, (Bass), 90, of Monroe TWP.,NJ on Friday, November 29th, 2103. Alumna of Hunter College. Mother of the late Fred Stein. Survived by brother Saul Bass and family, daughters: Deborah Staska and Stephanie Crease, six grandchildren, three great-grandchildren. Graveside service at Locust Valley Cemetery, NY, December 3 at 12:30pm.

BLUMENFELD--Beatrice, passed away November 19 just short of her 95th birthday. Born January 1, 1919, she lived life fully, married to her devoted husband Adrian. She was a skilled teacher who honed her craft into her 90's, and cut a fine figure attending concerts and traveling abroad. She will be deeply missed by her daughters Joan and Susan, their husbands Bob Krone and Philip Lisagor, grandchildren Robert, Max, Jessica and Sara, her many friends and colleagues who admired and loved her dearly.

BERTI--Albert J.,of Huntington, NY on November 28, 2013 in his 94th year. Beloved husband of Mary Vitelli Berti, and father of Paula Lake, Linda Bonforte, Dana Berti Cassillo, Andrea Hennessy, Peter Berti, Christopher Berti, Mary E. Berti, Martha Berti, and Monica Casazza as well as 21 grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren and his sister, Iris Scott Bangston. Mr. Berti was a proud veteran of WWII and a retired career officer of the US Treasury Department. Visitation Saturday 7pm-9pm and Sunday 2pm-4pm and 7pm-9pm at M.A. Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave., Huntington Station. Funeral Mass Monday 10:45am at St. Patrick's Church, Huntington. www.maconnellfuneralhome.com

BENENSON--Mark K.,84, of New York City and Port Murray New Jersey, died November 27 2013. He is survived by his son Alexander, his daughter Daniela Fifi, and was predeceased last year by his wife, artist Letizia Pitigliani. Mark, once called the only honest man by William F. Buckley Jr., was a life member of the National Rifle Association, a founder, general secretary and chairman of Amnesty International USA, special counsel to the Second Amendment Foundation, a genuine New Yorker, confirmed gun nut, labor lawyer, intellectual, bon vivant, and Krag Sporter expert. He was a good man and will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held in the spring. Memorial donations may be made to the American Custom Gunmakers Guild Education Foundation, Cody, WY.

VARIETY PUZZLE — SARAH VOWELL, who has one of the best names in the universe for a book with the word “WORDY” in the title, is an essayist and self-styled “social observer” who has been a contributing editor to NPR’s “This American Life.” She has also written a number of nonfiction books on American history and culture, although in many of them (including this one), she wanders off into anecdotes about her own life, politics and her apartment in New York City.

WITCOVER--Walt died November 15 at age 89. Received three battle stars (the Battle of North France, the Battle of Rhineland and the Battle of Austria) after serving in World War II as a Combat Field Artilleryman, then obtained his BA and MA from Cornell. His career as actor, director and teacher spanned more than 50 years: he directed in Lee Strasberg's Actors Studio Directors Unit after studying under Strasberg, where his production of Verdi's La Traviata won the Actors Studio Total Theatre Award. Walt also studied under Herbert Berghof and Curt Conway, and taught acting and directing at HB Studio for over 25 years. He later taught at the Stella Adler Studio, and was Professor of Theatre Arts at SUNY Purchase and in Baltimore. As co-founder and Artistic Director of Masterworks Laboratory Theatre, he staged over 30 productions of classic plays and operas, plus poetry, song and story-theatre projects. Three of his Off-Broadway productions won Obie Awards. Actors he taught or directed include Barbara Barrie, Robert Clohessy, Anne Meara and Jerry Stiller. The author of "Living on Stage: Acting from the Inside-Out: A Practical Process" in 2004, he also published "My Road, Less Traveled: Becoming an Actor, a Director, a Teacher" in 2011. Walt was predeceased by his partner of over 30 years, Richard Hughes, in 1996. Survivors include brother Tom Scheinman; sisters in law Bonnie and Evie; nieces Amy, Jessica, Joanne, Laurel and Peggy; grand-niece Liza, grand-nephews Griffin, Jackson, Koby, and Kyle; cousin Doug; his stage manager of 15 years Michael Stebbins; and by hundreds of students who carry on his theatre legacy. Memorial service to be held on March 22, 2014.

WEISS--Philis Babbit, 85, passed away peacefully on November 14, 2013 surrounded by her loving family and partner Stanley Gerla. Beloved mother of Michael, Larry and Peter, and mother-in-law of Carol, Juli and Gretha. Cherished Grammy of Drew, Brett, Meta, Aliya, Tallisker and Skyelar. Adored wife of the late Harold. Dear sister of the late Edna and Bebe. In lieu of flowers, Philis requested donations be made to the Lynn Cancer Institute of Boca Raton Regional Hospital (561) 479-4969.

WIENER--Sally Ann Dixon, of Manhattan and Aquinnah, died at her NY home on November 13th. Born in Burlington, Iowa on September 18, 1926 to George and Ellen Dixon. Sally attended Tucson High School and earned a degree in Journalism from the University of Arizona. Beginning with her "junior year abroad" at Barnard College, she loved New York City and after writing for dailies in the west she returned to work for several papers in New York. She wrote short stories under the name Samuel Devon Warner. She later studied piano and playwriting at the New School and wrote many musicals and plays which were produced at The Martha's Vineyard Playhouse and Off Off Broadway venues in New York. A member of The League of Professional Theatre Women, The Dramatists Guild, and The Writers Room, she wrote for the Dramatist's Guild Quarterly and The Best Plays of the Year series. Excellent linguist and fearless traveler, deft artist, endlessly patient mother, Sally was a woman of great humor and resilience. She was predeceased by her husband John A. Wiener and brother George L. Dixon. Sally will be missed, every day, by her children John Wiener, Ellen Wiener, and Ann Stodder; brother-in-law Geoffrey Wiener; companion Van Rogers; grandchildren Sophia, Emma, Claire and Samuel; by Michael and Andrew Wiener and many other nephews and nieces, and by her friends in New York and on the Vineyard. Service at 3pm, December 20. Church of the Ascension, 12 West 11th St., New York.

WEINBERG--Sue, (nee Fried), 81, died at her home in Englewood on November 23, 2013 surrounded by her loving family. Born and raised in Brooklyn, NY, she lived in Alpine, NJ for 34 years before moving to Scottsdale, AZ in 1989 and Englewood, NJ six years ago. She was a member of the Montammy Golf Club for 48 years and was also a member of the Boulders Golf Club in Scottsdale, AZ. Beloved wife of Herman Weinberg; loving mother of Patricia and Scott Frances of New York, NY and Eric and Hilary Weinberg of Los Angeles, CA; devoted grandmother of Benjamin, Julian, and Lulu; cherished sister of Bernard and Joan Fried of Santa Barbara, CA and Beverly Antis of Lincoln Park, NJ. She was loved by everyone she touched and will be missed by all. Memorial donations may be made in Mrs. Weinberg's memory to the charity of your choice.

WATERSTON--Nat, 95. Wordsmith; ballroom dancer; bridge and chess player; and all-around funny, thoughtful, and loving man. Nat was a former business administrator for Wells Rich Green and Doyle Dane Bernbach. He will be greatly missed.

SUTHERLAND--Glynda, 82, longtime resident of the city she loved. Fordham graduate. Daughter Krystal and beloved son-in-law Danny, missing you sweet lady. December 5 at 1:00, Immanuel, 88th St. and Lexington.

STERN--Ralph Warner, on November 27, 2013, New York, NY. Dearest husband of the late Joan Strauss Stern; beloved companion of Arlene Stern, father to Laurie Stern-Kluger and her husband Michael Kluger, and Paul Stern and his wife Denise in Jacksonville, FL; stepfather to Roberta Stern. Born December 5, 1924 in Mannheim, Germany; immigrated to the US and fought for the Allies in WWII. Pioneer in the field of Point-of Purchase advertising, he was a partner in the Merchandising Display Corporation, then joined Henschel, Steinau, and was most recently an adjunct professor at the NYU Stern School of Business, retiring in June 2013. Loved by many, he will be missed. Services will be held Monday, December 2, 10am at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave.

STEINER--Marilyn, age 87, of Westport, CT on Friday, November 22, 2013. Beloved wife of Monroe who passed away in 2009; devoted mother of Amy and Richard Schafrann, and Cindy and Leo Asen; adored sister of Helen and Robert Fried; grandmother of Dan (Rachel), Allie, Pam and Sara, and aunt of Patti Seymour and Pam Fox Joravsky. A devoted, gracious and stylish Nana who loved her "mountain," her family, Westport and Compo Beach. STARFIELD--Richard Livingston, 85, of Sarasota, FL, formerly of NYC, died on November 23, 2013.

SILVERMAN--Gloria Tobias, 76. Died peacefully at home on November 26th. Devoted mother of Jeffrey (Susan). Beloved grandmother of Samuel, Adam and Jeremy. Loving daughter of the late Samuel and Florence Tobias. Cherished friend and colleague of all who knew her. Services held by Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, (212) 769-4400.

SHULTZ--Cecile, passed away peacefully at home in New York, November 23, 2013. Born January 20, 1922, during a long full and happy life she bore witness to the Great Depression, World War II (which claimed her beloved brother Martin Unger), the changing role of women in the home and workplace, and advances in technology, which she embraced. A graduate of the Julia Richman Country School and Hunter College, class of 1942, Cecile was married for over 56 years to the late Abraham, and was the mother of Ellen and Stuart (Cherida) and grandmother of Oliver and Simon, whom she treasured. A person of considerable significance and talents, she was always available to others whether in her supervisory position at the New York State Employment Service or as a source of love, guidance and support to her family and many friends, all of whom will miss her terribly.

SEIXAS--Donald H.,91, of New York passed away peacefully at Mt. Sinai Hospice Center on November 29th. He served in the U.S. Army, received a law degree from New York University and was in the printing ink business. After retiring he received a Masters in Art History from NYU Institute of Fine Arts and had a gallery on Madison Avenue for several years. He will be greatly missed by his wife Lilyan, his children Vicky and David, his stepchildren Ken, Lisa and Mark, and seven grandchildren. Services at Riverside Chapel Sunday 11am.

SALVATORELLI--Louis, died November 7, 2013. Dad lived 65 years in his honeymoon apartment on Briggs Avenue in the Bronx. After he was widowed in 1980, he was seldom seen without a pretty lady on his arm. Born in an Italian tenement in Harlem, he carried coal up three flights and could have been a contender. See Dad in his muscle t-shirt at www.Dadadad.com/ He was a welder in the Brooklyn Navy Yard during WWII, later a bookbinder, a union man at Blumberg, where Dad produced faster, and with higher quality than the machines. On vacation through the South he ignored warnings not to buy gas from black station owners saying, "everyone's gotta make a living." I'd play piano and he'd be up dancing around the room. Dad was always for the underdog, a good man, who scoffed at pretension. In retirement, he loved driving St. Philip Neri parishioners to the senior center, to doctors and the airport. After moving into the Amsterdam House he became addicted to reduced fat Nilla wafers consuming about a box a day. He was proud of his son Louis, a NYC cop, and his daughter Geraldine, who worked in executive offices at NBC, who is writing a book about the shock of caring for aging parents and is publishing, "A Catholic Girl Leaves Home for Sex." He is survived by his son, daughter, daughter-in-law, three grandchildren, and three great-grandchildren.

SABLE--Dr. Jack. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home at Riverdale deeply mourn the loss of Rabbi Jack Sable. Jack was a great American who devoted his life to public service as well as Jewish causes. He lived each day to perform mitzvahs and was a teacher in words and deeds. Jack was a treasured friend of the Hebrew Home for decades. The world is a better place because of Rabbi Jack Sable. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Daniel Reingold, President & CEO

ROSENBERG--Allan Douglas, of Tuckahoe, New York died on November 27, 2013 at age 75. He is survived by his wife of 50 years Ellen Bukanz Rosenberg, daughters Elise Rosenberg and Gail Deutsch, son-in-law Gary Deutsch, grandsons Henry and Simon Deutsch, brother David Rosenberg and sister Doris Fleishman. His family celebrates his wonderful life and requests, in lieu of flowers, donations may be made in his memory to The Lustgarten Foundation, 1111 Stewart Avenue, Bethpage, NY 11714.

RAFF--Ruth, passed away peacefully at 90 on November 14, 2013, only a few months after her husband of 65 years, Emanuel. Survived by her sons and daughters-in-law Joshua Raff and Michele Fillion and Hershel and Judy Raff and her grandchildren, Jonathan Raff, and Simone, Camille and Luc Fillion-Raff. Ruth was a scientist, an avid reader, an expert gardener and an accomplished conversationalist and story-teller. She particularly loved to describe her life growing up in the Bronx, with little money but with an adventuresome spirit. She and Manny were passionate about theater, dance, music and art and loved to travel together. Ruth had an inquiring mind and strongly-held beliefs. After graduating from Hunter College, she earned a graduate degree in microbiology from the University of Wisconsin. Ruth was for many years a biology teacher at West Hempstead High School. She was a long-time member and one of the founders of the local branch of the Workmen's Circle. After her retirement, she was an active and effective volunteer in the community, including for many years in a laboratory at Winthrop Hospital. Per her wishes, no services were held. She was an inspiration to many and will be greatly missed.

RESNICK--Seymour. Beloved husband of Roberta. Loving father of Michael and Debbie, Lori and Bruce Dubinsky. Cherished grandfather of Jessica (Matthew Grossman), Andrea and David Resnick, Matthew and Brian Dubinsky. Devoted husband of the late Marian. He had a warm and caring relationship with Roberta's parents, her children, Richard, David and Julie, her grandchildren Matthew and Rachel. Sy was a member of numerous fraternal and industry organizations. A licensed Funeral Director since 1957, he was the Founder and Chairman of Sinai Chapels in Fresh Meadows, (Queens), NY. A kind, caring and gentle person who will be missed by all whose lives he touched. Sy's was a life well lived. Services Sunday 2pm at "Sinai Chapels" 162-05 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows, NY.

POHL--Elinor, 88, of Larchmont, NY, passed away on November 24, 2013. Born in Larchmont, on September 21, 1925, Elinor graduated from Mamaroneck High School and continued on to earn an Associate's Degree from Boston University. She devoted her life to caring for her family and enjoying her many friends and other interests. Elinor traveled throughout the world, worked with a number of companies and organizations and loved playing bridge and Maj Jong. She was committed to volunteering with community organizations, including the Neuberger Museum of Art and Women In Self Help (WISH), Westchester, Inc., an organization dedicated to helping women with problems help themselves. Elinor was predeceased by her husband, Henry Pohl, to whom she was married for fifty years and for whom she lovingly cared for at home during his long bout with Alzheimer's disease. She is survived by her brother, Robert Englebardt, her son Jeffrey Pohl (Mara) and her daughters Cathy Lee (David) and Alice Bruhl (Christopher), and her six beloved grandchildren, Barbara Pohl, Emily Bruhl, Rachel Lee, Martin Pohl, Matthew Lee, and Sarah Bruhl. Her grandchildren were among her proudest accomplishments. Funeral Services will be for the immediate family. In lieu of flowers, please make a donation to a charity of your choice.

O'CONNOR--Elisabeth Hopkinson, 88, a longtime resident of both New York City and Sheffield, MA, died November 22 after a short illness. Miss O'Connor was born in New York City February 6, 1925, the youngest daughter of Francis Barnard and Gabriella Gilpin O'Connor. She attended and graduated from the Chapin School in New York City and then from Barnard College, which was named for Frederick Barnard, her paternal great grand uncle, who was born and is buried in Sheffield. During a long working career that lasted until 2006, Miss O'Connor was employed mostly in the fields of public relations, fund raising and planned giving. In the 1950s, she worked as an editorial assistant, in succession, at Town and Country Magazine in New York, Realities Magazine in Paris, France, and Gourmet Magazine in New York. During her time in France, she also worked as an editorial assistant to the late Ludwig Bemelmans, remembered primarily as the author and illustrator of the "Madeline" series of children's stories. In the 1960s, she was employed in public-relations work and then, in 1970, became director of development for Girls Clubs of America and subsequently the Freedom from Hunger Foundation. From 1987 until 2006, she served as planned-giving officer for the national board of the YWCA and as director of trusts and estates for the Planned Parenthood Federation of America. She also held, in succession, all executive offices of the Planned Giving Group of New York and was a founding member of the Women in Financial Development organization. In Sheffield, she was a longtime and active member of the board of the Sheffield Land Trust and the finance committee, a member of the Sheffield Historical Society and of Christ Church, Episcopal. She was a passionate golf and tennis player until last month and an enthusiastic traveler. Her parents and three older sisters, Anne Fulton, Emily Fowler, and Frances Havemeyer predeceased her. A memorial service will be held Monday at 12 noon at Christ Episcopal and Trinity Lutheran Church, 180 Main Street in Sheffield, MA. In lieu of flowers the family suggests memorial donations may be made to The Sheffield Land Trust, 404 Legyt Rd., Sheffield, 01257, www.sheffieldland.org or Planned Parenthood, 434 West 33rd St., NY, NY 1001, www.plannedparenthood.org.

NELSON--Otto E.,1908-2013. Otto Nelson, esteemed photographer of fine art, whose clients included the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Asia Society, Japan Society, the Sackler and Freer Museums, and the private collections of David Rockefeller, Mary Burke and Malcolm Forbes died peacefully on November 17, of natural causes. He was 105. Nelson was renowned for the intelligence and respect with which he captured the objects and people he recorded, and for the simple elegance of his photographs. Throughout his long career, his beloved wife Marguerite did the printing, and the feisty photographer and his ever-gracious, Alsatian partner charmed their clients, family and friends as both bohemian couple and team. Born in Freiburg, Germany in the tumultuous years preceding the first World War, Nelson's career was shaped by art school in Berlin and years in Paris, where he fled Hitler and met his wife, and by their narrow and difficult escape to Switzerland and emigration to the U.S. With the help of friends and relatives, they settled in New York and established Nelson's career as a professional photographer. Before cultivating his niche in Asian, Islamic, and Ancient western art, Nelson photographed for a number of private schools and labor unions. He also photographed contemporary art in the Sixties, working for the Betty Parsons, Emmerich and Sydney Janis galleries, and sustaining longer relationships with such artists as Karel Appel, Pierre Alechinsky, Wallase Ting and Nell Blaine. A lifelong dedicatee of classical music and opera, he also made a series of portraits of such luminaries as Nathan Milstein, Vladimir Horowitz, Toscanini, and the famed Spanish pianist, Alicia de la Rocha. A highlight of his career was an invitation in the late Sixties to photograph in the famed Topkapi palace, in a library untouched for hundreds of years. Nelson had no children. He is survived by his niece, Ruth Norden, her daughter, Linda, and grandchildren, Luke and Alec Joyner, and by extended family in the UK, France and Israel, all of whom will miss him dearly.

MUSANTE--Tony, film, television and theatre actor died November 26, 2013 at Lenox Hill Hospital due to complications following surgery. Beloved husband of Jane Sparkes Musante, married June 2, 1962 in Manhattan. Visitation at Greenwich Village Funeral Home, 199 Bleecker Street, on Monday, December 2nd from 2-5 and 7-9 pm. Mass at Our Lady of Pompeii Church, 25 Carmine Street, Manhattan on Tuesday, December 3rd at 10:30 am. Interment will be held on Wednesday at Island Cemetery, Block Island, RI. Online condolences: greenwichvillagefuneralhome.com

MEHRAN--Masud, passed away November 26th after a short illness at his home in Atherton, California-- surrounded, as he was during his life, by his family. Masud was born in Tehran February 6, 1920 and attended the American College in Tehran. At the age of 22 he married Maryam Ansari, and they immigrated to New York two years later. There, Masud attended Columbia University and Cornell University, from which he graduated with a degree in Agricultural Economics in 1946. Curious to explore their newly adopted country, Masud and Maryam traveled to each of the then 48 states, finally settling in the Montclair neighborhood of Oakland. Eager to contribute to the dynamic growth of post-war California, Masud founded the Sunset Development Company in 1951 and began building homes in the city of Livermore-- eventually developing SunsetTown, one of the largest and most successful residential real estate projects in the San Francisco Bay Area. In 1978, Masud expanded Sunset's properties by purchasing a 585 acre portion of the Bishop Ranch in San Ramon. Over the next 35 years he transformed an orchard into a vibrant business community comprising more than 10 million square feet of world-class office space and facilities. Masud was active in a variety of industry and community organizations with far reaching benefits for the entire San Francisco Bay Region. These include The Urban Land Institute, Golden Gate University, Oakland's Children's Hospital, The Boy Scouts of America, and countless others. After his divorce from Maryam in 1978, Masud married Farideh Eshragi in 1987. The couple had homes in Atherton, San Francisco and Lake Tahoe, where they regularly entertained and enjoyed being with their family and friends. Masud had four children with his first wife, Houri, Casey, Susan and Alex. Three of the four--Houri, Casey and Susan--preceded him in death. Masud had seven grandchildren Diana, Mark, Rawley, Peter and Lacey by his son Casey; and Annabel and Alexander Jr. by his son Alex. He also leaves a stepdaughter, Sharmin Bock and her two children, Fiona and Alastair, and a step-granddaughter, Christina Kew. All who knew Masud Mehran will be forever reminded of the example he gave to so many, and values that guided his life, which will keep his legacy alive forever. A service to celebrate Masud's life will be held on Friday, December 6, at 4:00pm at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco. In lieu of flowers, a donation in Masud's name can be made to the Persian Center at University of California, Berkeley, the Contra Costa Food Bank, Cornell University, or the Urban Land Institute Foundation.

MARX--Nancy. It is with profound sadness that we mourn the passing of Harvey's beloved wife Nancy. She was a brilliant woman, an accomplished equestrian, an animal lover, an avid bridge and tennis player, a charitable humanitarian, a loving wife and our special friend. Our deepest condolences. Your loving friends and co-workers, Aileen and Alvin Murstein and the East Hills Team

MANUS--Janet Wilkens, died peacefully on November 21st, 2013. A memorial service will be held on Friday, December 6th at 4:30pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel (Madison Avenue and 81st Street). Memorial contributions may be made to The Authors League Fund.

MANSON--Florence Sando, A pioneering woman newscaster in radio and the early years of television journalism who hosted Pittsburgh's TV Show "The Florence Manson Show," died on November 25, 2013 at her home in Riverdale, New York at age 95 from complications related to dementia. Florence was born in 1918 and she graduated from Westminster College in 1939 and received her Master's Degree in Drama from Case Western Reserve the following year. Florence broke out of the usual confines of gossip and fashion coverage that women broadcasters were relegated to, spending 18 years as a popular on air Pittsburghbased personality. In her era when women broadcasters were usually expected to keep their shows light and frothy, Florence Sando tackled the leading hard news of the day in a career that ran from 1941 to 1959. Longtime viewers of Pittsburgh TV stations with signals that broadcast up and down the East Coast and into the Midwest would remember her for "The Florence Manson Show," which featured her as a host-interviewer, a pioneering use of that format. She interviewed well known public figures such as Eleanor Roosevelt (on radio) as well as celebrities on tv such as Danny Kaye and Louis Armstrong. Some of these interviews are available at the Museum of Broadcasting in New York. She also produced the earlier hard news breakthrough "Women's Angle" a 15 minute morning broadcast. Sando's "Women's Angle" spoke to women as adults, presenting news of the world, rather than the low-brow mix of fashion and decorating tips dished out to female audiences until then. "It was easy when the news was about Madame Chiang Kai-shek, or the ten bestdressed women, or Mrs. Roosevelt or Senator Margaret Chase Smith..." Sando told author and educator and former broadcaster Lynn Boyd Hinds in "Broadcasting the Local News- The Early Years of Pittsburgh's KDKA-TV." She was so popular with the Pittsburgh area audience that KDKA-TV asked her in 1957 to host "The Florence Manson Show," now using her married name after her wedding to film executive Arthur Manson. Her tv shows were always committed to public service as well as entertainment. She cooperated with government, civic, social and cultural agencies in support of the war effort during World War II and presented stories and interviews which contributed to Pittsburgh's post war development. The show had a successful run until Florence and Arthur moved to New York in 1959. Mrs. Manson remained active in theater and community affairs in New York City. She was a member of the Board of Ensemble Studio Theatre. She also served as a member of the Board of Riverdale Neighborhood House as well as serving as an Elder of the Riverdale Presbyterian Church. Florence is survived by her husband, Arthur, her daughter Cynthia Ann and son-in-law Jeffrey Faville, and their children James and Catherine and her son Anthony, her daughter-in-law Angela and their children, Daniel, William and Timothy. A memorial service will be held at the Riverdale Presbyterian Church on December 7th at 11:00am. Please send donations to The Riverdale Presbyterian Church at 4765 Henry Hudson Parkway West. Bronx, NY 10471.

The family summer cottage on Shelter Island was featured in numerous newspapers and magazines including The New York Times, British House & Garden, and House Beautiful. LONGLEY--Marjorie Watters, of NYC, passed away peacefully in her sleep November 17, 2013. She was 88. A trailblazer for women, Marjorie ("Midge") held several executive posts during her 40 year career at The New York Times, retiring in 1988. She worked tirelessly to improve literacy and education, establishing two scholarships and supporting the construction of a media student center at her beloved alma mater, St Lawrence University. She loved to travel and was a patron of the arts. She ran the NYC marathon on her 60th birthday before jumping on a plane to Budapest. Midge will be missed by her nieces, nephews and longtime friends.

GREENBERG--Sema Ann Tanzer, 86, died after a long illness on November 22, 2013. We will miss her warm generous spirit, passion for life, and above all, her unconditional love for her children - the late Josiah Greenberg, Sarah Greenberg, David Greenberg and Ezra Greenberg. Sema is also survived by her sister Miriam McKenzie and three grandchildren, Samuel Greenberg, Jessica Greenberg and Julia Greenberg. She cared deeply about Israel and the Jewish people, her first job being with an Israeli Shipping Company in New York City. Subsequently she worked for the Jewish Theological Seminary and American Jewish Committee. Her zeal for social causes was not just relegated to Zionism, and as a young woman growing up in segregated Wilmington, DE, she joined the NAACP. She married, in 1950, Jack Greenberg, a man who worked for the NAACP Legal Defense Fund, and fully encouraged him in his work. They had four children together. We will miss her deeply and always love and cherish her memory.

GRAY--Gareld Rex, II, affectionately known as "Doc", passed away on September 20, 2013 at the New York Presbyterian Hospital from complications after receiving a stem cell transplant. Doc was born on August 16, 1944 in Fargo, North Dakota. He graduated from The University of Pennsylvania and Columbia Business School. Doc went on to have a long and prosperous career in the leasing field, and he was a mentor to many. He was the managing director of Bank of America Institutional Leasing for the last 22 years. Doc also served in the Army during the Vietnam War. Doc was an avid boater, and he enjoyed many memorable trips on The Lady Libby with friends and family. Doc's quick wit, charisma, and kind heart made him admired and loved by all those he encountered. Doc is survived by his wife of 42 years, Judith Hunt Gray, his daughter Elizabeth Gray Whiton, his son Gardiner Trent Gray, his brother Stephen Peter Gray, and his sister Elizabeth Alice Gray. Doc was a remarkable husband, father, friend, and mentor, and he will be profoundly missed. A celebration of Doc's life will be held in the early spring of 2014. Anyone who wishes to correspond, can do so at grgray2@gmail.com

FRIEDMAN--Sue, age 79 of Bedford, New York passed away peacefully in her home on November 26, 2013 surrounded by her family. Adored grandmother of Maxwell (Erin), Justin, Kyle, Spencer, Evan, Oliver and Jacob. An extraordinary woman, she will be deeply missed by her family and others for her exceptional compassion, generosity, elegance, grace, intelligence, wit, love of literature and culture, and eternal strength. FRENCH--Carolyn S.,86, died with dignity on November 16, 2013. Educated at Vassar and UC Berkeley, she received a PhD in English Literature at Stanford University. Her doctoral dissertation on King Lear was performed at the Ashland Shakespeare Festival. Born in San Francisco, she traveled all over the world. In the Shah's Iran, she taught co-ed English classes. In England, she co-translated the untranslatable "Trans-Atlantyk" by Witold Gombrowicz with "breathtaking ingenuity" according to The New York Times Book Review. At age 72, she became a literary agent at Fifi Oscard Agency in New York City while she discovered and then nurtured Margaret Edson's play "Wit" towards the 1999 Pulitzer Prize and the HBO movie directed by Mike Nichols with Emma Thompson. Formerly married to James M. French, she is survived by their daughter, Gay French-Ottaviani and son-in-law, Lorenzo Ottaviani of Pound Ridge, NY. Her life will be celebrated in a memorial to be held in March in New York City.

FRANK--Robert Bloch. 86, passed away on November 24, 2013. Beloved husband of 58 years to the late Patricia Nover Frank. Loving father to Priscilla (Leonard) Adler and Karen "Kiki" (Howard) Kelrick and grandfather to Leslie Adler and Jamie Adler (Michael Weiner), Allison Kelrick Labovitz (Andrew) and Scott Kelrick (Michelle). Robert was raised in Larchmont, NY and graduated from Mamaroneck High School (1944), Dartmouth College (1947), and University of Michigan Law (1950). A former resident of Rye and Scarsdale, NY, London, England, and a resident of Boca Raton, FL since 1988. Robert was a lawyer and financial executive who worked at C.I.T., PepsiCo, and Concord International, an international leasing company of which he was the founding President.

DUNCAN--Dorothy, beloved mother of Shaun, Amy, and Jed died peacefully November 17. Memorial December 7, 11am at Sherman Church Fellowship Hall, 6 Church Rd, Sherman, CT. She filled us with love and laughter, and will be greatly missed.

DOUGLAS--Spencer, 95, of Boca Raton, FL, died November 22nd with his beloved partner Loretta Jungreis at his side. Born in 1918 to Sara and Dr. Louis Dlugasch. DIAMOND--Raphael. Friday, November 29, marked the passing of Raphael Diamond, devoted husband, caring father, doting grandfather, and beloved former director of Camp Lokanda. Ray is survived by his wife, Linda, his children Bonnie Diamond, Joan Diamond, Susan DiCicco, Jayne Drucker, Michael Drucker, his sons-in-law Daniel Price and James DiCicco, daughter-in-law Maria Drucker, and his wonderful grandchildren Jake, Dylan, Elizabeth, and Antoine. Ray Diamond will long be remembered as the Director of Camp Lokanda. Ray will also be equally remembered by his devoted staff who shared his dream and worked so hard to breathe life into "The Lokanda Way," the set of principles that guided everyone's interactions at camp. Services will be held at Star of David Memorial Chapels, 1236 Wellwood Ave. in West Babylon on Sunday, December 1 at noon For more info go to: jewish-funeral-home.com

COLLIER--Lois Miller, Born January 20, 1929. Died November 10, 2013. Friend, wife, and 56 year partner of Reginald B. (Reg) Collier (deceased, September, 2004). Mother of Mark D. (Sarah K.) Collier and Brynn Collier Helms. Grandmother of Zachary and Sarah E. Collier, and Kaleigh and Michael Jr. Helms. Graduate of Bryn Mawr College, 1950, Cum Laude.
