CANFIELD--Cass Jr.,distinguished book publisher and editor, and dear husband, father, grandfather, friend and mentor, died peacefully on July 30th at his home in Manhattan. He was 90. He was born in New York City on May 4th, 1923, the eldest son of Katharine Temple Emmet and Augustus Cass Canfield. He graduated from St. Bernard's and St. Mark's schools and attended the University of Chicago prior to enlisting in the Army in 1943, where he served in the Signal Corps in the Pacific until the end of World War II. After military service he followed his father's footsteps into the book business, initially taking a job as a salesman in the Doubleday bookstore in Grand Central Station. After holding publishing positions at McGraw Hill and Coward, McCann, he joined what was then Harper and Brothers in the mid-1950s. He rose quickly to head the high-growth trade paperback department in the 1960's, and occupied several other management roles, including vice president and publisher of the paperback, religious and medical divisions. He served on the company's board of directors from 1967 to 1987. In his long career he was known for publishing books of quality and lasting influence. With the help of his colleague Hugh Van Dusen, he initiated Colophon Books and reorganized and developed the Perennial line of paperbacks. He also created the Icon Editions imprint, a line of accessible academic art history titles in paperback. He was responsible for bringing a number of distinguished Latin American authors into English translation for the first time, including Guillermo Cabrera Infante, Julio Cortazar, Reinaldo Arenas, Joao Ubaldo Ribeiro, Alvaro Mutis, and Ilan Stavans, as well as Nobel Prize winners Gabriel Garcia Marquez and Mario Vargas Llosa. Among the many authors he worked with were Peter F. Drucker, Craig Claiborne, Hugh Thomas, Enrique Krauze, Otto Friedrich, Paul Johnson, and art historians Robert Rosenbloom, Laurie Schneider Adams, Irving Sandler, and Bruce Cole. He adored his family, and considered his six children as his greatest life accomplishment. He plunged with joy into sailing, skiing and large dinners with his family at home, taking great pride in his roasts, risottos, and his famous boiled dinner with green sauce. He was proud of his Irish American heritage, taking his family to Ireland in 1998 for the 200th anniversary of the rebellion of the United Irishmen, in which his ancestor Thomas Addis Emmet (an Attorney General of New York State, and prominent lawyer in the Jeffersonian period) was a main participant. He is survived by his wife of 40 years, Abigail Angell Canfield, his sons Thomas, Temple, Lewis, Michael and Nicholas Canfield, daughter Susannah Canfield Hurd, granddaughters Juliana and Sophie Canfield and Ellory Hurd, grandsons Samuel Canfield and Ethan Hurd, daughter-in-law Danielle Parris, son-in-law Stephen Hurd, and dear step-sister Isabel Fuller Fox. His brother Michael Temple Canfield died in 1967. A memorial celebration will be held on Saturday, December 14th at the Lotos Club in New York at 5:00pm.

BRAUNSTEIN--Sumner, 86, on November 16, 2013. Loving husband of thirty-eight-years to Gail, devoted father to Harry, caring father-in-law to Jennifer, adoring grandfather to Lucas and Abraham, he will be greatly missed by family and friends. Sumner was a life-long learner and teacher, having graduated from Erasmus Hall High School, Brooklyn College and Columbia University. After a 27.8 year career as a New York City public school teacher, he "retired", but continued to work as a writer, consultant, curriculum developer and teacher-- including educating student teachers at Barnard College. In addition to his loving family, he nurtured enduring friendships with a coterie of companions poets, artists, jurists, scientist, workers who enjoyed the warmth of his generosity of spirit, his wit and his extraordinary sense of humor. Sumner is buried in Sag Harbor. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Doctors Without Borders in his memory.

BLUMENFELD--Beatrice, passed away November 19 just short of her 95th birthday. Born January 1, 1919, she lived life fully, married to her devoted husband Adrian. She was a skilled teacher who honed her craft into her 90's, and cut a fine figure attending concerts and traveling abroad. She will be deeply missed by her daughters Joan and Susan, their husbands Bob Krone and Philip Lisagor, grandchildren Robert, Max, Jessica and Sara, her many friends and colleagues who admired and loved her dearly.

BISSELL--Elliston Perot III. Pete passed away peacefully on the evening of November 19, 2013 in Chatham, New Jersey. Pete was well known and loved by many and lived a rich and rewarding life. The son of Elliston Perot Bissell, Jr. and Ann Packard Bissell, Pete was born In Jamaica Queens New York on May 26th, 1935. He spent his early years in Morristown, New Jersey and Haverford, Pennsylvania. He attended the Episcopal School in Philadelphia and graduated from St. Paul's School in Concord, New Hampshire in 1953. Pete attended Harvard College, where he majored in Biochemical Sciences. While at Harvard he was a member of the Hasty Pudding, Lampoon, and President of the Phoenix-S.K. After graduating from Harvard in 1957, Pete joined the US Navy as a junior lieutenant. He was married to Edith (Edie) Mabelle Roach of Newtown Square, Pennsylvania in March 1958. Pete and Edie spent the early years of their marriage in Japan while he was stationed at the Yokosuka Naval base attached to a naval intelligence unit. After his discharge from active duty in 1961, Pete continued to serve in the Naval Reserves for 30 years and retired with the rank of Commander. Following his return to Philadelphia in 1961, Pete went to work for Pennsylvania Bell. Pete had a long and distinguished career at AT&T and its predecessor companies including vice president of Diamond State Telephone Company, working in AT&T's international division, and finally serving in AT&T's global strategy group. His career took him to many interesting places including living in Egypt from 1982 to 1984. He also gained recognition through obtaining two patents for proprietary telecommunication devices. Pete retired in from AT&T in 1997. In addition to his work, Pete played a very active role in numerous community organizations including the Kiwanis in Norristown, Pennsylvania, the Rotary Club of Wilmington, Delaware (serving as President in 1981), the Opportunity Center, Inc (a group that seek to educate and help the disabled), and the Urban League of Wilmington. Pete will be remembered fondly by the many lives he touched. He was always willing to lend a helping hand or provide sage advice. Pete had many hobbies gardening, HO Gage trains, model building, furniture making, bridge, military history, fine wine collecting, and painting lead soldiers. An avid golfer, he was a member of the Merion Golf Club, Pine Valley Golf Club, and the Morris County Golf Club. He was also a member of the Morristown Club. Pete was well known as a bon-vivant and a humorous raconteur! After nearly 40 years of happy marriage, Edie passed away. Pete was very lucky and fortunate to fall in love with and in 1999 marry Elizabeth (Betty) Lee Cutler. Pete and Betty had a wonderful time together and spending time with their 13 grandchildren. For many years they spent their winters in Albufeira, Portugal and summers at Fossil Hill Farm in Morristown, New Jersey. In these years Pete and Betty continued to explore the four corners of the earth and hone their prodigious bridge skills. Pete is survived by Betty, his three children Elliston Perot Bissell IV, Rolin Plumb Bissell, and Ann Packard Bissell, and five grandchildren Elliston Perot Bissell V, Ulysses Duncan Lighthill Bissell, Samuel Randolph Bissell, Tilden Avery Bissell, and Helen Packard Bissell. A remembrance service and burial will be held at Old Saint David's Church 763 Valley Forge Rd, Wayne, PA on Saturday, November 30, 2012 at 11:00 am with a reception to follow at The Merion Golf Club 450 Ardmore Avenue, Ardmore. The family has asked that in lieu of flowers contributions be made to The Alzheimer's Foundation of America 822 Eighth Ave., 7th fl., New York, NY 10001. Services by Wm. A. Bradley & Son Funeral Home, Chatham. For additional information or to leave the family a message of condolence, go to bradleyfuneralhomes.com.

BICKLEY--Ervin Felton Jr.,92, Redding, CT on November 26, 2013. Survived by his wife Edith, daughters Lynn, Ann, and Jean, five grandsons, two great-grandchildren. Chairman of the Board/CEO New England Envelope Manufacturing Company, Worcester, MA 1969-1999, Trustee Emeritus, Drexel University, Philadelphia, PA, WWII Veteran, beloved husband and father. Memorial Service December 7, at 11:00am, Congregational Church, 23 Park Street, New Canaan, CT. In lieu of flowers, donations to: Drexel University, Attn: David J. Toll, Office of Institutional Advancement, Drexel University 3141 Chestnut Street, Suite 310, Philadelphia, PA 19104 Notation: Ervin F. Bickley, Jr. Endowed Scholarship Fund, College of Engineering. For online condolences and directions please visit: www.hoytfuneralhome.com

BERTI--Albert J.,of Huntington, NY on November 28, 2013 in his 94th year. Beloved husband of Mary Vitelli Berti, and father of Paula Lake, Linda Bonforte, Dana Berti Cassillo, Andrea Hennessy, Peter Berti, Christopher Berti, Mary E. Berti, Martha Berti, and Monica Casazza as well as 21 grandchildren, and five great-grandchildren and his sister, Iris Scott Bangston. Mr. Berti was a proud veteran of WWII and a retired career officer of the US Treasury Department. Visitation Saturday 7pm-9pm and Sunday 2pm-4pm and 7pm-9pm at M.A. Connell Funeral Home, 934 New York Ave., Huntington Station. Funeral Mass Monday 10:45am at St. Patrick's Church, Huntington. www.maconnellfuneralhome.com

BERG--Ceil "Gloria," of Tappan, NY passed away Thursday, October 10, 2013 at age 79. She was born November 27, 1933 in Brooklyn, NY to the late Joseph and Esther Grashow. She was a graduate of Midwood High School and City College of New York. She worked for the American Red Cross, as a school teacher for the New York City Board of Education in Brooklyn and later in her family's business, Quick Mount Mfg. Co., Inc. Gloria moved with her husband and children to Tappan, NY in 1969 where she raised her family and became an active participant in the community. She was a member of the Orangetown Jewish Center for more than 40 years. The warmth and generosity Gloria brought to her many remarkable friendships and family relationships endure. Gloria is survived by her beloved husband Melvin, cherished children Victor (Deborah) and William (Elizabeth), adoring grandchildren Joshua, Hannah, Noah and Eli, and her brother Stanley. Memorial contributions may be made in Gloria's memory to the Lustgarten Foundation (seeking a cure for pancreatic cancer) at Lustgarten.org or 1111 Stewart Ave., Bethpage, NY 11714; 866-789-1000.

BENENSON--Mark K.,84, of New York City and Port Murray New Jersey, died November 27 2013. He is survived by his son Alexander, his daughter Daniela Fifi, and was predeceased last year by his wife, artist Letizia Pitigliani. Mark, once called the only honest man by William F. Buckley Jr., was a life member of the National Rifle Association, a founder, general secretary and chairman of Amnesty International USA, special counsel to the Second Amendment Foundation, a genuine New Yorker, confirmed gun nut, labor lawyer, intellectual, bon vivant, and Krag Sporter expert. He was a good man and will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held in the spring. Memorial donations may be made to the American Custom Gunmakers Guild Education Foundation, Cody, WY.

BENENSON--Letizia Pitigliani. Artist Letizia Pitigliani, born November 23, 1935, of New York City, Port Murray, New Jersey and Rome, Italy, died on January 24, 2012 in Cancun, Mexico. She is survived by her son Alexander, her daughter Daniela Fifi and her sister Anna Drago. Her husband Mark K. Benenson passed away on November 26 2013. Born in Rome, her family fled Italy at the beginning of WWII for New York City, to which she returned in marriage, to raise a family, and make her career as a painter. She is best known in New York City for her Harbor Festival posters from 1976-1986. Her work is found worldwide in private and public collections, and printed in hundreds of thousands of posters celebrating festivals and events big and small. Letizia Pitigliani's works can be seen at www.pitigliani.com. A memorial will be held in the spring.

ATHANASSIADES--Thomas, MD. The SUNY Downstate Medical Center community mourns the passing of Thomas J. Athanassiades, MD, distinguished educator in the Department of Pathology, on November 25, 2013. "Dr. A," as students called him, oversaw teaching of pathology in the College of Medicine for multiple generations of students. We extend our deep sympathy to his wife, Despo, family, colleagues, and friends. Dr. John F. Williams, President Dr. Ian Taylor, Dean, College of Medicine Dr. Suzanne S. Mirra, Chair, Department of Pathology.

ANTHONY--Mary Kathryn, "Polly" November 15, 1952 September 29, 2013. After a courageous fight, Polly lost her battle with pancreatic cancer. Polly passed away surrounded by her family and beloved French bulldogs, Reggie and Meg. Polly was born in Alexandria, Virginia and moved with her family to Dayton, Ohio, before spending her formative years on the Palos Verdes Peninsula, CA. Polly had a lifelong love affair with popular music. In 1974, she began a music industry career that spanned four decades. In Los Angeles, after working briefly at RCA Records and Management III, she joined what would become the Sony Music family at Epic Associated Labels as an assistant in 1978, moved to New York in 1988, and eventually became President of Epic Records in 1997, making her the first female in history to helm a major record label. She culminated her career at Sony in 2003, returning to Los Angeles to join the Universal Music Group as president of DreamWorks Records and later co-president of Geffen Records. In 2006, she became head of TV and film for UMG, transitioning into executive producer on film and TV projects. Since leaving UMG, she worked on TV, film and theatrical projects. Polly's love of and generosity toward her family, friends, relatives, colleagues and dogs was obvious to all who knew her. She possessed incredible style and talent, whether cooking and entertaining at her beautiful home, or in fashioning the perfect outfit for herself or others. She was an inspiration and a mentor to many; had tremendous curiosity and focus, and will be greatly missed. She was preceded in death by her father, Bernard J. Anthony, as well as her grandparents, William and Helen Anthony, and Theodore and Ethel Haley. She is survived by her mother, Patricia H. Anthony, of Rancho Palos Verdes, CA; sister, Carrie Kelley (Bobby) of Stevinson, CA; brother, Ted Anthony (Teresa) of Austin, TX; sister, Betsy Anthony-Brodey of Los Angeles; brother, B.J. Anthony (Elisa) of Hermosa Beach, CA; nieces and nephews, Danny and Alex Kelley, Lily and Quinn Brodey, and Delaney and Marley Anthony. A private Celebration of Life was recently held in Polly's honor. In lieu of flowers, her family requests that memorial donations be made for pancreatic cancer research to The Polly Anthony Memorial Fund at the City of Hope, 1500 E. Duarte Ave., Duarte, CA 91010 (www.cityofhope.org), 626-256-4673; and The Polly Anthony Memorial Fund at the Lustgarten Foundation, 1111 Stewart Ave., Bethpage, NY 11714 (www.lustgarten.org), 516-803-2304.cakelley360@yahoo.com

ANDERSON--Cary M.,of Boca Raton, FL, died Sunday, November 24, 2013. Cary had a successful career on Wall Street selling Bonds for his own firm, Anderson, Peters & Hunt, then becoming an associate with Merrill Lynch in New York and was recently with Herbert J. Sims of Boca Raton. Cary is survived by his beloved wife, Carol Wingate Anderson; devoted daughter Joi Anderson of California and son Dr. Christopher Anderson of Wisconsin. Cary's last wish was for donations to go to the Haitian Children's Fund, run by St. Paul's Episcopal Church (stpaulsdelray.org) of Delray Beach, FL.

ABELSON--Mildred "Jigga," (nee Sheinberg), 91, died peacefully on Saturday, November 23, at home in Middlebury, VT., surrounded by her family. Mildred was a world traveler, early dedicated prochoice advocate, wife, mother, grandmother and jewelry designer. She was born on September 27, 1922 in Brooklyn, NY. She lived with cancer for over 21 years. Mildred is survived by Arnold, her husband of 71 years, her son Skipper and his wife Ila, her granddaughter Sasha, her son Donald and his husband Joseph. If so inclined, memorial gifts may be made to Planned Parenthood or Addison County Home Health & Hospice Inc.

BEECH--Kenneth Leo, born Philadelphia 1922, died November 27, 2013 at 91, at home in NYC. Art and estate appraiser by profession, Ken served in the US Navy in WWII. He loved his dogs, the ocean, fine art, and cooking. A true gentleman, cultured, gracious and kind by nature, firmly engaged in the world, soft-spoken, self-reliant to the end, uncomplaining, always caring. Ken is predeceased by his partner Malcolm Kriger and brother George A. Beech, Jr. He is survived by many beloved nieces and nephews and their families and by many dedicated, cherished friends. In honor of Ken, nothing would be more fitting than a donation to the Humane Society of New York.

WITCOVER--Walt died November 15 at age 89. Received three battle stars (the Battle of North France, the Battle of Rhineland and the Battle of Austria) after serving in World War II as a Combat Field Artilleryman, then obtained his BA and MA from Cornell. His career as actor, director and teacher spanned more than 50 years: he directed in Lee Strasberg's Actors Studio Directors Unit after studying under Strasberg, where his production of Verdi's La Traviata won the Actors Studio Total Theatre Award. Walt also studied under Herbert Berghof and Curt Conway, and taught acting and directing at HB Studio for over 25 years. He later taught at the Stella Adler Studio, and was Professor of Theatre Arts at SUNY Purchase and in Baltimore. As co-founder and Artistic Director of Masterworks Laboratory Theatre, he staged over 30 productions of classic plays and operas, plus poetry, song and story-theatre projects. Three of his Off-Broadway productions won Obie Awards. Actors he taught or directed include Barbara Barrie, Robert Clohessy, Anne Meara and Jerry Stiller. The author of "Living on Stage: Acting from the Inside-Out: A Practical Process" in 2004, he also published "My Road, Less Traveled: Becoming an Actor, a Director, a Teacher" in 2011. Walt was predeceased by his partner of over 30 years, Richard Hughes, in 1996. Survivors include brother Tom Scheinman; sisters in law Bonnie and Evie; nieces Amy, Jessica, Joanne, Laurel and Peggy; grand-niece Liza, grand-nephews Griffin, Jackson, Koby, and Kyle; cousin Doug; his stage manager of 15 years Michael Stebbins; and by hundreds of students who carry on his theatre legacy. Memorial service to be held on March 22, 2014.
WECHSLER--Robert, on November 18. A Memorial service to celebrate his life will be held on Thursday, December 5 at 6pm in the recital hall at CUNY Graduate Center, 365 Fifth Avenue.

STERN--Ralph Warner, on November 27, 2013, New York, NY. Dearest husband of the late Joan Strauss Stern; beloved companion of Arlene Stern, father to Laurie Stern-Kluger and her husband Michael Kluger, and Paul Stern and his wife Denise in Jacksonville, FL; stepfather to Roberta Stern. Born December 5, 1924 in Mannheim, Germany; immigrated to the US and fought for the Allies in WWII. Pioneer in the field of Point-of Purchase advertising, he was a partner in the Merchandising Display Corporation, then joined Henschel, Steinau, and was most recently an adjunct professor at the NYU Stern School of Business, retiring in June 2013. Loved by many, he will be missed. Services will be held Monday, December 2, 10am at The Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th St. at Amsterdam Ave.

We extend our condolences to his wife, Elissa; his children David Sable, Judy Sable Berman and Ari Sable; to his grandchildren; and to the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

PATIKY--Annabelle, passed away Saturday evening, November 30, 2013 in Greenwich, CT, at the age of 83. Miss Patiky was the daughter of Sam and Rose Patiky of Centerport (later Smithtown), Long Island, NY. Despite crippling cerebral palsy she led a life of accomplishment, due to her own perseverance as well as the farsightedness of her parents, who left no resource untapped in an age when most children with CP were given no opportunity for advancement and were institutionalized. Miss Patiky graduated Huntington High School, Hofstra University and the New York School of Social Work (now the Columbia School of Social Work), where she received her MSW. She worked as a social worker first at ICD Rehabilitation and Research Center and then at United Cerebral Palsy of NYC, where she also mentored other social workers. Miss Patiky's family were founding members of the Kings Park Jewish Center on Long Island, which she attended in her youth. Later on, she was an active member of the Brotherhood Synagogue in Manhattan, where she did volunteer work. She was an avid traveler and cruise-goer, as well as an accomplished watercolor artist whose works were exhibited in numerous venues. After living on her own in Manhattan for forty years, Annabelle moved to Stamford, CT, in 2005 to be near her niece. She is survived by her sister, Mrs. Leah Rubin, and Leah's children, Marion Copley, Elizabeth Rubin, Michael Rubin, Gabriel Rubin, and their families. The funeral will be held at Temple Sholom, 300 East Putnam Avenue, Greenwich, CT at 11:30am on December 02, 2013. To leave online condolences for the family, please visit GreenwichFuneralhome.com

SABLE--Dr. Jack. The Board of Directors, residents and staff of The Hebrew Home at Riverdale deeply mourn the loss of Rabbi Jack Sable. Jack was a great American who devoted his life to public service as well as Jewish causes. He lived each day to perform mitzvahs and was a teacher in words and deeds. Jack was a treasured friend of the Hebrew Home for decades. The world is a better place because of Rabbi Jack Sable. We extend our heartfelt condolences to the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion. The Hebrew Home at Riverdale Daniel Reingold, President & CEO

MEHRAN--Masud, passed away November 26th after a short illness at his home in Atherton, California-- surrounded, as he was during his life, by his family. Masud was born in Tehran February 6, 1920 and attended the American College in Tehran. At the age of 22 he married Maryam Ansari, and they immigrated to New York two years later. There, Masud attended Columbia University and Cornell University, from which he graduated with a degree in Agricultural Economics in 1946. Curious to explore their newly adopted country, Masud and Maryam traveled to each of the then 48 states, finally settling in the Montclair neighborhood of Oakland. Eager to contribute to the dynamic growth of post-war California, Masud founded the Sunset Development Company in 1951 and began building homes in the city of Livermore-- eventually developing SunsetTown, one of the largest and most successful residential real estate projects in the San Francisco Bay Area. In 1978, Masud expanded Sunset's properties by purchasing a 585 acre portion of the Bishop Ranch in San Ramon. Over the next 35 years he transformed an orchard into a vibrant business community comprising more than 10 million square feet of world-class office space and facilities. Masud was active in a variety of industry and community organizations with far reaching benefits for the entire San Francisco Bay Region. These include The Urban Land Institute, Golden Gate University, Oakland's Children's Hospital, The Boy Scouts of America, and countless others. After his divorce from Maryam in 1978, Masud married Farideh Eshragi in 1987. The couple had homes in Atherton, San Francisco and Lake Tahoe, where they regularly entertained and enjoyed being with their family and friends. Masud had four children with his first wife, Houri, Casey, Susan and Alex. Three of the four--Houri, Casey and Susan--preceded him in death. Masud had seven grandchildren Diana, Mark, Rawley, Peter and Lacey by his son Casey; and Annabel and Alexander Jr. by his son Alex. He also leaves a stepdaughter, Sharmin Bock and her two children, Fiona and Alastair, and a step-granddaughter, Christina Kew. All who knew Masud Mehran will be forever reminded of the example he gave to so many, and values that guided his life, which will keep his legacy alive forever. A service to celebrate Masud's life will be held on Friday, December 6, at 4:00pm at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco. In lieu of flowers, a donation in Masud's name can be made to the Persian Center at University of California, Berkeley, the Contra Costa Food Bank, Cornell University, or the Urban Land Institute Foundation.

LUBARS--Regina "Jean," (nee Gipfel), 81, of Brookline, MA and Brooklyn, NY; on November 30th. Cherished wife of Walter; adored mother of Susan, David and Steven; beloved grandmother of Paul and Elissa Dunn, Michael, Alex, Jayden and Nya Lubars; treasured mother-in-law of Buddy, Cindy and Iwen; and revered sister of Elinor. LOOKSTEIN--Joanne (Creveling). November 26th, 2013 at the age of 78 following a long battle with breast cancer. Beloved wife of Franklin Lookstein for 45 years, devoted mother of Robert and Thomas Lookstein, adoring mother-in-law of Danielle Bajakian and Jaimee Lookstein, and loving grandmother of Olivia, Charlotte, Jordan, and Emily Lookstein. Pioneer in Publicity and Public Relations. Founding Partner of Halston Inc: 1968. Public Relations Director Henri Bendel: 1970-1974. Owner and Manager, Joanne Creveling Public Relations: 1975 present. Clients included Angelo Donghia, Ralph Lauren, Winter Antiques Show, European Fine Art Fair, Grosvenor House Antiques Fair, Brunschwig & Fils, Gallerie Ariane Dandois, Chinese Porcelain Company, Vernay and Jussel, A La Veille Russie, Zandra Rhodes, Ossie Clark, Rizzoli, Christie's Auction House, Philips Auction House, British Khaki, Pinky and Diane, Mario Nievera, Newell Art Gallery, Ballyfin Demesne. The family summer cottage on Shelter Island was featured in numerous newspapers and magazines including The New York Times, British House & Garden, and House Beautiful. Service will be held Tuesday, December 3rd 3-7pm at Frank E Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, New York, NY. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made in her memory to the Mount Sinai Dubin Breast Center. http://philanthropy.mountsinai.org/donate

FERRIGNO DYCKE--Marjorie (nee Platt) 97 years old of Flushing, NY died November 15, 2013. Marjorie was an educator. Founding chairman, Drama Department, School of Performing Arts, NYC (the school was the originator of the term, "performing arts"). Past President of the American Educational Theatre Association which represented all non-professional theatre in the U.S. (1962); Former Secretary and Executive Committee member of the American National Theatre and Academy (ANTA); member of the National Council on the Arts and Government (NCAG) which worked with Senator Jacob Javits to develop legislation to establish a National Cultural Center which became Kennedy Center on the death of JFK; consultant to the Governor's School (Governor Terry Sanford) at Winston-Salem which became The North Carolina School of the Arts. Marjorie taught Speech courses at Hunter College, Teachers College - Columbia University, New York University, York College (NYC), Queens College Continuing Education Department. Chairman, North Shore Branch of League of Woman Voters, NYC; steering committee member, Economic Development Committee, LWVNYC. Founding member (1964) and Past President of Broadway-Flushing Homeowners' Association, Inc. which won a landmark court case to enforce a restrictive covenant, and led to a rezoning of part of Northern Boulevard; helped BFHA achieve National and State Historic Preservation District status; member of Queens Borough President Claire Shulman's Zoning Task Force. Listed in Who's Who in the East, Who's Who of American Theatre. Directory of American Scholars. Marjorie was predeceased by her inseparable husband, Nicholas Ferrigno in 2010 after 55 years of marriage. She was a devoted sister to Janice Platt Johnson. Aunt Marge was adored by her nieces and nephews, Linda (Baldo) Forte, Henry Caltabiano, Susan (John) Archer, Charles Ferrigno, Maggie Clarke, along with their children and grandchildren. Following cremation, interment will be at Flushing Cemetery. A brief Memorial will be planned with happy memories to be shared of a truly remarkable and unforgettable woman on December 10, 2013 at 10am at the Flushing Cemetery Chapel.

DORN--Dr. Jack, Beloved husband, father, son, brother, uncle, and respected endodontist passed away on November 29, 2013. He is survived by his wife, Gloria; son, Andrew; mother, Leah Dorn; sister, Cecille Freilich, and extended family. Services will be held at noon at the Plaza Jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Avenue, NY.

BYRON--Charles A.,founded the Byron Gallery at 1018 Madison Avenue in 1961. A member of the Art Dealers Association and a preeminent Surrealist Art dealer, he also championed early 1960s American avant-garde art. His renown stretched from Paris to The Menil Collection in Houston. Byron was among the last representatives of an old-world style of art dealing -one based not on commerce but aesthetics and generosity, taste and friendships. He was born on December 15, 1918, in Turkey, to Sophia Alatary and Antoine Patrikiades, both of Greek descent. He inherited American citizenship at birth from his father. After a youth spent in various European countries, he came to America and graduated from Harvard College in 1940. In World War II he served in the US Army in England and France. In 1965 he married Elizabeth Sverbeyeff Tarsaidze, a distinguished presence in architectural publishing from the 1960s to the present. His gift to the Archives of American Art of the meticulous records of the Byron Gallery reflects the clarity, care, and perceptiveness he gave all his projects. Friends may visit Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. on Wednesday, December 4, from 3-5pm and from 6-8pm. The funeral will take place at St. John the Baptist Greek Orthodox Church, 143 East 17th St. on Thursday, December 5th at 10am.

BOSSINGER--Julia Irene, (Bass), 90, of Monroe Twp.,NJ on Friday, November 29th, 2013. Alumna of Hunter College. Mother of the late Fred Stein. Survived by brother Saul Bass and family, daughters: Deborah Staska and Stephanie Crease, six grandchildren, three great-grandchildren. Graveside service at Locust Valley Cemetery, NY, December 3 at 12:30pm.

BENENSON--Mark K.,84, of New York City and Port Murray New Jersey, died November 27 2013. He is survived by his son Alexander, his daughter Daniela Fifi, and was predeceased last year by his wife, artist Letizia Pitigliani. Mark, once called the only honest man by William F. Buckley Jr., was a life member of the National Rifle Association, a founder, general secretary and chairman of Amnesty International USA, special counsel to the Second Amendment Foundation, a genuine New Yorker, confirmed gun nut, labor lawyer, intellectual, bon vivant, and Krag Sporter expert. He was a good man and will be greatly missed. A memorial service will be held in the spring. Memorial donations may be made to the American Custom Gunmakers Guild Education Foundation, Cody, WY.

BENENSON--Letizia Pitigliani. Artist Letizia Pitigliani, born November 23, 1935, of New York City, Port Murray, New Jersey and Rome, Italy, died on January 24, 2012 in Cancun, Mexico. She is survived by her son Alexander, her daughter Daniela Fifi and her sister Anna Drago. Her husband Mark K. Benenson passed away on November 26 2013. Born in Rome, her family fled Italy at the beginning of WWII for New York City, to which she returned in marriage, to raise a family, and make her career as a painter. She is best known in New York City for her Harbor Festival posters from 1976-1986. Her work is found worldwide in private and public collections, and printed in hundreds of thousands of posters celebrating festivals and events big and small. Letizia Pitigliani's works can be seen at www.pitigliani.com. A memorial will be held in the spring.

When the Olympic torch reaches Sochi, Russia, to begin the Winter Games two months from now, it will have traveled farther than any other torch in Winter Olympics history. Since its odyssey began in Moscow, the torch has been carried by foot, on trains, planes and troikas, taken to the North Pole via icebreaker and into lower Earth orbit on a Soyuz rocket.

PELL--Christine Benson, 1945-2013. Christine Benson Pell died November 29, 2013 surrounded by her family. A lifelong resident of Long Island, Christine attended Green Vale School, Emma Willard, Wheaton College and later earned a degree from C.W. Post. She joined Glen Cove Boys & Girls Club's Board of Directors in 1977, became president, and was chairman of the board at the time of her death. Her 25 years of professional service to Green Vale included the roles of teacher, trustee, assistant business manager, development officer, alumni director, and head of the Parents' Association. She also belonged to the Glen Cove Hospital Advisory Council and had served on the boards of Piping Rock Club and Womens' Long Island Golf Association. Christine is survived by her husband, Peter J. Pell, her mother, Helen V. Benson, and her four children: Christine M. Corey; Cynthia Corey Dolezal; Alan L. Corey IV; and R. William Corey. She also leaves a sister, two brothers, two stepchildren, and three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am Thursday December 5 at St. John's of Lattingtown (325 Lattingtown Road, Locust Valley, New York). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Glen Cove Boys & Girls Club (113 Glen Cove Avenue, Glen Cove, New York 11542).

PARSONS--Patricia, (nee O'Brien), 83, of Redding, CT and Essex, NY, and formerly of Burlington, VT, passed away on Saturday, November 30 following a brief illness. Her extraordinary enthusiasm for life, art, people and martinis will be greatly missed by her family and her many friends of all ages. Born to Isabel Munroe O'Brien and John Larkin O'Brien, in Albany, NY, on May 26, 1930, Pat attended St. Agnes School and graduated from Miss Porter's School and Vassar College. She raised her family in Bedford, NY, and opened an art gallery, Webb & Parsons, in Bedford Village in the early 1970s, showing contemporary art. After seeing the work of Inez Nathaniel Walker, an inmate at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, she began showing and collecting the work of self-taught artists as well. Pat shared her love of art passionately, insistently and generously, and she donated many works from her collection of self-taught art to museums, including the American Folk Art Museum and the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center at Vassar, where her collection was the subject of an exhibition, "Faith and Fantasy in Outsider Art," in 2009. An artist herself, Pat saw beauty everywhere she looked. She was predeceased by her brothers Jerry and Duncan O'Brien, and her former husband, James O. Parsons, Jr. She is survived by her daughters Laurie and Amy, her adored son-in-law Paul Bird and beloved grandchildren Isabel and Henry Bird. A service will be held at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, NY, on Saturday, December 7 at 11:00am.

NOTIAS--Irene "Rena," age 48, of New York City, passed away on November 27, 2013. She was the beloved daughter of the late Captain Harry Notias and Phyllis Thravalos Notias, sister of Nicholas Notias. Rena was a graduate of Columbia University/ Barnard College and an accomplished Artist. Professionally she was an Executive in her Father's shipping company. She will be greatly missed by her family and many friends. A private burial was held December 2, 2013 at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Memorial donations, in lieu of flowers may be sent to The Hellenic Relief Foundation, Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital at New York Presbyterian or Free Arts.

MEHRAN--Masud, passed away November 26th after a short illness at his home in Atherton, California-- surrounded, as he was during his life, by his family. Masud was born in Tehran February 6, 1920 and attended the American College in Tehran. At the age of 22 he married Maryam Ansari, and they immigrated to New York two years later. There, Masud attended Columbia University and Cornell University, from which he graduated with a degree in Agricultural Economics in 1946. Curious to explore their newly adopted country, Masud and Maryam traveled to each of the then 48 states, finally settling in the Montclair neighborhood of Oakland. Eager to contribute to the dynamic growth of post-war California, Masud founded the Sunset Development Company in 1951 and began building homes in the city of Livermore-- eventually developing SunsetTown, one of the largest and most successful residential real estate projects in the San Francisco Bay Area. In 1978, Masud expanded Sunset's properties by purchasing a 585 acre portion of the Bishop Ranch in San Ramon. Over the next 35 years he transformed an orchard into a vibrant business community comprising more than 10 million square feet of world-class office space and facilities. Masud was active in a variety of industry and community organizations with far reaching benefits for the entire San Francisco Bay Region. These include The Urban Land Institute, Golden Gate University, Oakland's Children's Hospital, The Boy Scouts of America, and countless others. After his divorce from Maryam in 1978, Masud married Farideh Eshragi in 1987. The couple had homes in Atherton, San Francisco and Lake Tahoe, where they regularly entertained and enjoyed being with their family and friends. Masud had four children with his first wife, Houri, Casey, Susan and Alex. Three of the four--Houri, Casey and Susan--preceded him in death. Masud had seven grandchildren Diana, Mark, Rawley, Peter and Lacey by his son Casey; and Annabel and Alexander Jr. by his son Alex. He also leaves a stepdaughter, Sharmin Bock and her two children, Fiona and Alastair, and a step-granddaughter, Christina Kew. All who knew Masud Mehran will be forever reminded of the example he gave to so many, and values that guided his life, which will keep his legacy alive forever. A service to celebrate Masud's life will be held on Friday, December 6, at 4:00pm at Grace Cathedral in San Francisco. In lieu of flowers, a donation in Masud's name can be made to the Persian Center at University of California, Berkeley, the Contra Costa Food Bank, Cornell University, or the Urban Land Institute Foundation.

BRAUNSTEIN--Sumner, 86, on November 16, 2013. Loving husband of thirty-eight-years to Gail, devoted father to Harry, caring father-in-law to Jennifer, adoring grandfather to Lucas and Abraham, he will be greatly missed by family and friends. Sumner was a life-long learner and teacher, having graduated from Erasmus Hall High School, Brooklyn College and Columbia University. After a 27.8 year career as a New York City public school teacher, he "retired", but continued to work as a writer, consultant, curriculum developer and teacher-- including educating student teachers at Barnard College. In addition to his loving family, he nurtured enduring friendships with a coterie of companions poets, artists, jurists, scientists and workers who enjoyed the warmth of his generosity of spirit, his wit and his extraordinary sense of humor. Sumner is buried in Sag Harbor, New York. In lieu of flowers, please send donations to Doctors Without Borders in his memory.

WOS--Paul Zenon. In loving memory, on December 2, 2013. Paul Wos passed away at his home in Sarasota, FL at the age of 92. An intrepid fighter for freedom all his life, Paul was a combat veteran of the anti-Nazi and anti-Soviet invasion of Poland in September 1939. During the Holocaust, Paul Wos, along with his father, mother, and siblings, rescued the Jewish Melamed family and other Jews, including future professor Israel Shahak. For this selfless act, Paul was awarded the Yad Vashem Medal, "The Righteous Among the Nations." At the time Paul Wos also volunteered as a soldier in the underground Polish Home Army. In its ranks he participated in the Warsaw Rising of 1944. Captured by the Germans, along with his family members, he became a prisoner of the Nazi Flossenburg Concentration Camp. After the liberation by the Americans, he participated as a courier in the anti-Communist underground, traveling between the West and Soviet-occupied Poland, which he was eventually forced to leave. Paul Wos settled in the United States, first in New York, and then retiring in Sarasota, FL. Engineer, entrepreneur, philanthropist, Polish and American Patriot, he became an avid traveler upon his rather late retirement. He also penned a memoir, sponsored a variety of charitable and educational causes and remained active in various Polish organizations including Veteran groups. Paul Wos lived his life by believing it was everyone's moral obligation to always do the right thing. He is survived by his wife of 65 years, Wanda; his son, Konrad Wos; his daughter, Ambassador Aldona Wos; their spouses Meggan Walsh and Louis DeJoy as well as four grandchildren, Taylor and Carson Wos and Ania and Andrew DeJoy and a sister, Wanda Wos-Lorenc. He is preceded in death by his sister, Irena Wos-Madejski and his brother, Jerzy Odon Wos. Contributions may be made to: Institute of World Politics, 1521 16th Street, NW, Washington, DC 20036; Designate for the Kosciusko Chair.

WELLS--Andrea. The Board and Staff of St. Mary's Healthcare System for Children mourn the passing of Andrea Wells, the beloved wife of our Chairman, Stephen Brent Wells. Our thoughts are with the entire Wells Family during this difficult time.

SCHWARTZ--Bernard, of Neponsit, NY passed away on December 2, 2013 surrounded by his family. He graduated Townsend Harris High School at 15, attended Brooklyn College '45, married Elinore in 1955 and worked at Jack Schwartz Shoes Incorporated, the company his father founded in 1936. He worked alongside his older brother Donald, his daughter Janet and two generations of nephews. All who knew him will remember his kindness and robust laugh, his love of the beach and outdoors, his scholarly interests and tireless support of Israel. He was much loved and will be deeply missed. He is survived by his children Lisa Reik, Janet Feldman, Marjorie Nielsen, Mitchell Schwartz and ten grandchildren.

REICH--Julie Kaye, of New York City and Tyringham, Massachusetts, died Friday, November 29 of ovarian cancer. Born in 1946, she was raised in Queens and Great Neck, New York. She graduated from the University of Wisconsin and spent a year in Aix-en-Provence as a Fulbright Teaching Fellow where she was an enthusiastic participant in the events of May 1968. In 1969 she married Charles Reich, and the couple moved to Paris, where she worked as an English Language teacher for many years at the University of Paris XI in Orsay. Later she earned a Masters in Public Health from Hunter College and worked at the Guttmacher Institute and then the Population Council, where she was Managing Editor of Studies in Family Planning, a peer-reviewed scientific journal on women's reproductive health. She was a beautiful, accomplished woman with a fierce moral center. An insightful editor and a writer of wit and passion, she was also a warm and generous friend, a loving parent and spouse. During a period of 31 years she endured three cancers (as well as several other illnesses) with quiet courage and humility and never let her health problems diminish her humor or her highly developed sense of the ridiculous and the absurd. She is survived by her husband, her twin brother Joel Kaye and his wife Theodora Lurie of New York City, her sister Carole of Saugerties, NY, sons Gabriel of Richmond, VA, and Benjamin of Hanoi, Vietnam, granddaughter Isabella, and grandsons Hosea and Tobias. Memorial Service: Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., Friday, December 13, 1:00pm.

PELL--Christine Benson, 1945-2013. Christine Benson Pell died November 29, 2013 surrounded by her family. A lifelong resident of Long Island, Christine attended Green Vale School, Emma Willard, Wheaton College and later earned a degree from C.W. Post. She joined Glen Cove Boys & Girls Club's Board of Directors in 1977, became president, and was chairman of the board at the time of her death. Her 25 years of professional service to Green Vale included the roles of teacher, trustee, assistant business manager, development officer, alumni director, and head of the Parents' Association. She also belonged to the Glen Cove Hospital Advisory Council and had served on the boards of Piping Rock Club and Womens' Long Island Golf Association. Christine is survived by her husband, Peter J. Pell, her mother, Helen V. Benson, and her four children: Christine M. Corey; Cynthia Corey Dolezal; Alan L. Corey IV; and R. William Corey. She also leaves a sister, two brothers, two stepchildren, and three grandchildren. A memorial service will be held at 11:00am Thursday December 5 at St. John's of Lattingtown (325 Lattingtown Road, Locust Valley, New York). In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to Glen Cove Boys & Girls Club (113 Glen Cove Avenue, Glen Cove, New York 11542).

PARSONS--Patricia, (nee O'Brien), 83, of Redding, CT and Essex, NY, and formerly of Burlington, VT, passed away on Saturday, November 30 following a brief illness. Her extraordinary enthusiasm for life, art, people and martinis will be greatly missed by her family and her many friends of all ages. Born to Isabel Munroe O'Brien and John Larkin O'Brien, in Albany, NY, on May 26, 1930, Pat attended St. Agnes School and graduated from Miss Porter's School and Vassar College. She raised her family in Bedford, NY, and opened an art gallery, Webb & Parsons, in Bedford Village in the early 1970s, showing contemporary art. After seeing the work of Inez Nathaniel Walker, an inmate at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, she began showing and collecting the work of self-taught artists as well. Pat shared her love of art passionately, insistently and generously, and she donated many works from her collection of self-taught art to museums, including the American Folk Art Museum and the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center at Vassar, where her collection was the subject of an exhibition, "Faith and Fantasy in Outsider Art," in 2009. An artist herself, Pat saw beauty everywhere she looked. She was predeceased by her brothers Jerry and Duncan O'Brien, and her former husband, James O. Parsons, Jr. She is survived by her daughters Laurie and Amy, her adored son-in-law Paul Bird and beloved grandchildren Isabel and Henry Bird. A service will be held at St. Matthew's Church, Bedford, NY, on Saturday, December 7 at 11:00am.

NORMANDIA--Alphonse, (1928-2013), 85, of Glen Cove, NY and previously NYC, died peacefully in his sleep on Monday morning, December 2. He is survived by children Lynne, Karen, Camille, Paul and Mary; granddaughter Phoebe; siblings Robert and Caroline Dodaro and many nieces and nephews. A beloved father, friend and member of the BBDO community, Alphonse worked in the BBDO Art Department for 59 years, collaborating with many of the agency's major clients. A graduate of Cooper Union, Alphonse was one of the original designers of the TV storyboard. He was also the illustrator for BBDO's alumni newsletter, "The Pink Sheet," for 30+ years. Alphonse was best known for his unique ability to make people laugh. He is the subject of a blog created by longtime friend Tom Villante, called "Me and Alphonse," which has been shared among hundreds of fans for years. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Parkinson's Foundation in Alphonse's memory would be appreciated. A life celebration for Alphonse will be held in NYC in Spring 2014. Alphonse will forever be a member of the BBDO "Hall of Fame." A bronze bust was made in his honor and all are encouraged to rub his nose for good luck. Rest in peace, Alphonse. Your loving friends at BBDO.

MANUS--Janet Wilkens, died peacefully on November 21st, 2013. A memorial service will be held on Friday, December 6th at 4:30pm at Frank E. Campbell Funeral Chapel (Madison Avenue and 81st Street). Memorial contributions may be made to The Authors League Fund.

MILLER--Raymond K.,77, of Brick, NJ, died suddenly November 29th. He graduated from Ridgewood High School and from Pace College (now University) with a BBA. He was a furniture buyer for Bloomingdale's and worked closely with Barbara D'Arcy. For details see: www.feeneyfuneralhome.com

LEVIN--Donald R.,of Roslyn, New York passed away on December 1, 2013. He was 84 years old. Donald was born on November 3, 1929 in Brooklyn, New York to Adele and Ira Levin. He is survived by his wife Eleanore Levin, his children William Andrew Levin and Cathy Jane Levin; his daughter-in-law Laurel Simes-Levin and five grandchildren Rebekah Levin, Sarah Cohen, Jessica Levin, Jennifer Cohen, Melissa Levin and Joseph Ira Levin. He served in the Marine Corps, attended Franklin Marshall College and graduated from NYU Law School. He was a Real Estate partner at the law firm of Parker Chapin Flattau & Klimpl his entire career. Funeral Service will be held on Wednesday, December 4th at 12:45pm at Sinai Chapel located at 16205 Horace Harding Expressway, Fresh Meadows followed by a graveside burial at Mount Hebron Cemetery. Shiva will be on Wednesday, December 4th from 5-9pm and Thursday, December 5th from 2-9pm.

LEIGHT--Grace. We note with sorrow the passing of our member Grace Leight and extend sincerest condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein and President David B. Edelson, Central Synagogue of New York City

KAUFTHAL--Edith. The Aleph Society mourns the passing of Edith Kaufthal, mother of our esteemed Board Member Ilan (and Linda) Kaufthal and of fellow benefactor Uri (and Judy) Kaufthal, grandmother of Jonathan, Jeremy, Josh, Daniel, David and Joshua, and a doting great-grandmother as well. The legacy of her loving-kindness and generosity continues through the good deeds and the grace of her sons and grandsons. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Rabbi Adin Steinsaltz

KULKA--Marilisa Jusko. Born January 14, 1928 in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. Died November 18, 2013 in Manhattan. Daughter of John and Mary Jusko. Survived by her son Robert. Funeral to be held at Church of the Blessed Sacrament, 152 West 71 Street, NY, NY. Saturday, December 7, 2013 at 10am. Donations may be made to Muscular Dystrophy Association.

KAUFTHAL--Edith. Matriarch of our family, passed away in her 93rd year. She was a survivor who rebuilt her life from the depths of the Holocaust. Imma, as she was known by everyone, was a unique and special person who served as a role model for our entire family. Survived in deep mourning by her children, Uri and Judy and Ilan and Linda, by her grandchildren, Josh and Abby, Jon and Dina, David and Lori, Jeremy and Keren, Daniel and Laura and Joshie, and her great-grandchildren, Jenna, Joseph, Evan, Sydney, Jack, Jacob, Fred and Noah. Imma will be sorely missed.

KATZIN--Annette (Stollnan), beloved wife of Dr. Herbert Katzin, loving mother of Dr. Richard Katzin (Jaquie) and Mary Katzin-Simon (Charles), adoring grandmother of Nicholas (Stephanie) and Samuel K. Simon. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to the FIPPOA Post Office Box 5305 Fire Island Pines, New York 11782. Shiva at 180 Riverside Dr. December 4, 5 and 8 from 4:00pm-8:00pm, December 6 2:00pm-4:00pm, December 7 6:00pm-8:00pm. Minyan at 7:00pm.

GOLDBERG--Dr. Ivan K.,of Pomona, NY on November 26, 2013. He attended Johns Hopkins University and NYU College of Medicine. In private practice, specializing in psycho-pharmacology and depression, with offices in New York City and Bardonia, NY. In 1986 he founded Psycom.net. The site includes, "Dr. Ivan's Depression Central" and a listserv with many email lists used by over 4,000 mental health professionals worldwide. Dr. Goldberg is the author of "Questions and Answers About Depression and its Treatment" and many other books. He received numerous awards including the American Psychiatric Association's 2014 Distinguished Service Award. Dr. Goldberg was also an avid photographer in black and white and infrared. Many of his photographs are displayed in museums worldwide. Ivan is survived by his wife, Cynthia Meyer Goldberg; two daughters, Bonni Goldberg and Meredith Goldberg; two step-sons, Vincent and Eric Matal, and one granddaughter, Isabel Kendall. He is predeceased by his brother, Steven and his sister, Diane. Memorial Service will be held at Wanamaker & Carlough Funeral Home, Suffern, NY on December 7, from 12-2pm. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions can be made to the ACLU. Condolences can be sent via wanamakercarlough.com

FRIEDMAN--Natalie, (nee Scharlin), 83, of Sea Cliff, NY, and Palm Desert, CA, passed away peacefully on December 2. She is survived by her loving husband of 60 years, Lee (Bud), and by her children Andrea (Barry), Nancy (Jim), Linda (Jim), John (Kate), 10 beloved grandchildren and her sister, Pat Scharlin Taylor. Natalie loved her family and was active her whole life. A memorial service will be held on Wednesday, December 4, at 4:00 pm, at Old Westbury Country Club, 250 Wheatley Rd., Old Westbury. Donations in her memory may be made to Cedar Sinai Women's Cancer Research Center, Los Angeles

FORD--Shirley on November 30, 2013, age 75, after a brief illness. She brought music and laughter to all she met. Shirley will be missed by all who knew her. She is survived by Tony Monte (Anthony Monte-Bovi), her husband of 36 years. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Tuesday and Wednesday from 2-5 and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the MS Society (NY Chapter).

FISCH--Jerome, June 22, 1926 to December 3, 2013, 87 years of age. Dedicated, loving, devoted and heartfelt marriage of 64 years to Lorraine (Rager) Fisch of Teaneck, New Jersey. Loving father of David Fisch and his wife Wendy, of Fort Lee, New Jersey and Martin Fisch and his wife Paula of Andover, Massachusetts. Devoted grandfather of Matthew Fisch of Beverly Hills, California and Daniel Fisch of Andover, Massachusetts. Veteran of the United States Navy, WWII. Graduate of the City College of New York and Harvard Law School, Class of 1951. Practicing attorney in New York City for 60 years with membership to New York and American Bar Associations. Member of numerous fraternal associations and long time member of the Oritani Racquet Club of Hackensack, New Jersey. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, December 5, 2013 at Temple Emeth 1666 Windzor Rd Teaneck, NJ at 10:00am.

FELDMAN--Seymour, 94, of Hurley, NY passed peacefully at home on November 27, 2013. Born in Brooklyn. Past president Queensboro Hill Jewish Center in Queens. Leadership positions in pharmaceutical with Premo and Forest Labs. Generous loving spirit, devoted family man, perfectionist with hatred of injustice. Survived by his wife of 73 years, Rebecca Feldman, his son Dr. Sheldon Feldman and his wife Gayle Saunders of New York City, daughter Ellen Gust and husband Alan of Ft. Lauderdale, FL, six grandchildren, six great-grandchildren, a nephew and niece. In 1994, he partnered with Benedictine Hospital in Kingston, NY to establish the Fern Feldman Anolick Breast Center to honor the memory of his daughter Fern who died from breast cancer at age 37. Contributions to Benedictine Health Foundation-Breast Center. Online condolences: www.Simpson-Gaus.com

ENGER--Paul, 86, retired newsman, playwright and co-founder of a soup kitchen for the homeless, died November 29, 2013. Born in Fargo, ND, Paul graduated from the University of Minnesota, began a career as a newspaper reporter in his hometown, worked for UPI and CBS News in New York. There he wrote for evening anchors Walter Cronkite and Dan Rather. He also wrote for Good Morning America and All My Children on ABC-TV, as well as scripts for A&E Cable and The History Channel. He holds three awards from the Writers Guild of America and is the recipient of the International Radio NY Festival Gold Award. Paul authored nine full-length plays, including "Vestigial Parts" and "Harmon and Ruth." His works have been performed Off Broadway as well as in Massachusetts, Florida, Arizona, California and Indiana. His most recent play, "Benefit Performance," a play with songs written with Tom Ferriter and Michael Valenti is slated for production at Stageplays Theatre in the coming season. Paul was an active member of Holy Trinity Lutheran Church on West 65th Street in Manhattan, where he co-founded HUG, a soup kitchen program for homeless men and women, and assisted in planning the Bach Vespers program. Paul, who lived in Jackson Heights, Queens, was the beloved brother of Mary K. Katz and beloved uncle of Gretchen Browne and Richard Katz. A funeral service will be held at Holy Trinity Lutheran Church on Saturday, December 7 at 9:30am. Burial will be at Riverside Cemetery in Fargo, ND. Services are under the direction of Conway Funeral Home, Jackson Heights.

EDELSTEIN--Florence, (nee Goldsholl) 92, died October 13, 2013. Florence was born in New York City of Jewish immigrant parents who were Pioneer Cooperators in the Amalgamated Cooperative Apartments in the Bronx where Florence lived for over 80 years. Her father was a union organizer for The Amalgamated Clothing Workers and from an early age Florence became involved in progressive social causes. She remained an active participant in the civil rights, anti-war, and labor movements throughout her life. Florence was also the copy editor for Natural History Magazine for 37 years until retiring in 1999 at age 78. She is survived by her two sons Victor, and Thomas, as well as a number of nephews, nieces, cousins and dear friends.

D'AMARO--Dr. Joseph, October 22, 1929 to April 8, 2013. Formerly from N.Y. where he graduated from CCNY with a Bachelor of Science Degree. He went to Holland in 1966. He received his M.D. from the University of Lieden in 1974. During that time he became a research assistant and developed and automated the micro compliment fixation. He worked for the Dutch Organization of Pure Research, concentrating on Immuno-hematology. He received his PhD in 1978 with his Thesis HLA polymorphisms in the Netherlands. He authored and coauthored 44 books and 154 publications. He leaves behind one sister, nephews, nieces, grandnephews and grandnieces as well as his dear friends the Van Cauberg family.

COLLIER--Lois M. City Harvest remembers Lois M. Collier, a generous friend and dedicated partner in the fight to end hunger. Lois's steadfast commitment to helping New Yorkers live healthier, hunger-free lives made an impact on millions of her neighbors. We offer condolences to her family and friends, and join them in celebrating her life. Lois was a kind and forthright woman, and we will miss her.

BYRON--Charles. The members of the Art Dealers Association of America mourn the passing of their distinguished colleague. He built the Charles Byron Gallery on his connoisseurship and integrity. As a result, he won the friendship and trust of his clients and the respect and admiration of his colleagues. Our sympathy and condolences go to his wife, Elizabeth. Dorsey Waxter, President Linda Blumberg, Exec. Dir.

BYRON--Charles A.,founded the Byron Gallery at 1018 Madison Avenue in 1961. A member of the Art Dealers Association and a preeminent Surrealist Art dealer, he also championed early 1960s American avant-garde art. His renown stretched from Paris to The Menil Collection in Houston. Byron was among the last representatives of an old-world style of art dealing -one based not on commerce but aesthetics and generosity, taste and friendships. He was born on December 15, 1918, in Turkey, to Sophia Alatary and Antoine Patrikiades, both of Greek descent. He inherited American citizenship at birth from his father. After a youth spent in various European countries, he came to America and graduated from Harvard College in 1940. In World War II he served in the US Army in England and France. In 1965 he married Elizabeth Sverbeyeff Tarsaidze, a distinguished presence in architectural publishing from the 1960s to the present. His gift to the Archives of American Art of the meticulous records of the Byron Gallery reflects the clarity, care, and perceptiveness he gave all his projects. Friends may visit Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. on Wednesday, December 4, from 3-5pm and from 6-8pm. The funeral will take place at St. John the Baptist Greek Orthodox Church, 143 East 17th St. on Thursday, December 5th at 10am.

BROWN--Curtis Jay, LCSW, 57, on November 25, 2013. Cherished husband of Alastair, devoted son of Patricia and the late Norman, loving brother to Karen and Duane and beloved brother-in-law to Belinda. Memorial to be held December 7, 2013, 10:30am at Greenwich Village Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to www.fingerlakesspca.org.

BENENSON--Letizia Pitigliani. Artist Letizia Pitigliani, born November 23, 1935, of New York City, Port Murray, New Jersey and Rome, Italy, died on January 24, 2012 in Cancun, Mexico. She is survived by her son Alexander, her daughter Daniela Fifi and her sister Anna Drago. Her husband Mark K. Benenson passed away on November 26 2013. Born in Rome, her family fled Italy at the beginning of WWII for New York City, to which she returned in marriage, to raise a family, and make her career as a painter. She is best known in New York City for her Harbor Festival posters from 1976-1986. Her work is found worldwide in private and public collections, and printed in hundreds of thousands of posters celebrating festivals and events big and small. Letizia Pitigliani's works can be seen at www.pitigliani.com. A memorial will be held in the spring.

ZILLIAC--Cynthia Burkhart, a former Editor at the then Scott Foresman, in Glenview, IL, mother of three, born December 7, 1931, died November 28, 2013, at Sunrise Senior Living in Wilmette. Surviving are her husband of 59 years, George; three children, Gregory George Zilliac (Jennifer), Barbara Zilliac Graham (Neal), and Jocelyn Zilliac DeVault (Chip) and nine grandchildren (three each). Cynthia (Cindy) was born in New York City and grew up near Union City, PA. Cindy attended Allegheny College, Meadville, PA, as a Psychology major, where she met George in a psychological statistics class. She lived in Evanston, IL for the last 42 years. Growing up on what might be called a rural-nonfarm Cindy rode and cared for a horse named Chain. Our family loved to camp where she was sometimes referred to as "Ranger Cindy" by the kids for her organizing of the chaos of camping with family and dog. She also enjoyed private flying with her husband. One of her major interests was singing - she was trained as an operatic soprano in her youth, sang for years with the North Shore Choral Society, and sang in Aida at Chautauqua, NY. She made stained glass art, painted, and tutored urban disadvantaged youth in reading in a special program at Scott Foresman, after hours. Perhaps her most notable accomplishments lay in 20 or more years of lexicography in dictionary editing, at Scott Foresman. She was responsible for a lot that went into several first grade through High School Thorn- dike-Barnhart dictionaries, where she specialized in science definitions. She was also responsible for much of the dictionary art. Later she worked in the Social Studies department, working with authors on several middle-school social studies books on the histories of Florida and Texas. She was loved by all of us for her understanding and loving spirit. She is sorely missed. A celebration of her life is being planned. For more information contact zilliac@aol.com

SCHWARTZ--Bernard, of Neponsit, NY passed away on December 2, 2013 surrounded by his family. He graduated Townsend Harris High School at 15, attended Brooklyn College '45, married Elinore in 1955 and worked at Jack Schwartz Shoes Incorporated, the company his father founded in 1936. He worked alongside his older brother Donald, his daughter Janet and two generations of nephews. All who knew him will remember his kindness and robust laugh, his love of the beach and outdoors, his scholarly interests and tireless support of Israel. He was much loved and will be deeply missed. He is survived by his children Lisa Reik, Janet Feldman, Marjorie Nielsen, Mitchell Schwartz and ten grandchildren.

SCHIFFRIN--Andre. The New Press Board of Directors and staff mourn the loss of The New Press founding director and editor-at-large Andre Schiffrin, brilliant editor, publisher, mentor, progressive thinker, and publishing visionary. His legacy will carry on through our books and authors. We extend our deepest condolences to his family.

OCKENDEN--Edward, of Paoli, PA, author of "The Ghosts of Company G" a Pacific war memoir has died at 89. He was predeceased by his wife of 60 years, Dawn Leonard, and is survived by his daughter Marianne Sanders and four sons, Stephen, William, Robert and John as well as eight grand and two great-grandchildren and three sisters. He grew up in Northampton, MA., where his father, The Rev. Albion Ockenden was rector of St. John's Episcopal Church. He attended the Lenox School, enlisted in the army at 18 serving in the Southwest Pacific region and saw heavy action. He was severely wounded during the invasion of Luzon, the Phillipines and was awarded the Bronze Star, the Purple Heart and the Combat Infantry Badge. After his discharge he graduated from the University of Connecticut and worked in New York and Ohio in advertising. He subsequently moved into radio, retiring as General Manager of a radio station in Maine. A funeral service will be held at St. Peter's Church in the Green Valley in Malvern, PA at 1:00pm on December 14 and if desired contributions may be made to Episcopal Community Services, 225 South Third Street, Philadelphia, PA 19106.

NORMANDIA--Alphonse, (1928-2013), 85, of Glen Cove, NY and previously NYC, died peacefully in his sleep on Monday morning, December 2. He is survived by children Lynne, Karen, Camille, Paul and Mary; granddaughter Phoebe; siblings Robert and Caroline Dodaro and many nieces and nephews. A beloved father, friend and member of the BBDO community, Alphonse worked in the BBDO Art Department for 59 years, collaborating with many of the agency's major clients. A graduate of Cooper Union, Alphonse was one of the original designers of the TV storyboard. He was also the illustrator for BBDO's alumni newsletter, "The Pink Sheet," for 30+ years. Alphonse was best known for his unique ability to make people laugh. He is the subject of a blog created by longtime friend Tom Villante, called "Me and Alphonse," which has been shared among hundreds of fans for years. In lieu of flowers, donations to the Parkinson's Foundation in Alphonse's memory would be appreciated. A life celebration for Alphonse will be held in NYC in Spring 2014. Alphonse will forever be a member of the BBDO "Hall of Fame." A bronze bust was made in his honor and all are encouraged to rub his nose for good luck. Rest in peace, Alphonse. Your loving friends at BBDO.

FISCH--Jerome, June 22, 1926 to December 3, 2013, 87 years of age. Dedicated, loving, devoted and heartfelt marriage of 64 years to Lorraine (Rager) Fisch of Teaneck, New Jersey. Loving father of David Fisch and his wife Wendy, of Fort Lee, New Jersey and Martin Fisch and his wife Paula of Andover, Massachusetts. Devoted grandfather of Matthew Fisch of Beverly Hills, California and Daniel Fisch of Andover, Massachusetts. Veteran of the United States Navy, WWII. Graduate of the City College of New York and Harvard Law School, Class of 1951. Practicing attorney in New York City for 60 years with membership to New York and American Bar Associations. Member of numerous fraternal associations and long time member of the Oritani Racquet Club of Hackensack, New Jersey. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, December 5, 2013 at Temple Emeth 1666 Windzor Rd Teaneck, NJ at 10:00am.

ENGER--Paul. The Board of Directors of Stageplays Theatre Company mourns the loss of our friend and fellow Board member, Paul Enger, who passed away on Friday, November 29th. Paul will be remembered as a kind, warm and supportive individual, always affirming, ever positive, and as playwright and artist of the first rank. Paul will live on through his work and the plays he authored, "In the Air", "Benefit Performance", "Harmon and Ruth", "Wise Women", and "Last Night in Naples", with which we are very proud to have been associated. Richard Hirschman, M.D., Chairman Tom Ferriter, Artistic Director

DRUCKER--John J. M.D.,age 94, of Media, PA., formerly of Forest Hills, NY, passed away peacefully on December 2. Beloved husband of Marguerite (Mershon) for 68 years. Loving father of Mary Jane Gabbay (Meir), Elizabeth Condrige (John J.), John Jr, M.D., Suzanne Robotham (John), Dale Drucker Prifti (Michael), Joseph (Kathy), and Eileen Zwart (Peter). Also survived by fifteen grandchildren, five great- grandchildren, seven nieces and nephews, and his sisters, Ruth Drucker and Rosemary Preis. He is a graduate of Xavier High School, Fordham College, the Cornell University School of Medicine and Babies Hospital at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center. Following completion of his medical training, he served in the U.S. Army in the Philippines. He will be remembered as a dedicated pediatrician in Forest Hills, where he practiced for 42 years and was known for his unfailing kindness and generosity by all who knew him. Visitation hours at Fox Funeral Home, 98-07 Ascan Avenue, Forest Hills, NY on Friday, December 6th from 2-5 and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial at Our Lady Queen of Martyrs Church, Forest Hills, NY on Saturday at 10am. In lieu of flowers, donations would be appreciated to the National Parkinson Foundation, PO Box 5018 Hagerstown, MD 21741 or to the Granite Farms Estates Samaritan Fund, 1343 W. Baltimore Pike, Media, PA 19063

CULBERTSON--John "Jack" Harrison Junior, Beloved father, husband, brother, son, and friend departed this earth on Monday, December 2, 2013 at 7:10pm at the age of 62. Jack is survived by his wife, Elizabeth Broaddus Culbertson, and his children, Kirby Steele Culbertson (25), John "Jake" Harrison Culbertson III (22), and Katharine Louise Culbertson (19); his mother, Grace Culbertson; and his sisters, Marian Burke, and Katharine Prentice. Jack was born on July 23, 1951, in Morristown, NJ to Mr. and Mrs. John H. Culbertson Sr. Jack attended The Peck Elementary School, and The Lawrenceville School in Princeton, NJ, class of 1970. Growing up, Jack attended the Camp Timanous in Raymond, ME, which shaped his lifelong passion for the outdoors. Jack graduated from The University of California, Berkeley, in 1974. He attended Emory University Medical School, graduating in 1978. Jack continued at Emory for his internship in general surgery from 1978-79, residency in general surgery at Wayne State University in Detroit, MI from 1981-81, and residency in plastic surgery at Emory from 1982-84. He joined Emory as a faculty member in 1986. In addition to his exceptional work with patients at Emory, he held a strong belief in the importance of education and training for the next generation of plastic and reconstructive surgeons. He put that belief into action as Director of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery services at Grady Memorial Hospital, mentoring hundreds of plastic and reconstructive surgery residents during his 27 years at Emory. He also served as Associate Professor of Surgery, Division of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery, Chief in the Department of Plastic Surgery at Grady Memorial Hospital and Emory University Hospital Midtown, and Section Chief of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at Children's Healthcare of Atlanta. For many years, Dr. Culbertson annually travelled with his students to Shiprock Northern Navajo Medical Center in New Mexico, and received the Navajo Area Indian Health Service Area Director's Award for Outstanding Health Care Provider in 1997. Jack was a teacher in all respects of life, sharing his knowledge and passion for the world with his friends and family. Jack was a curious and energetic man, demonstrated through his passions for flying, skiing, fly-fishing, ice hockey, carpentry, and mountaineering. He frequently spent time in the outdoors and logged hundreds of hours flying to Maine and Telluride. His sense of adventure was contagious to those closest to him, cultivating a wonder of the world and a desire to see and learn from all experiences. A celebration of the life of Jack Culbertson will be held on Saturday, December 7, 2013 at 3pm at Peachtree Presbyterian, 3434 Roswell Road NW, Atlanta, GA, 30305. The family is requesting that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to Doctors Without Borders or Island Heritage Trust, P.O. Box 42, Deer Isle, ME 04627.

BROWN--Curtis Jay, LCSW, 57, on November 25, 2013. Cherished husband of Alastair, devoted son of Patricia and the late Norman, loving brother to Karen and Duane and beloved brother-in-law to Belinda. BAMBERGER--Gerald F.,age 93, died on December 2, 2013 in Sarasota, FL. He is survived by his beloved wife, Ursula; their children Gale (Philip Davis), Richard (Barbara), Annette (Marc Lieber), and Peter (Ellen); their devoted grandchildren Jonah (Ayelet), Corinna, Sivan, Daniel, Rachel, Talia, Maya, Zachary, Sarah, and Noa; their loving great-grandchildren Liam and Natan; his sister, Vera; and by numerous cousins, nieces and friends.
