GRIFFIN--Dr. Alice. The Trustees, Staff and Artists of Signature Theatre lovingly remember Dr. Alice Griffin. She was an amazing, inspiring woman; we celebrate Alice today and always.

ZISES--Bernard Donald, passed away Thursday at the age of 98 in the comfort of his home, surrounded by his family. He was married to the late Ruth (Grau) Zises. He is survived by his sons Selig, Jay and his wife Nancy, and Seymour, his grandchildren Lynn and her husband Doug, Lara, Samantha and her husband Drew, Justin and his wife Amy, Meryl, Aaron, Samuel, Benjamin and Natalie, and his great-grandchildren Isabelle, Macklin, Ryder, Lily, Simon, Julian, Oliver, Freddie and Margot, his niece Shea and her husband Jeffrey, his great-nieces Heather, Julie and Kaitlyn, and his daughters-in-law Susan, Susan and Cathy.

WELCH--Christopher Evan, Todd Haimes and the entire Roundabout Theatre Company staff mourn the loss of an extraordinarily talented member of our theatrical family, Christopher Evan Welch. His wit and humor were felt both on stage and off by all who experienced his work. Our thoughts and prayers are with his family during this difficult time.

WEINSTEIN--Rosalind, Darling spouse of the late Mike Weinstein, beloved mother of Karen Laufer (Marty), Ilene Weinstein, and Robin Meyer (Stuart). Doting and loving grandmother of Sari Laufer (Benjamin Cutter), Meredith Meyer and Megan Meyer. Cherished great-grandmother of Jacob Samuel Cutter. Adored aunt, cousin, and friend to many.

KULKA--Marilisa Jusko. Born January 14, 1928 in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. Died November 18, 2013 in Manhattan. Daughter of John and Elizabeth Jusko. Survived by her son Robert. Funeral to be held at Church of the Blessed Sacrament, 152 West 71 Street, NY, NY. Saturday, December 7, 2013 at 10am. Donations may be made to Muscular Dystrophy Association.
OROZCO--Dr. Julia, (nee Mayer) passed away on November 27, 2013. She touched many lives. She made the world a better place for those who knew her, and for many who didn't.

HIRSCH--Charles William. Brilliant, beloved Charles William Hirsch passed away on November 26th, he was 66 years young. Dedicated English Professor at New York City Technical College in Brooklyn. Born in St. Paul, Minnesota, survived by innumerable friends and family. Funeral Mass Monday, December 9 at 1pm, Oratory Church of St. Bonifice, 190 Duffield Street, Brooklyn, NY.

ENGER--Paul. The Board of Directors of Stageplays Theatre Company mourns the loss of our friend and fellow Board member, Paul Enger, who passed away on Friday, November 29th. Paul will be remembered as a kind, warm and supportive individual, always affirming, ever positive, and as playwright and artist of the first rank. Paul will live on through his work and the plays he authored, "In the Air", "Benefit Performance", "Harmon and Ruth", "Wise Women", and "Last Night in Naples", with which we are very proud to have been associated. Richard Hirschman, M.D., Chairman Tom Ferriter, Artistic Director

CULBERTSON--John "Jack" Harrison Junior, Beloved father, husband, brother, son, and friend departed this earth on Monday, December 2, 2013 at 7:10pm at the age of 62. Jack is survived by his wife, Elizabeth Broaddus Culbertson, and his children, Kirby Steele Culbertson (25), John "Jake" Harrison Culbertson III (22), and Katharine Louise Culbertson (19); his mother, Grace Culbertson; and his sisters, Marian Burke, and Katharine Prentice. Jack was born on July 23, 1951, in Morristown, NJ to Mr. and Mrs. John H. Culbertson Sr. Jack attended The Peck Elementary School, and The Lawrenceville School in Princeton, NJ, class of 1970. Growing up, Jack attended the Camp Timanous in Raymond, ME, which shaped his lifelong passion for the outdoors. Jack graduated from The University of California, Berkeley, in 1974. He attended Emory University Medical School, graduating in 1978. Jack continued at Emory for his internship in general surgery from 1978-79, residency in general surgery at Wayne State University in Detroit, MI from 1981-81, and residency in plastic surgery at Emory from 1982-84. He joined Emory as a faculty member in 1986. In addition to his exceptional work with patients at Emory, he held a strong belief in the importance of education and training for the next generation of plastic and reconstructive surgeons. He put that belief into action as Director of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery services at Grady Memorial Hospital, mentoring hundreds of plastic and reconstructive surgery residents during his 27 years at Emory. He also served as Associate Professor of Surgery, Division of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery, Chief in the Department of Plastic Surgery at Grady Memorial Hospital and Emory University Hospital Midtown, and Section Chief of Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery at Children's Healthcare of Atlanta. For many years, Dr. Culbertson annually travelled with his students to Shiprock Northern Navajo Medical Center in New Mexico, and received the Navajo Area Indian Health Service Area Director's Award for Outstanding Health Care Provider in 1997. Jack was a teacher in all respects of life, sharing his knowledge and passion for the world with his friends and family. Jack was a curious and energetic man, demonstrated through his passions for flying, skiing, fly-fishing, ice hockey, carpentry, and mountaineering. He frequently spent time in the outdoors and logged hundreds of hours flying to Maine and Telluride. His sense of adventure was contagious to those closest to him, cultivating a wonder of the world and a desire to see and learn from all experiences. A celebration of the life of Jack Culbertson will be held on Saturday, December 7, 2013 at 3pm at Peachtree Presbyterian, 3434 Roswell Road NW, Atlanta, GA, 30305. The family is requesting that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to Doctors Without Borders or Island Heritage Trust, P.O. Box 42, Deer Isle, ME 04627.

The Fallons, Langinos, Cornells mourn the loss and celebrate the life of our beloved sister-in-law, aunt and matriarch for her brilliance, kindness, love of family, and generosity to all. Her 90 years inspired many: from housewife and mother, to Vice President at Chase MB, to J.D. at age 68, to Chair of Greater Jamaica Development Corp., to Eucharistic Minister, to inner city family law practice. Wake: Dalton Funeral Home, New Hyde Park, on December 7th and 8th.

MOLLOY--Therese M.,90, on December 5, 2013. Devoted wife of the late William. Loving mother of Michael, Kevin (Sally), and William (Dorothy). Cherished grandmother of Thomas, Brian, Nikki (Eyal), Kevin (Tomy), Meghan, Caitlin, Elizabeth and Ivy. Beloved great-grandmother of Adar and Mila. Loving sister of the late Moira, John and Della. GLICKER--Stanley. We honor the legacy of this wonderful man and extend our deepest sympathies to his wife Rosalind and their entire family. Jolyne Caruso-FitzGerald, Chair, Board of Trustees Debora Spar, President

GALLEN--Richard Theodore, passed away on Tuesday, December 3. He had been suffering from Parkinson's Disease for 12 years. Richard was a beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend to many, a successful and innovative publisher, and standout member of a great generation.

GALLEN--Richard T.,age 80, died peacefully on December 3, 2013 from complications of Parkinson's Disease. Beloved husband for 54 years to Jill. Adored father of Jonathan, David, and daughter-in-law Amy. Proud and delighted grandfather of Hannah, Samuel, Grace, Harry and Sarah who should have had him longer. Gifted publisher. Dealmaker in publishing. Founded many new publishing companies who owe him their existence. Passionate and generous helper, rescuer, career-maker to hundreds. Thousand acts of anonymous personal charity to anyone he knew in need. Lover of nature, cats, dogs, squirrels, birds; no number of legs or wings beneath his empathy. Memorial gifts to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research or Mt. Sinai Hospital, NYC in Departments of Cardiology and Neurology would be appreciated by the family. His memory will be a blessing.

CANFIELD--Cass Jr.,distinguished book publisher and editor, and dear husband, father, grandfather, friend and mentor, died peacefully on July 30th at his home in Manhattan. He was 90. He was born in New York City on May 4th, 1923, the eldest son of Katharine Temple Emmet and Augustus Cass Canfield. He graduated from St. Bernard's and St. Mark's schools and attended the University of Chicago prior to enlisting in the Army in 1943, where he served in the Signal Corps in the Pacific until the end of World War II. After military service he followed his father's footsteps into the book business, initially taking a job as a salesman in the Doubleday bookstore in Grand Central Station. After holding publishing positions at McGraw Hill and Coward, McCann, he joined what was then Harper and Brothers in the mid-1950s. He rose quickly to head the high-growth trade paperback department in the 1960's, and occupied several other management roles, including vice president and publisher of the paperback, religious and medical divisions. He served on the company's board of directors from 1967 to 1987. In his long career he was known for publishing books of quality and lasting influence. With the help of his colleague Hugh Van Dusen, he initiated Colophon Books and reorganized and developed the Perennial line of paperbacks. He also created the Icon Editions imprint, a line of accessible academic art history titles in paperback. He was responsible for bringing a number of distinguished Latin American authors into English translation for the first time, including Guillermo Cabrera Infante, Julio Cortazar, Reinaldo Arenas, Joao Ubaldo Ribeiro, Alvaro Mutis, and Ilan Stavans, as well as Nobel Prize winners Gabriel Garcia Marquez and Mario Vargas Llosa. Among the many authors he worked with were Peter F. Drucker, Craig Claiborne, Hugh Thomas, Enrique Krauze, Otto Friedrich, Paul Johnson, and art historians Robert Rosenbloom, Laurie Schneider Adams, Irving Sandler, and Bruce Cole. He adored his family, and considered his six children as his greatest life accomplishment. He plunged with joy into sailing, skiing and large dinners with his family at home, taking great pride in his roasts, risottos, and his famous boiled dinner with green sauce. He was proud of his Irish American heritage, taking his family to Ireland in 1998 for the 200th anniversary of the rebellion of the United Irishmen, in which his ancestor Thomas Addis Emmet (an Attorney General of New York State, and prominent lawyer in the Jeffersonian period) was a main participant. He is survived by his wife of 40 years, Abigail Angell Canfield, his sons Thomas, Temple, Lewis, Michael and Nicholas Canfield, daughter Susannah Canfield Hurd, granddaughters Juliana and Sophie Canfield and Ellory Hurd, grandsons Samuel Canfield and Ethan Hurd, daughter-in-law Danielle Parris, son-in-law Stephen Hurd, and dear step-sister Isabel Fuller Fox. His brother Michael Temple Canfield died in 1967. A memorial celebration will be held on Saturday, December 14th at the Lotos Club in New York at 5:00pm.

ANNIS--Esther, Born in Brooklyn on February 19, 1923, she died peacefully, in bed, on December 5, 2013. An educator, a volunteer, a mother and aunt and grandmother, her hands were always busy. Wrapped in a gentle shell covering a steely interior, she provided a strong center for her family. She parented until the end, always ready with hug, a smile, a shoulder to lean on, and chocolate to soothe any frazzled soul who crossed her path. Predeceased by her husband of 53 years, Herbert, she is survived by her children Susan (Bill Hileman), Jeffrey (Terri Lynn), and Jean, and eight grandchildren Billy, Jennifer (Brian Petersen), Sarah, Rebecca, Naomi, Miriam and Benjamin.) Funeral Service will be held 11am on Sunday December 8th at the Gutterman and Musicant Jewish Funeral Directors, Hackensack, NJ, www.guttermanandmusicant.com. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to Oceanside (NY) Scholarship Fund, Hadassah, or GRIN GrandparentsINresidence.

ZITRIN--Charlotte Marker, MD, died peacefully at home on December 3, 2013, at the age of 95. Dr. Zitrin was born in Brooklyn on September 30, 1918, before women had the right to vote. She was the daughter of the late Abraham Marker and Regina Adler Marker, and the older sister of the late Harold Marker. An exceptionally gifted musician and academic student, she became interested in psychiatry when she heard a lecture about Sigmund Freud in the Community Hall in Sea Gate, where she lived. With a small handful of women, she attended NYU Medical School (class of 1943), when she met and married Arthur Zitrin (NYU Med 1945), who survives her. Everyone in the class wanted her notes. The Doctors Zitrin moved with their children, Richard and Elizabeth, from Brooklyn to Great Neck, to take advantage of the excellent public education. Dr. Zitrin died in the home they purchased new in 1954. Supremely disciplined and organized, she started in practice as a pediatrician, and completed a second residency in psychiatry when both of her children were in Junior High School and could no longer come home for lunch. She was the founding Director of the Phobia Clinic at Long Island Jewish Hillside Medical Center, and held that position until her retirement in her 70s. She was lead investigator in many peer-reviewed studies on phobias, conducting groundbreaking research on desensitization and talk therapies for usual phobias, and drug and talk therapies for agoraphobia and panic attacks. Charlotte was a generous philanthropist with wide-ranging interests including progressive politics, human rights, health, women's rights, the environment and the survival of Israel. Her husband said that if they could have, the whales she saved would have swum up to their door. She was a patron of the many arts of New York. Her Metropolitan Museum membership card says "member since 1955." She endowed scholarships for medical students at NYU and law students at Columbia, where her brother studied. In addition to her husband of 71 years, her children and daughter-in-law Victoria, she is survived by four grandchildren, Jesse (and his wife Ashley), Gabriel, Jacob and Maya, and a great-granddaughter Lauren Charlotte. There was a private burial. Donations in her memory may be made to the Charlotte Zitrin Scholarship Fund at NYU at: https://onlinegiving.nyumc.org

ZILLIAC--Cynthia Burkhart, a former Editor at the then Scott Foresman, in Glenview, IL, mother of three, born December 7, 1931, died November 28, 2013, at Sunrise Senior Living in Wilmette. Surviving are her husband of 59 years, George; three children, Gregory George Zilliac (Jennifer), Barbara Zilliac Graham (Neal), and Jocelyn Zilliac DeVault (Chip) and nine grandchildren (three each). Cynthia (Cindy) was born in New York City and grew up near Union City, PA. Cindy attended Allegheny College, Meadville, PA, as a Psychology major, where she met George in a psychological statistics class. She lived in Evanston, IL for the last 42 years. Growing up on what might be called a rural-nonfarm Cindy rode and cared for a horse named Chain. Our family loved to camp where she was sometimes referred to as "Ranger Cindy" by the kids for her organizing of the chaos of camping with family and dog. She also enjoyed private flying with her husband. One of her major interests was singing - she was trained as an operatic soprano in her youth, sang for years with the North Shore Choral Society, and sang in Aida at Chautauqua, NY. She made stained glass art, painted, and tutored urban disadvantaged youth in reading in a special program at Scott Foresman, after hours. Perhaps her most notable accomplishments lay in 20 or more years of lexicography in dictionary editing, at Scott Foresman. She was responsible for a lot that went into several first grade through High School Thorn- dike-Barnhart dictionaries, where she specialized in science definitions. She was also responsible for much of the dictionary art. Later she worked in the Social Studies department, working with authors on several middle-school social studies books on the histories of Florida and Texas. She was loved by all of us for her understanding and loving spirit. She is sorely missed. A celebration of her life is being planned. For more information contact zilliac@aol.com

WOS--Paul Zenon. In loving memory, on December 2, 2013. Paul Wos passed away at his home in Sarasota, FL at the age of 92. An intrepid fighter for freedom all his life, Paul was a combat veteran of the anti-Nazi and anti-Soviet invasion of Poland in September 1939. During the Holocaust, Paul Wos, along with his father, mother, and siblings, rescued the Jewish Melamed family and other Jews, including future professor Israel Shahak. For this selfless act, Paul was awarded the Yad Vashem Medal, "The Righteous Among the Nations." At the time Paul Wos also volunteered as a soldier in the underground Polish Home Army. In its ranks he participated in the Warsaw Rising of 1944. Captured by the Germans, along with his family members, he became a prisoner of the Nazi Flossenburg Concentration Camp. After the liberation by the Americans, he participated as a courier in the anti-Communist underground, traveling between the West and Soviet-occupied Poland, which he was eventually forced to leave. Paul Wos settled in the United States, first in New York, and then retiring in Sarasota, FL. Engineer, entrepreneur, philanthropist, Polish and American Patriot, he became an avid traveler upon his rather late retirement. He also penned a memoir, sponsored a variety of charitable and educational causes and remained active in various Polish organizations including Veteran groups. Paul Wos lived his life by believing it was everyone's moral obligation to always do the right thing. He is survived by his wife of 65 years, Wanda; his son, Konrad Wos; his daughter, Ambassador Aldona Wos; their spouses Meggan Walsh and Louis DeJoy as well as four grandchildren, Taylor and Carson Wos and Ania and Andrew DeJoy and a sister, Wanda Wos-Lorenc. He is preceded in death by his sister, Irena Wos-Madejski and his brother, Jerzy Odon Wos. Contributions may be made to: Institute of World Politics, 1521 16th Street, NW, Washington, DC 20036; Designate for the Kosciusko Chair.

VANDEN BROECK--Ellen, 90, of Louisville, passed away peacefully with her family by her side on November 17, 2013. A Memorial service with committal will be held at 2:00pm Saturday, January 18, 2014 at St. John's Episcopal Church, 1419 Pine St. in Boulder. There will be a reception immediately following the services. Ellen was born on June 5, 1923, to Gottfried Walker and Frieda Bessire Walker in Buffalo, N.Y. She was raised in North Tonawanda, a suburb of Buffalo. In 1925 her parents, Swiss immigrants, founded Walker Brothers and Monroe, a watch and jewelry shop that remains in business today. The family was able to weather the difficulties of the Depression, sharing food with friends and neighbors and, most significantly for Ellen, ensuring her piano studies continued. World War II interrupted Ellen's music career when at age 21 she joined the Coast Guard as a WAVES radio operator stationed in St. Louis. After her honorable discharge in 1946 she attended the Zurich Music Conservatory to study piano. It was there that she met her future husband, Claude Vanden Broeck, and together they raised their four children in Haworth, N.J. During her time in Haworth Ellen was active in the local swim club, an avid tennis player, skier and bridge player and sang in local choirs in Haworth and Englewood. A gourmet cook, Ellen was also known for her legendary garden. An active member of the Swiss Society of New York, Ellen remained connected to her Swiss relatives by hosting them in her home in Haworth or visiting them in Switzerland. She spoke Swiss, her first language, her entire life. Music was Ellen's passion and sharing her love of piano with her children, friends and neighbors was her utmost delight. A music room with two grand pianos provided the perfect venue for concerts she hosted regularly. Opening her home to the community and inviting neighbors and fellow musicians to both enjoy and perform was her raison d'etre. After her marriage ended, Ellen moved to New York in 1980 ready to reinvent herself and embark on her career as student, musician and philanthropist. She earned her bachelor's degree from Sarah Lawrence College in 1979 and her master's degree in creative writing from Brooklyn College in 1984. She continued her piano studies with the Leschetizky Association in New York, spent summers at the Adamant Music School in Vermont and continued to host home concerts at her Manhattan Apartment. Ellen's love of the arts and generous nature touched the lives of aspiring musicians and artists from graduate students to young children. She was instrumental in launching the New World Symphony in New York, sponsored students at the Mannes School of Music and was a major benefactor of the Third Street Music School Settlement in New York. Ellen was a fierce supporter of Native American art and culture and local modern artists, and served on the board of the New Museum. She was also an ardent supporter of Israel, Jewish causes and civil rights. In 1994, Ellen began to divide her time between New York and Boulder to be closer to family. She moved to Boulder permanently in 2004 and became involved with the CU College of Music's Adopt-a-Student program and was a major supporter of the Boulder Philharmonic Orchestra. Ellen is survived by her four children, Leslie Vanden Broeck Dale and her husband Kenneth of Portland, Oregon, Barbara Vanden Broeck Fernie and her husband John of Lafayette, Claire Ellen Vanden Broeck of Lafayette, and Peter A. Vanden Broeck and his wife Sabrina of Shaker Heights, Ohio; and her grandchildren Sarah Dale of Washington D.C., Elliot Dale of Bozeman, Montana, Eliza and Luke Fernie of Denver, Paul and Andrew Vanden Broeck of Shaker Heights, and Lauren Vanden Broeck, attending The College of Wooster in Ohio. She was preceded in death by her brother Gottfried "Fred" Walker. Donations in Ellen's memory may be made to the Third Street Music School 235 East 11th Street New York, NY 10003

TOBIAS--Donald J.,a devoted husband and humanitarian committed to improving the lives of New Yorkers, died November 22, 2013. Dr. Tobias served as executive director of Cornell Cooperative Extension NYC since 2005. His impact lives on in individuals and communities throughout New York. From 1980-2006, he held the position of Associate Professor at Cornell University in the College of Human Ecology's Department of Policy Analysis and Management. Dr. Tobias was respected by colleagues and friends as a mentor, visionary, teacher and researcher and known as someone who transformed people's lives. In 1996, he married his wife Brenda. They met at Cornell, where a conversation in a hallway led to the adventure of a lifetime. Through time and space, there will be no story like theirs. Those wishing to honor Dr. Tobias's memory can send a gift to Congregation Rodeph Sholom, 7 West 83rd Street, NYC, 10024, in c/o Rabbi Spratt, or the Donald J. Tobias Memorial Fund in c/o the College of Human Ecology at Cornell University.

Born in New York City on December 5, 1915, to Albert and Clara Freeman Smullyan. Beloved husband of the late Irene (Lapouse) Smullyan. Loving father of Daniel Smullyan of New York City and Deborah Smullyan of Milton, MA. Cherished father-in-law of Char Smullyan and John Sullivan. Dear cousin of Raymond Smullyan of Elka Park, NY. Also survived by four grandchildren, Brady and Egon Smullyan and John and Margaret Sullivan; a niece, Margot Capra of Rancho Mirage, CA; and two nephews, Andrew Terris of Halifax, Nova Scotia, and Jacob Smullyan of New York City. Sloan; also an art dealer, restorer, and appraiser. Lover of cosmology and classical music, especially Mozart. Charitable contributions in his memory may be made to Perkins School for the Blind, 175 North Beacon St., Watertown, MA 02472. Services will be private.

RITTER--Marie (Ree-Ree), passed peacefully On December 6, 2013 after a long fight with cancer. She died in the comfort of her home surrounded by the love of her family. Marie was loved for her generosity, laughter and wit, bringing Light to the darkest of situations with astonishing ease. Much of her life was dedicated to selfless service. As a devoted wife and mother, she had a flair for making a house a home. Ree-Ree shared this gift with the wider world, volunteering her time and talents where many would not go. Crowned as the "Foot Rub Fairy" she dedicated countless hours on various AIDS units during the height of the epidemic, providing much needed support, relief and dignity to those affected by HIV. Most recently, during her personal battle with cancer, Marie's service branched worldwide taking the form of her online discussion and support forum "Tarceva Divas and Dudes" as "Marie-Zee100". Marie is survived by her husband David, her children Jenna and Michael, and her cat Taki. Private cremation. In lieu of flowers, kindly make contributions to your favorite charity.

PAVLICH-CARRON--Jacqueline, (1945-2013), member of the dance faculty at the University of Southern California Glorya Kaufman School of Dance, passed away on November 30, in Los Angeles. She danced professionally in Europe and, in California, as Principal Dancer of the Oakland Ballet Company. As Associate Member of the Royal Academy of Dance, London, she worked throughout Europe and in the United States as teacher, choreographer, ballet mistress and private coach. In Los Angeles, she taught at a number of dance studios and, from 1987 to 1997, she was Director of her own dance academy, School of Ballet Arts, before being hired by USC in 2001. She was an inspiration to her students who found in her the challenge of a demanding teacher with a sympathetic ear but ultimately a professional artist to emulate.

PARSONS--Patricia, (nee O'Brien), 83, of Redding, CT and Essex, NY, and formerly of Burlington, VT, passed away on Saturday, November 30 following a brief illness. Her extraordinary enthusiasm for life, art, people and martinis will be greatly missed by her family and her many friends of all ages. Born to Isabel Munroe O'Brien and John Larkin O'Brien, in Albany, NY, on May 26, 1930, Pat attended St. Agnes School and graduated from Miss Porter's School and Vassar College. She raised her family in Bedford, NY, and opened an art gallery, Webb & Parsons, in Bedford Village in the early 1970s, showing contemporary art. After seeing the work of Inez Nathaniel Walker, an inmate at the Bedford Hills Correctional Facility, she began showing and collecting the work of self-taught artists as well. Pat shared her love of art passionately, insistently and generously, and she donated many works from her collection of self-taught art to museums, including the American Folk Art Museum and the Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center at Vassar, where her collection was the subject of an exhibition, "Faith and Fantasy in Outsider Art," in 2009. An artist herself, Pat saw beauty everywhere she looked. She was predeceased by her brothers Jerry and Duncan O'Brien, and her former husband, James O. Parsons, Jr. She is survived by her daughters Laurie and Amy, her adored son-in-law Paul Bird and beloved grandchildren Isabel and Henry Bird.
OROZCO--Dr. Julia, (nee Mayer) passed away on November 27, 2013. She touched many lives. She made the world a better place for those who knew her, and for many who didn't.

OCKENDEN--Edward, of Paoli, PA, author of "The Ghosts of Company G" a Pacific war memoir has died at 89. He was predeceased by his wife of 60 years, Dawn Leonard, and is survived by his daughter Marianne Sanders and four sons, Stephen, William, Robert and John as well as eight grand and two great-grandchildren and three sisters. He grew up in Northampton, MA., where his father, The Rev. Albion Ockenden was rector of St. John's Episcopal Church. He attended the Lenox School, enlisted in the army at 18 serving in the Southwest Pacific region and saw heavy action. He was severely wounded during the invasion of Luzon, the Phillipines and was awarded the Bronze Star, the Purple Heart and the Combat Infantry Badge. After his discharge he graduated from the University of Connecticut and worked in New York and Ohio in advertising. He subsequently moved into radio, retiring as General Manager of a radio station in Maine. A funeral service will be held at St. Peter's Church in the Green Valley in Malvern, PA at 1:00pm on December 14 and if desired contributions may be made to Episcopal Community Services, 225 South Third Street, Philadelphia, PA 19106.

OPPENHEIMER--Henry. Much loved husband of Ruth. He had a love of art and life and will be irreplaceable. Do- nations in memory may be sent to Laniado Hospital in Israel. www.en.laniado.org.il Memorial service to be announced at a later date.

OBRENTZ--Bert. Loving husband of Arlene. Father to Barbara. Stepfather to Gary and Rick. Adoring grandfather to Joshua, Noah, Xander, Julius, and Mika. Great-grandfather to Leila. Decorated veteran in WWII. Died peacefully at his home in San Francisco on December 5. He was as curious about life at 92 as he was at 22. We will miss him.

NOTIAS--Irene "Rena," age 48, of New York City, passed away on November 27, 2013. She was the beloved daughter of the late Captain Harry Notias and Phyllis Thravalos Notias, sister of Nicholas Notias. Rena was a graduate of Columbia University/ Barnard College and an accomplished Artist. Professionally she was an Executive in her Father's shipping company. She will be greatly missed by her family and many friends. A private burial was held December 2, 2013 at Kensico Cemetery, Valhalla, NY. Memorial donations, in lieu of flowers may be sent to The Hellenic Relief Foundation, Morgan Stanley Children's Hospital at New York Presbyterian or Free Arts.

NOBANDEGANI--Fariborz, The Iranian American community mourns the loss of its prodigal son Dr. Fariborz Nobandegani, known professionally as Fred Noban, who passed away at the untimely age of 49, on November 29th from complications following bone marrow and liver transplants. He was the youngest Director of Neurosurgery at Lenox Hill Hospital, and was touted as "the Doctor's Doctor" by many of his colleagues. Dr. Nobandegani was a diplomate of the American Board of Neurological Surgery as well as the American Board of Pain Medicine. He was a member of the prestigious Alpha Omega Alpha National Medical Honor Society and an Assistant Professor at NYU School of Medicine. Fariborz emigrated with his family from Iran in December of 1978, in the midst of the Islamic Revolution. He began his first day of classes as a 9th grader just 12 hours after his arrival in the United States. Working late into the night and often with a dictionary by his side, he quickly rose to the top and consistently graduated first in his class. He received his electrical engineering degree from the State University of New York at Stony Brook, only to realize that his passion lay in medicine. While working for Symbol Technologies as a researcher, he studied for his MCAT and was accepted to Down State Medical School where he also completed his residency training. He found his calling in neurosurgery while treating many police officers with gunshot wounds in the crime spree of 1980's Brooklyn. He went on to become a highly successful and respected neurosurgeon, practicing both at the Lenox Hill Hospital and the NYU Medical Center. He and his partners founded Neuroaxis in Manhattan in an upper eastside historical brownstone, which he meticulously restored and refitted to serve the needs of his patients. Neuroaxis became a pioneer approach in patient care from pain management to post-operative rehab, nutrition counseling, and holistic care. An avid sportsman who loved nature and "beautiful America", he often traveled to far away places to find the perfect fly-fishing spots. He loved his adopted country so deeply that he routinely dedicated his first Thanksgiving prayer to the "blessings of this wonderful country." His heartfelt speeches and unique humor would move everyone to tears, only to be followed by exploding laughter. His larger than life personality, his passion for life and huge smile was contagious. His love for his wife, Jennifer, and their two daughters, Alexa and Ava was unmatched. His dedication to his mom, for whom he planted a rose garden in the backyard of his Ridgefield, Connecticut home was unconditional. His relationship with his adoring sisters was magical. He had unwavering commitment to the state of Israel and Jewish charities. For five grueling months his loving brothers-in-law, nephews and close family and friends held daily prayers for him often behind his hospital door. A memorial was held on Friday, December 6th at the Academy of Medicine in NYC. Over seven hundred people were in attendance. Many were his former patients, whose lives he had saved. Contributions in his memory can be made to Save Our Kids foundation. Headed by the angelic Dr. Tom Walsh, the S.O.S Kids Foundation (SOSkidsfoundation.org) is a not-for-profit that finds treatments for resistant bacteria and helps patients with severely compromised immune system. Fariborz, your gentle voice and giant laughter will forever echo in our broken hearts. You lived for the truth and you fought bravely and with dignity till the very end. Your loving family: The Nobandegani, Brown, Adelipour, Zand, Moinian, Kermanshahchi, and Samuel families.

MULLER--Lorenzo C. 74, of Springfield, OR died November 28, 2013. He is survived in NY by his adoring daughter, Lani C. Muller and step-children Monica and Floyd. He will always be remembered with love and respect.

MOLLOY--Therese. The Fallons, Langinos, Cornells mourn the loss and celebrate the life of our beloved sister-in-law, aunt and matriarch for her brilliance, kindness, love of family, and generosity to all. Her 90 years inspired many: from housewife and mother, to Vice President at Chase MB, to J.D. at age 68, to Chair of Greater Jamaica Development Corp., to Eucharistic Minister, to inner city family law practice. Wake: Dalton Funeral Home, New Hyde Park, on December 7th and 8th.

MARGAN--Louis, on Wednesday evening November 27, 2013 at age 83. Dearest husband of Betty for 63 years. Beloved father of Patrice Fine (Paul), Michelle Carr (Bernard), grandchildren Jonathan, Andrea, Regin (Matt) and Peter. Louis was the owner of John Margan & Sons for 55 years, an avid gardener and jack-of-all-trades. Louis (Louie) will be greatly missed by family, friends and associates. Donatons to the National Aphasia Foundation.

MANDELA--Nelson. The Harlem Educational Activities Fund (HEAF) notes the passing of one of the great men of our time, who said that "Education is the most powerful weapon you can use to change the world." In his honor, we are designating donors to our endowment fund members of the Mandela Society. The Harlem Educational Activities Fund

MALONEY--John H.,81, of the North Shore of Long Island, NY on November 30, 2013. Born in the Bronx, he attended Cardinal Hays High School, Iona College and New York University. He is survived by his wife Josephine, his children Patrick (Karen), Maria (Danny) and Anne (Rick). He will be sorely missed by his grandchildren Meghan, Liam, Taylor, Stephanie, Maya, John, and Anthony. In lieu of flowers, donations are greatly appreciated to the Long Island Cares - The Harry Chapin Food Bank, 10 David's Drive, Hauppauge, NY 11788.
LEVINE--Doris, (nee Peskin) passed away at home on December 3, 2013 at 96. She is the beloved wife of the late Dr. Harold A. Levine, mother of Sally Anne Levine and sister of Arthur Peskin.

KENNEY--James Joseph, beloved father, husband, friend, and longtime editor of photography at Newsweek magazine, died Friday, December 6th in Charleston, South Carolina at the age of 81, after a prolonged illness. He is survived by daughters Elizabeth, Theresa, and Patricia; predeceased by his beloved wife Frances and son James. He was born in Manhattan on March 19, 1932 to Delia and Andrew Kenney. He attended the Power Memorial Academy High School and graduated from Iona College in 1954. He worked for the Associated Press before beginning his distinguished career at Newsweek, where he dedicated himself to advancing the magazine's award-winning photojournalism. Jim was a sharp-witted conversationalist with a wide variety of interests; he loved nature and the outdoors, and was an avid golfer and fan of the Mets and football Giants. He will be deeply missed by colleagues and friends, who fondly remember his laughter, warmth, and easygoing manner. His loved ones invite remembrances to be posted at Legacy.com.

KELLER--Donal E.,DDS, 89, of Manhasset and Westhampton Beach, NY, died peacefully, surrounded by his loving family on December 3, 2013. He leaves his wife, Barbara; children Andrew Keller, MD (Gillian), Jane Gordon (Lawrence), and Marjorie Powers (Alan); five grandchildren, nephew and niece. Memorial donations: Cancer Can't Get Me or St. Jude's.

KAUFTHAL--Edith, Father Patrick Desbois and the Board of The American Friends of Yahad-In Unum extend deep condolences to Judy and Uri Kaufthal, and Linda and Ilan Kaufthal, on the passing of their mother and mother-in-law, Edith. May her legacy of kindness live on through the generations. Our thoughts and prayers are with the entire Kaufthal family. David Black, President, Robin Massee, Executive Director

KAPLAN--Theodore. Born November 11, 1923, died December 6, 2013 in Manhattan. Known for his droll sense of humor and business acumen, Ted was respected by his colleagues and cherished by his friends. Born in Brooklyn, he attended St. John's University, where he was Sports Editor of the college newspaper. World War II interrupted his plan to obtain a law degree. He enlisted in 1942 and served as a trainer of B-17 and B-29 bomber crews with the US Army Air Force. He met his first wife, the former Rae Klausner, at a USO Dance, and upon his discharge in 1946 returned to New York with her and their infant daughter, Gene. He obtained a degree in Accounting from Long Island University and began his career as a manufacturing and sales executive. After retiring as President of AllForms Packaging, a division of Clevepak Corporation, he became advisor to the management of Plastirun Corporation. After daughter Mindy was born, the family moved to Hicksville, NY. Rae died in 1977 after 32 years of marriage, and in 1983 Ted married the former Elizabeth White Kahn, widow of Robert Propper Kahn. They moved from Manhattan to Stony Brook, New York in 1988, to St. James in 1997, and returned to Manhattan in March of this year. Ted was an entertaining storyteller about his adventures growing up in Williamsburg, his humorous misdeeds during the war that resulted in an inordinate amount of KP, and his racehorse, Champagne Night. He relished talking about his experiences photographing Bob Hope during the entertainer's WWII USO tour; his photographs appear in "The Spirit of Bob Hope" (Richard Grudens, 2002). After offering complimentary investment advice to widows of his close friends, Ted was invited to write a bi-weekly investment column for Times Beacon Record Newspapers on Long Island. Ted is survived by his wife, Elizabeth Kahn Kaplan; his daughters, Gene Wichman (Louis) and Mindy Taragan (Michael); four grandchildren, Ian Wichman (Lisa), Sheryl Ezratty (Dan); David Wichman (Maytal); and Robyn Taragan; seven great-grandchildren, and Liz's daughter Joanne Wolochow (Peter) and her two granddaughters, Jennifer and Robyn Wolochow. A private burial service will be held on December 8th, and a memorial service in the early spring. Gifts in his name to MJHS Hospice and Palliative Care, 39 Broadway #

HIRSCH--Charles William. Brilliant, beloved Charles William Hirsch passed away on November 26th, he was 66 years young. Dedicated English Professor at New York City Technical College in Brooklyn. Born in St. Paul, Minnesota, survived by innumerable friends and family. Funeral Mass Monday, December 9 at 1pm, Oratory Church of St. Bonifice, 190 Duffield Street, Brooklyn, NY.

HANELLIN--A. Stuart. December 6th. Beloved father of Andrew (Leslie) and Lisa (Arthur). Grandfather of Drew, David, Cort, Moshe. Loved his family, tennis, traveling, reading, theater, music, the beach, road trips. He was friendly, warm and kind.

GALLEN--Richard Theodore, passed away on Tuesday, December 3. He had been suffering from Parkinson's Disease for 12 years. Richard was a beloved husband, father, grandfather and friend to many, a successful and innovative publisher, and standout member of a great generation.

GALLEN--Richard T.,age 80, died peacefully on December 3, 2013 from complications of Parkinson's Disease. Beloved husband for 54 years to Jill. Adored father of Jonathan, David, and daughter-in-law Amy. Proud and delighted grandfather of Hannah, Samuel, Grace, Harry and Sarah who should have had him longer. Gifted publisher. Dealmaker in publishing. Founded many new publishing companies who owe him their existence. Passionate and generous helper, rescuer, career-maker to hundreds. Thousand acts of anonymous personal charity to anyone he knew in need. Lover of nature, cats, dogs, squirrels, birds; no number of legs or wings beneath his empathy. Memorial gifts to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research or Mt. Sinai Hospital, NYC in Departments of Cardiology and Neurology would be appreciated by the family. His memory will be a blessing. Funeral Monday, 10am, Riverside Memorial Chapel.

GALLAGHER--John E.,Sr. ("Captain Jack") "Aviation Pioneer" took his final flight here on Earth November 27, 2013. Born March 4th, 1920, he is survived by his wife Joan of 69 years, his three sons, five grandchildren, and seven great-grandchildren. He graduated from Parks Air College of St. Louis University in 1943. In 1963 he received the University's distinguished Oliver Parks Merit Award for his outstanding advancement of Civil Aviation both in the United States and Europe. He was principle engineer for the Air Force P-47 Thunderbolt Fighter and started the first scheduled helicopter service in New York (New York Airways) in 1949. Established the helicopter logistic and maintenance systems for then President John F. Kennedy White House called HMX1. He holds the first commercial helicopter pilot's license. He has slipped the surly bonds of Earth and is dancing in the sky on silver wings. He goes now where neither falcon nor eagle have ever gone and has touched the face of God. We love you Dad.

FORD--Shirley on November 30, 2013, age 75, after a brief illness. She brought music and laughter to all she met. Shirley will be missed by all who knew her. She is survived by Tony Monte (Anthony Monte-Bovi), her husband of 36 years. Reposing at Frank E. Campbell, The Funeral Chapel, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. on Tuesday and Wednesday from 2-5 and 7-9pm. In lieu of flowers, please make contributions to the MS Society (NY Chapter).

FELDMAN--Seymour, 94, of Hurley, NY passed peacefully at home on November 27, 2013. Born in Brooklyn. Past president Queensboro Hill Jewish Center in Queens. Leadership positions in pharmaceutical with Premo and Forest Labs. Generous loving spirit, devoted family man, perfectionist with hatred of injustice. Survived by his wife of 73 years, Rebecca Feldman, his son Dr. Sheldon Feldman and his wife Gayle Saunders of New York City, daughter Ellen Gust and husband Alan of Ft. Lauderdale, FL, six grandchildren, six great-grandchildren, a nephew and niece. In 1994, he partnered with Benedictine Hospital in Kingston, NY to establish the Fern Feldman Anolick Breast Center to honor the memory of his daughter Fern who died from breast cancer at age 37. Contributions to Benedictine Health Foundation-Breast Center. Online condolences: www.Simpson-Gaus.com

EDWARDS--Rev. Tom Turney, of Wilmington, NC, retired Episcopal minister, passed away peacefully on Saturday, November 30, 2013, after hospitalization due to a fall. He was the son of the late Eldorado Franklin Edwards and Sarah Elizabeth Turney. He is survived by his intrepid wife and companion of 69 loving years, Rosemary Cody (Romey). Tom was born in Winston-Salem, NC, graduated in 1942 from Sewanee, University of the South, and served as Lieutenant in the U.S. Navy during WWII. Upon discharge from the Navy, he prepared for the ministry at the Episcopal Theological Seminary (ETS) in Cambridge, MA, while simultaneously pursuing studies in French history at Harvard University. He was ordained in 1948. After ministering to several small North Carolina parishes, he served as Canon at the American Cathedral in Paris from 1950-1951. That yearlong experience cemented his passion for French culture, his mastery of the language, spoken and written, and his delight in the novels of Georges Simenon. It also enabled him to complete original research on Jansenism in 17th century France. He received his Ph.D. from Harvard in 1961 and a Master of Sacred Theology from ETS that same year. During an uninterrupted career in the ministry, he served five years as rector at St. Philip's Church in Durham, NC, 19 years at St. Paul's Church in Chestnut Hill, Philadelphia, and eleven years at Church of the Ascension in Clearwater, FL. In his sermons he used his scholarship, story-telling ability and sense of humor to illuminate the dilemmas facing Christians in the modern world. Church membership grew during his tenures; church building projects were funded; music, pageantry, and Christian education flourished. He also served on the boards of several civic organizations, including the Library Company of Philadelphia. In 1988, Tom and Romey returned joyfully to the American Cathedral for two more years before retiring to Wilmington. In addition to his full time parish work, Tom served for 53 years as a summer chaplain at St. Christopher's by the Sea in Winter Harbor, ME. There he captured the beauty of sea, rocks and pines in deft watercolors, and kept watch on wild birds. His many friends remember Tom as a bruising tennis player, a sympathetic listener, an enthusiast of puns and bon mots and as great company over the dinner table. His mind was broad and his view cosmopolitan throughout his long life. In addition to his wife, he leaves four children: Rosemary Sedgwick (Kevin Boyle) of Boxborough, MA, Lacy Bryce of Sioux City, IA, Tom T. Edwards Jr. of San Francisco, CA, and Claire Kearney (Theron) of Old Lyme, CT, eight grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. He is also survived by his sister-in-law, Sophia Cody of Winston-Salem, NC, six loving nieces and nephews and their families. Tom's life will be celebrated in a memorial service at 2:00pm on Friday, December 13, at St. James Church, 25 South Third Street, Wilmington. A reception will follow in the parish hall. All are welcome to attend. In lieu of flowers, Tom's family asks that donations be made to Friends of the American Cathedral, c/o Sherman and Sterling LLP, 599 Lexington Ave., New York, NY 10022 or to Lower Cape Fear Hospice, 1406 Physicians Dr., Wilmington, NC 28401.

ECKHARDT-GOODWIN--Barbara, artist, died Wednesday, December 4, at age 92. After studying at the Art Students League, she married fellow student Harold Goodwin and dedicated her life to painting. A sensitive and serious artist, her work has been collected internationally, appeared as murals and reproduced on book jackets. She is survived by her daughter, Georgiana Goodwin, and granddaughter, Sophia Harvey. There will be no public service.

DANIELSON--Barbara Strachan Deering, 66, passed away at her home in Maine on December 2nd. She was born in Charlottesville, Virginia to Rosemary Sankey, a former dancer with the New York City Ballet and a John Powers model, and James Deering Danielson, a Foreign Service officer. Barbara spent much of her early childhood in Europe and the Middle East, returning to the United States as a teenager. She graduated from Hollins College, Roanoke, Virginia, with a degree in Military History, followed by a degree in Interior Design from Inchbald School of Design in England. Upon her return to the US, she worked for Hastings Design and then the Greater Miami Opera, where she was a member of the production staff. In 1985, she became a director of Miami Corporation, a family concern. Barbara's civic activities included the Dade-Monroe Mental Health Board in Miami, Florida, where she chaired the Alcohol Committee and the Cuban Haitian Task Force before becoming President of the organization. She was a Founding Member of the Miami City Ballet, serving on the Board for many years. Barbara represented the Deering family for the Vizcaya Museum and the Charles Deering Estate. In Northeast Harbor, Maine, she was a board member of the College of the Atlantic and of the Women's Health Center. Barbara supported the Northeast Harbor Library, the YMCA, and Friends of Acadia. She was a hospice volunteer with Hospice Volunteers of Hancock County, Maine. Barbara adored the beauty and tranquility of Northeast Harbor and Mt. Desert Island. In recent years, she spent much of her time in Sun Valley, Idaho, which she similarly cherished. Barbara is survived by stepdaughters, Carolyn Napolitano, Lindsley Lowell Monfort and Loring Lowell, her sister, Jocelyn Tennille, her brother, Charles Seitz, her stepmother, Beverly Danielson, two nieces and five nephews. Barbara was an exceedingly warm and loving person, and radiated an infectious happiness to her many friends and family. Her credo "Live Well Laugh Often Love Much" captures her spirit quite beautifully. Barbara will be greatly missed. A celebration of Barbara's life will be held at a later date. In lieu of flowers, memorial donations may be made to The Deering Estate Foundation, 16701 SW 72nd Avenue, Palmetto Bay, FL, 33157 or Friends of Acadia, 43 Cottage Street, P.O. Box 45, Bar Harbor, ME, 04609.

COLLIER--Lois M. City Harvest remembers Lois M. Collier, a generous friend and dedicated partner in the fight to end hunger. Lois's steadfast commitment to helping New Yorkers live healthier, hunger-free lives made an impact on millions of her neighbors. We offer condolences to her family and friends, and join them in celebrating her life. Lois was a kind and forthright woman, and we will miss her.

CHAZANOW--Adraia, age 86, passed away on, Wednesday, the 4th of December 2013, in Houston. Adraia was born in New York City on the 14th of March 1927 to Sampson and Celia Koe. She had a career in television, broadcasting and public relations and was part of the program staff of Goodson-Todman Productions where she worked on "I've got a secret." Her lifestyle was always very exciting and loved a party where she would be impeccably dressed. She was an integral part of the fabric of New York. She married Steve Chazanow and moved to Houston in 1963 where she assisted her husband in growing their business, Chazanow Jewelers. She loved to travel and theater in New York. Adraia always considered herself a New Yorker as well as a Houstonian. She had many loyal friends who she was very dedicated to. She is predeceased by both parents as well as her husband, Steve Chazanow. She is survived by two nieces and many cousins. The interment service was conducted on Friday, the 6th of December, at Beth Yeshurun Cemetery, 1037 North Post Oak Road in Houston, where Rabbi Adrienne P. Scott, Associate Rabbi, officiated. In lieu of customary remembrances, contributions in Adraia's memory may be directed to the charity of one's choice.
BRODIE--Annabel, formerly of Manhattan, died Friday. Sister of Peter (Carole), aunt of Sharon (Seth) and great-aunt of Sam.

BLUM--Martin, MD. Institute for Psychoanalytic Education (affiliated with NYU School of Medicine) and the Psychoanalytic Association of New York (PANY) mourn the loss of a remarkable teacher and friend.

BAYLISS--Ann Palmer, died November 20, 2013, in Chapel Hill, NC. She was born October 16, 1924, in Orange, NJ, to Theodore and Margaret Ochs Palmer. She was a granddaughter of Milton Ochs, publisher of The Chattanooga Times, and a grandniece of Adolph Ochs, publisher of The New York Times. She graduated from Miss Beard's School in 1942 and Wells College in 1946. She married William Bayliss in 1957 and worked for over 20 years as a school library aide in Chapel Hill. She is survived by her sister, Dean Hall, three sons and daughters-in-law (and four grandchildren): George and Svea Herbst; Theodore and Maura Landry (Margaret, Andrew and Caroline); Mark and Christianne Edkins (Alexander).

BARRETT--Constance E.,D.M.A., 52, died December 2 in Hope, NY. Cellist, performer and teacher, she was a resident of Elmsford. Services will be held at 2:00pm, January 11, 2014, St. John the Divine Cathedral, NYC. Memorial contributions may be made to Chamber Music Connection www.cmconnection.org

AUGENBLICK--Gilbert Lewis; Denver; Formerly of New Jersey; husband of the late Alma Silberstein Augenblick, the late Maxine Hillman Augenblickand the late Elaine Shulman Augenblick; father of John (Frances) Augenblick, Denver, Susan Raskin, MD and Kathryn (Loren) Munk, NY; stepfather of Audree (Ron) Saliman, Denver, Glenn Burdick, MI & Clifton Burdick, CA; brother of Alan Augenblick; grandfather of nine; great-grandfather of eight. Services and burial will be held Monday in Denver, Colorado; Contributions to Newark Academy (NJ) and Dartmouth College.

ADELMAN--Stanley, born January 25, 1925 in Syracuse, NY died December 3, 2013 in Sarasota, FL with his loving wife of 65 years, Francine, at his side. Stanley graduated from Syracuse University where he met Fran on a blind date after serving in the Navy during WWII. He began his career in the NYC textile converting business with Loewenstein & Sons, eventually co-founding his own successful business, Townley Mfg., where he was known for his honesty and integrity. He always felt lucky to retire in 1990, just prior to the downfall of the U.S. textile industry. After raising his family in Merrick, NY, he spent his retirement in Pittsfield, MA and Longboat Key, FL. In addition to Fran, he is survived by his sons Larry of San Francisco, Jim of Waban, MA and Jon of Ossining, NY, their respective spouses, Andrea Snow, Cindy Jaynes and Nancy Adelman, and his grandchildren Stella, Jessica, Sam, Jake and Sophie, all of whom were blessed by his unstinting love and devotion. He will be dearly missed. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Planned Parenthood.

In Tintin: The Art of Hergé (Abrams Comic­arts/Éditions Moulinsart, $45), a “museum on paper,” Michel Daubert, with translation assistance from Michael Farr, documents the photographs, juvenilia, pencil roughs and comics pages in the Hergé Museum in Louvain-la-Neuve, Belgium. Like Tintin, the book has a lot of dash: perfectly square, with red-and-white racing checks on the edges of the pages.
 
From gorgeous outtakes from “Where the Wild Things Are” and brightly colored sketches for a 1997 Bell Atlantic ad campaign to doodles on private correspondence, Maurice Sendak: A Celebration of the Artist and His Work (Abrams, $45) catalogs an exhibition at the Society of Illustrators last summer. Essays by experts like the children’s literature scholars Leonard S. Marcus and Iona Opie balance less gripping personal recollections by friends.
Given the history of refugee housing – flimsy tents that were replaced by multi-story dwellings – the Lebanese view even the most modest of new shelters for Syrians with suspicion.
The Jets beat the Raiders behind a revitalized offense led by Geno Smith, who delivered his best performance in two months.
In the Kliptown section of Soweto, $180-a-night hotel rooms sit 30 yards from tin shacks.
When Sergio Kletnoy, the executive assistant to the Cosmopolitan editor Joanna Coles, saw “The Devil Wears Prada” years ago, he knew this was the industry he wanted to work in.
At Regina Mundi Catholic Church in Soweto, not far from his former home, parishioners gathered on Sunday to celebrate the memories and legacy of Nelson Mandela.
Alessandra Ferri and Herman Cornejo in a scene from a new piece directed and choreographed by Martha Clarke.

“Spill,” a new play based on interviews with dozens of people affected by the Gulf of Mexico oil rig explosion in 2010, will have its premiere production this spring in the state that was at the center of the environmental disaster. The drama, which features some 30 real-life characters speaking in the verbatim style of the documentary-like “Laramie Project” plays, will run March 12 through 30, at the Swine Palace theater on the Louisiana State University campus in Baton Rouge, the theater and the play’s creators announced on Sunday.
Protests in Ukraine’s capital, which have grown steadily for weeks, reached new heights on Sunday when demonstrators toppled a statue of Vladimir Lenin.
1963: Thai anti-Communist prime minister dies

For the last seven years, Andrew Moore has been traveling to the northern Great Plains to photograph the land and the people who live there. In this week’s edition of the magazine, we feature several of Moore’s pictures from this project, which he has titled “Dirt Meridian.” You can see how he made the pictures in this video. What follows is a condensed version of a conversation we had recently about the project.
Paulie Malignaggi rebounded from being knocked down in the second round to record a unanimous decision over Zab Judah in a welterweight bout.

Ohio State needed a victory in the Big Ten title game to keep pace with Florida State and Auburn. Instead, Michigan State handed the Buckeyes their first loss under Urban Meyer.
Jameis Winston and the Seminoles pulled away in the third quarter of the A.C.C. championship game on their way to a spot in the B.C.S. title game, most likely against Auburn.
The Nets grabbed a sorely needed win against the Milwaukee Bucks in a battle of the two teams with the worst records in the Eastern Conference.
Dr. Christine Newman always knew what she wanted to be; Eileen Bruns was always true to herself.
The bride is the White House liaison for the Small Business Administration; the groom is the communications director for Senator Charles E. Schumer.
The couple are lawyers.
The couple are retired.
The couple work in television.
A couple who could design a house, the interior and the yard.
Dr. Gabel was the western regional director of Lambda Legal in Los Angeles; Dr. Shatz was the dean of the College of Social Work at the University of Tennessee.
The bride is a teacher; the groom is a bond salesman.
The bride and groom met in high school and are graduates of the University of Maryland.
Two doctors are married in Toronto.
The couple are graduates of Penn, where they met.
The bride and groom work in public relations.
The bride is a senior business manager for the National Audubon Society; the groom is a freelance television producer and editor.
The bride is the director of programs at an arts service organization; the groom is a partner in a hospitality company.
The bride is a New York Times staff editor; the groom is a lawyer.
The bride and groom met at Oxford.
India faces expulsion from the Olympics unless it keeps corruption-tainted officials out of its ranks, said Thomas Bach, the president of the International Olympic Committee.

ZITRIN--Charlotte Marker, MD, died peacefully at home on December 3, 2013, at the age of 95. Dr. Zitrin was born in Brooklyn on September 30, 1918, before women had the right to vote. She was the daughter of the late Abraham Marker and Regina Adler Marker, and the older sister of the late Harold Marker. An exceptionally gifted musician and academic student, she became interested in psychiatry when she heard a lecture about Sigmund Freud in the Community Hall in Sea Gate, where she lived. With a small handful of women, she attended NYU Medical School (class of 1943), when she met and married Arthur Zitrin (NYU Med 1945), who survives her. Everyone in the class wanted her notes. The Doctors Zitrin moved with their children, Richard and Elizabeth, from Brooklyn to Great Neck, to take advantage of the excellent public education. Dr. Zitrin died in the home they purchased new in 1954. Supremely disciplined and organized, she started in practice as a pediatrician, and completed a second residency in psychiatry when both of her children were in Junior High School and could no longer come home for lunch. She was the founding Director of the Phobia Clinic at Long Island Jewish Hillside Medical Center, and held that position until her retirement in her 70s. She was lead investigator in many peer-reviewed studies on phobias, conducting groundbreaking research on desensitization and talk therapies for usual phobias, and drug and talk therapies for agoraphobia and panic attacks. Charlotte was a generous philanthropist with wide-ranging interests including progressive politics, human rights, health, women's rights, the environment and the survival of Israel. Her husband said that if they could have, the whales she saved would have swum up to their door. She was a patron of the many arts of New York. Her Metropolitan Museum membership card says "member since 1955." She endowed scholarships for medical students at NYU and law students at Columbia, where her brother studied. In addition to her husband of 71 years, her children and daughter-in-law Victoria, she is survived by four grandchildren, Jesse (and his wife Ashley), Gabriel, Jacob and Maya, and a great-granddaughter Lauren Charlotte. There was a private burial. Donations in her memory may be made to the Charlotte Zitrin Scholarship Fund at NYU at: https://onlinegiving.nyumc.org

ZISES--Bernard.We wish to express our sincere condolences to our very dear friends, Jay and Nancy, and the entire Zises family on the passing of the family patriarch, Bernie. "The Dean" was a great role model and mentor to many. Hedy and Arthur Lucille and Jay

WEXLER--Hannan, of White Plains, NY passed away at his home on December 7, 2013. He was born on March 22, 1930 and attended CCNY, as well as Columbia School of Journalism. The earlier years of his career were spent in radio and TV, he then joined Newsweek for a 20 year tenure working in advertising and promotions. He is survived by his loving and devoted wife Barbara, children, Sarah Levine, Joanna Bayer, Daniel Wexler and two grandchildren, Ellie and Brooke. Hannan was a lifelong learner, enjoyed sharing his rich life experiences and will be missed dearly by many. The funeral will be held at 11:00 am Tuesday, December 10 at Kol Ami Chapel in the Woods, 252 Soundview Avenue, White Plains and burial will follow at Mount Hebron Cemetery. Donations in Hannan's name can be made to New York Presbyterian Hospital, Department of Neurology.

RUBINSTEIN--Richard, MD, 69, at home in Brooklyn on December 7. A graduate of Downstate Medical School, the Brooklyn native practiced Psychiatry in Indiana before practicing at Brooklyn Hospital. He is survived by his loving family: brother Robert (Joan) of Armonk, NY; nephews David (Jessica) and Kenneth (Karen Shlitzer) and grandnephews and nieces. ROSENTHAL--Michael, 68, on December 7, 2013. Beloved husband of Linda, dear uncle of Dr. Ira and Linda Skolnik, and Brandon Skolnik. Adored great uncle of Jonah and Zara Skolnik. Service Monday, December 9, 2013, 11:15am at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave.

RITTER--Marie (Ree-Ree), passed peacefully on December 6, 2013 after a long fight with cancer. She died in the comfort of her home surrounded by the love of her family. Marie was loved for her generosity, laughter and wit, bringing Light to the darkest of situations with astonishing ease. Much of her life was dedicated to selfless service. As a devoted wife and mother, she had a flair for making a house a home. Ree-Ree shared this gift with the wider world, volunteering her time and talents where many would not go. Crowned as the "Foot Rub Fairy" she dedicated countless hours on various AIDS units during the height of the epidemic, providing much needed support, relief and dignity to those affected by HIV. Most recently, during her personal battle with cancer, Marie's service branched worldwide taking the form of her online discussion and support forum "Tarceva Divas and Dudes" as "Marie-Zee100". Marie is survived by her husband David, her children Jenna and Michael, and her cat Taki. Private cremation. In lieu of flowers, kindly make contributions to your favorite charity.

REGA--Philip, reunited with his darling Kitty on December 4th. Beloved father of Cathy and Russ Brudnicki and Anne Rega. Brother of Mario and affectionate uncle Angie to his nieces and nephews. Retired Lieutenant FDNY (Engines 91 and 65 and Division of Training). US Army Veteran WWII. He will be missed by all those whose lives he touched. Mandela--Nelson, The words of Anne Frank ring true today as a eulogy to this great man: "I must uphold my ideals, for perhaps the time will come when I shall be able to carry them out." His lifelong work to achieve his ideals of social equality and the elimination of discrimination is a lesson for us all. The Anne Frank Center (USA), Paul Kaplan and Deborah Chapin, Co-Chairs; Yvonne Simons, Executive Director.

KENNEY--James Joseph, beloved father, husband, friend, and longtime editor of photography at Newsweek magazine, died Friday, December 6th in Charleston, South Carolina at the age of 81, after a prolonged illness. He is survived by daughters Elizabeth, Theresa, and Patricia; predeceased by his beloved wife Frances and son James. He was born in Manhattan on March 19, 1932 to Delia and Andrew Kenney. He attended the Power Memorial Academy High School and graduated from Iona College in 1954. He worked for the Associated Press before beginning his distinguished career at Newsweek, where he dedicated himself to advancing the magazine's award-winning photojournalism. Jim was a sharp-witted conversationalist with a wide variety of interests; he loved nature and the outdoors, and was an avid golfer and fan of the Mets and football Giants. He will be deeply missed by colleagues and friends, who fondly remember his laughter, warmth, and easygoing manner. His loved ones invite remembrances to be posted at Legacy.com.

Husband of Marianne Carey Hayes, father of Owen Dennis Carey Hayes and Delia HelenAnn Carey Hayes and family dog Rosie. Son of the late Ann Hayes. He is forever with us. Services by Fred H. GFELLER--John Charles, Sr.,age 76, of Fairfield, CT beloved husband of Lorraine A. Jaccarino, passed, Thursday, December 5, 2013. John held senior management positions at Gulf and Western Industries, including Liggett & Meyers Tobacco, Co., Consolidated Cigar Corp., Madison Square Garden, culminating with president and general manager of Silhouette Books, a division of Simon & Schuster. He finished his career at his own company Sigma Marketing. Friends may call Tuesday, December 10, 2013 from 3-6pm in the Spear-Miller Funeral Home, 39 S Benson Rd., Fairfield, CT 06824. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated Wednesday, December 11, 2013 meeting directly at St. Pius X Church, 834 Brookside Dr., Fairfield, CT with interment to follow in St. Mary's Cemetery, Greenwich, CT.

FISHMAN--Dr. Jack, passed away peacefully at his home in Long Island on December 7, 2013. Born in 1930, Dr. Fishman fled Nazi-occupied Poland with his family and found refuge in Shanghai, China. From 1942 until 1945, he attended the Shanghai Jewish School and, in 1948, immigrated to the United States. Dr. Fishman rose to scientific fame for his research on steroid hormones and their role in endocrine-related cancers. He pioneered the study of opiate antagonists and developed a number of medicinal compounds that aid in reversing the effects of narcotics, the most prominent of these being Naloxone and Narcan, life saving medicines that are now in use in hospitals and emergency rooms throughout the world. His positions over the years have included serving as a professor at Yeshiva University's Albert Einstein College of Medicine, the director of the Institute of Steroid Research at Montefiore Medical Center and professor and director of the Laboratory for Biochemical Endocrinology at The Rockefeller University and the Director of Research at the Strang-Cornell Institute for Cancer Research and, until, his death, was still involved in scientific research. In 1988, Dr. Fishman became president of the Miami-based IVAX Corporation and later served as the company's vice chairman of the board and chief scientific officer. Dr. Fishman has also served as consultant to a number of highly prominent institutions, including the World Health Organization, Food and Drug Administration and National Science Foundation. Among his numerous honors and recognitions, he was the recipient of the highly-prestigious John Scott Award for the synthesis and development of Naloxone. Dr. Fishman never forgot his humble roots and his debt to those who contributed to his success. He endowed the Dr. Jack Fishman Scholarship for Immigrant Students at Yeshiva College, the Jack and Joy Fishman Professorship at Rockefeller University, and was a generous donor to numerous causes. Dr. Fishman is survived by his loving wife and partner, Joy, his brother, Jerry, five children and ten grandchildren. He will be deeply missed by his family, friends, associates and the countless number of people throughout the world whose lives he touched and changed for the better. Memorial service Tuesday, December 10, 2013, 11:45am at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

DONNER--Aaron B.,respected attorney and political leader, died Friday, December 6, 2013 surrounded by his family in Bay Shore, New York. He was 88 years old. Aaron's life represents a great American success story. His father was a Russian immigrant who entered the US through Ellis Island. Aaron was born in 1925 and raised in Jamaica, Queens. He enlisted in the Army in World War II and fought in the Battle of Saipan. After the war, the GI Bill supported his undergraduate and Law degrees at NYU. He married Doris Schneider in 1951, and moved to Bay Shore, where he established a law practice specializing in real estate and became a leading legal figure on Long Island. He had a passion for politics, became active in the New York Democratic Party and Campaign Manager for Congressman Otis G. Pike, serving as his Congressional Aide from 1961-1978. He took pride in helping to create Congressional designation of the Fire Island National Seashore. He was chosen as Chief Counsel for the House Select Committee on Intelligence, and with Pike, led an historic investigation of the US Intelligence Community, leading to significant reforms of the CIA. In 1989 Aaron was appointed by then-Governor Mario Cuomo as Chair of SUNY Stony Brook Council. Aaron lived a full and accomplished life, pursuing his passions for family, recreation, and social activism with equal vigor. He adored sailing and fishing on the Great South Bay, and was never happier then when on the water in his boat. Aaron's Maine Lobster boat, the "Hannah J." was the source of great pride and enjoyment. He held an unflinching commitment to improving society and, together with Doris, engaged in numerous civil, social and political causes. Notable activism included work for the Development Disabilities Institute of Long Island, Planned Parenthood and Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. After the death of Doris, he retired and continued to divide his time between the Bay, supporting friends and local causes, and becoming an accomplished writer of short stories, based on his life experiences. In recent years Aaron lived with his dear companion, Molly Blue of Babylon with the kind support of Meg Green. Those who knew Aaron will speak of his extraordinary, noble values, his love of his family, his engagement with life and the world around him, his booming voice and mischievous sense of humor. He despised injustice and took every opportunity to challenge it, becoming a role model who influenced and shaped the lives of family and those around him. He leaves a proud legacy of achievement, integrity and love. Aaron is survived by his three children; Lauren, Jonathan and Ann, his grandchildren; Jesse, Becky, James, Julian, Olivia and Noah, and his daughter and sons-in-law; Louise, John and Kelley. The family requests in lieu of flowers that donations are sent to Calvary Hospital, Planned Parenthood and the Developmental Disabilities Institute of Long Island.

CONNABLE--Alfred B.,age 82, died peacefully on December 7, 2013 at home. He is survived by his wife, Roma Connable, and his son Benjamin Connable, daughter-in-law Rebecca Morrissey and two grandsons Aram and Charlie. His late son Joel Connable died in 2012. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

CHUNG--Kanik, beloved bro-ther, friend, teacher and mentor, departed this earth on Wednesday, November 4 at the age of 45. Kanik, who is survived by his sister Ling-Fong, was born on February 1, 1968 in Dallas, Texas to David and May Chung and grew up in Palo Alto, California, where he attended Gunn High School. There, he excelled at track and field and became enchanted with ceramics, a passion which eventually led him to follow a career in art, specifically working in a glass medium. He began his career in San Francisco in the early 1990s. After graduating from San Francisco State University, he received an MFA from Ohio State University in 1998 and then moved to New York City in 2000. As a glass artist Kanik was both feared and revered for his skill and control of the medium. His work has been shown throughout the US and internationally. From his stylized vessel work to large installations and architectural designs, his work was versatile in both its use of the medium and the direction of its design. As head of the NYU glass department, Kanik taught students throughout the US, Europe, and the Middle East. Kanik was diagnosed with cancer in early 2012 and fought the disease valiantly with the help of friends, family, the Bellevue Hospital Center and Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. Kanik had originally asked for a memorial TV timeout during a Golden State Warriors game, but we decided to go with this obit instead. Sorry man! The family is requesting that in lieu of flowers, donations be made to any living artist you know, like, or love. A celebration of Kanik's life will be held at a later date, please check www.keepingupwithkanik.blogspot.com for updates.

BAYLISS--Ann Palmer, died November 20, 2013, in Chapel Hill, NC. She was born October 16, 1924, in Orange, NJ, to Theodore and Margaret Ochs Palmer. She was a granddaughter of Milton Ochs, publisher of The Chattanooga Times, and a grandniece of Adolph Ochs, publisher of The New York Times. She graduated from Miss Beard's School in 1942 and Wells College in 1946. She married William Bayliss in 1957 and worked for over 20 years as a school library aide in Chapel Hill. She is survived by her sister, Dean Hall, three sons and daughters-in-law (and four grandchildren): George and Svea Herbst; Theodore and Maura Landry (Margaret, Andrew and Caroline); Mark and Christianne Edkins (Alexander).

The jewel-box-small, down-at-the-heels Minetta Lane Theater is the perfect setting for this opulently burlesque and deliciously Freudian retelling of “The Nutcracker,” which has shades of Cirque du Soleil, “Sleep No More” and “Fanny and Alexander” (with a dash of “Satyricon”). It’s the work of the Brooklyn-based, largely Juilliard-trained dance-and-acrobatics ensemble Company XIV. On a proscenium framed by heavy red curtains, with candelabra where the footlights would usually be, Tchaikovsky’s darling little Clara (a radiant Laura Careless) is a mini-Marie Antoinette with a comeuppance in store, to be delivered by Drosselmeyer, her godfather, played like a smarmy satyr pimp by Jeff Takacs. The genius of this production, which includes eye-dazzling physical feats performed on giant hula hoops and from silken swings, is its transformation of traditional ballet into louche vaudeville: the famous Spanish dance becomes a foot-stomping, castanet-clicking striptease; in the storied Kingdom of the Sweets, Clara wields a fat black whip to play gleeful dominatrix over a troupe of bare-bottomed, harnessed Licorice Boys.

I don’t know any foreign business owner in China who hasn’t been to labor court at least once. Labor courts address and adjudicate cases very quickly, and you will need a Chinese lawyer to represent you. The courts are organized into a three-tiered system in which the first arbitrator makes a decision, and then each party has the right to appeal it to the next-highest tier.
