MUNOZ--Jose Esteban, age 46, passed away on December 3 in New York City. The Tisch School of the Arts deeply mourns the loss of Jose Esteban Munoz, professor and former chair of the Department of Performance Studies. He is the author of two influential books: Disidentifications: Queers of Color and the Performance of Politics and Cruising Utopia: The Them and There of Queer Futurity, a queer studies book series at NYU Press; co-editor of Everynight Life: Culture and Dance in Latin/o America and Pop Out: Queer Warhol; and the author of dozens of influential articles, book chapters, and essays in journals, anthologies, and artist catalogues. Extraordinary teacher and writer of astonishing grace, Jose was particularly adept at seeing beauty where others sometimes failed to discern it: in the face of his beloved French bulldog Lydia, in the vulnerable flounderings of the queer downtown performance artists he loved, and in his enormous circle of friends on, as he put it, "the island of misfit toys." The Dean of the NYU Tisch School of the Arts and the Department of Performance Studies offer our deepest sympathy, love and support to Jose's family and his partner, John Andrews, friends, students, colleagues, and loved ones in this difficult time. The Department of Performance Studies will announce plans for a memorial service to be held in Spring 2014; please check performance.tisch.nyu.edu for updates.

O'KEEFE--Catherine, (nee Wallace), died on Sunday December 8, 2013 at the Morristown Memorial Hospital in Morristown, she was 89 years old. Mrs. O'Keefe was born in Brooklyn, NY and lived in Richmond Hill, Queens, Vero Beach Florida and the last 10 years in Madison. Mrs. O'Keefe was a Registered Nurse and Head Nurse at Double Day Publishing and Co. in Garden City, NY for 20 years retiring many years ago. She is predeceased by her husband John and is survived by her children, Kenneth and his wife Sandra, Andrew and his wife Anne, Bridget Crowley and her husband Vincent, Donald and his wife Laura, 19 grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Relatives and friends are invited to attend the funeral Wednesday, December 11, 9am from the Madison Memorial Home 159 Main St. Madison with a funeral mass at 10am at St. Vincent Martyr Church, Madison. Interment St. Vincents Cemetery. Visitation Tuesday 5-8pm.

MOSES--Steven. UJA-Federation of New York mourns with sadness the passing of Steven Moses. He leaves behind a loving family that carries on a tradition of exceptional philanthropy. We extend our condolences to Steven's wife, Beth; his daughters; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

LLOYD--Tess Stampler, passed away surrounded by her family on December 7, 2013. Living her entire life on her terms, she left an indelible impression on everyone she met. While small in stature, her spirit and personality could fill any space- whether it be in New York City, Westhampton or the card room at the Polo Club in Boca Raton. Her impeccable taste was evidenced by the clothes she wore and the people she chose to spend her time with but her greatest gift was the unyielding love, dedication and generosity she had for her family and friends. She will be deeply missed by everyone who knew her including her two daughters, Suzen Drogin and Penni Schimel, sons-in-law, Gerald and Carl, and grandchildren Lawrence and his husband Santiago, Elyse and her partner Adam, Jamie and her husband Jeffrey, Marisa, Marcy, Julie and her wife Michelle and great-grandchildren Max and Micah. Donations in her memory may be made to support bladder cancer research at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center. To make a gift, please visit http://mskcc.convio.net/goto/ tesslloyd.

MOLLOY--Therese M. The Board and staff of Greater Jamaica Development Corporation mourn the loss of Terry Molloy, whose exemplary personal and profession roles in the rebuilding of Jamaica, Queens were profound. Representing Chase Bank as a Director of GJDC and its chair for five years, she championed the political and public advocacy and development of York College and the decision to build a new Queens Family Court in Jamaica. Following retirement from banking, she secured at age 65, a degree from the City University of New York Law School and actively practiced, often pro bono, in the Family Court, where she initiated pioneering visitation programs. With the Queens County Bar, Queens Borough President and GJDC, she led in the effort to replace an outdated Family Court structure with a new and larger exceptionally hospitable court. Her exceptional, engaging commitments and leadership in the business and government communities are irreplaceable. Our grief is tempered by the special and significant contributions she made to community development for the citizens of Queens. F. Carlisle Towery, President

IANNI--Dr. Francis A.J.,of Atlantic Highlands, NJ died on Monday, December 2, following a brief illness. The author of numerous books and articles, Dr. Ianni was best known for his break-through study of organized crime, A Family Business, published in 1972. Subsequent works included Black Mafia, published in 1974, and The Search for Structure, published in 1989. Dr. Ianni was born on March 29, 1926, in Wilmington, Delaware to Italian immigrant parents. From early childhood on he strived to acquire knowledge, both through life experience and formal education. He joined the US Navy in 1943 and after a three year tour of active duty in the Pacific Theater, entered the Naval Reserves where he attained the rank of Lieutenant Commander. Dr. Ianni received B.S., M.A., and Ph.D. degrees in Psychology, Sociology, and Anthropology from Pennsylvania State University. His multi-faceted professional career included positions in academia: Associate Professor of Anthropology and Psychology at Russell Sage College, Assistant Professor of Sociology at Yale University, and Professor of Anthropology and Psychology at University College in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, where he conducted several expeditions to explore remote regions and study the nomadic cultures that inhabited them. Ultimately, Dr. Ianni joined the faculty of Teachers College, Columbia University, where he taught graduate courses in the social sciences and organizational theory and served as Director of the Horace Mann Lincoln Institute. Upon retiring from Columbia University, Dr. Ianni was named Professor Emeritus. During the Kennedy and Johnson administrations, Dr. Ianni served as Associate Commissioner for Research in the U.S. Office of Education. A graduate of the New York Psychoanalytic Institute, he maintained a successful private practice as a psychoanalyst in New York City for many years. Dr. Ianni was preceded in death by Marguerite B. Ianni, his former wife and the mother of his sons, Juan B. Ianni, Anthony M. Ianni, and Andrea (Andrew) D. Ianni. He also was predeceased by wife Elizabeth Reuss-Ianni and two sisters, Dolores Headley and Rita Cirillo. He is survived by his wife, Nina Kasdon Ianni, his sons, his brother, James A. Ianni, and granddaughters Lydia, Malyka, Nora, Caroline, and Haleigh as well as numerous extended family members throughout the U.S. and Italy.

HAYES--Dennis John. A shining example of father, husband, family man and lawyer. We are forever thankful for the joy you brought to our sister Marianne and for all you have done for Owen and Delia. They are treasures. Love, The Carey Family
HAYES--Dennis. The love of Marianne's life who is beloved by all of us at Event Associates. We are heartbroken for her, Delia and Owen and anyone who had the joy of knowing Dennis.

FISHMAN--Dr. Jack. Yeshiva University deeply mourns the passing of Dr. Jack Fishman our distinguished alumnus, friend and Benefactor, an internationally renowned scientist and exemplary humanitarian. Born in Cracow, Poland, Jack and his family fled to Shanghai in 1942. After the war, the Fishmans immigrated to the United States, whereupon Jack enrolled in Yeshiva University, receiving a full scholarship. Jack graduated with honors and pursued graduate work in the sciences. In 1991, Jack endowed the Dr. Jack Fishman Scholarship Fund for undergraduate students attending Yeshiva University. He served as a role model, an inspiration to young men and women. He was a man who believed in "giving back" so that others would receive the unique educational experience provided by Yeshiva. In recognition of Jack's visionary philanthropy and professional achievements, Yeshiva University proudly awarded Jack an honorary doctorate in 1992. Our heartfelt condolences to Joy, his wife, his children and grandchildren, and the entire family. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President Norman Lamm President Emeritus

HAYES--Dennis John, Courageous champion, handsome husband, fabulous father, best brother, accomplished attorney, fun friend, great guy. Dennis led the New York State Insurance Fund as Chief Executive Deputy Director. He served in New York State Government under four administrations and his guiding philosophy was always integrity, fairness and efficiency. Husband of Marianne Carey Hayes, father of Owen Dennis Carey Hayes and Delia HelenAnn Carey Hayes and family dog Rosie. Son of the late Ann Hayes. He is forever with us. Services by Fred H. McGrath & Son Funeral Home, Bronxville, mcgrathandson.com. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center, Department of Neurology, 633 Third Avenue, New York, NY 10017 Attention: Joan Carter.

FISHMAN--Jack. The trustees, faculty, and staff of The Rockefeller University deeply mourn the loss of our beloved colleague and friend Jack Fishman. Jack was an extraordinary man whose life story was truly inspirational. We were fortunate to count him as a member of our community for nearly forty years, first as a faculty member and then as a Rockefeller University Council member. Jack first joined Rockefeller in 1977, inspired by a strong belief in the power of investigative medicine. In 1980, he became head of Rockefeller's laboratory of biochemical endocrinology, where he studied the role of sex hormones in several diseases predominant in women, including various types of cancer. In the 1980s, he co-founded the Miami-based IVAX Corporation. Jack provided many long-lasting contributions to the scientific community, perhaps most notably the development of Naloxone, a drug that has saved countless lives in its 50-year history. In honor of this achievement, Jack received the John Scott Award, presented in recognition of an outstanding positive impact on the welfare of humankind. We will always remember Jack's unique blend of wisdom and generosity, as well as his profound sense of service. His philanthropic spirit led him to create two endowed professorships at The Rockefeller University: the Jack Fishman Professorship, currently held by Seth Darst, and the Joy and Jack Fishman Professorship, now held by David Allis. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his beloved wife and partner, Joy. We also extend our sympathy to Jack's five children, his ten grandchildren, and his brother, Jerry. David Rockefeller, Honorary Chair and Life Trustee Russell Carson, Chair Marc Tessier-Lavigne, President C. David Allis, Ph.D. Seth Darst, Ph.D.

FISHMAN--Dr. Jack, passed away peacefully at his home in Long Island on December 7, 2013. Born in 1930, Dr. Fishman fled Nazi-occupied Poland with his family and found refuge in Shanghai, China. From 1942 until 1945, he attended the Shanghai Jewish School and, in 1948, immigrated to the United States. Dr. Fishman rose to scientific fame for his research on steroid hormones and their role in endocrine-related cancers. He pioneered the study of opiate antagonists and developed a number of medicinal compounds that aid in reversing the effects of narcotics, the most prominent of these being Naloxone and Narcan, life saving medicines that are now in use in hospitals and emergency rooms throughout the world. His positions over the years have included serving as a professor at Yeshiva University's Albert Einstein College of Medicine, the director of the Institute of Steroid Research at Montefiore Medical Center and professor and director of the Laboratory for Biochemical Endocrinology at The Rockefeller University and the Director of Research at the Strang-Cornell Institute for Cancer Research and, until, his death, was still involved in scientific research. In 1988, Dr. Fishman became president of the Miami-based IVAX Corporation and later served as the company's vice chairman of the board and chief scientific officer. Dr. Fishman has also served as consultant to a number of highly prominent institutions, including the World Health Organization, Food and Drug Administration and National Science Foundation. Among his numerous honors and recognitions, he was the recipient of the highly-prestigious John Scott Award for the synthesis and development of Naloxone. Dr. Fishman never forgot his humble roots and his debt to those who contributed to his success. He endowed the Dr. Jack Fishman Scholarship for Immigrant Students at Yeshiva College, the Jack and Joy Fishman Professorship at Rockefeller University, and was a generous donor to numerous causes. Dr. Fishman is survived by his loving wife and partner, Joy, his brother, Jerry, five children and ten grandchildren. He will be deeply missed by his family, friends, associates and the countless number of people throughout the world whose lives he touched and changed for the better. Memorial service Tuesday, December 10, 2013, 11:45am at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Avenue.

FAIN--Yonia. Hofstra University is deeply saddened by the passing of Yonia Fain, associate professor emeritus of art history. An internationally acclaimed artist and poet, Mr. Fain employed powerful visual imagery in his canvases and works on paper to pay tribute to the memories of those lost during the Holocaust. Born in the Ukraine in 1913, his family fled Bolshevik Russia. He outran Nazi troops in Poland, survived the Shanghai Ghetto of World War II, and after the war made his way to Mexico where he was befriended by the Mexican muralist Diego Rivera. Mr. Fain arrived in the U.S. in 1953 and was in a number of Whitney annuals and one-man shows. Mr. Fain served on the faculty of Hofstra University's Department of Fine Arts, Design and Art History from 1971-1985. In 2012 Mr. Fain attended the opening of the Hofstra University Museum exhibition in his honor, Yonia Fain: Remembrance. In tribute to the memory of Mr. Fain, all Hofstra University flags are lowered to half-staff. Janis M. Meyer Chair, Board of Trustees Stuart Rabinowitz President

EPSTEIN--Steven, 59 years old, died unexpectedly at home on Saturday, December 7, 2013. Steven was born on July 19, 1954, to parents Selwyn "Buddy" Epstein and Phyllis (Abowitz) Epstein in Queens, New York. He graduated from John F. Kennedy High School in Plainview, New York, in 1972, and in 1975 he was proud to move to Greenwich Village in his beloved New York City. He pursued a career in the food and wine industry and enjoyed working at a variety of establishments, including Tastings, a wine bar that had been located in midtown Manhattan, Rusty's on Fifth, the restaurant owned by Rusty Staub, the Burgundy Wine Company, and most recently at Rocking Horse Cafe in Chelsea, where he was the manager. Steven was an avowed Francophile and particularly enjoyed spending his fortieth birthday in Paris, one of many trips to France. He also loved music, the theater, crossword puzzles, and his cherished dog, Shayna. Steven was preceded in death by his longtime partner, Lou Mora, who passed away in 1992. One would be hard pressed to find another person who loved New York City as much as Steven. He lived in Greenwich Village from 1975 until 1990, when he and Lou relocated to his current residence in Chelsea. Steven is survived by his parents, his sister, Roni (Epstein) Green, of Plainview, New York, her husband, Joe Green, one niece, Jamie (Green) Langone, and two nephews, Ben and Dan Green. He will also be dearly missed and remembered by many loving cousins and friends. Funeral arrangements are being handled by Star of David Memorial Chapel in Farmingdale, New York. A memorial service is planned for a later date.

DURKIN--Julie, on December 9, 2013. Devoted daughter of Constance and the late Anthony Durkin. Beloved wife of Christopher Ang. Loving sister of Caroline and Christopher Durkin. Dear aunt of two nephews and five nieces. Visitation Thursday, December 12, 2013 from 2-5pm at "The Riverside", 76 St. and Amsterdam Ave., doors reopening at 6:30pm with ceremony at 7pm. Reception to follow. In lieu of flowers, donations to Julie Durkin would be preferred.

BURMAN--Martin Hon.,of Blue Bell, PA, age 69. Member of New Jersey and Pennsylvania Bar since 1969 and Pennsylvania Workers Comp Judge since 1987. Beloved wife Lorraine, sister Phyllis her partner Karen Rappaport, nieces Russita and Kristina. Services Wednesday, 1pm at Mt. Moriah Cemetery, Fair-view, NJ. For info "Eden Memorial Chapels," Fort Lee (201) 947 3336.

ALBERT--Mary Sparrow, 88, of North Branford CT, formerly of Hamilton, NY; Baltimore, MD; Cleveland Heights, OH; Riverside, CT and Brooklyn, NY, died December 4, 2013. She was the beloved wife of the late Harold G. Albert, Managing Director of the American Management Association at his death in 1990. She is survived by her children: Mary Agnes Jopson of Baltimore, MD, Katherine A. Albert and E. Jane Albert Hubbard of New York, NY, and Harold G. Albert, Jr. of Clinton, NY, five grandchildren and three great-grandchildren. A graduate of St. Joseph's College in Brooklyn, she taught at New York City public schools, the Convent of the Sacred Heart in Greenwich, CT and the Cuyahoga Community College in Cleveland. Among many community activities, she co-founded the inter-church Worn Again Thrift Shop in Hamilton and was a long-time member of the Hamilton Fortnighly Club. She was a well-traveled, generous, literary, artistic, musical, and intellectually curious person who enjoyed life to the fullest. All who had the privilege to know her will miss her ready smile, witty sense of humor and keen insights into life. Funeral Mass December 10, 10am in St. Therese Church, Branford. Burial December 12, 1pm in Greenwood Cemetery, Brooklyn. For further information see wsclancy.com

VOLPE--Josephine R. Beloved wife of the late John. Loving mother of Thomas and Ronald and mother-in- law of Anita and Maria. Cherished grandmother of six loving grandchildren and fourteen great-grandchildren. Reposing at Andrew Torregrossa & Son's Funeral Home 1305 79th Street, Brooklyn, NY 11228 on Thursday 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Funeral Mass: Friday 9:30am at St. Ephrem. Entombment at Garden of Memories Beth-EL Cemetery, New Jersey.

TURNER--Richard J. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, uncle, and great-uncle, Richard Joseph Turner, died peacefully in his sleep on December 5, 2013 in Southbury, CT. Born December 18, 1920, in New York City, he attended Yale University, acquiring his BS and PhD in organic chemistry. He worked for American Cyanamid Company for 25 years before starting Turner Associates. He devoted his career to developing medical and surgical devices, including the first biodegradable synthetic suture, Dexon. Resided for many years in Wilton, CT. Survived by his wife of 69 years, Viola Tracy Turner, two daughters, Tracy Turner and Carole Turner Reading, and her husband Ron Reading, three grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A celebration remembrance will be held at the Yale Club of New York City on January 19, 2014.

TOLKAN--Norman N.,of Washington, D.C. Much loved by his son, Victor K. Tolkan, his daughter-in-law, Julia A. Springer and his grandchildren, John Victor (Jack), Nicholas Springer, and Emma Constance Tolkan of whom he was enormously proud and to whom he was deeply devoted. Beloved husband of 40 years of the late Constance H. Tolkan, and brother of Helen T. Greenwald. Cherished brother-in-law, uncle, cousin and friend. Founder of the Door Store of Washington, D.C. and until his death at 87 of complications from pneumonia, operator of Homeward, Inc. a mail order furniture business. He was his own man, self-made, colorful, idiosyncratic, intensely private and honorable.

MILLER--Sidney M.,died suddenly in his home in Del Ray Beach Florida on December 5 at the age of 86. Sid was a top agent at the New York Life Insurance company for over 60 years. An active member of his community in Rye Brook, NY, he served as chairman of the Recreation Commission initiating the development of parks and sports facilities. He was also an active member of the Rye Community Synagogue where he served as President. An outstanding athlete and avid sports enthusiast, he was a proud season ticket holder for the NY Giants since 1955. Sid is survived by Marilyn, his loving wife for 61 years, as well as his children Robert Anne and Jonathan, their spouses Kathy Stuart and Lisa, and his grandchildren Whitney, Sarah, Parker, Nicholas, Philip, Elana, Daniel and Joshua. He will be sorely missed by a large circle of loving friends and colleagues. Donations may be sent to the Miller Family Fund at Rye Community Synagogue: 200 Forest Avenue Rye, NY 10580.

MANLEY--John Kay, an architect employed in the office of Philip Johnson for 53 years, died December 8th, 2013. He was 88 years old. Born and raised in Brattleboro, VT, he enlisted in the army after graduating high school at age 17, spending two and a half years in uniform during World War II, including 15 months in France, Belgium, and Germany. Following the war, he moved to NYC where he received a B.A. in architecture from Pratt Institute in 1951; married dancer, actress, athlete, and practicing clinical psychologist Thea Trauner in 1953; and appeared in 17 amateur and semi-professional stage productions. In 1955, John was invited to work for Mies van der Rohe and Philip Johnson on the Seagram Building and its Four Seasons Restaurant. He subsequently decided to join Johnson's firm, where he became the principal designer. During his lengthy career, he worked for and with Johnson on some 178 built and unbuilt projects in this country and abroad. Among the buildings to which he contributed most significantly: New York State Theater at Lincoln Center; Kunsthaus (Art Museum), Bielefeld, Germany; Boston Public Library Addition; IDS Center in Minneapolis; Pennzoil and Transco, Houston; Thanksgiving Square Chapel and Park, as well as the unrealized Cathedral of Hope, Dallas; 1976 re-do of Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center; three iterations of Amon Carter Museum, Fort Worth; Checkpoint Charlie I, Berlin; National Center for Performing Arts, Mumbai; Lancey Office Building, Geneva; the abandoned Lauder Oasis, Negev Desert, Israel; and the Visitor's Center on Philip Johnson's New Canaan, Connecticut estate. In 1991, Johnson listed him as co-architect of St. Basil's Chapel at the University of St. Thomas in Houston. Because of Johnson's declining health and infrequent office presence after the late 1990s, although none of these projects were ever publicly attributed to him, John perforce became the actual designer of the Domus Showroom at Madison and 34th Street, The Metropolitan Condo at 181 East 90th Street, The "Urban Glass House" at 330 Spring Street, and Number 5 Condo on East 44th Street all located in NYC; and the Sanctuary for Sufism Revised, Walnut Creek, California. Following a quadruple bypass in 1985, he suffered multiple, ongoing medical problems for the remainder of his life, which forced him to retire in 2008 at age 83. In spite of his many health issues, he remained an active, intelligent, and genuinely kind person who made a positive difference in the lives of everyone who knew him. He is survived by his daughter, Gail Faber, and two granddaughters, Lisa and Rachel, of Bridgewater, NJ; and by his partner of 44 years, Richard DeThuin, an author and reporter, of NYC.

LEWIN--Elsbeth Gaertner, 89. Born Mainz, Germany; widow of composer Frank Lewin. Died peacefully at home in Princeton, on December 9. Mother, grandmother, editor, docent; strong of spirit and gentle to all. Lovingly remembered by daughters Naomi, Eva Radding (Alan), and Miriam; granddaughters Lisa and Amy. Contributions: Leo Baeck Institute or Princeton University Art Museum.

HOLTZMANN--Honorable Howard M. We note with sorrow the passing of our member and extend sincerest condolences to his bereaved family. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein President David B. Edelson, Central Synagogue of New York City

HOLTZMANN--Hon. Howard M.,The Jewish Theological Seminary joins the family in mourning the loss of Judge Howard Holtzmann, honorary chair and longtime member of the JTS Board of Trustees. A decorated and award-winning judge, arbiter, and author, Judge Holtzmann was an active and generous supporter of JTS, committed to scholarship and academic publication. He served on a number of major international tribunals, including his 14 years of service as a senior US member of the Iran-US Claims Tribunal in The Hague. Judge Holtzmann is survived by his wife Carol, their five children, and grandchildren. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Arnold M. Eisen, Chancellor Abby Joseph Cohen, Board Chair

HOLTZMANN--Hon. Howard Marshall, died at home in Manhattan, December 9, 2013, hours before his 92nd birthday. Judge Holtzmann was an original Member of the Iran-United State Claims Tribunal, which was established as part of the settlement of the Iranian hostage crisis. Among his many other contributions to the field of international arbitration, he long served as a member of the United States Delegation to the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law. He graduated from Yale College in 1942 and Yale Law School in 1947, and he received the Yale Medal in 2006. He was the son of the late Lillian Plotz Holtzmann and Jacob L. Holtzmann. He is survived by his wife Carol E. Holtzmann and daughters Susan Richardson of Palo Alto, CA and Betsey Holtzmann of Southwest Harbor, ME. He is also survived by his stepdaughter, Louise Muller (Henry), his stepson, William van Berg and grand children MacLaren Richardson (Jodi), Andrew Richardson (Erin), Abe Noyes, Jill van Berg (David Manella), Elizabeth van Berg and Allison van Berg and five great grand children. He was predeceased by his first wife, Anne Fisher Holtzmann and stepson, Peter van Berg. Services will be held on Friday, December 13, 2013 at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10022 at 11am. The family will welcome friends at their residence from 4:30pm to 7:30pm. No flowers please.

HAYES--Dennis John. A shining example of father, husband, family man and lawyer. We are forever thankful for the joy you brought to our sister Marianne and for all you have done for Owen and Delia. They are treasures. Love, The Carey Family

FREE--Florence. The officers, board and staff of the American Technion Society (ATS) are saddened by the loss of Florence Free of Palm Beach, FL. She was a Technion Guardian, a designation for those who have reached the highest level of commitment, and she and her late husband Benjamin supported numerous Technion projects, including the Benjamin and Florence Free Chair in Industrial Engineering and Management and the Benjamin J. and Florence Free/Palm Beach Chapter Dormitory. Mrs. Free was a past member of the ATS National Board of Directors, and a trustee of the ATS Palm Beach Chapter. To her son Steven, and the entire Free family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. American Technion Society Scott Leemaster, President Joel S. Rothman, Chairman of the Board Melvyn H. Bloom, Executive Vice President

FRAWLEY--Cornelius Peter, 92, of Mount Laurel and formerly Teaneck, NJ, died December 6, 2013 after a brief illness. Born January 31, 1921 in Harlem, New York City. Survived by loving wife of 58 years Marianne Frawley, sons, Ronald and wife Saundra of Concord, NC, and Thomas and wife Patricia of Berwyn, PA, and extended family. Son of William and Emily Frawley of County Claire, Ireland. US Marine Corps, WWII Saipan and Tinian. Decorated Officer, New York City Police Department 1949-1984. Funeral Mass: December 14, 10:30am, Saint Monica RC Church, 635 First Avenue, Berwyn, PA. Viewing: Donohue Funeral Home, 366 West Lancaster Avenue, Wayne, PA 610-989-9600 Friday eve 7-9pm and Saturday 8:30-10am. In lieu of flowers contributions in his memory to American Diabetes Association or National Hemophilia Foundation would be appreciated. Online condolences at www.donohuefuneralhome. com.

FISHMAN--Dr. Jack. The Hampton Synagogue mourns the passing of Dr. Jack Fishman, who with his beloved wife, Joy, was a benefactor of our congregation. Heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Rabbi Marc Schneier Morris Tuchman, President Seymour Siegel, Treasurer

FISHMAN--Dr. Jack. The Aleph Institute mourns the loss of Dr. Jack Fishman, husband of our beloved board member, Joy Fishman. Our deep condolences to the entire Fishman family. Dr. Fishman's extraordinary generosity and deep commitment to sustaining hope and delivering a helping hand to families in crisis was unique. Aleph and the community it serves know first-hand the tangible, life-saving and oft overlooked impact of Dr. Fishman's work in the development of Naloxone, a drug used to treat opioid-related addiction. His deep care and concern for those that everyone else forgets will reverberate for generations. Jack will be sorely missed but never forgotten. Rabbi Aaron Lipskar, Rabbi Mendy Katz

DERN--Thomas Aquinas, of Baldwin, suddenly, on December 9, 2013. Devoted husband of Patricia (nee Bartkowski). Beloved father of Marc Thomas. Loving son of the late Colleen and Howard Dern. Cherished brother of Darinda Gest (Richard), Dennis (Alicia), Daniel (Claire) and the late Joseph and Howard. Also survived by many loving nieces and nephews. Beloved coach, mentor and lifelong resident of Baldwin. As C.O.O. of Young Adult Institute, Thomas made it his life's work assisting those with developmental disabilities for over 35 years. Proud graduate of St. John's University and Hunter school of Social Work. The family will receive friends Wednesday, December 11 and Thursday, December 12 from 2-4 and 7-9pm at the Cecere Family Funeral Home 2283 Grand Avenue, Baldwin, NY 11510. Funeral Mass Friday 10:45am at St. Christopher RC Church, Baldwin, NY. Interment will follow in St. Charles Cemetery, East Farmingdale, NY. Please visit cecerefamilyfunerals.com

CONDREN--Dr. Raymond J.,Clinical Psychologist, 80, of Lake Worth, FL passed away December 1, 2013. Raymond was born in Brooklyn, NY March 1, 1933. He was married to Eny M. Condren and they lived together in Dix Hills, NY before retiring to Florida. Raymond earned his his PhD in Psychology from Texas Tech University. He served in the United States Air force for five years. Raymond retired in 1991 as First Deputy Commissioner of Nassau County Department of Drug and Alcohol Addiction. Raymond is survived by his six children and seven grandchildren. Raymond loved life, and his laugh still resounds in the ears of those who knew and loved him. He was an avid reader of the New York Times, a habit he carried with him to Florida. His strength and generosity inspired those around him; he will be missed.

BROWN--Eileen P.,of Glen Head, NY on December 9, 2013. Beloved wife of Louis. Loving mother of Edward (Tricia), Alicia Doodian (Robert), Marguerite Toohey (Thomas) and Louis. Cherished grandmother of Sarah, Patrick, Thomas, Grace, Matthew, Henry, Liam, Emma, Anna and William. Dear sister of Theresa, Ann, Thomas, Patrick and the late James. Visiting Thursday 7-9pm and Friday 2-4 and 7-9pm at Whitting Funeral Home 300, Glen Cove Ave., Glen Head, NY 11545 www. whitting.com. Funeral Mass Saturday 10am at St. Mary's R. C. Church, Roslyn, NY. Interment Long Island National Cemetery, Farmingdale, NY. Contributions may be made to Memorial Sloan-Kettering, 1275 York Ave., New York, NY 10021.

ROBERTS--Flora. December 12, 1998. Memory now is unreliable, but I would make a sizable bet that we who knew you have not forgotten the essence of you: your negotiating voice, with a range most opera singers pray for; who can forget you crossing mid-57th St. at high noon from your office to the original Russian Tea Room, a short, round figure in a long red coat, the traffic bearing down on you, coming to a halt as you made your near-sighted, humming, leisurely way to lunch? Your singing jazz to rival Ella. Wise, funny, original, in love with music and words, you were a great literary agent, and an even greater friend. Helen

ZUCKERMAN--Bernice, (Delfiner). Died at home on December 10, 2013 after a brief illness. Beloved wife of the late Aaron. Loving mother of Barry (Michelene), Lenny (Gail) and Jerry (Kendra). Cherished grandmother of Hana, Justin, Leah, Rachel and Emily. Services are Friday, December 13 at 10am, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 21 Broad Street West, Mt. Vernon, NY. In lieu of flowers contributions may be made to the Rabbi's Discretionary Fund, Beth El Synagogue, New Rochelle, NY.

ZINAMAN--Lawrence (Dick). On December 10. Singular and beloved husband of Lynn for 34 blessed years. Proud father of Steven (Nan) and Michael (Tina). Brother of the late Jules. Cherished son-in-law of Arthur and Sylvia Glasser. Wonderful grandfather, brother-in-law, uncle and friend. His million watt smile will continue to light our way to infinity and beyond. Services, Friday, December 13, at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue, New York, NY at 9:30am.

TOLKAN--Norman N.,of Washington, D.C. Much loved by his son, Victor K. Tolkan, his daughter-in-law, Julia A. Springer and his grandchildren, John Victor (Jack), Nicholas Springer, and Emma Constance Tolkan of whom he was enormously proud and to whom he was deeply devoted. Beloved husband of 40 years of the late Constance H. Tolkan, and brother of Helen T. Greenwald. Cherished brother-in-law, uncle, cousin and friend. Founder of the Door Store of Washington, D.C. and until his death at 87 of complications from pneumonia, operator of Homeward, Inc. a mail order furniture business. He was his own man, self-made, colorful, idiosyncratic, intensely private and honorable.

SHIRLEY--Homer Clifton, III. The Society of Colonial Wars in the State of New York regrets to announce the passing of Homer Clifton Shirley III of the New York and the New Jersey Societies, on December 7, 2013. William R. Brunger, Governor

SEILER--Seymour A.,of Palm City, FL, died December 10, 2013 at his son's home in New York City. He was 88 years old. Born and raised in Brooklyn, NY, he was a graduate of Erasmus Hall High School, received a BS in Engineering from City College and a JD from the University of Miami. He married Dolores June Levine in December 1953, and they lived in Liberty, NY before relocating to Florida in 1975. He had a successful career as a licensed architect and engineer designing private homes and hotels and developing shopping centers throughout the northeast. He had a second career as a lawyer in Florida along with his wife Dolores who attended law school with him. In addition to his wife, he is survived by his sister Sylvia Bromberg of Hartford, CT, his daughter Karen and her husband Daniel Stone of Providence, RI and his son Eric and his wife Darcy Bradbury of New York City, and six grandchildren, Alexander, Joshua and Samuel Stone of Providence, RI and Brad, Benjamin and Eleanor Seiler of New York City. He is also survived by his in-laws, Ellen and David Brown of Tampa, FL and Leslie and Rebecca Levine of Sands Point, NY, and numerous nieces and nephews. Internment will be at a private service in Hurleyville, NY on December 12. Contributions may be made to the City College 21st Century Foundation, City College of New York, 160 Convent Avenue, SH 154, New York, NY 10031, with reference to the Seymour A. Seiler Undergraduate Research Fund.

RYDEN--Margaret "Peg" Bastable, 96, formerly of Forest Hills, NY, died on December 9, 2013. Wife of the late Albert G. Ryden, she will be remembered by her son John and his wife Barbara, her son Bill, and her daughter Katherine and her husband Paul; granddaughters Linda and Tricia; and great-grandchildren Rosemary, Henry and Sophie. The Ryden family moved to Forest Hills in 1940, where Peg was best known and loved as keeper of a home that was open to all relatives, friends and neighbors, generations of children, and singers. "For thy sweet love remember'd...Mom, How much do we love you." Consider donation to the ASPCA.

RIKLIN--Marilyn, The Board of Governors and members of Fairview Country Club note with profound sorrow the passing of our beloved longtime member, Marilyn Riklin. On behalf of all our members we express our deepest sympathy to her husband Bernard, sons Jeff and Matthew, and the entire family. Fredric Apter, President Bryna Sweedler, Secretary

RIKLIN--Marilyn, 89, of Greenwich, CT. Died peacefully on December 10th. Devoted wife and golf partner to her loving husband of 66 years Bernard. Loving mother to Jeff, Matthew and Scott who predeceased her, mother-in-law to Liz, grandmother to Leah, Eric and Allison, sister to Norman Glaser. With a BA from Hunter College and two Masters in Education from Columbia and Lehman, Marilyn taught elementary and special ed. students. She volunteered for both religious and secular causes, and was a founding president of Rye Hadassah. Marilyn won may prestigious golf tournaments and mentored younger golfers at Fairview Country Club where she had many joyous years. Her enthusiasm and ever present optimism were an inspiration for all. Funeral on December 13th, 10am at Community Synagogue, 200 Forest Ave., Rye. The family will receive visitors at home Friday 5p-8pm and Saturday 1-4pm. Contributions may be sent to COMSYNRYE.ORG or NFFR.ORG.

QUADRACCI--Betty Ewens. Betty died peacefully in her Wisconsin home, surrounded by family and friends, on Monday, December 9, 2013, at age 75. She is survived by her children, Elizabeth (Chris) Quadracci Harned; Joel (Caran) Quadracci; Kathryn (Raja) Quadracci Flores; and Harry Richard (Emilio Cabrera) Quadracci; grandchildren Ellie, Kit, William and Alec Harned; Meghan, Halle and Danica Quadracci; and Isabella, Kaitlin and Harry Flores; brothers Jim (Pat) Ewens and Tom (Ellen) Ewens; sisters Jane (Dion Kempthorne) Ewens, Sue Ewens and Sister Mary Ewens; and many nephews and nieces. Betty was preceded in death by her husband and partner, Harry V. Quadracci, with whom she co-founded Quad/Graphics in 1971. With little money and big dreams, they launched Quad/Graphics in Pewaukee, WI., with 11 employees. The Quadraccis and their team persevered during the company's early, lean years to build a premier printing company. Today, Quad/Graphics is a leading global printer and media channel integrator with approximately 25,000 employees in eight countries. Betty was Quad/Graphics' matriarch and will long be revered for helping create the company's culture, which takes better care of employees' needs, including providing onsite childcare, which Betty first championed in the mid-80s; treating employees with dignity and respect; empowering employees to make decisions and innovate solutions; and providing employees with continuous training and education. A member of Quad/Graphics' board of directors since 2002, Betty played a pivotal role in the company's 2010 transition from a privately held company to a family controlled publicly traded company, which enabled Quad/Graphics to acquire its next largest competitor and further secure its leadership of the printing industry. For nearly 30 years, Betty was president and publisher of Milwaukee Magazine, acquired by Quad/Graphics in 1983. During her tenure, the magazine garnered hundreds of awards, including a Best Editorial Gold Medal for Betty's publisher's letter "The First Amendment Starts Here." Betty's creative inclinations led her to found Quad/Creative, a graphic design firm, in 1985. Betty served on the Milwaukee Art Museum's board for many years. In 1997 she and Harry spearheaded a $10 million matching donation from Quad/Graphics to kick off fundraising for a major museum addition. Designed by Santiago Calatrava and completed in 2001, the Quadracci Pavilion is a widely recognized symbol of Milwaukee. Betty also served on the boards of Artists Working in Education, a Milwaukee non-profit; the Greater Milwaukee Committee; and Milwaukee Women Inc., which she founded. Betty also led the Windhover Foundation, a philanthropic organization funded by the Quadracci family. Betty was one of the first Montessori teachers in the U.S. and helped establish the Waukesha (Wis.) Montessori School in 1964 and the Waukesha Head Start program in 1968, now the nation's oldest continually operating Head Start program. Visitation will be held at Blessed Teresa of Calcutta Catholic Church in North Lake, WI on December 13, from 3-7pm and December 14, from 9-10:45am. A Funeral Mass follows Saturday's visitation at 11am. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be sent to Children's Hospital Foundation, PO Box 1997 MS3050, Milwaukee, WI 53201; Women's Center of Waukesha, PO. Box 554, Waukesha, WI 53187; or Waukesha Montessori School, Att: Bill Walsh, 2600 Summit Ave., Waukesha, WI 53188.

MANLEY--John Kay, an architect employed in the office of Philip Johnson for 53 years, died December 8th, 2013. He was 88 years old. Born and raised in Brattleboro, VT, he enlisted in the army after graduating high school at age 17, spending two and a half years in uniform during World War II, including 15 months in France, Belgium, and Germany. Following the war, he moved to NYC where he received a B.A. in architecture from Pratt Institute in 1951; married dancer, actress, athlete, and practicing clinical psychologist Thea Trauner in 1953; and appeared in 17 amateur and semi-professional stage productions. In 1955, John was invited to work for Mies van der Rohe and Philip Johnson on the Seagram Building and its Four Seasons Restaurant. He subsequently decided to join Johnson's firm, where he became the principal designer. During his lengthy career, he worked for and with Johnson on some 178 built and unbuilt projects in this country and abroad. Among the buildings to which he contributed most significantly: New York State Theater at Lincoln Center; Kunsthaus (Art Museum), Bielefeld, Germany; Boston Public Library Addition; IDS Center in Minneapolis; Pennzoil and Transco, Houston; Thanksgiving Square Chapel and Park, as well as the unrealized Cathedral of Hope, Dallas; 1976 re-do of Avery Fisher Hall at Lincoln Center; three iterations of Amon Carter Museum, Fort Worth; Checkpoint Charlie I, Berlin; National Center for Performing Arts, Mumbai; Lancey Office Building, Geneva; the abandoned Lauder Oasis, Negev Desert, Israel; and the Visitor's Center on Philip Johnson's New Canaan, Connecticut estate. In 1991, Johnson listed him as co-architect of St. Basil's Chapel at the University of St. Thomas in Houston. Because of Johnson's declining health and infrequent office presence after the late 1990s, although none of these projects were ever publicly attributed to him, John perforce became the actual designer of the Domus Showroom at Madison and 34th Street, The Metropolitan Condo at 181 East 90th Street, The "Urban Glass House" at 330 Spring Street, and Number 5 Condo on East 44th Street all located in NYC; and the Sanctuary for Sufism Revised, Walnut Creek, California. Following a quadruple bypass in 1985, he suffered multiple, ongoing medical problems for the remainder of his life, which forced him to retire in 2008 at age 83. In spite of his many health issues, he remained an active, intelligent, and genuinely kind person who made a positive difference in the lives of everyone who knew him. He is survived by his daughter, Gail Faber, and two granddaughters, Lisa and Rachel, of Bridgewater, NJ; and by his partner of 44 years, Richard DeThuin, an author and reporter, of NYC.

KLIPPER--Sara Ida, beloved grandmother and concentration camp survivor died on Tuesday December 10th at 93. Until recently, she could be seen uptown sporting her furs unbound by the narrative of her heroic past. In her twenties she married and found refuge in the home of a Nazi resistance activist. She soon began trafficking weapons and playing an active role in the resistance movement. Her husband was discovered and killed and Ida became an inmate at Ravensbruk until liberation. Belgium later officially recognized her contribution: accolades she treated with a disparaging sense of humor. In her later life, Ida maintained her heroic spirit and became a most beloved mother-in-law, and adored grandmother. She lived with valor, an affinity for alternative medicine, convicted vegetarianism and a propensity for rhinestones. She will be sincerely missed.
HORN--Geoffrey M.,beloved writer, editor, husband, father, mentor, 19442013. Services December 15 at Monmouth Reform Temple, N.J. www.bit.ly/J4pcRD

HYMAN--Philip H.,94, of Ft. Lee, NJ. A graduate of Townsend Harris Hall and Baruch College, he served in the Navy in WWII and then was a valued tax strategist and CPA. Preceded in death by Helen, his beloved wife of over 70 years. Survived by his sons Douglas of Del Mar, CA and Laurence of San Francisco. Memorial service at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Ave., NY, NY, Friday, December 13, 1:30pm.

HOLTZMANN--Howard M. It is with great sorrow that the Kahn Family notes the passing of Judge Howard M. Holtzmann. It has been our privilege to advise the Holtzmann family for over 70 years in a relationship extending back to Howard's father, attorney Jacob Holtzmann. Howard was a brilliant attorney and a noted expert in the field of arbitration. He worked tirelessly in the Hague to settle claims resulting from the Iranian Hostage Crisis and served the Jewish community as a trustee of the Jewish Theological Seminary. We extend our condolences to Carol, Susie, Betsey and the extended Holtzmann family. Irving Kahn, Thomas Kahn, Andrew Kahn and everyone at Kahn Brothers Advisors LLC.

HOLTZMANN--Howard. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Howard Holtzmann. He leaves behind a legacy of exceptional philanthropy and consistent generosity to UJA-Federation. We extend our condolences to Howard's wife, Carol; his daughters, Susan and Betsey; his stepchildren, Louise (Henry) and William; his grandchildren; his great-grandchildren; and the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President; Linda Mirels, Chair of the Board; John S. Ruskay, Executive VP & CEO

HOLTZMANN--Hon. Howard M. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our lifelong friend and associate, Howard M. Holtzmann. His memory will remain forever in our hearts. George and Edith Rosenkranz and Family

HOLTZMANN--Hon. Howard Marshall, died at home in Manhattan, December 9, 2013, hours before his 92nd birthday. Judge Holtzmann was an original Member of the Iran-United State Claims Tribunal, which was established as part of the settlement of the Iranian hostage crisis. Among his many other contributions to the field of international arbitration, he long served as a member of the United States Delegation to the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law. He graduated from Yale College in 1942 and Yale Law School in 1947, and he received the Yale Medal in 2006. He was the son of the late Lillian Plotz Holtzmann and Jacob L. Holtzmann. He is survived by his wife Carol E. Holtzmann and daughters Susan Richardson of Palo Alto, CA and Betsey Holtzmann of Southwest Harbor, ME. He is also survived by his stepdaughter, Louise Muller (Henry), his stepson, William van Berg and grand children MacLaren Richardson (Jodi), Andrew Richardson (Erin), Abe Noyes, Jill van Berg (David Manella), Elizabeth van Berg and Allison van Berg and five great grand children. He was predeceased by his first wife, Anne Fisher Holtzmann and stepson, Peter van Berg. Services will be held on Friday, December 13, 2013 at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10022 at 11am. The family will welcome friends at their residence from 4:30pm to 7:30pm. No flowers please.

EGNER--Philip Richard, passed away peacefully at his home in Manhattan on December 10th. Born December 11th, 1926, Philip attended Brooklyn Prep High School and Georgetown University. He served in WWII in the Army, and was stationed in Manila, where he edited and wrote for the Army newsletter. After the war, he earned a degree in economics from Georgetown and went on to a seat on the New York Stock Exchange. He retired young to pursue other interests, such as real estate and arts and collectibles. He leaves behind his beloved sister, Doris Egner Tilyou, four devoted nieces Maureen Tilyou, Elizabeth Tilyou, Sarah Tilyou Albaneze and Susan Tilyou Stepney, and many dear and cherished friends. Visiting for family and friends 2-4 and 7-9pm Friday at Fairchild Sons Funeral Home, 1201 Franklin Ave, Garden City. Funeral Mass Saturday 9:30am at St. Agnes Cathedral, Rockville Centre. Interment to follow at Calvary Cemetery, Woodside NY.

DERN--Thomas A. The Board of Trustees, staff and individuals served by the YAI Network mourn the sudden loss of Thomas Dern, our long-time friend and beloved C.O.O., on December 9. Tom was a formative leader whose contribution to the agency and the field is hard to overstate. In his over 35-year career, he ushered in a new era, having worked in one of New York State's first group homes. He helped develop new models of community-based services. His passionate advocacy for people with disabilities and their families will remain his legacy. We extend our deepest condolences to the Dern family. Eliot P. Green, Chair Stephen E. Freeman, CEO

ZUCKERMAN--Abraham, 89, of Livingston, NJ died peacefully on Thursday December 12, 2013. Funeral services will be 10am today December 13 at the JEC, Elmora Ave, Elizabeth, NJ. Services made by Bernheim-Apter-Kreitzman, Livingston, NJ. Mr. Zuckerman is survived by his wife Millie of 66 years, his daughter Ann and son-in-law Bernard Sklar, his daughter Ruth and son-in-law Steven Katz, his son Wayne and daughter-in-law Deborah, twelve grandchildren and four great-grandchildren. Mr. Zuckerman, a real estate developer and Holocaust survivor devoted his life to numerous charitable organizations as well as memorializing Oscar Schindler by naming streets in more than 25 communities throughout the tri-state area. He also authored A Voice in the Chorus, a story of his life in the Holocaust.

ZINAMAN--Lawrence (Dick). On December 10. Singular and beloved husband of Lynn for 34 blessed years. Proud father of Steven (Nan) and Michael (Tina). Brother of the late Jules. SHERMAN--Myrna, 73, of Englewood, New Jersey. The Sherman Family mourns the tragic loss of beloved matriarch, Myrna Sherman who passed on December 11th. Myrna Sherman was a cherished wife and life-partner to her adoring husband of 54 years, Joel Sherman, President and Chief Executive Officer of Nat Sherman International, tobacconist to the world since 1930; mother to Michele, Bill and Larry; mother-in-law to Barry, Marla and Maureen; and grandmother to Alex, Emily, Madeline, Wylie, Cole, Emma, Annie and Bridget. Myrna was an inspiration, not only to her family but to everyone who knew her, and was actively involved in a number of charitable and community organizations, especially The Davis Phinney Foundation for Parkinson's. Myrna will forever be remembered for her passion for life, her love of family, and for her extraordinary spirit. Memorial services will take place at 1:15pm on Sunday, December 15, 2013, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY 10023. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research or Dr. Susan B. Bressman, M.D., Chairman, Parkinson's Research Department at Beth Israel Medical Center, 10 Union Sq. East, Suite 2Q, New York, NY. 10003.

RUSSETT--Cynthia Eagle. Born February 1, 1937, died December 5, 2013. Beloved wife of Bruce and mother of Margaret, Mark, Lucia, and Daniel. Memorial service at 11am on December 19 at St. Thomas More Chapel at Yale. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to the chapel or World Wildlife Fund.

QUADRACCI--Betty Ewens. Betty died peacefully in her Wisconsin home, surrounded by family and friends, on Monday, December 9, 2013, at age 75. She is survived by her children, Elizabeth (Chris) Quadracci Harned; Joel (Caran) Quadracci; Kathryn (Raja) Quadracci Flores; and Harry Richard (Emilio Cabrera) Quadracci; grandchildren Ellie, Kit, William and Alec Harned; Meghan, Halle and Danica Quadracci; and Isabella, Kaitlin and Harry Flores; brothers Jim (Pat) Ewens and Tom (Ellen) Ewens; sisters Jane (Dion Kempthorne) Ewens, Sue Ewens and Sister Mary Ewens; and many nephews and nieces. Betty was preceded in death by her husband and partner, Harry V. Quadracci, with whom she co-founded Quad/Graphics in 1971. With little money and big dreams, they launched Quad/Graphics in Pewaukee, WI., with 11 employees. The Quadraccis and their team persevered during the company's early, lean years to build a premier printing company. Today, Quad/Graphics is a leading global printer and media channel integrator with approximately 25,000 employees in eight countries. Betty was Quad/Graphics' matriarch and will long be revered for helping create the company's culture, which takes better care of employees' needs, including providing onsite childcare, which Betty first championed in the mid-80s; treating employees with dignity and respect; empowering employees to make decisions and innovate solutions; and providing employees with continuous training and education. A member of Quad/Graphics' board of directors since 2002, Betty played a pivotal role in the company's 2010 transition from a privately held company to a family controlled publicly traded company, which enabled Quad/Graphics to acquire its next largest competitor and further secure its leadership of the printing industry. For nearly 30 years, Betty was president and publisher of Milwaukee Magazine, acquired by Quad/Graphics in 1983. During her tenure, the magazine garnered hundreds of awards, including a Best Editorial Gold Medal for Betty's publisher's letter "The First Amendment Starts Here." Betty's creative inclinations led her to found Quad/Creative, a graphic design firm, in 1985. Betty served on the Milwaukee Art Museum's board for many years. In 1997 she and Harry spearheaded a $10 million matching donation from Quad/Graphics to kick off fundraising for a major museum addition. Designed by Santiago Calatrava and completed in 2001, the Quadracci Pavilion is a widely recognized symbol of Milwaukee. Betty also served on the boards of Artists Working in Education, a Milwaukee non-profit; the Greater Milwaukee Committee; and Milwaukee Women Inc., which she founded. Betty also led the Windhover Foundation, a philanthropic organization funded by the Quadracci family. Betty was one of the first Montessori teachers in the U.S. and helped establish the Waukesha (Wis.) Montessori School in 1964 and the Waukesha Head Start program in 1968, now the nation's oldest continually operating Head Start program. Visitation will be held at Blessed Teresa of Calcutta Catholic Church in North Lake, WI on December 13, from 3-7pm and December 14, from 9-10:45am. A Funeral Mass follows Saturday's visitation at 11am. In lieu of flowers, memorials may be sent to Children's Hospital Foundation, PO Box 1997 MS3050, Milwaukee, WI 53201; Women's Center of Waukesha, PO. Box 554, Waukesha, WI 53187; or Waukesha Montessori School, Att: Bill Walsh, 2600 Summit Ave., Waukesha, WI 53188.

HOLTZMANN--Howard M. It is with great sorrow that the Kahn Family notes the passing of Judge Howard M. Holtzmann. It has been our privilege to advise the Holtzmann family for over 70 years in a relationship extending back to Howard's father, attorney Jacob Holtzmann. Howard was a brilliant attorney and a noted expert in the field of arbitration. He worked tirelessly in the Hague to settle claims resulting from the Iranian Hostage Crisis and served the Jewish community as a trustee of the Jewish Theological Seminary. We extend our condolences to Carol, Susie, Betsey and the extended Holtzmann family. Irving Kahn, Thomas Kahn, Andrew Kahn and everyone at Kahn Brothers Advisors LLC.

HOLTZMANN--Hon. Howard M.,The Poly Prep Country Day School community mourns the loss of Poly alumnus Judge Howard M. Holtzmann (Class of 1938), distinguished jurist, author, and award-winning expert in international arbitration. Judge Holtzmann was also a generous and visionary benefactor to our school. We offer our deepest sympathies to his wife, Carol, and his entire family. Scott Smith (Class of 1975), Chairman David B. Harman, Headmaster

HOLTZMANN--Hon. Howard Marshall, died at home in Manhattan, December 9, 2013, hours before his 92nd birthday. Judge Holtzmann was an original Member of the Iran-United State Claims Tribunal, which was established as part of the settlement of the Iranian hostage crisis. Among his many other contributions to the field of international arbitration, he long served as a member of the United States Delegation to the United Nations Commission on International Trade Law. He graduated from Yale College in 1942 and Yale Law School in 1947, and he received the Yale Medal in 2006. He was the son of the late Lillian Plotz Holtzmann and Jacob L. Holtzmann. He is survived by his wife Carol E. Holtzmann and daughters Susan Richardson of Palo Alto, CA and Betsey Holtzmann of Southwest Harbor, ME. He is also survived by his stepdaughter, Louise Muller (Henry), his stepson, William van Berg and grand children MacLaren Richardson (Jodi), Andrew Richardson (Erin), Abe Noyes, Jill van Berg (David Manella), Elizabeth van Berg and Allison van Berg and five great grand children. He was predeceased by his first wife, Anne Fisher Holtzmann and stepson, Peter van Berg. Services will be held on Friday, December 13, 2013 at Central Synagogue, 652 Lexington Avenue, New York, NY 10022 at 11am. The family will welcome friends at their residence from 4:30pm to 7:30pm. No flowers please.

HOLTZMANN--Hon. Howard M. We are deeply saddened by the passing of our lifelong friend and associate, Howard M. Holtzmann. His memory will remain forever in our hearts. George and Edith Rosenkranz and Family

FRAZER--Edwin Churchill, 86, on December 11, 2013. A longtime resident of Englewood, NJ and Southampton, NY, Mr. Frazer served in the US Navy, graduated from Princeton University and retired from Citibank. Services Barrett Funeral Home, Tenafly, NJ.

FISHMAN--Dr. Jack, The Carlebach Shul mourns the passing of Dr. Jack Fishman. Jack was an exemplary human being and a brilliant scientist who developed numerous pharmaceutical compounds including the drug Naloxone, which has saved countless lives around the globe. Jack was also a visionary philanthropist, who along with his wife Joy, helped create a better life for thousands of people. Joy and Jack chaired the Carlebach Shul's annual dinner since 2005 and sponsored our organization's yearly conference focused on spiritual development. Jack is survived by his wife Joy, his sons Howard, Leslie, Neil, and Dan, stepdaughter Julie, ten grandchildren, his brother Dr. Jerry Fishman, and many students who looked to Jack for inspiration and guidance. He will be sorely missed.

DECOMBRAY--Richard, August 31, 1931 December 6, 2013. Richard de Combray was a New York-born citizen of the world who wrote about, photographed and spent most of his life in Europe and the Middle East. His books include Venice, Frail Barrier, Caravansary, Goodbye Europe, Lost in the City of Light, and Certain Restrictions May Apply. Always multi-talented, he was a singer and pianist as a teenager, first in American cities, then in Paris, and eventually at the Ruban Bleu in Manhattan. His photography studio in Rome became a social and intellectual center for American expatriates, and his own natural elegance inspired other artists to photograph and sculpt him, including a cameo appearance in the film, "Tender Is the Night." The son of Joseph and Miriam Harris of New York, he was educated at Stuyvesant High School, the Rhodes School, University of Wisconsin, University of Bridgeport and New York University. He moved to Europe in 1960, and in recent years, lived in Manhattan, La Colle sur Loup and Venice. For four years, he taught writing at Marymount College, and published a collection of his students' writings. He is survived by Miles Morgan, his life partner of 59 years, by a nephew Jed Harris, a niece Mara Bayless, and by former wife Natalie Hough de Combray. He is also survived by many friends for whom he was a teacher of creativity, kindness, beauty and the importance of friendship itself.

STIMPSON--William Arthur (Art), 95, of Woodway, WA, died December 7, 2013. Art was preceded in death by his beloved wife Marjorie (Margie) Jeanne Stimpson. He is survived by three children and two grandchildren. Art was the Partner in Charge of the SEC Dept. at Price Waterhouse in New York City retiring in 1979. He was the beloved son of William George and Ruby King Stimpson and born October 21, 1918 in Regina, Saskatchewan. Burial will be at Abbey View Memorial Park in Brier, WA, Tuesday, December 17, 2013. Tributes may be made at: http://www.Washelli.com/ memorials/memorials. php/dID/489118

SIROW--Doris. The Palm Beach Country Club expresses its profound sorrow at the passing of it's esteemed member, Doris Sirow, and extends sincere sympathy to her husband, children, grandchildren and other members of her family. William L. Mack, President Alan Curtis, Secretary

SIROW--Doris, The Board of Governors and the Members of Glen Oaks Club express our deepest sorrow at the passing of Doris, wife of our esteemed member Melvin, and extend our heartfelt sympathy to the entire family. Board of Governors Michael Mann President

Sirow--Doris 86, adored wife of Melvin for 66 years, loving mother to Richard (Lynn), Linda (Harold Koplewicz), Daniel (JoAnn), proud grandmother to Michael (Jessica) and Stacey Sirow, Joshua, Adam, and Sam Koplewicz, Gabrielle, Sarah, and Arianne Sirow, beloved sister to Roberta Wells, loyal sister in law to Lila Levy, and cherished aunt, grandaunt, and devoted friend died December 13, 2013 after a courageous four year battle with cancer. Doris was a beautiful and elegant woman who had a fairy tale romance with the man of her dreams who she met when she was 18 and spent the rest of her life with him. With Mel they had a wonderful family and great friends in Great Neck, NYC and Palm Beach. They traveled the world, collected art, enjoyed their family and loved being with each other. Funeral services Sunday, December 15, 11:30am, Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave (81 St). In lieu of flowers please send contributions to the Child Mind Institute 445 Park Ave, NY, NY 10022.
SIROW--Doris. We mourn the loss of our dear Aunt Doris and offer love and condolences to Mel, Linda, Ricky, and Danny. Erica and Ken

SILVER--Florette Zachary, died peacefully at home in Delray Beach, FL, at age 91. Beloved wife of the late Solomon Silver, DDS. Loving mother of Janet and Ken, adoring Nanny of Mariel and William, beloved aunt. A native of the Bronx, proud alumna of Walton High School and Lehman College, a speech therapist in New York. Member NYSUT. The family extends eternal gratitude to Florette's many friends and neighbors. Donations in her memory to Paps Corps Cancer Research, Planned Parenthood, or the charity of your choice. Interment Sunday 2pm at Beth Israel in Woodbridge, NJ.

SHERMAN--Myrna, 73, of Englewood, New Jersey. The Sherman Family mourns the tragic loss of beloved matriarch, Myrna Sherman who passed on December 11th. Myrna Sherman was a cherished wife and life-partner to her adoring husband of 54 years, Joel Sherman, President and Chief Executive Officer of Nat Sherman International, tobacconist to the world since 1930; mother to Michele, Bill and Larry; mother-in-law to Barry, Marla and Maureen; and grandmother to Alex, Emily, Madeline, Wylie, Cole, Emma, Annie and Bridget. Myrna was an inspiration, not only to her family but to everyone who knew her, and was actively involved in a number of charitable and community organizations, especially The Davis Phinney Foundation for Parkinson's. Myrna will forever be remembered for her passion for life, her love of family, and for her extraordinary spirit. Memorial services will take place at 1:15pm on Sunday, December 15, 2013, Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York, NY 10023. In lieu of flowers, the family requests that donations be sent to the Michael J. Fox Foundation for Parkinson's Research or Dr. Susan B. Bressman, M.D., Chairman, Parkinson's Research Department at Beth Israel Medical Center, 10 Union Sq. East, Suite 2Q, New York, NY. 10003.

HERCZ--Andre, The Board of Governors and the Members of Glen Oaks Club express our deepest sorrow at the passing our esteemed member Andre and extend our heartfelt sympathy to his wife Eve, and the entire family. Board of Governors Michael Mann President

NISSENSON--Hugh. 80, died suddenly at home in Manhattan on December 13. He is survived by his wife, Marilyn, daughter Kate and son-in-law Alan Scott, daughter Kore and son-in-law Allen Glied, and grandchildren Lily and Charlie Scott, and Kyle and Asher Glied. A native New Yorker, Hugh graduated from the Fieldston School and Swarthmore College. He was a distinguished author, whose novels include the critically-acclaimed The Tree of Life and The Song of the Earth. A memorial service will take place at the Frank E. Campbell Funeral Home, 1076 Madison Avenue, on Sunday, December 15 at 3:30pm. The family will welcome friends at their home, 411 West End Avenue, on Sunday after 6pm and on Monday, after 4pm. Donations may be made to Ethical Culture Fieldston School.

FISHER--Ellen C.,died December 7. A life long New Yorker, Ellen lit our lives with her joie d' vivre, creativity, impeccable style, her smarts and her genius for friendship. Her talents took her from award winning creative director at several advertising agencies to respected scholar and lecturer in the field of costume history. At 81, Ellen was moments away from receiving her PH.D. She is survived by her sister, Beth Karlan (Art); niece, Pam Karlan (Viola Canales); nephew, Pete Karlan (Kirsten); two grand nieces, Rose and Leah; many relatives and a legion of devoted friends on three continents. A memorial is planned for early 2014.

QUADRACCI--Betty Ewens, died peacefully in her Wisconsin home, surrounded by family and friends, on Monday, December 9, 2013, at age 75. She is survived by her children, Elizabeth (Chris) Quadracci Harned; Joel (Caran) Quadracci; Kathryn (Raja) Quadracci Flores; and Harry Richard (Emilio Cabrera) Quadracci; grandchildren Ellie, Kit, William and Alec Harned; Meghan, Halle and Danica Quadracci; and Isabella, Kaitlin and Harry Flores; brothers Jim (Pat) Ewens and Tom (Ellen) Ewens; sisters Jane (Dion Kempthorne) Ewens, Sue Ewens and Sister Mary Ewens; and many nephews and nieces. Betty was preceded in death by her husband and partner, Harry V. Quadracci, with whom she co-founded Quad/Graphics in 1971. With little money and big dreams, they launched Quad/Graphics in Pewaukee, WI, with 11 employees. The Quadraccis and their team persevered during the company's early, lean years to build a premier printing company. Today Quad/Graphics is a leading global printer and media channel integrator with approximately 25,000 employees in eight countries. Betty was Quad/Graphics' matriarch and will long be revered for helping create the company's culture, which takes better care of employees' needs, including providing onsite childcare, which Betty first championed in the mid-80s; treating employees with dignity and respect; empowering employees to make decisions and innovate solutions; and providing employees with continuous training and education. A member of Quad/Graphics' board of directors since 2002, Betty played a pivotal role in the company's 2010 transition from a privately held company to a family controlled publicly traded company, which enabled Quad/Graphics to acquire its next largest competitor and further secure its leadership of the printing industry. For nearly 30 years, Betty was president and publisher of Milwaukee Magazine, acquired by Quad/Graphics in 1983. During her tenure, the magazine garnered hundreds of awards, including a Best Editorial Gold Medal for Betty's publisher's letter "The First Amendment Starts Here." Betty's creative inclinations led her to found Quad/Creative, a graphic design firm, in 1985. Betty served on the Milwaukee Art Museum's board for many years. In 1997 she and Harry spearheaded a $10 million matching donation from Quad/Graphics to kick off fundraising for a major museum addition. Designed by Santiago Calatrava and completed in 2001, the Quadracci Pavilion is a widely recognized symbol of Milwaukee. Betty also served on the boards of Artists Working in Education, a Milwaukee non-profit; the Greater Milwaukee Committee; and Milwaukee Women Inc., which she founded. Betty also led the Windhover Foundation, a philanthropic organization funded by the Quadracci family. Betty was one of the first Montessori teachers in the U.S. and helped establish the Waukesha (WI) Montessori School in 1964 and the Waukesha Head Start program in 1968, now the nation's oldest continually operating Head Start program. A native of Milwaukee, Betty earned a bachelor's degree from Trinity College in Washington, D.C., in 1961 and attended the University of Fribourg in Fribourg, Switzerland. Visitation and the Funeral Mass were held at Blessed Teresa of Calcutta Catholic Church in North Lake, WI. Memorials may be sent to Children's Hospital Foundation, PO Box 1997 MS3050, Milwaukee, WI 53201; Women's Center of Waukesha, PO. Box 554, Waukesha, WI 53187; or Waukesha Montessori School, Att: Bill Walsh, 2600 Summit Ave., Waukesha, WI 53188.

HAMBRICK--Dr. George W. Jr.,died at his home with his family by his side on Tuesday, December 10, 2013; six days after his 91st birthday. Dr. Hambrick, born on December 4, 1922 in Charlottesville, Virginia, was the son of a veterinarian and a nurse. He was preceded in death by his parents George Walter Hambrick, DVM and Anna McCallum Hambrick, and his sister, Anne Hambrick Uzmed. His mother's and father's families were descended from early settlers in Virginia. He believed himself to be one of the oldest survivors in his generation of the Coleman and Harris families of Virginia, both originally from England. His mother was also a descendant of those families although she herself was a member of the McCallum family of Scotland. Dr. Hambrick was a Virginian by birth and graduated from Concord College in Athens, West Virginia. He received his MD degree from the University of Virginia School of Medicine and remained there for his first year of dermatological training. Following an internship at the University of Iowa Hospital, he trained in Dermatology at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and Duke University in North Carolina. From 1948 to 1950 he served in the United States Army in Georgia and Okinawa, Japan. Beginning in the early 1950's George launched an academic career, equaled by few in his field, in which he rose through the ranks at Columbia University, the University of Pennsylvania, and Johns Hopkins University, where he served as Professor and Chairman of Dermatology for nearly ten years, until 1976. He then directed the Department of Dermatology at the University of Cincinnati for five years before moving to Cornell University in New York, where he co-directed the Division of Dermatology for an additional 12 years, until 1993 and established Dermatology as full Department status. Dr. Hambrick was a Professor Emeritus at Cornell and Senior Lecturer at Columbia. His appointments have included editorial journal responsibilities as well as a variety of committees with the National Institute of Health. In 1987, together with Rockefeller University's Martin Carter, MD, PhD and Herzog Foundation President Peter Bentley, Dr. Hambrick founded the American Skin Association to represent the interest of skin disease victims and their families. At the age of 85, Dr. Hambrick would leave his home in Charlottesville, drive to Richmond, Virginia and fly to New York City. There he would stay Monday through Thursday to fulfill his duties as President of the American Skin Association. The American Skin Association remains a singular voice dedicated to overcoming the most serious forms of skin cancer and disease through research and education. In 1993, the Weill Cornell Medical College honored him by establishing the George W. Hambrick, Jr. Professorship in Dermatology. The Hambrick Professorship, is currently held by Dr. Richard Granstein, chairman of the Department of Dermatology at Weill Cornell. Most recently The George W. Hambrick Jr., a M.D. leadership fund in Oncological Dermatology was initiated by the Johns Hopkins Department of Dermatology in recognition of Dr. Hambrick's great contributions to Johns Hopkins and to the field of Dermatology. This endowed professorship honored Dr. Hambrick's record of excellence in promoting healthy skin through skin cancer research and exemplary leadership in the field of Dermatology. Among his countless other accolades is the Dermatology Foundation's first Lifetime Career Educator Award for his service as a mentor, role model, and inspiration to students and residents. He served as president of both the Dermatology Foundation and the Society of Investigative Dermatology and, for 11 years, as a delegate to the American Medical Association. With more than 75 publications to his credit, he was an advisor to Skin & Allergy News and a member of the editorial board for the Journal of the American Academy of Dermatology. As an academic administrator, investigator, author and thoughtful leader, George influenced generations of dermatologists. Nothing, however, conveys his contributions as a formative teacher of young dermatologists more eloquently than the words of a former student. "I wish to convey the compassion he exemplified to his patients while also imparting his wealth of knowledge to the residents. He worked tirelessly to stress excellence and to make sure we were performing to the best of our abilities." In addition to Dr. Hambrick's professional credentials, his primary devotion was to his family and friends. Known affectionately as Dee Dee, his passion was nurturing relationships. As a visionary he took great pride in watching people grow, mentoring many throughout his long life. Dee Dee read constantly, his magnifying glass always in hand. He was an avid genealogist with an impressive memory for details, never forgetting a person or a name. Hours were spent researching his lineage, looking up Hambricks in phonebooks, leading to connections with newly found relatives, which became life-long kinships. History, opera, music, gardening, and travel were among his interests. He was also trained as a classical pianist. He has been called a gifted soul with a brilliant mind. What a wonderful life. He is survived by his niece, Anna "Terry" Bruce Columbus and her husband Marc and their children Jillian A. Columbus and Cole M. Columbus of Charlottesville, Virginia. The family would like to thank the caregivers of T&L Companions. We are grateful for the expert medical care from many University of Virginia Medical Center physicians including his primary care doctor, Dr. Diane Snustad. A special thank you goes out to his very dear friends, Howard and Abby Milstein of New York, recognizing them for their genuine support and steadfast commitment throughout their enduring friendship. A funeral service will be held at 11:00am, Thursday, December 19, 2013 at Westminster Presbyterian Church in Charlottesville, VA with the Reverend Dr. Laura S. Sugg and the Reverend Dr. John G. McFayden of Philadelphia, PA officiating. Interment will follow at Monticello Memory Gardens. Visitation will be held 6:00pm to 8:00pm, Wednesday, December 18, 2013 at Hill and Wood Funeral Home. In lieu of flowers, if one wishes, memorial contributions may be made to the American Skin Association, 6 East 43rd St., 28th Flr., New York, NY 10017.

GORDON--Russell T. American-born painter and art teacher Russell T. Gordon died at home in Montreal in early November 2013, of cancer. He was 77 years old. Gordon was born in 1936, in Philadelphia, PA, where he received his early training (BFA) at Temple University with a basketball scholarship; he later took a double Master's Degree (Arts and Fine Arts) at the University of Wisconsin. His initial employment as a fine arts instructor was at the University of Utah in Salt Lake City, followed by a teaching engagement at the University of California at Berkeley. In 1973 he first came to Montreal as a visiting professor to Sir George Williams (now Concordia) University, where he joined the faculty the following year and remained for almost 25 years until his retirement in 1998. Throughout his career, Russell Gordon never ceased painting; his works have been widely shown, and can be found in several prominent museum and corporate collections in both the USA and Canada. He was also much sought after as a visiting artist, speaker and jury member, and received bursaries and grants from many sources, including the Carnegie Foundation for his work with inner city youth and the Rockefeller Foundation, for a residency at Bellagio (Italy) in 2006. He will be warmly remembered by many colleagues, students and friends. His ashes will be buried at Stonington, ME, where he found both peace and inspiration.

FISHMAN--Dr. Jack. The Aleph Institute mourns the loss of Dr. Jack Fishman, husband of our beloved board member, Joy Fishman. Our deep condolences to the entire Fishman family. Dr. Fishman's extraordinary generosity and deep commitment to sustaining hope and delivering a helping hand to families in crisis was unique. Aleph and the community it serves know first-hand the tangible, life-saving and oft overlooked impact of Dr. Fishman's work in the development of Naloxone, a drug used to treat opioid-related addiction. His deep care and concern for those that everyone else forgets will reverberate for generations. Jack will be sorely missed but never forgotten. Rabbi Aaron Lipskar, Rabbi Mendy Katz
