DONNER--Aaron B.,respected attorney and political leader, died Friday, December 6, 2013 surrounded by his family in Bay Shore, New York. He was 88 years old. Aaron's life represents a great American success story. His father was a Russian immigrant who entered the US through Ellis Island. Aaron was born in 1925 and raised in Jamaica, Queens. He enlisted in the Army in World War II and fought in the Battle of Saipan. After the war, the GI Bill supported his undergraduate and Law degrees at NYU. He married Doris Schneider in 1951, and moved to Bay Shore, where he established a law practice specializing in real estate and became a leading legal figure on Long Island. He had a passion for politics, became active in the New York Democratic Party and Campaign Manager for Congressman Otis G. Pike, serving as his Congressional Aide from 1961-1978. He took pride in helping to create Congressional designation of the Fire Island National Seashore. He was chosen as Chief Counsel for the House Select Committee on Intelligence, and with Pike, led an historic investigation of the US Intelligence Community, leading to significant reforms of the CIA. In 1989 Aaron was appointed by then-Governor Mario Cuomo as Chair of SUNY Stony Brook Council. Aaron lived a full and accomplished life, pursuing his passions for family, recreation, and social activism with equal vigor. He adored sailing and fishing on the Great South Bay, and was never happier then when on the water in his boat. Aaron's Maine Lobster boat, the "Hannah J." was the source of great pride and enjoyment. He held an unflinching commitment to improving society and, together with Doris, engaged in numerous civil, social and political causes. Notable activism included work for the Development Disabilities Institute of Long Island, Planned Parenthood and Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. After the death of Doris, he retired and continued to divide his time between the Bay, supporting friends and local causes, and becoming an accomplished writer of short stories, based on his life experiences. In recent years Aaron lived with his dear companion, Molly Blue of Babylon with the kind support of Meg Green. Those who knew Aaron will speak of his extraordinary, noble values, his love of his family, his engagement with life and the world around him, his booming voice and mischievous sense of humor. He despised injustice and took every opportunity to challenge it, becoming a role model who influenced and shaped the lives of family and those around him. He leaves a proud legacy of achievement, integrity and love. Aaron is survived by his three children; Lauren, Jonathan and Ann, his grandchildren; Jesse, Becky, James, Julian, Olivia and Noah, and his daughter and sons-in-law; Louise, John and Kelley. The family requests in lieu of flowers that donations are sent to Calvary Hospital, Planned Parenthood and the Developmental Disabilities Institute of Long Island.

DADIRRIAN--Arthur, 88, Dr. of Internal Medicine and veteran, died on December 1st, 2013. He passed away peacefully surrounded by his loving family. He was born in Lynbrook, NY to Edna Keeler Dadirrian and Arthur N. Dadirrian, Sr. As a child he often visited his grandfather's pharmacy in Far Rockaway, one of the first on Long Island. At age 18, he lost his father to leukemia. He attended Cornell University and graduated from the Medical College in 1948. His residencies included the Walter Reed Army Hospital in Washington and Fitzsimons in Denver. He served in the Navy and later became a major in the Army during the Korean War. He graduated from the University of Pennsylvania Graduate School of Medicine in 1955 and married later that year. Dr. Dadirrian had a private practice in the financial district of lower Manhattan for 30 years. In 1992, he moved from Manhasset to Palm Beach Gardens, FL for his retirement. His quiet intelligence and compassionate nature will be missed by many. He is survived by his wife Dorothy, daughters Janet Hughes (Cory), Susan Sosa (Vince), Nancy Kazmierowicz (Jack), and seven grandchildren.

DECOMBRAY--Richard, August 31, 1931 December 6, 2013. Richard de Combray was a New York-born citizen of the world who wrote about, photographed and spent most of his life in Europe and the Middle East. His books include Venice, Frail Barrier, Caravansary, Goodbye Europe, Lost in the City of Light, and Certain Restrictions May Apply. Always multi-talented, he was a singer and pianist as a teenager, first in American cities, then in Paris, and eventually at the Ruban Bleu in Manhattan. His photography studio in Rome became a social and intellectual center for American expatriates, and his own natural elegance inspired other artists to photograph and sculpt him, including a cameo appearance in the film, "Tender Is the Night." The son of Joseph and Miriam Harris of New York, he was educated at Stuyvesant High School, the Rhodes School, University of Wisconsin, University of Bridgeport and New York University. He moved to Europe in 1960, and in recent years, lived in Manhattan, La Colle sur Loup and Venice. For four years, he taught writing at Marymount College, and published a collection of his students' writings. He is survived by Miles Morgan, his life partner of 59 years, by a nephew Jed Harris, a niece Mara Bayless, and by former wife Natalie Hough de Combray. He is also survived by many friends for whom he was a teacher of creativity, kindness, beauty and the importance of friendship itself.

CONNABLE--Alfred B.,age 82, died peacefully on December 7, 2013 at home. He is survived by his wife, Roma Connable, and his son Benjamin Connable, daughter-in-law Rebecca Morrissey and two grandsons Aram and Charlie. His late son Joel Connable died in 2012. A memorial service will be announced at a later date.

CONDREN--Dr. Raymond J.,Clinical Psychologist, 80, of Lake Worth, FL passed away December 1, 2013. Raymond was born in Brooklyn, NY March 1, 1933. He was married to Eny M. Condren and they lived together in Dix Hills, NY before retiring to Florida. Raymond earned his his PhD in Psychology from Texas Tech University. He served in the United States Air force for five years. Raymond retired in 1991 as First Deputy Commissioner of Nassau County Department of Drug and Alcohol Addiction. Raymond is survived by his six children and seven grandchildren. Raymond loved life, and his laugh still resounds in the ears of those who knew and loved him. He was an avid reader of the New York Times, a habit he carried with him to Florida. His strength and generosity inspired those around him; he will be missed.
Chisholm--Corning, born July 18, 1914 in Cleveland, Ohio. Corning passed away peacefully on December 12th in Oberlin, Ohio. He is survived by two nieces, Adele Eells Pierce and Kate Halle Briggs.

CHARLTON--Maryette. Filmmaker, photographer, artist, performer and downtown arts advocate extraordinaire Maryette Charlton passed away in New York City on November 25 at the age of 89. Born in Manchester, Iowa in 1924, educated at Pratt and Columbia University. Founded and taught at the Art department of American University of Beirut in the fifties. Her work as a filmmaker documented the works of Alexander Calder, e.e. cummings, Frederick Kiesler, Pierre Matisse, Dorothy Miller, Lenore Tawney, Loren MacIver and others. Over the years Maryette and longtime partner Lillian Kiesler became the most enthusiastic supporters of many young artists. As a performer Maryette appeared in the works of Cindy Lubar, Richard Foreman, Jo Andres, Tim Miller, Steve Buscemi and others. She most recently appeared in the film "Ghostlight" as Helen Keller. She was the mother of the late photographer Kirk Winslow. Maryette's e.e. cummings archives have been left to Harvard University. Her extensive collection of downtown New York arts memorabilia has been left to the Smithsonian Archives of American Art.
CAHN--Juliette. You are a celebration of life. Wishing you a peaceful and happy journey filled with love and joy. We love you. Always.

BRILOFF--Abraham J. The Baruch College community notes with deepest sorrow the passing of legendary alumnus, accountant, and Baruch College Professor Abraham J. Briloff ('37, MSEd '41). In a profession known for integrity and character, he stood out as a champion of the highest principals and ethics. Professor Briloff was 96 years old. To the world at large, Abraham Briloff was one of the most significant accountants of the last century. His writings were prodigious and influential, including four books: "Effectiveness of Accounting Communication;" "Unaccountable Accounting;" "More Debits Than Credits: The Burnt Investors' Guide to Financial Statements;" and "The Truth About Corporate Accounting." For three decades, he wrote a column for Barron's in which he frequently discussed irregular accounting practices. On numerous occasions, he testified before accounting and governmental bodies. Born and educated in New York City, Briloff earned a BBA and an MSEd from City College/ Baruch in 1937 and 1941, respectively, later earning a doctorate in accountancy and taxation from New York University in 1965. In 1976 he was named the Emanuel Saxe Distinguished Professor of Accountancy. He also served as a Baruch College Fund Trustee from 1969 to 1974 and was, at his death, a Trustee Emeritus. He was much admired by alumni, who established in his name an ethics prize, awarded annually to a faculty member and student, and a scholarship. The College's sympathies are extended to his entire family, especially daughters Leonore A. Briloff and Alice Ebenstein. Mitchel B. Wallerstein President, Baruch College

BRILOFF--Abraham J.,age 96 died peacefully at home on December 12, 2013 after a brief illness. He was the beloved husband of the late Edith M. Briloff, loving father and father-in-law of Leonore A. Briloff, Alice Ebenstein and William Ebenstein and devoted grandfather of Julie Ebenstein. Funeral services Tuesday, December 17th at 11am at Temple Beth-el of Great Neck, 5 Old Mill Rd. No flowers please.
BLOOM--Jewel Landau, of Miami Beach, Florida died peacefully at home on December 12, 2013, at the age of 84. Devoted wife to Stanley, Cherished Sister, Mother and Grandmother.

BLATT--Daniel Harry, age 76, died Wednesday, October 9, 2013 of pancreatic cancer. The son of German immigrants, Blatt grew up in Haverstraw, NY. He graduated Andover in 1955, Duke University in 1959 and Northwestern Law School in 1962. In the early 1960's Blatt worked as a Legal Aid lawyer in New York and served with Lawyers for Constitutional Defense Committee. A career as a producer of feature films, movies for television and television series followed. It began in the late 1970's as Vice President of Palomar Pictures, with credits including "The Heartbreak Kid" and "The Stepford Wives." Blatt's subsequent, independently produced films include "I Never Promised You a Rose Garden," "The Howling," "Cujo," "Common Ground," "Kissinger and Nixon," "Sadat" and "Raid on Entebee." He also produced, with partner Robert Singer, the popular mini-series and subsequent television series "V." Most recently Blatt produced "The Wishing Tree," starring Jason Gedrick and "Twist of Faith," starring singer-actress Toni Braxton. Blatt had passion for his work and golf but his deepest loves were the two daughters he shared with his second wife, Judy Brown, and his third wife, literary agent, Marti Blumenthal. Blatt is survived by wife Marti, his two daughters, Jessica and Chelsea, son-in-law Gregory Ezor, grandson Benjamin Ezor, sister Dr. Ruth Merkatz, brother-in-law Dr. Irwin Merkatz, brother Dr. Philip Blatt and sister-in-law Paula Breen. Donations may be made to The First Tee or to the Lustgarten Foundation for pancreatic cancer research.

BEYDA--Barbara Milstein, of Cupertino, California formerly of Rockville Centre, New York on December 12, 2013 at her home. Barbara was the beloved wife of the late Joseph David Beyda, devoted mother of William Joseph Beyda and his wife Cathy, cherished grandmother of Joseph William Beyda and Rachel Ann Beyda, treasured sister of Monroe Milstein, and beloved aunt of her many devoted nieces and nephews. A caring and intellectually vibrant woman, Barbara adored her grandchildren, loved animals and enjoyed reading and learning. She earned a Bachelor of Arts degree with distinction from Cornell University when she was 20 years old, and took graduate courses at the New School and UCLA. She held various administrative and editorial positions both in international business and education, before retiring to sunny California in 1984. Most of all, she was a wonderful wife, mother, and grandmother. She will be greatly missed by all.

BENN--Alec, for 20 years president of Benn & MacDonough, Inc., a New York City advertising agency specializing in finance, died on December 6 at the age of 95. His advertisements won a number of awards. He was also the author of four published books and several prize-winning plays. His first book, "The 27 Most Common Mistakes in Advertising," published in 1978 by AMACOM, was translated into Japanese, Spanish, Portuguese and in 2004 - 25 years after its initial publication - into Chinese. His fourth book, "The Unseen Wall Street of 1967-1975," published in 2000 by Quorum Books, revealed little known facts about the near collapse of The New York Stock Exchange. A graduate of Brown University in 1939 with a degree in Mechanical Engineering, he played tournament tennis from when he was a teenager until his mid-eighties. In 1999, he reached the consolation finals of the National USTA tournament for players 80 and over. In 1943, he joined the US Navy as an ensign and was sent to Midway Island to help introduce the acoustic torpedo, then a Top Secret weapon, to the Pacific submarine force. A resident of New York City and Palm Desert, CA, he is survived by his wife of 53 years, Caroline, and by three sons: Ted of Aurora, CO, Alex of Los Angeles, CA, and Rennie of Summit, NJ, five grandchildren and one great- granddaughter. He was a long-time member of The University Club in NYC. A memorial will be held there at a date to be announced.

ASCH--Florence Rossman, 88, of Greenwich, CT died on December 6, 2013 following complications from Parkinson's Disease. In lieu of flowers, memorial contributions may be made to Pegasus Therapeutic Riding Program, 310 Peach Lake Road, Brewster, NY 10509. (845)669-8235 ext.101

ABROFF--Harold, 102 years old, died December 13, 2013 in Great Neck, NY. For more than 50 years was an owner of David Abroff Manufacturing Corporation in Brooklyn. For 76 years was the beloved husband of Gertrude Abroff, who died two years ago. Devoted father of Susan and Richard Olshen, and David and Patty Abroff. Cherished grandfather of seven and great-grandfather of nine. Graveside services 11:30am, Sunday at Beth Moses Cemetery, Pinelawn, LI, NY.

Chain Reactions
 
The Rube Goldberg contraption that is the cover of The Art of Rube Goldberg (Abrams Comic­Arts, $60), with a manually operated rising sun and clashing cymbals, is a pure delight, albeit foolishly excessive. It is a primitive way to animate the cartoonist Goldberg’s signature fantasy mechanisms that prompted the adjective “Rube Goldbergian,” which, according to Merriam-Webster, means “accomplishing by complex means what seemingly could be done simply.” Goldberg’s silly inventions, satires on the absurdity of our machine age, are just a portion of the wackily conceived, beautifully drawn cartoons, comics and games lovingly selected by his granddaughter Jennifer George. She also provides a preface that serves as a touching memoir: “My favorite thing to do with Papa Rube was make paper balloons. The first time my grandfather made one, I was mesmerized.”
SANDS--Donna Lynn, (1964 - 2008). Light of our lives, always in our thoughts, you are greatly missed. Mom, Michael, Svetlana & Isabelle Donna Sands and Richard Sands
GOLD--Arthur A.,M.D. 11/3/29 to 12/15/06. Deeply loved. We miss your warmth and wit. Bobbie and The Family
BELENKY--Selma. 12/17/12 Mom(Nana), your indomitable spirit is with us forever. Love, Katrin, Rachel, and Sara

ZUCKERMAN--Abraham. The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum mourns the passing of Abraham Zuckerman. A Holocaust survivor from Krakow, Mr. Zuckerman spent his youth working at a factory run by Oskar Schindler and later devoted much of his life to memorializing Schindler's efforts to save Jews. As a Museum Founder, Mr. Zuckerman was among the Museum's earliest supporters, helping to build this institution and playing an active role in its growth. Our sincere condolences go to his wife, Millie, his children Ann and Bernie Sklar, Ruth and Steven Katz and Wayne and Deborah Zuckerman, and his many grandchildren and great-grandchildren. Tom A. Bernstein, Chairman Joshua B. Bolten, Vice Chairman Sara J. Bloomfield, Director The United States Holocaust Memorial Museum

ZUCKERMAN--Abraham. Yeshiva University and the Benjamin N. Cardozo School of Law extend their heartfelt condolences to Millie Zuckerman and to Ruth and Steven Katz and their entire family on the loss of Millie's husband and Ruth's father, Abraham Zuckerman. Ever-vital and engaged members of the Yeshiva University and Cardozo Law families, the Zuckerman and Katz families have been steadfast in their friendship and generous in their philanthropy. Steven's many years of service on the Cardozo Board of Overseers, begun during the law school career of his daughter Hillary '04, and his and Ruth's support for the law school's scholarship, building and public service programs extends Abraham's legacy into the present day. Abraham Zuckerman's lifelong dedication to honoring the heroism of his wartime protector Oscar Schindler continues to illuminate the work and inspire the lives of new generations of university and law school students. Abraham's post-war business success in New Jersey, the fullness of his home and community life and his loving devotion to the task of memorializing Oscar Schindler have left a vibrant legacy. We join his family in affirming his extraordinary life and in deeply mourning his passing. Yeshiva University Richard M. Joel, President

WILLIAMSON--Elaine Potasky, 74, of New York City, died on November 12, 2013. Elaine, throughout her entire adult life, was a teacher; from her beginning as a student teacher in Newton, MA to her most recent twenty-seven year career at the Nightingale Bamford School in New York City. In the interim she taught at the Ledyard Connecticut Elementary School, the Mystic Aquarium, and the New York City Boathouse. In Mystic she developed and taught in a popular traveling classroom that brought sea-creatures into the classrooms of Connecticut and Rhode Island elementary schools. At the Boathouse she brought students from the New York public schools into the Boathouse where she introduced them to marine life found along the local shores. Her teaching was facilitated by a touch-tank that she designed and stocked with the local shore-side fauna and flora. Elaine will be dearly missed by her husband of fifty years, her brother, her three children, their wonderful spouses, her seven grandchildren, and her many cherished friends. In lieu of flowers, please make a contribution to your favorite charity in memory of Elaine or please make a tax deductible contribution to The Nightingale Bamford School, 20 East 92nd Street, New York, NY 10128. (www.Nightingale.org).

WROBEL--Bruce James, 56, of NYC passed away on December 10, 2013. Bruce was born in Chicago, IL on July 5, 1957 to his beloved parents, Virginia I Wrobel and the late Walter J Wrobel. After a very successful academic and athletic career at Evergreen Park High School in Evergreen Park, IL, Bruce went on to the Massachusetts Institute of Technology where he developed his passion for energy development, drove the establishment of a varsity football team after a 70-year hiatus, and formed many treasured and lifelong friendships. After receiving degrees in economics and resource management, Bruce cofounded MITEX Corporation, a hydropower company later sold to Sithe Energies. As a Sithe Energies executive and eventual Sithe Global Power CEO, Bruce was responsible for the identification and development of dozens of power plants throughout the world. Power plant development eventually took him to Africa where he fell in love with the people and became committed to addressing many of the challenges preventing African nations from overcoming poverty. Whether building power plants to deliver reliable energy and much needed jobs (SITHE GLOBAL), laying fiber optic cable on the ocean floor to enable global connectivity and access (SEACOM), or helping nations realize the full value of their natural resources (GAPCO), Bruce envisioned real solutions and worked tirelessly to secure the required funding and manage the projects through to completion. Always a generous and giving man, Bruce formalized his philanthropy through many charitable organizations, including his own All for Africa, with school construction and education being his favored focus. He was fueled by the joy on student's faces when able to receive their education in a real school environment for the first time. Bruce is survived by his greatest assets -- his loving mother Virginia (Evergreen Park, IL), his once wife and now dear friend Marlo Marron, his beloved children, Dylan and Summer, his wonderful siblings Dawn (Bob Mason) of Beecher, IL, Walter (Susan) of Houston, TX, and Sandra (Robbie Robinson) of Redwood City, CA, his six handsome nephews, and a world full of cherished friends and respected colleagues. For those wishing to continue Bruce's legacy, donations in his memory can be made to the Bruce Wrobel Memorial Foundation.
WALDEN--Olga Lucille, October 1, 1939, died December 11, 2013. Beloved wife of Marvin, mother to Katherine, Gerald, and Eugene, and grandmother to Anna, Charlotte, and Julia.

TURNER--Richard J. Beloved husband, father, grandfather, great-grandfather, uncle, and great-uncle, Richard Joseph Turner, died peacefully in his sleep on December 5, 2013 in Southbury, CT. Born December 18, 1920, in New York City, he attended Yale University, acquiring his BS and PhD in organic chemistry. He worked for American Cyanamid Company for 25 years before starting Turner Associates. He devoted his career to developing medical and surgical devices, including the first biodegradable synthetic suture, Dexon. Resided for many years in Wilton, CT. Survived by his wife of 69 years, Viola Tracy Turner, two daughters, Tracy Turner and Carole Turner Reading, and her husband Ron Reading, three grandchildren and two great-grandchildren. A celebration remembrance will be held at the Yale Club of New York City on January 19, 2014.

TROY--Dr. Leo, 89, of West Orange, NJ.,died Saturday, November 2, 2013, at home peacefully in his sleep. Born in Wilkes-Barre, PA., September 17, 1924, the son of Isaiah and Zelda Israel Troy. He served in the US Army during World War II, fought in the Battle of the Bulge and was awarded the Meritorious Service Medal, the European African Middle Eastern Campaign Medal and the Medal of Freedom. He graduated from Penn State and Columbia University, where he earned his PhD in Economics. Dr. Troy was a professor at Rutgers University for 53 years and Chairman of the Economics Department for 17 years. He won two Fulbright Scholarships to research UK labor unions, moving his family to England in 1962 and 1973. Dr. Troy was the author of three books, "Almanac of Financial Ratios", "Beyond Unions and Collective Bargaining" and "Twilight of the Old Unionism." He was quoted often in The New York Times about unions over the years, most recently at the age of 88, in 2012. Dan Seligman of Forbes Magazine, in a tribute to Dr. Troy entitled "Driving the AFL-CIO Crazy," wrote: "LEO TROY, Rutgers economist, has long been giving fits to organized labor...now 75, and still carrying a heavy teaching load (his title is Distinguished Professor of Economics)..." Dr. Troy is survived by his children, Suzannah and Alexander, his daughter-in-law Dale, grandchildren Ariel, Abby, Rachel, and his ex-wife Sandra.

TOTO--James Vincent, 79, East Brunswick, NJ, on December 13, 2013. Retired Civil Engineer. Husband of Addie Pizzoli Toto. Father of Carolyn Wolf, Chuck and James Toto. Grandfather of nine. Visitation 6-8pm Sunday; 2-4 and 7-9pm Monday. Service 9:15am, Brunswick Memorial Home: E. Brunswick, NJ (www.brunswickmemorial home.com). Mass 10:00am, St. Bartholomew RC Church, E. Brunswick. Entombment Holy Cross Burial Park, South Brunswick, NJ.

ZARCHIN--Blanche, 91 years old, died last night, peacefully, in her sleep, in her own bed, in her own apartment, which was how she hoped it would be. She is survived by her children, Linda, Susan, Jill and Jim, their spouses, David, Cathy and Scott, her grandchildren and their spouses , Josh and Clare, Noah, Leah, Max and Jenna, and her sister, Harriet. The tender care and love she showed so many through her life was returned to her, especially in her last years. Blanche grew up in New York, first in Far Rockaway, and then on the Upper West Side. With her husband, Irving, she raised four children in Fair Lawn, New Jersey, where she made a tremendous impact on the community. She was instrumental in building the Fair Lawn Co-op Nursery School, helped start the Fair Lawn Mental Health Center and was a charter member of the Fair Housing Committee, bringing integration to the town. She worked side by side with her late husband, Irving, for twenty-five years at Zarchin Fabrics. When she retired from Zarchin Fabrics, she was the designated tour guide of New York for all her children, grandchildren, cousins, nieces and nephews, and all of their friends. As a member of Central Synagogue, her grace and dignity were recognized by everyone, and her smile on Friday nights lit up the Temple like the Sabbath candles. Friends and relatives whose lives she touched, and know her as Blanche, Aunt Blanche, Gram, or Mrs. Zarchin please join those of us who knew her as Mom as we share in a celebration of her life, at Central Synagogue, East 55th and Lexington at 9:00am on Tuesday December 17th. Those who wish to remember Blanche may send donations to the Central Synagogue Mitzvah Fund.

ROSENTHAL--Dr. Alan, died peacefully on Friday, December 13, 2013, surrounded by loving family and friends. Dr. Rosenthal's passionate dedication to healing led to a remarkable career in neurosurgery, with a subspecialty in pediatric neurosurgery. After graduating from Yale University (1958) and the University of Virginia Medical School (1962), he pursued his fascination with the neurosciences to a residency at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital and the Children's Medical Center of Boston, where he served as Chief Resident and Teaching Fellow in Neurosurgery at Harvard Medical School in 1968. His remarkable ability to perform intricate surgical procedures and his intense interest in pediatrics took him to Long Island, where, as a founding member of Long Island Neurosurgical Associates, he developed the first pediatric neurosurgical practice in the region. He then left LINA to become Co-Director of Winthrop-University Hospital's Institute for Neurosciences and Chief of their Division of Neurosurgery, where he was a principal player in the development of Winthrop's Neuroscience Intensive Care Unit--the first of its kind on Long Island. Dr. Rosenthal was also instrumental in bringing the first CyberKnife, used to perform non-invasive robotic radio-surgery, to the NY metropolitan area. Additionally, Dr. Rosenthal was an Attending Neurosurgeon at several other Long Island hospitals, including Long Island Jewish Medical Center, North Shore University Hospital, St. Francis Hospital, Nassau County Medical Center and South Nassau Community Hospital. He was a contributing author to three major textbooks on pediatric neurosurgery, and his bibliography includes over 25 articles in peer reviewed journals. He has been an invited speaker at many international symposia. His greatest gift, however, found expression in the personal side of medicine. He remained in contact with many of his first patients, and followed their lives as they grew into adulthood. He continued to receive birthday and holiday greetings from several of them until he died. Dr. Rosenthal loved to play golf and tennis and to listen to baroque and classical music. He drove high performance sports cars and read volumes of history and international intrigue with equal relish. He delighted in a high-spirited conversation about history or politics. But his close family and friends remember him most often saying "What can I do to help?" Alan Rosenthal's memory survives as a blessing in the thousands of lives he touched and saved, but most especially in the hearts of his beloved and devoted wife Enid Feldman Rosenthal; daughters Amy Ilyse Rosenthal and Nina Michelle Rosenthal Fusillo; son-in-law Michael Fusillo; grandsons Nathaniel James and Benjamin Paul Fusillo; brothers-in-law Barry and Joel Feldman; and sisters-in-law Diane and Tina Feldman. Services will be held at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel in Boynton Beach, FL on Tuesday, December 17 at 1:45pm.

OSTROW--Seymour, Devoted stepfather of Karen, Jill and Kate. His generous heart will be with us always.

LESTER--Dr. Louis J.,one of New York's preeminent surgeons for over half a century, died peacefully on Saturday, December 14th in Jupiter, Florida. He was 98 years old. He is survived by his beloved wife of 70 years Sylvia (Ziebelman) of Philadelphia, two children, Dr. Robert Lester (Linda) of Reno, Nevada and Diane Barone of Jupiter, Florida. He is also survived by his five grandchildren; Benjamin Lester (Rebecca), Kelly Berlin (Raul), Courtney Berlin (Erin), Rachel Lester and Bryan Lester. Dr. Lester was a native of Toronto, Canada where he was valedictorian of his medical school class at University of Toronto Medical School. He served in the United States Army during World War II, spending two and a half years with a M.A.S.H. unit in China, Burma and India. He was the recipient of a Bronze Star and was released with a rank of Major. He trained under the auspices of Dr. Ralph Colp and Dr. John Garlock at Mount Sinai Hospital in New York, and proceeded to build a private surgical practice in Great Neck, New York that spanned more than 50 years. He was a founding surgeon of North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, New York where he eventually became President of the Medical Staff. He was a Professor of Surgery at Cornell Medical School and also served on the surgical staff of Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was an active participant in numerous philanthropic organizations that supported Judaism and the state of Israel. During the 1967 Israeli War, he volunteered his surgical services for three months at Poria Hospital in Tiberias, Israel. He was an avid golfer and former President of North Shore Country Club in Glen Head, New York. His practice in general surgery evolved into a focus on breast surgery during the last 25 years of his career. Thanks to his outstanding surgical skill and compassionate manner, he contributed to the health and well being of thousands of patients. His presence will be deeply missed by his loving family and the medical community. Funeral services will be held at Temple Beth-El in Great Neck, New York on Thursday, December 19th at 11am.

LEIBOWITZ--Harry, born in Brooklyn, NY, June 6, 1930. Died in Austin, Texas, December 6, 2013. Beloved husband of Helene (Wachtel). Loving father of Lori Roslawski (Bob) and Stuart Leibowitz (Linda). Adoring grandfather of Matthew and Emily Leibowitz. Lived in New York City until retiring in Austin five years ago. Enjoyed a career as a financial executive in real estate. Harry was loved and highly respected by all who knew him. He will be deeply missed.

HAMBRICK--Dr. George W. Jr.,Died at his home with his family by his side on Tuesday, December 10, 2013; six days after his 91st birthday. Dr. Hambrick, born on December 4, 1922 in Charlottesville, Virginia, was the son of a veterinarian and a nurse. He was preceded in death by his parents George Walter Hambrick, DVM and Anna McCallum Hambrick, and his sister, Anne Hambrick Uzmed. His mother's and father's families were descended from early settlers in Virginia. Dr. Hambrick was a Virginian by birth and graduated from Concord College in Athens, West Virginia. He received his MD degree from the University of Virginia School of Medicine and remained there for his first year of dermatological training. Following an internship at the University of Iowa Hospital, he trained in Dermatology at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and Duke University in North Carolina. From 1948 to 1950 he served in the United States Army in Georgia and Okinawa, Japan. Beginning in the early 1950's George launched an academic career, equaled by few in his field, in which he rose through the ranks at Columbia University, the University of Pennsylvania, and Johns Hopkins University, where he served as Professor and Chairman of Dermatology for nearly ten years, until 1976. He then directed the Department of Dermatology at the University of Cincinnati for five years before moving to Cornell University in New York, where he co-directed the Division of Dermatology for an additional 12 years, until 1993 and established Dermatology as full Department status. Dr. Hambrick was a Professor Emeritus at Cornell and Senior Lecturer at Columbia. In 1987, together with Rockefeller University's Martin Carter, MD, PhD and Herzog Foundation President Peter Bentley, Dr. Hambrick founded the American Skin Association to represent the interest of skin disease victims and their families. At the age of 85, Dr. Hambrick would leave his home in Charlottesville, drive to Richmond, Virginia and fly to New York City. There he would stay Monday through Thursday to fulfill his duties as President of the American Skin Association. The American Skin Association remains a singular voice dedicated to overcoming the most serious forms of skin cancer and disease through research and education. In 1993, the Weill Cornell Medical College honored him by establishing the George W. Hambrick, Jr. Professorship in Dermatology. Most recently The George W. Hambrick Jr., a MD leadership fund in Oncological Dermatology was initiated by the Johns Hopkins Department of Dermatology in recognition of Dr. Hambrick's great contributions to Johns Hopkins and to the field of Dermatology. This endowed professorship honored Dr. Hambrick's record of excellence in promoting healthy skin through skin cancer research and exemplary leadership in the field of Dermatology. Among his countless other accolades is the Dermatology Foundation's first Lifetime Career Educator Award for his service as a mentor, role model, and inspiration to students and residents. He served as president of both the Dermatology Foundation and the Society of Investigative Dermatology and, for 11 years, as a delegate to the American Medical Association. With more than 75 publications to his credit, he was an advisor to Skin & Allergy News and a member of the editorial board for the Journal of the American Academy of Dermatology. As an academic administrator, investigator, author and thoughtful leader, George influenced generations of dermatologists. Nothing, however, conveys his contributions as a formative teacher of young dermatologists more eloquently than the words of a former student. "I wish to convey the compassion he exemplified to his patients while also imparting his wealth of knowledge to the residents. He worked tirelessly to stress excellence and to make sure we were performing to the best of our abilities." In addition to Dr. Hambrick's professional credentials, his primary devotion was to his family and friends. Known affectionately as Dee Dee, his passion was nurturing relationships. As a visionary he took great pride in watching people grow, mentoring many throughout his long life. Dee Dee read constantly, his magnifying glass always in hand. He was an avid genealogist with an impressive memory for details, never forgetting a person or a name. Hours were spent researching his lineage, looking up Hambricks in phonebooks, leading to connections with newly found relatives, which became life-long kinships. History, opera, music, gardening, and travel were among his interests. He was also trained as a classical pianist. He has been called a gifted soul with a brilliant mind. What a wonderful life. He is survived by his niece, Anna "Terry" Bruce Columbus and her husband Marc and their children Jillian A. Columbus and Cole M. Columbus of Charlottesville, Virginia. The family would like to thank the caregivers of T&L Companions. We are grateful for the expert medical care from many University of Virginia Medical Center physicians including his primary care doctor, Dr. Diane Snustad. A special thank you goes out to his very dear friends, Howard and Abby Milstein of New York, recognizing them for their genuine support and steadfast commitment throughout their enduring friendship. A funeral service will be held at 11:00am Thursday, December 19, 2013 at Westminster Presbyterian Church in Charlottesville, VA with the Reverend Dr. Laura S. Sugg and the Reverend Dr. John G. McFayden of Philadelphia, PA officiating. Interment will follow at Monticello Memory Gardens. In lieu of flowers, if one wishes, memorial contributions may be made to the American Skin Association, 6 East 43rd Street, 28th Floor, New York, NY 10017.

HERCZ--Andre, survived by his wife Eve Zetlin, his devoted daughters Evelyn Paltrow, Theresa (Mark) Greene, Ilana (Dr. Jeffrey) Kessler and Kathryn (Edward) Lapidus; his adoring grandchildren Marlene (Christopher), Elysse (Nicholas), the late Keith, Rebekah (Adam), Tiffany (Evan), Jennifer (Jordan), Kimberly (Robert), Jordan (Dawn), Gianna (David), Veronica, Andrew (Jennifer), James (Jessica), Ian, Victoria (Evan), Jaime (David), Mark (Cari) and Gregg (Tara) and his 28 loving great-grandchildren, Sally, who we are forever grateful to. Chisholm--Corning, born July 18, 1914 in Cleveland, Ohio. Corning passed away peacefully on December 12th in Oberlin, Ohio. He is survived by two nieces, Adele Eells Pierce and Kate Halle Briggs.

GOLD--Bernard Ralph, died Peacefully at Home in New Rochelle at age 89. Beloved, dedicated husband for 59 years of Dina and beloved father of Billy and Bobby and grandfather of Michael, Brian, John, David, Liz, Tom and Danny. A cherished brother, father-in-law, uncle and friend. Bernard set a standard for kindness, ethics, compassion, love and humor. He had a good word to say about everyone and touched all he came into contact. He will be missed by all. He was a World War II Veteran and served his country in the Pacific with distinction. After the war he earned his CPA and rose to be the CFO and Executive Vice President of Polychrome and afterwards a commodities trader and seat owner on the NYMEX. He was a man of honor and distinction who set a wonderful example in everything he did. Private funeral services followed by Shiva on Monday, December 16 at his home, where Dina and he raised their family and lived for 53 years.

ZUCKERMAN--Abraham. The American Society for Yad Vashem mourns the passing of its Board member, Abraham Zuckerman. Mr. Zuckerman was a Supporter of the Valley of the Communities at Yad Vashem. Born and raised in Cracow, Poland, Mr. Zuckerman survived the war working in Oskar Schindler's factory. ZARCHIN--Blanche, We note with sorrow the passing of our member Blanche Zarchin and extend sincerest condolences to her bereaved family. Rabbi Peter J. Rubinstein and President David B. Edelson, Central Synagogue of New York City

ZARCHIN--Blanche, 91 years old, died last night, peacefully, in her sleep, in her own bed, in her own apartment, which was how she hoped it would be. She is survived by her children, Linda, Susan, Jill and Jim, their spouses, David, Cathy and Scott, her grandchildren and their spouses , Josh and Clare, Noah, Leah, Max and Jenna, and her sister, Harriet. The tender care and love she showed so many through her life was returned to her, especially in her last years. Blanche grew up in New York, first in Far Rockaway, and then on the Upper West Side. With her husband, Irving, she raised four children in Fair Lawn, New Jersey, where she made a tremendous impact on the community. She was instrumental in building the Fair Lawn Co-op Nursery School, helped start the Fair Lawn Mental Health Center and was a charter member of the Fair Housing Committee, bringing integration to the town. She worked side by side with her late husband, Irving, for twenty-five years at Zarchin Fabrics. When she retired from Zarchin Fabrics, she was the designated tour guide of New York for all her children, grandchildren, cousins, nieces and nephews, and all of their friends. As a member of Central Synagogue, her grace and dignity were recognized by everyone, and her smile on Friday nights lit up the Temple like the Sabbath candles. Friends and relatives whose lives she touched, and know her as Blanche, Aunt Blanche, Gram, or Mrs. Zarchin please join those of us who knew her as Mom as we share in a celebration of her life, at Central Synagogue, East 55th and Lexington at 9:00am on Tuesday December 17th. Those who wish to remember Blanche may send donations to the Central Synagogue Mitzvah Fund.

ROSENTHAL--Dr. Alan, Alan a man who both loved life and saved lives. He was a wonderful friend and extremely devoted to his family. You will be missed. Deepest condolences Enid, Nina and Amy. Diane and Marshall Felenstein

ROSENTHAL--Alan, we are very saddened by the loss of our dear friend. Alan was a neurosurgeon par excellence. He not only saved the lives of many, but also enabled them to resume normal lives. We are forever grateful. Our sympathy to his loved and loving Enid and the entire family. Malka and Paul Herman

ROSENTHAL--Dr. Alan, died peacefully on Friday, December 13, 2013, surrounded by loving family and friends. Dr. Rosenthal's passionate dedication to healing led to a remarkable career in neurosurgery, with a subspecialty in pediatric neurosurgery. After graduating from Yale University (1958) and the University of Virginia Medical School (1962), he pursued his fascination with the neurosciences to a residency at Peter Bent Brigham Hospital and the Children's Medical Center of Boston, where he served as Chief Resident and Teaching Fellow in Neurosurgery at Harvard Medical School in 1968. His remarkable ability to perform intricate surgical procedures and his intense interest in pediatrics took him to Long Island, where, as a founding member of Long Island Neurosurgical Associates, he developed the first pediatric neurosurgical practice in the region. He then left LINA to become Co-Director of Winthrop-University Hospital's Institute for Neurosciences and Chief of their Division of Neurosurgery, where he was a principal player in the development of Winthrop's Neuroscience Intensive Care Unit--the first of its kind on Long Island. Dr. Rosenthal was also instrumental in bringing the first CyberKnife, used to perform non-invasive robotic radio-surgery, to the NY metropolitan area. Additionally, Dr. Rosenthal was an Attending Neurosurgeon at several other Long Island hospitals, including Long Island Jewish Medical Center, North Shore University Hospital, St. Francis Hospital, Nassau County Medical Center and South Nassau Community Hospital. He was a contributing author to three major textbooks on pediatric neurosurgery, and his bibliography includes over 25 articles in peer reviewed journals. He has been an invited speaker at many international symposia. His greatest gift, however, found expression in the personal side of medicine. He remained in contact with many of his first patients, and followed their lives as they grew into adulthood. He continued to receive birthday and holiday greetings from several of them until he died. Dr. Rosenthal loved to play golf and tennis and to listen to baroque and classical music. He drove high performance sports cars and read volumes of history and international intrigue with equal relish. He delighted in a high-spirited conversation about history or politics. But his close family and friends remember him most often saying "What can I do to help?" Alan Rosenthal's memory survives as a blessing in the thousands of lives he touched and saved, but most especially in the hearts of his beloved and devoted wife Enid Feldman Rosenthal; daughters Amy Ilyse Rosenthal and Nina Michelle Rosenthal Fusillo; son-in-law Michael Fusillo; grandsons Nathaniel James and Benjamin Paul Fusillo; brothers-in-law Barry and Joel Feldman; and sisters-in-law Diane and Tina Feldman. Services will be held at Beth Israel Memorial Chapel in Boynton Beach, FL on Tuesday, December 17 at 1:45pm.

LESTER--Louis MD, Physicians and staff of North Shore University Hospital, and trustees of the North Shore-LIJ Health System mourn this weekend's passing of Louis Lester, MD, who would have turned age 99 on January 1. The husband of North Shore-LIJ life trustee Sylvia Lester, Dr. Lester was one of North Shore's founding surgeons when the hospital opened in 1953, along with the late Arnold Fenton, MD. He was president of the hospital's Medical Staff Society in 1964 and 1965. While he was a general surgeon, he specialized in breast surgery during the last half of his career. During World War II, he served as an Army surgeon in MASH units in China, Burma and India, achieving the rank of major. Well-regarded for his compassionate care, he retired in 1988 after practicing for more than 50 years. Married for more than 70 years, Dr. and Mrs. Lester have been long-time generous supporters of the hospital and the North Shore-LIJ Health System. Among their many causes, the Lesters donated funds to establish a meditation room in the hospital. North Shore University Hospital named the Sylvia M. Lester Patient and Family Relations Dept. in her honor in 2012. We extend our sincere condolences to the entire Lester family. Susan Somerville Executive Director, North Shore University Hospital Richard Goldstein, Chair Michael Dowling, Pres. & CEO North Shore-LIJ Health System

LEET--Arabella Iris Catherine, a pediatric orthopedic surgeon and Chief of Staff at the Shriners Hospitals for Children in Honolulu, died on December 15, 2013 after a sudden illness. Dr. Leet was born in 1965 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania. She attended the Winsor School in Boston, and graduated from Harvard College summa cum laude with a B.A. in Anthropology. She received her M.D. from the Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons. She came to the Shriners Hospital in March 2012 after ten years at Johns Hopkins University, where she was Associate Professor and Director of the Orthopedic Center for Children with Cerebral Palsy at the Kennedy Krieger Institute. She was a highly accomplished physician who was known for her compassion for her young patients and their families. She was also a distinguished research scientist who conducted and published extensive research on cerebral palsy, osteogenesis imperfecta and fibrous dysplasia. Dr. Leet was the devoted mother of Kenneth Francis Nyman and cherished wife of Steven Nyman, both of Honolulu. She is also survived by her father, Kenneth Leet, of Honolulu and her brother, Kenneth Leet of London and Chicago. Contributions in her memory may be made to "Friends of Shriners Honolulu", c/o 1310 Punahou Street, Honolulu, HI 96826.

LEBER--Arthur MD, 95, passed away December 15, 2013. He was a Holocaust survivor, the last of his family's generation. He was a devoted husband of 54 years to late wife Lucia. An outstanding Ob-Gyn physician and consummate scholar, he impressed the value of education upon his family. He will be missed by son Mark, daughter-in-law Vivian, grandchildren Jessica, Stephanie, and Rebecca, grandson-in-law Jared, niece Bernice and nephew George.

JASON--Shirley, on December 15th. Beloved wife of the late Mel Jason. Survived by her devoted daughters Ellen Brady (Terry), Jill Wainer (Eric), Laurie Goldstein (Richard) and her loving grandchildren Lindsay (Ryan), Michael, Jaclyn and Jordan. Deeply loved, always remembered.
JACOBS--Martin, (The Splendid Peasant), on December 11, 2013. Beloved husband of Kitty, devoted father of Peter and Claudia, dear grandfather of Emily Jacobs-Palmer.

HOOK--Howard J.,Jr. born Pittsburgh July 7, 1925, son of Howard J. and Sarah Easton Hook, co-founder of the Metropolitan Opera National Council Auditions, died peacefully December 7, leaving his brother Donald of Pittsburgh and his faithful and loving companion Michael Denney. His was an extraordinary life well lived. Ashes to the Chapel of the Resurrection, St. Thomas Episcopal Church.

HAMBRICK--George W.,Jr., M.D., Weill Cornell Medical College and New York-Presbyterian Hospital mourn the passing of our colleague and friend, Dr. George W. Hambrick, Jr. A preeminent dermatologist, Dr. Hambrick leaves a legacy of medical education, clinical service and philanthropy. Dr. Hambrick led the dermatology program at Weill Cornell Medical College and NewYork-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell from 1981 to 1993 before becoming professor emeritus in 1995. Committed to supporting fellow dermatologists, he was the force behind establishing an endowed professorship at Weill Cornell. He was also president and founder of the American Skin Association. We will greatly miss Dr. Hambrick's dedication and energy. Our deepest condolences to his family and colleagues. Dr. Laurie H. Glimcher, Dean, Weill Cornell Medical College Dr. Steven J. Corwin, CEO, NY-Presbyterian Hospital Dr. Richard Granstein, Chairman of Dermatology, Dermatologist-in-Chief and the George W. Hambrick, Jr. Professor of Dermatology, NY-Presbyterian/Weill Cornell

GOLD--Bernard Ralph, died Peacefully at Home in New Rochelle at age 89. Beloved, dedicated husband for 59 years of Dina and beloved father of Billy and Bobby and grandfather of Michael, Brian, John, David, Liz, Tom and Danny. A cherished brother, father-in-law, uncle and friend. Bernard set a standard for kindness, ethics, compassion, love and humor. He had a good word to say about everyone and touched all he came into contact. He will be missed by all. He was a World War II Veteran and served his country in the Pacific with distinction. After the war he earned his CPA and rose to be the CFO and Executive Vice President of Polychrome and afterwards a commodities trader and seat owner on the NYMEX. He was a man of honor and distinction who set a wonderful example in everything he did. Private funeral services followed by Shiva on Monday, December 16 at his home, where Dina and he raised their family and lived for 53 years.

GINGOLD--Allan. We are deeply saddened by the untimely passing of our dear cousin Allan. Heartfelt condolences to his wife Dawn, children Ben and Alex, mother Arlene, and sisters Wendy and Debbie. Stephen, Samantha, David and Jason.

GINGOLD--Allan, 58, passed away while surrounded by his loved ones on December 15, 2013 following a stoic battle with an unforgiving illness. A kind and fine gentleman, he was a devoted husband of Dawn Gingold, loving father of Ben, 9, and Alex, 7. Cherished son of Arlene and Lenny Russin and the late Harold Gingold. Dear brother of Debbie Mallin-Adelman and Steven Adelman and Wendy Lichtenberg-Kaplan and Gary Kaplan. Beloved in-law, uncle, cousin, nephew and friend. He will remain in our hearts and minds always. Debbie, Wendy and Mom

GINGOLD--Allan J.,58, of East Rockaway, NY passed away on December 15, 2013. Beloved husband of ten years to Dawn Gingold. Loving father of Ben and Alex. Cherished son of Arlene and Leonard Russin and son of the late Harold Gingold. Dear brother of Wendy (Gary) Kaplan and Debbie (Steven) Adelman. Allan was a loving, gentle and kind father and husband; this world will miss him forever. Funeral services will be held at Boulevard-Riverside Chapels, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY on Tuesday, December 17, 2013 commencing at 10am with interment to immediately follow at the Beth Moses Cemetery in Pinelawn, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made in Allan's name to: Donate Life America. (www.Donatelife.net)

EYAL--Orna, 60, of Englewood, New Jersey, died peacefully on Sunday, December 15, 2013 at Villa Marie Claire Hospice after a valiant 16 year battle with cancer. She was surrounded by her daughter, Tal, and friend and confidant of 40 years, Sylvia Taubman. A sabra, she emigrated to the United States where she attended high school and continued her studies at NYU. She returned to Israel where she owned and operated a highly successful travel business, and taught both high school and adult education in the Occupied Territories; she returned to the US with her children and went on to become an honored and highly respected colleague and friend at Herbert H. Lehman High School in the Bronx, New York where she taught United States history, and served as Case Manager for students with disabilities, her special love. Fiercely proud of both her native land and her adopted country, her desire to integrate both cultures led her to become involved in and maintain Lehman's participation in the American Israel Friendship League, an organization that teaches tolerance and compromise, and includes visits to Israeli cultural sites in New York City and Washington, D.C. She was most proud of the highlight of the program, a three week cultural tour of Israel for a small group of inner city high school students. Ms. Eyal will be sorely missed by a large circle of international friends and colleagues, as well as by her Lehman High School family. She is survived by two sisters, Haia Nathan and Dafna Schwartz, daughter Tal, and son Jonathan. Burial is Tuesday, December 17, 2013 at 11am at Louis Suburban Funeral Home in Fair Lawn, NJ, followed by interment at Riverside Cemetery in Saddle Brook, NJ. Memorial contributions may be made to St. Barnabas Cancer Center in Livingston, NJ.
DUFFY--Edward. The New York Times records with deep sorrow the passing of Edward Duffy, associated with The New York Times from October 8, 1977 until retiring on January 1, 1993.

CAVANAGH--Dr. James J. M.D.,on December 14, 2013. Beloved husband of Anne E. (nee O'Shea). Loving father of Justin, Cornelia and Anastasia Coleman. Cherished grandfather of Julia and Sean Cavanagh; Campbell, Avery and Brooke Coleman. Graduate of Regis High School, Fordham University and New York Medical College. Services entrusted to the Macken Mortuary 3930 Long Bench Rd., Island Park, NY. Family will receive friends Tuesday 2:00-4:00pm and 7:00-9:00pm. Mass of Christian Burial, Wednesday 10:30am at Our Lady of the Miraculous Medal Church, Point Lookout, NY. Interment Holy Rood Cemetery. Donations to the Wounded Warrior Fund would be appreciated.

BUSTI--Dennis A.,July 21, 1942- December 14, 2013. Long time Insurance Leader passed away quietly Saturday at his home in Eastchester. Dennis had been a leading Executive in the Property and Casualty Industry throughout the 1980's and 90's. Dennis began his career as an underwriter in 1964 with Empire Mutual. He moved to AIG in 1970 where he ultimately became President of American Home Assurance Co. the largest of AIG's domestic companies. In 1987 after a brief stint with Berkshire Hathaway, Dennis was hired as President and CEO of Reliance National Insurance Co. Dennis remained as CEO for 13 years building Reliance National from a company with two employees and no premium to a company of 1500 employees and over four billion in premium. Along the way, Dennis was the recipient of several Industry awards. Including, United Jewish Appeals- Insurance Man of the Year. College of Insurance- Man of the year, and Chinese Insurance Industry association, Insurance Leader of the year. Dennis, will always be remembered for his winning smile and kindness to all those he met. He was not only a friend but a mentor to all those who worked with him or for him. Dennis is survived by his wife of 46 years Mary, His Son Jason, Daughter Joanna, also by his two grandchildren, Matthew and Chelsea. Dennis is also survived by his brothers Louis and Edward. He was preceded in death by his brother Andrew and his parents. Visitation will take place at the Westchester Funeral Home, 190 Main St. Eastchester, NY on Tuesday, December 17, 2013 from 2-4pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial at Saints Peter and Paul Church, Mount Vernon, NY, with entombment to follow at Ferncliff Mausoleum, Hartsdale, NY. In lieu of flowers, friends who wish may donate in Dennis's memory to The Bowery Mission, 227 Bowery, New York, NY 10002, (212) 674-3456, www.bowery.org. To sign our online guest-book, please visit www.westchesterfuneralhome.com.

BRILOFF--Abraham. Our hearts break. No more Friday phone calls. He was a blessing, an inspiration to all. Profound condolences to Abe's extraordinary family and caregivers. Now he sees the colors of the rainbow and the flowers in the garden that he and Edith sowed. Love, The Dreifus Family
BODENSTEIN--Diane L.,54, of NYC, passed away December 9. Services entrusted Star of David Cemetery of the Palm Beaches, (561) 627-2277

ALBERT--Gerald. 96, passed away on December 12, 2013, due to complications from recent medical issues. His wife, Norma, is deceased. He is survived by his two children, Laurie and Jay, two granddaughters, and one great-granddaughter. He led a life full of great compassion, intellectual curiosity, interesting challenges, and humor. He was a graduate of City College, and was editor of The Mercury. He went on to write a popular syndicated comic in the 1940's, become the educational films public relations director at Universal Pictures, and run a family business with his father. Later in life, he received a doctorate in psychology from Columbia University. He then practiced individual and family therapy, taught psychology at Long Island University, directed the counseling center at C.W. Post, was a psychologist and clinical director of Long Island Consultation Center, wrote for various professional journals, and authored a book entitled, No Fault Living. He sang semi-professionally and wrote several ballads, was an avid reader as well as a sports enthusiast, and enjoyed contributing to letters to the editor columns. A memorial service will be held at his assisted living home in Forest Hills on December 18, 2013. He will be greatly missed by family, friends, clients, and colleagues.

Addison of New York and Matthew D. Addison of Dallas. Grandmother of Anabelle H. Addison and Carolina Gillis Addison of New York. At her request, funeral and Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers, contributions to the Parrish Art Museum, 279 Montauk Highway, Water Mill, NY 11976 or East End Hospice, PO Box 1048, Westhampton Beach, NY 11978 would be appreciated.

WOLFF--Linda, an early and ardent feminist, who achieved success in several contiguous careers in law, politics, catering, and real estate, died Sunday, December 15, 2013 from complications resulting from a stroke. She was 66. Linda is survived by her husband, John Romanow, a Connecticut labor arbitrator; daughter, Elissa Goldstone; stepson, Daniel Romanow; and brother, Ivan Wolff. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, December 19, 2013 at 2pm at The Brooklyn Heights Synagogue in Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Brooklyn Heights Synagogue or to the Connecticut Hospice. Linda was a great and generous wife, mother, sister, and friend, who will be dearly missed.

VAN NUYS--Peter, 74, a 23 year resident of Bedford, NY died at home on December 13, 2013. Peter was born June 19, 1939 in New York City. He was a graduate of Harvard Law School and was an attorney with the firm of Becker, Glynn, Muffly, Chassin and Hosinski LLP. He will be remembered for his love of life, sense of humor and his devotion to his family and others. The Memorial Service will be held on Sunday, December 22, 2013 at 2pm at the Bedford Presbyterian Church. Memorial contributions may be made to: www.disabledandalone.org

STONE--Irving, 90, died peacefully at home on December 16, 2013. He was predeceased by his wife Clara and son Daniel. He is survived by his son Philip (Katie Green) of Princeton, MA and daughter Louise (Jos Ruks) of Portland, ME. Born in New York, he graduated from Townsend Harris High School, served in the United Staes Navy in the Pacific during WWll. He received his PhD from Columbia University and taught Economics at Baruch College (CUNY) until retiring at age 79. He was a voracious reader and music lover, from jazz to classical. He will be sadly missed by many lifelong friends, extended family and loving caregivers. A memorial service will be held Thursday, December 19 at 11am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (91st Street). Donations may be made in his memory to The Fortune Society or the Riverside Park Fund.

SIEGEL--Irving. We are heartbroken to lose our loving grandfather who taught us many life lessons about hard work and the importance of family. He enjoyed all that life had to offer and passed that joy along to his grandchildren. He will remain forever in our hearts and will be greatly missed. Love, Jared, Denise, Ali, Steven, Drew, Jacob, Carly, Isabel, Amelia and Carter

Manno and daughter-in-law Christine Burke Scott. She is the loving grandmother of Peter Scott Manno and his wife Jane, Laura Amelia Manno, Gillian Catherine Hanna, Kieran David Hanna, Emily Abigale Scott, Ian Robert Scott and Elizabeth Jane Scott. SCHACHTER--Justine Ranson, of Levittown, NY, died on December 17, 2013, 1 day shy of her 86th birthday. Beloved wife of the late Scott Schachter for 51 years. Cherished mother of Linda Wright, the late Barbara Costa, Peter Schachter, and David Schachter. Treasured mother-in-law of Robert Wright, Antonia Schachter, and Scott Hunt. Adored grandmother of Jeffrey and Bryan Wright, and Nicholas and Jonathan Schachter. Dearest sister of Ellen Adams. Loving friend to many. Justine was a talented artist who delighted in traveling the world with her husband and volunteering her time and talents to progressive social causes. Memorial service on Sunday, January 5 at 11am at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, L.I.

PALADINI--Albert Jr.,died on December 12, 2013 at Holy Cross Hospital in Silver Spring, Maryland. He was born to the late Albert Sr. and Ann Paladini in Manhattan in 1935 and grew up on the Lower East Side where he experienced life as only someone from New York City in the 40s and 50s could. He graduated from Brooklyn Tech and Brooklyn College before going on to a fulfilling career as a physicist, an engineer, a mathematician and finally as a senior patent examiner. During that time he also received his Master's Degree from Syracuse University, performed in amateur theater and spent countless hours conversing with the many cats he shared his life with. Al will be remembered for his kindness, his love of animals, his impersonations of Richard Burton, Stan Laurel, Danny Kaye and others, and for his wonderful and quirky sense of humor. We will never watch a Marx Brothers movie or an episode of Seinfeld again without hearing his laugh. He will be missed. Al is survived by his loving wife, Marylynn Paladini; his son, Marc Paladini and his brother, William Paladini. A memorial service will be held at Cunningham Turch Funeral Home, 811 Cameron St., Alexandria VA 22314 on Wednesday, December 18, 2013 at 1:00pm. Interment will be private. In lieu of flowers donations may be made in memory of Albert to: Best Friends Animals Society at www.bestfriends.org then click "donate today."

MOLDENHAUER--Charles A. Charles ("Chuck") A. Moldenhauer, age 69, passed away unexpectedly at his home in NYC on December 13, 2013. Chuck's love and devotion for his children and fiancee had no bounds. Born in Augusta, WI, he passed away at the pinnacle of his life: Enjoying runs in Central Park; strolls in Spring Lake with their Westie, Scooter; walking his daughter down-the-aisle; and visiting his son and grandchildren in D.C. A Columbia M.B.A. alumnus and entrepreneur who founded and ran various businesses, Chuck was passionate about marketing, whether through brand management or executive coaching. Chuck is survived by his sister, Jacquie; his children, Brooke Mayne and Chip Moldenhauer; grandchildren, Grady and Hadley Moldenhauer; fiancee, Trisha Scudder; and former wife, Liz, all of whom will strive to live a life as full and optimistic as he did. A Mass will be celebrated at 11am on December 21st at Holy Trinity Church, 213 W. 82nd St. Contributions, Central Park Conservancy's Adopt-a-Bench Program in Memory of Charles.

LEBER--Arthur MD, 95, passed away December 15, 2013. He was a Holocaust survivor, the last of his family's generation. He was a devoted husband of 54 years to late wife Lucia. An outstanding Ob-Gyn physician and consummate scholar, he impressed the value of education upon his family. He will be missed by son Mark, daughter-in-law Vivian, grandchildren Jessica, Stephanie, and Rebecca, grandson-in-law Jared, niece Bernice and nephew George.

MARKS--Stanley H.,93, died peacefully at home on December 15th. Loving husband of Ruth for 69 years, devoted father of Andrea and the late Marjorie. Brother of the late Clarence and Jack Marks. Father-in-law of David Warmflash and Allen Carney, brother-in-law of Bernice and Arnold Conn, Judy Gurlitz and the late Eugene. Stanley adored his grandchildren, Gillian and Jordana Warmflash, Jacob and Caitlin Carney. Adoring and adored by his caretakers, Myrtle, Janet and Angel. He was overjoyed by the simple things in life, especially a great parking spot. His love and warmth will be greatly missed. Grave- side memorial Wednesday, December 18, Montefiore Cemetery, Springfield, LI, at 1pm. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to: the Mt. Sinai Visiting Doctors Program.

LANG--Enid, December 7, 2013, age 88 years, of Mequon, WI. Beloved wife of the late Mark L. Lang. Dear mother of Jill (Charles) Jacobs, Buffalo, NY, Fredrica (Steven) Spector, River Hills, WI and Jonathan Lang, Winchester, MA. Loving Grandmother of Eliza (Brian Fiore) Jacobs, Lauren Jacobs, Caroline Jacobs, Adam (Ilana) Spector, Andrew Spector, Robert Spector, Hunter Lang, Sara Lang and Emily Lang and great-grandmother of Leyton Fiore. Interment was held in Milwaukee, WI. Memorials to the cancer charity of your choice.

HUGHES--Mike, 65, president and creative chief of The Martin Agency, Richmond, VA passed away at home on Sunday, December 15, 2013. The Board of Directors of The One Club and all its members mourn the loss of a true gentleman who taught us the importance of finding joy in life and work. As a former board member of The One Club, Mike was a stalwart for recognizing creative excellence. He originated the idea for the One Club publication, Best of the Decade 1980-1990, which included his introduction. Mike was the ultimate storyteller and he truly valued work that was entertaining, honest and intelligent. But most of all, he valued his family, friends and the people he worked with. Mike was inducted into the Creative Hall of Fame in 2010. He was a giant in the industry and continued to be an inspiration for many of his peers. Our thoughts are with Ginny, Jason and his family, and all his colleagues, past and present at The Martin Agency.
HANO--Linda Swann. Born 1936, Canton, OH, of NYC passed December 16. Survived by husband Peter Hano, sons Gregg (Jill) and Randy (Margaret) and four grandchildren. RIP Mom.

HAMBRICK--Dr. George W. Jr. December 4, 1922 December 10, 2013. We honor the life of George W. Hambrick, Jr., MD, a man who devoted his life to helping other people. A giant in the field of medicine, he was the father of the modern field of dermatology. A superb clinician and prolific researcher, he was able to help millions of people through the doctors he trained and mentored, the medical breakthroughs he pioneered, and the philosophy by which he lived. He was a devoted public health advocate and spent much of the second half of his life using his medical knowledge to serve people at free clinics. In 1987, drawing on a loyal following of patients and his considerable administrative skills, Dr. Hambrick established American Skin Association (ASA), a lay organization for educating the public, building bridges with the dermatology community, and raising funds to support dermatology research. As Founder and the first President of ASA, he nurtured the development of a far reaching network which, along with its affiliates, has contributed tens of millions of dollars in recent years to fund the work of both young and established investigators while raising the level of public awareness about skin disorders. Retirement was not a part of his professional lexicon; through his ninth decade, Dr. Hambrick was still teaching, caring for patients, and playing an active and defining the role in ASA. Dr. Hambrick tirelessly devoted his professional life to the advancement of cutaneous medicine both at the bedside and as a scientific discipline. He served with great distinction as the Chair of three Departments of Dermatology: Johns Hopkins University, University of Cincinnati, and Cornell University. An enduring legacy of Dr. Hambrick's chairmanships was the evolution to full departmental status of the Divisions of Dermatology at Johns Hopkins and at Cornell. Dr. Hambrick was an influential leader in the profession, serving as Trustee and President of the Dermatology Foundation, as a member of the Board of Directors of both the Association of Professors of Dermatology and the American Academy of Dermatology, and member of the House of Delegates of the American Medical Association, representing the Society for Investigative Dermatology for many years. At the Society for Investigative Dermatology, Dr. Hambrick served in virtually all official capacities, including Vice President and President, as well as Secretary-Treasurer. He has held visiting lectureships and professorships at many institutions in the United States and around the world, and he is first or co-author of 75 publications. A graduate of Concord College (BS, magna cum laude, 1944) and the University of Virginia (MD, Alpha Omega Alpha, 1946), Dr. Hambrick pursued his dermatology residency training at the University of Virginia Hospitals and Columbia-Presbyterian Hospital. He served in the United States Army Medical Corps stationed in Okinawa, Japan (1948-50). With the completion of a research fellowship at Duke University Medical Center, he taught at Duke, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, and the University of Pennsylvania. After positions a the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine and the University of Cincinnati Medical Center, with the encouragement of his former student and long-time colleague and friend, the late D. Martin Carter, he became Professor and Co-Head of the Division of Dermatology at the Cornell University Medical College in New York City and then Emeritus Professor of Dermatology at Weill Cornell. The George W. Hambrick, Jr. Professorship of Dermatology was established in 1993. The Chairman of the Weill Cornell Medical College Department of Dermatology occupies the George W. Hambrick Chair. Dr. Hambrick was an energetic and elegant gentleman. He was a proud son of Virginia who honored the traditions of his forbearers who first settled in the colony of Virginia in the early 17th century. He was devoted to the memory of Thomas Jefferson and although his medical career took him to many other places, George Hambrick remained throughout a leading citizen of Charlottesville. After 70 years of dedication to medical practice and education, Dr. Hambrick stands out as a champion of excellence in patient care, teaching, scholarship and advocacy for dermatology whose career perfectly reflects the highest ideals of the medical profession. Beyond a prodigious commitment to training generations of dermatologists and promoting scientific excellence in dermatology, he was always first and foremost a humane and compassionate physician. The entire Board and staff of American Skin Association and all those who had the good fortune to be touched by his genius and his generosity of spirit grieve for his loss. He will be sorely missed. Howard P. Milstein Chairman American Skin Association

GOLDMAN--Samuel Seymour, passed away on December 16, 2013. Born in Brooklyn, New York in 1929 he died soon after his beloved wife Shirley of 67 years. He is survived by his children Elaine, Donna, Robert and Lori, grandchildren Allison, Avi, Amanda, Harrison, Elizabeth, Bryan and Dina, and great- granddaughter Samantha. DUBIN--Frieda, 84, passed on December 16. Beloved mother of Elyse and Marc (Judy), grandmother of Joshua and Jared. Her loving, generous, and youthful spirit will always remain in our hearts. The family deeply mourns the loss of our dear Fredi.

BRILOFF--Abraham J. The City University of New York mourns the passing of Abraham J. Briloff, Ph.D, City College/Baruch College alumnus, who joined the Baruch College accounting faculty in 1944. He was named Emanuel Saxe Distinguished Professor of Accountancy in 1976, a title he held until his death. He served as a trustee of the Baruch College Fund from 1969 to 1974. Deeply concerned about the integrity of the accounting profession, he was the author of four influential books and dozens of important articles for Barron's Magazine and accounting journals. We offer our deepest condolences to his daughters Lenore Briloff and Alice Ebenstein, and a granddaughter. Benno Schmidt, Chairman, Board of Trustees William P. Kelly Interim Chancellor

WILLNER--Alvin. Greatly beloved. You are remembered with love. Jane (Harold), Jay (Jeanne), Stella.
