ALGRANT--Roland. December 19, 2007 In loving memory of Roland Algrant, a good and gentle man.

WALTON--Samuel. Herzfeld & Rubin, PC joins in grieving the loss of a truly iconic figure. First and foremost, a caring husband to his beloved, now deceased, Jean, he was a wise and totally supporting father to his daughters, Carolyn, Susan and Janice, his son, Stuart, and his grandchildren and great- grandchildren. He was the ultimate exemplar of responsibility in community, religious and philanthropic activities. Sam was meticulous and highly respected in his seventy years of business dealings as an enterprising builder. As an operator of real estate properties, his were quality units. He demanded and received the highest order of maintenance. He extended fairness to all and expected fairness from all in his dealings with the lowest level employee to the most imposing banking institution. He was a wonderful friend whose legacy creates a high bar in the field of felicitous personal and business relationships. Herbert Rubin President

WALTON--Samuel, to the most wonderful grandfather. Our lives will never be the same without you. You inspired us with your strength, wisdom, and outstanding work ethic. You instilled in all of us the importance of hard work, commitment to truth, generosity and the love of family. We will love you and will miss you forever. You will live on in each of us. Your loving grandchildren and great-grandchildren

WALTON--Samuel, the employees of Samuel Walton mourn this enormous loss. Mr. Walton was a dynamic Long Island developer for over 60 years. We will always remember your honesty, wisdom, strength, fairness, and hard work. You will be deeply missed by all of us.

WALTON--Samuel, we are heartbroken by the loss of our extraordinary father, grandfather and great-grandfather. Dearly beloved husband of the late Jean Walton. Cherished and devoted father of Carolyn and Stanley Fried, Susan and Steven Tomback, Janice and Robert Genser, and Diane and Stuart Walton. Treasured, wonderful grandfather of Robin Fried, Kristin and Andrew Fried, Jessica Tomback and Peter Fraize, Dayna Morris and David Tomback, Alyssa Tomback, Lori and Stu Burkhoff, Lee Genser, and Christina and Josh Walton. Proud great-grandfather of Leo, Owen, Juliet and Dylan. Dearest and loving brother of the late Mike Wolsky. He led his life with integrity, generosity, and the importance of family. Services Thursday, December 19 11:15am, Riverside Nassau North Chapel Great Neck, NY. Any contributions will be appreciated to the Jean Walton Lymphoma and Myeloma Research Fund at the Feinstein Institute at North Shore Hospital or Temple Israel of Great Neck.

STONE--Irving, 90, died peacefully at home on December 16, 2013. He was predeceased by his wife Clara and son Daniel. He is survived by his son Philip (Katie Green) of Princeton, MA and daughter Louise (Jos Ruks) of Portland, ME. Born in New York, he graduated from Townsend Harris High School, served in the United Staes Navy in the Pacific during WWll. He received his PhD from Columbia University and taught Economics at Baruch College (CUNY) until retiring at age 79. He was a voracious reader and music lover, from jazz to classical. He will be sadly missed by many lifelong friends, extended family and loving caregivers. A memorial service will be held Thursday, December 19 at 11am at Plaza Jewish Community Chapel, 630 Amsterdam Avenue (91st Street). Donations may be made in his memory to The Fortune Society or the Riverside Park Fund.

STECHLER--Gerald, PhD, of Lexington, MA on Wednesday, December 18, 2013. For 33 years, he was the beloved husband of Antonia "Toni" (Halton) Stechler. Loving father of Amy Stechler of Walpole, NH and Nancy Stechler Gawle of Sharon, MA. Adored grandfather of Sarah Burns, Lilly Burns, Julia Stechler Gawle and Adam Stechler Gawle and great-grandfather of Lyla. Dear brother of Mildred Wolkow of New York, NY. Services at Temple Emunah, 9 Piper Rd., Lexington, MA 02421 on Friday, December 20 at 12noon. Burial in the Beit Olam East Cemetery, 42 Concord Rd., Wayland, MA. Memorial observance his late residence with details to follow. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to Temple Emunah.

SIEGEL--Irving, 82, of Fisher Island, Florida and New York, New York, died on December 17, 2013, peacefully, with his devoted and loving family by his side. He is survived by his wife Diane, his children and their spouses, Kenneth and Andrea Siegel, Terri and Jed Kaminetsky, Stuart and Jill Siegel, David Steinberg, Jonathan and Rachel Steinberg, and his ten grandchildren: Jared, Denise, Alexandra, Steven, Drew, Jacob, Carly, Isabel, Amelia and Carter.

NEUWIRTH--Robert S.,80, pioneer in reproductive health, passed away peacefully on December 17th. Born in Floral Park, Long Island, he graduated from Yale College magna cum laude ('55) and Yale School of Medicine ('58). He trained at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and served as Chairman of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at St. Luke's Roosevelt from 1971 to 1991, and as the first Babcock Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology at the College of Physicans and Surgeons of Columbia University from 1977 to 2000. He was known for having introduced laparascopy and hysteroscopy to the United States in the late 1960s, and as the inventor of balloon endometrial ablation, a technique to control menorrhagia and avoid hysterectomy, one of many innovative medical techniques he patented. His family will most remember him for his caring love, generosity and guidance. He is survived by five children Susan, Jessica, Laura (Adam), Michael (Deena) and Alexander (Madalyn), his former wife Gloria, and six grandchildren - Madelyn, Ethan, James, Sarah, Bennett and Juliette. A memorial service will be held December 20 at 10am at Campbell Funeral Chapel, NYC.

SCOTT--Marie Dilliard, of Garden City, Long Island, NY on December 17, 2013. She was predeceased by her husband of 38 years, John Julian Scott, MD. She is survived by her loving children: Jane Dilliard Scott of Bethesda, MD; Catherine Scott Manno of Huntingdon Valley, PA; Margaret Scott Hanna of Avondale, PA; a son Andrew Reginald Scott of Garden City; a son-in-law Bruno V. Manno and daughter-in-law Christine Burke Scott. She is the loving grandmother of Peter Scott Manno and his wife Jane, Laura Amelia Manno, Gillian Catherine Hanna, Kieran David Hanna, Emily Abigale Scott, Ian Robert Scott and Elizabeth Jane Scott. Friends may call at Fairchild Funeral Home in Garden City on Thursday, December 19, from 3-5pm and 7-9pm. A funeral service will be held at the Cathedral of the Incarnation, Garden City on Friday, December 20 at 10am.

NATIELLO--Gloria JoAnn, passed away on Tuesday, December 17, 2013 after a long illness; with her were her adored husband Anthony and her son AnthonyCraig. She also leaves behind Sweetie, Noel, and Kate. Visitation will take place at the Edwin L. Bennett Funeral Homes 824 Scarsdale Ave, Scarsdale NY 10583 from 2-4pm on Thursday December 19, 2013. A funeral Mass will be held Friday, December 20, 2013 at Sacred Heart Church Hartsdale 11am. Entombment will follow immediately at Ferncliff Cemetery.

MURPHY--John "Jack" J.,passed away Tuesday, December 17. Born in Brooklyn, NY. Husband of Ursula; son of Josephine and Christopher; brother of Rosemary and Patty; uncle to PJ, Matthew, Mary, Joseph, and Christina. Attended St. Francis Prep in Brooklyn. Served as quartermaster in US Navy aboard the destroyer Melvyn R. Norman. Graduated from NYU under the G.I. Bill. Jack had a wide ranging career in broadcasting as a successful sales and management executive. Jack had a special gift for friendship and will be missed by his friends and family in New York and Ireland. Jack knew everyone - barmen, bishops, CEOs, and doormen. All were charmed by his sharp wit and Irish good looks. Jack married the love of his life, Ursula, and entertained friends in New York and Long Island. A mass is scheduled for Saturday, December 21st, 11:00am at Our Lady of Peace, 237 E. 62nd St., New York, NY 10065. In lieu of flowers, donations may be made to www.gofundme.com/noragetchell.

KAUFF--Peter. To our dear friend of over 50 years. We will miss that great sense of humor, which was your signature. You were responsible for our meeting each other, for which we will be eternally grateful. Rest in Peace, my friend. Richard and Kay Sherman

JAFFEE--Estelle, (nee Steppler), age 95. Beloved mother of Neil (Laura) and Frederic; grandmother of Marc, Samara, and Nelle. Private graveside service at Beth Moses Cemetery on Thursday, December 19, 2013 at 1 pm.

JACOBS--Barbara. Barbara Jacobs, 76, nee Trenk, died peacefully December 18 surrounded by family and friends at New York-Presbyterian Hospital. A graduate of Boston University and a former elementary school teacher, Barbara known to her Columbia High School friends as Bobbie -- was an incomparably devoted and beloved mother, wife and grandmother who spread warmth, words of wisdom, baked goods and unconditional love to all those she encountered. Along with her late husband, Dr. Martin G. Jacobs, she was an intrepid traveler and voracious consumer of Manhattan culture. She is survived by her children: Wendy, a county commissioner in Durham, N.C., Ellen a psychotherapist in Manhattan, and Andrew, a New York Times reporter, and a brother Alvin Trenk. Funeral services will be held December 20, 1pm, at B'nai Abraham, Livingston, NJ. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to Uniting Against Lung Cancer.

HEFFNER--Richard D.,The world has lost a visionary scholar who chronicled American history as an author, a teacher and the founder and host of "The Open Mind" on PBS for more than 50 years. We have lost a great friend. Our thoughts are with Elaine and the Heffner family. Stephanie & Steve Axinn

GOLDRING--Lionel Solomon, 90, on October 20, 2013, peacefully, at his winter home in Cocoa, FL. Beloved companion of Beverly Anne Broderick, father of Michael Peter Goldring, brother to Gloria Baker of Los Angeles, with several nieces and nephews. Lionel received an AB degree from UCLA, Phi Beta Kappa and a member of Phi Eta Sigma and Phi Lambda Upsilon honorary societies, in 1943 and immediately reported for work on the Manhattan project in Oak Ridge, TN. Shortly after the end of WWII he got his Ph.D. at MIT in Physical Chemistry and subsequently an MBA in Management from NYU. He spent several years at Brookhaven National Laboratory and seven years with Nuclear Development Corp. of America. He then worked in and managed the Corporate Technical Center of AMF for eighteen years, receiving the AMF Achievement Award; spent two years at Orion Research in Cambridge, MA; seven years with Novametrix Medical Systems in Wallingford, CT and Swansea, Wales; followed by several years with Space Labs in Costa Mesa, CA and Redmond, WA. He chaired Gordon Research Conferences and was president of the MIT club of Orlando for years. Throughout his life, he traveled internationally, read extensively, loved cooking, gardening, birding, his extended family and its dogs.

HEFFNER--Richard Douglas, the Heffner family mourns the loss of our patriarch, Richard D. Heffner, husband of Elaine, father of Daniel and Beth, Andrew and Carla, grandfather to Alexander, Jeremy, Zachary and Sophia. Memorial service to be held at a future time.

GOLDMAN--Samuel Seymour, passed away on December 16, 2013. Born in Brooklyn, New York in 1929 he died soon after his beloved wife Shirley of 67 years. He is survived by his children Elaine, Donna, Robert and Lori, grandchildren Allison, Avi, Amanda, Harrison, Elizabeth, Bryan and Dina, and great- granddaughter Samantha. A passionate lover of music and accomplished pilot, Seymour and two friends flew his single engine airplane to Europe before GPS navigation. Service: Thursday, December 19 at 12:00pm at Gutterman's Funeral Home, Woodbury, NY.

GLENN--Hannah Schildhause, died peacefully at the age of 94 on December 16 at her home in Hollywood, FL with her family by her side. Formerly an avid horsewoman, a superb golfer, and a businesswoman, Hannah and husband Herman (deceased) owned and operated Ritz and Rival Drug stores in Elizabeth, Jersey City and Eatontown, NJ. She was a kind, generous and devoted friend who loved her family deeply. Hannah was above all an ally for all unfortunate, homeless or mistreated animals, and never met a stray cat she wouldn't provide for. Her granddaughters Mindy Tucker (Short Hills, NJ), Leslie Chesloff (Atlanta, GA) and Jackie Lewis (Springfield, NJ), niece and nephews Susan Tash (Saunderstown, RI), Peter Schildhause (San Francisco) and Richard Shieldhouse (Jacksonville, FL), many great- grandchildren, greatnieces and nephews, and friends, especially Sunshine Williams and Myrna Creary, grieve for her. Her brother Sol and sister Shirley predeceased her. Hannah would have been pleased to know that friends chose to honor her memory with a donation to an animal rights charity of their choice.

STECHLER--Dr. Gerry, died peacefully at home on December 18 after a courageous battle with cancer. Born in New York City in 1928, Gerry graduated from the Bronx High School of Science, University of Chicago, Columbia University (Phi Beta Kappa), and Yale University (Ph.D., Psychology). His career spanned almost 60 years as a researcher, clinician, teacher, and theoretical analyst, with special interests in infant development, the integration of psychoanalysis and family systems, therapist's affects, and couple and family therapy. In 1964 he published a game-changing article in Science showing how anesthesia (specifically ether) given to mothers in the delivery room reduced the newborns' ability to attend to stimuli. The practice of using ether soon stopped. Dr. Stechler was at Boston University School of Medicine for his entire career, as Professor of Psychiatry since 1968, Chairman of the Department of Child Psychiatry for 11 years, and Director of Child and Adolescent Services at Charles River Hospital in Wellesley in the 1980s. He helped to found the Massachusetts Institute for Psychoanalysis and the Psychoanalytic Couple and Family Institute of New England; and was an active member of Division 39 of the American Psychological Association, Couple and Family Therapy and Psychoanalysis. He was a founding member of Temple Emunah in Lexington, MA and served as its second president. Gerry is survived by his wife Toni (Halton) Stechler; daughters Amy Stechler (Bill Patterson) and Nancy Stechler Gawle (Peter); grandchildren Sarah Burns (David McMahon), Lilly Burns, Julia Gawle, and Adam Gawle; great-granddaughter Lyla Quinn McMahon; sister Mildred (Israel) Wolkow; and many nieces and nephews. His first wife Ellen died in 1977. In lieu of flowers, remembrances may be made to Temple Emunah, 9 Piper Rd, Lexington MA 02421.

NEUWIRTH--Robert, MD. The entire St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center (SLR) community joins with the leadership of our parent company, the Mount Sinai Health System, in acknowledging the passing of our dear friend and colleague, Robert Neuwirth, MD who served with great distinction as chairman of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology, first at St. Luke's Hospital and subsequently at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He will be forever remembered for his pioneering contributions to the field of OB/GYN, particularly his innovations in minimally invasive techniques used during gynecologic surgery. Dr. Neuwirth also will be remembered for his medical excellence, his notable research, and his role in training the next generation of physicians. He will be greatly missed by those who knew, worked with and were treated by him. To his entire family, we extend our heartfelt condolences. Kenneth L. Davis, MD CEO and President, the Mount Sinai Health System Frank J. Cracolici President, SLR Peter G. McGovern, MD Chairman, Dept., Obstetrics and Gynecology

NEUWIRTH--Robert S.,80, pioneer in reproductive health, passed away peacefully on December 17th. Born in Floral Park, Long Island, he graduated from Yale College magna cum laude ('55) and Yale School of Medicine ('58). He trained at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and served as Chairman of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at St. Luke's Roosevelt from 1971 to 1991, and as the first Babcock Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology at the College of Physicans and Surgeons of Columbia University from 1977 to 2000. He was known for having introduced laparascopy and hysteroscopy to the United States in the late 1960s, and as the inventor of balloon endometrial ablation, a technique to control menorrhagia and avoid hysterectomy, one of many innovative medical techniques he patented. His family will most remember him for his caring love, generosity and guidance. He is survived by five children Susan, Jessica, Laura (Adam), Michael (Deena) and Alexander (Madalyn), his former wife Gloria, and six grandchildren - Madelyn, Ethan, James, Sarah, Bennett and Juliette. A memorial service will be held December 20 at 10am at Campbell Funeral Chapel, NYC.

LICHTBLAU--Charlotte, 1925 2013. Renowned painter Charlotte Lichtblau died December 18th in New York City. Born in Vienna in 1925, Charlotte (Adelberg) Lichtblau came to the United States in 1940 with her parents and sister Doris. She lived and worked in New York City from 1953. Following her emigration to America, she returned repeatedly to her native country, primarily to Vienna and to her childhood summer home in Altaussee, in Austria's Salzkammergut region. Over a career spanning six decades, Lichtblau exhibited in galleries, museums, universities, and churches throughout the US and Austria. For more than four years, she had weekly drawings in America Magazine. Lichtblau was an art critic, as well, writing for The Philadelphia Inquirer, New York Herald Tribune, Arts Magazine, and other publications. Her collected reviews are archived at the Smithsonian Institution. She had two major career retrospective exhibitions in Austria, one at the Palais Palffy in Vienna (1994) and the Pfarrheim Arts Center in Bad Aussee, near Altaussee (2002). A planned career retrospective in 2000 led to the publication of Origin and Transformation: Life and Art of the Painter Charlotte Lichtblau by Albert Lichtblau (no relation). Charlotte Lichtblau's work is represented in museums and private collections across the United States and Europe. She is survived by her husband of 68 years, John (Hans) Lichtblau, daughter Claudia Payne (Robert Roden), sister Doris Orgel (Dr. Shelley Orgel), nieces, nephews and family. Services will be Monday, December 23rd at 10am at Holy Trinity Church, 213 West 82nd St, New York City.

ABU-LUGHOD--Janet Lippman. It is with great sadness that we announce the death of Janet Lippman Abu-Lughod on December 14, 2013, at the age of 85 in New York City. Dr. Abu-Lughod joined the Graduate Faculty of The New School for Social Research during the 1986-87 and served as Professor of Sociology for 12 years. A renowned urban sociologist, she published ground-breaking works about Cairo and Rabat, New York, Chicago and Los Angeles. She will be missed by countless colleagues, former students, and readers. A memorial for Dr. Abu-Lughod will be held at The New School in early 2014. David E. Van Zandt, President The New School William Milberg, Dean The New School for Social Research

Advances in treatment have improved survival rates for women with breast cancer in the United States, but the majority of those gains have bypassed black women.
Mary Singleton, 57, learned in July that she had Stage 4 breast cancer. After the diagnosis her son, George, moved home to Memphis to help take care of her and to help run her printing business.

The difference in mortality rates between black women and white women with breast cancer has widened since 1975, in part because black women have not benefited as much from improvements in screening and treatment. Among the states with available data, Tennessee has the largest gap. Massachusetts, where the rates have converged, has the smallest.

VIZZINI--Ned. The Hunter College community is shocked and saddened by the loss of our extraordinarily talented alumnus, Ned Vizzini, Class of 2003. Ned wrote his first novel, Be More Chill, as a student at Hunter and maintained a close relationship with the College ever since. He returned to his alma mater on several occasions to speak with students, always inspiring them to pursue their dreams in spite of all obstacles. Ned was a valued friend to me and to Hunter, and we will always remember his gifts of kindness, humor, and generosity of time and spirit. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, son, parents, and entire family. Jennifer J. Raab, President, Hunter College

STRACHAN--John R.,92, a man of notable tenacity, charm, humor, intelligence and generosity moved on to eternal life on December 19, in Loudonville, NY. John was born May 9, 1921 in Mount Vernon, NY to William J. Strachan and Josephine McCormack Strachan of Harlem, NY. He was predeceased by his brother William J. Strachan, Jr. and his beloved wife Frances Marie Weir. John graduated from Mount Saint Michael Academy in the Bronx and was a member of the United States Naval Academy's class of 1944. He served in the Navy during World War II and the Korean War primarily aboard the destroyers USS Kearny and USS Rodman. John attained the rank of Captain. In 1952, John partnered with David Weir to purchase the Pepsi-Cola Albany Bottling Company, adding 17 more franchises in New York, Massachusetts and Connecticut over the next 30 years. John served as President of the Pepsi Cola Bottlers Association in 1972, and led the fight to protect small business against the FTC, which resulted in President Carter signing into law the Soft Drink Interbrand Competition Act of 1980. He was named the Beverage Industry Man of the Year in 1985, and was inducted into the national Soft Drink Hall of Fame in 1987. John is survived by his daughters Mary Strachan (Nick Ward), Patricia O'Keeffe (Tom O'Keeffe), Ellen Pappas (Michael Pappas), and Angela Strachan, and his son John Strachan, Jr. (Janie Strachan) and seventeen grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated 9:00am on December 27, at St Mary's Church, 10 Lodge Street, Albany, NY. Interment will be at St. Agnes Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Center for Disability Services Foundation, 314 S Manning Blvd., Albany, NY 12208. To leave a message for the family, obtain directions, or view other helpful services visit McveighFuneralHome.com
RUDER--Betty. Rest in peace dear friend and send our love to Bill. Barbara and Mark

RUDER--Betty, 85, died peacefully at home on December 18, 2013, surrounded by love and memories of a life well lived. A lifelong New Yorker, Betty and her late husband, Bill, cherished time in Manhattan, East Hampton, and Ireland and built circles of friends wherever they went. Betty was devoted to her daughter, Jennifer Cott, and a sprawling family. Passionate, generous, smart, and stylish, Betty was a voracious reader, avid traveler, and patient listener who shared her wisdom with gentle candor. She was a public relations executive at Ruder Finn, former VP of public affairs at NYU, an early president of the Women's Forum, and an enthusiastic fan of the arts and all things Frank Sinatra. We will miss Betty's warmth and hearty laugh. Along with Jennifer, Betty leaves Robin (Daniel), Abby (Ellen), Brian (Ginny), Michal (Amy), Eric (Debbie); grandchildren Sarah, Aron, Eliza, Dylan, Aaron (Kirsti), Adam (Amy), David, Jerusha (David), Susannah, Mira, Jesse, Josh, and Ethan; great-granddaughter Maia; ex-husband Ted. The funeral is private; the family will observe Shiva at Betty's home Sunday (December 22) 7:00-9:00pm and Monday 2:00-5:00pm. Memorial contributions may be made to Planned Parenthood, NARAL, or the Tisch MS Research Center of New York.

DEUTSCH--Sondra Ann (nee Serota), of Miami Beach, Florida, died on Friday December 20, 2013 in Miami, where she has lived with her husband, Dr. Leonard Deutsch for over 20 years. She was 76 years old. She is survived by her husband of 30 years, Dr. Leonard Deutsch, and three children, Steven Bercovitz of Leominster, MA, Michael Bercovitz of Denver, CO, and Cynthia Eckes of New York City; and six grandchildren, Madeline, Andrew, Laudon, Sadie, Brett, and Mollie. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Hadassah. Services to be held at noon, Sunday, December 22nd at Lakeside Memorial Park, Miami, Florida.

NYIRI--Peter Victor. 7/22/47 - 12/19/2003. Remembered always. Betty Gerendasy
MINSKOFF--Joseph Henry, Happy Birthday, Sweetheart We miss you Mom and the gang
GARITY--Natalie Lyons 122/1989 Mom/m, you are remembered and loved by your family.
FRANCIS--Francesca Zolotov. Deceased 10/20/11. Remembering you and missing you on your birthday (December 20) and every day. You always scattered stardust.
ERVIN--Roger W. Dec. 25. Missing you since 1990 - Loving father, husband, brother, teacher, friend. Never forgotten.

YAEGER--Ruth (nee Hoffman), of Scarsdale, Washington, DC and New York City. Born May 2, 1921. Died December 16, 2013. Ruth lived a rich and full life with her family and the many friends that she made throughout her entire life. She was vital to the end; she volunteered at the Dorot Foundation and even took up a job at Synergos in her 80s. Ruth was a much loved wife, mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, and we will miss her deeply. She is survived by her daughter Deborah Yaeger, son-in-law John Emshwiller, daughter-in-law Diane Lloyd Yaeger, and her six grandchildren and five great-grandchildren.

WOLFF--Linda, an early and ardent feminist, who achieved success in several contiguous careers in law, politics, catering, and real estate, died Sunday, December 15, 2013 from complications resulting from a stroke. She was 66. Linda is survived by her husband, John Romanow, a Connecticut labor arbitrator; daughter, Elissa Goldstone; stepson, Daniel Romanow; and brother, Ivan Wolff. A memorial service will be held on Thursday, December 19, 2013 at 2pm at The Brooklyn Heights Synagogue in Brooklyn, NY. In lieu of flowers, donations can be made to the Brooklyn Heights Synagogue or to the Connecticut Hospice. Linda was a great and generous wife, mother, sister, and friend, who will be dearly missed.

WHITNEY--John. The Board of Overseers of Columbia Business School expresses deep sorrow at the passing of John Whitney, professor emeritus in the Management Division of Columbia Business School. For more than 18 years, Professor Whitney taught hundreds of students in leadership and turnaround management, and his first book became a hallmark in turnaround business for both students and the corporate world. He was a successful entrepreneur and a beloved teacher, earning several awards for his contributions both in academia and in business. Columbia Business School extends its profound sympathy to the Whitney family. Glenn Hubbard, Dean, Columbia Business School

WEITZNER--Dorothea Marilyn, born April 2, 1922, died peacefully at home on December 14, 2013. Dorothea's loving and beloved parents were Henry Mitchell Weitzner, born in Austro-Hungary, deceased 1954, a prominent New York City real estate developer and civil engineer, and Edna Hilda Kheel Weitzner, a versatile woman who was born in Odessa, Russia, deceased 1955. Dorothea's loving and beloved brother, Morton Leonard Weitzner, also a New York real estate developer and trophied sportsman, carried on the family concern, Lehigh Management Inc., until his death in 2004. Morton's beloved wife, Carol Richter Weitzner, passed away in 2009. In her lifetime, Dorothea attended Barnard College and Columbia University School of Law, before shifting her attention to the arts, pursuing the zeitgeist as feverishly as possible. She studied painting, music and theosophy, and traveled in creative circles. In 1969, she was awarded first prize for both substance and presentation at the First International Inventors' Exhibition at the New York City Coliseum. In 1972, she founded the Gallery of the Aquarian Republic to acquire, exhibit and develop 20th Century esoteric arts and letters that expand human conscience and consciousness. In 2010 she made a substantial gift for research and cutting edge technology to the Columbia University Fu Foundation School of Engineering and Applied Science, in loving memory of her father. Dorothea is survived by her niece, Cherie Acierno, Cherie's husband Lou Acierno, their daughter (Dorothea's grand-niece) Jane Celine Acierno, and by her nephew, Gregg Harrison Weitzner. Surviving cousins and their families include Sara Schweig and family; the Martin Meyers; Lawrence (Larry) Weitzner; Dr. Charles Weitzner; and Sima, Ernest, Dr. Cheryl and Risa Hanau. Dorothea leaves loving remembrance of those who mutually befriended her along Life's Way. She requested no funeral. A private interment service will be held at Mt. Hope Cemetery, Hastings-on-Hudson, NY.

WATERS--Sheilah Ross, of Bedford, NY and Nantucket, MA died serenely at home in Bedford on Saturday, December 14. Swathed in her usual brightly-patterned pillowcases and gown, she simply and quietly stopped breathing. She was born April 25, 1928 in New York City. She graduated from The Brearley School in New York City in 1946 and Vassar College in 1950. Mrs. Waters was a successful fashion model from her late teens into her 30s, appearing on the covers of Vogue and Harper's Bazaar. She devoted herself to her two daughters' academic and cultural education and was very much a part of the New York City 1960s political scene. She was proud of her work as a docent at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and of teaching art at New York City public schools. A trained artist, Sheilah presented art programs for the Mount Kisco Day Care Center and the Bedford Library. Sheilah found solace in historical novels and the New York Times crossword. She measured her medical recovery by her ability to finish increasingly difficult crosswords, and a day without the New York Times was not a day. Her tremendous loyalty to her old friends also carried her through. Sheilah took a festive approach to everything in her life: her home was adorned with pattern, color, brightness and humorous detail. One of the keys to her happiness is that she happily anticipated and then savored the small things: a rich dessert, a new book, the TV show MASH, a Porthault washcloth on sale, the bias cut of a dress, the opportunity to be silly. Her wide group of friends always looked forward to her lively and glamorous parties, where she was in her element. She was treated with charm and good manners by everyone she met as she went through her day. It is fitting she died shortly after a day of decorating the tree and wrapping presents. Christmas was her favorite time, because it is all about ornament, festivity and celebration of loyalty and love. All in all, she was what her first husband called, "a classy dame". She is survived by her husband, William Waters; her daughters Amanda Cross and Lisa Pownall-Gray (Dickon); her three granddaughters: Lindsay, Ella and Saskia; her brother Christopher Ross; her cousin Jane Frost; and her favorite niece and 'third daughter' Vickie Green. Her two husbands, Theodore Cross and Regis Gignoux, predeceased her. A memorial service will be held at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church on Saturday, January 11 at 11am (382 Cantitoe St, Bedford NY 10506). A celebration of her life will be held on Nantucket in the summer. Donations in Sheilah's memory may be made to the Bedford Free Library (32 Village Green, Bedford NY 10506), the Artists Association of Nantucket (Box 1104, Nantucket MA 02554) or to a charity of choice.

WALTON--Samuel. The Partners and Staff of WeiserMazars LLP mourn the passing of our long time client and friend Samuel Walton. We extend our sincere condolences to his children, Carolyn, Susan, Stuart, and Janice, their spouses, his eight grandchildren, and four great-grandchildren.

VIZZINI--Ned. The Hunter College community is shocked and saddened by the loss of our extraordinarily talented alumnus, Ned Vizzini, Class of 2003. Ned wrote his first novel, Be More Chill, as a student at Hunter and maintained a close relationship with the College ever since. He returned to his alma mater on several occasions to speak with students, always inspiring them to pursue their dreams in spite of all obstacles. Ned was a valued friend to me and to Hunter, and we will always remember his gifts of kindness, humor, and generosity of time and spirit. Our heartfelt condolences to his wife, son, parents, and entire family. Jennifer J. Raab, President, Hunter College

TRENARY--David K.,77, passed on December 1, 2013. David retired as a Colonel in the Army Reserves and Senior Medical Conduct Investigator for New York OPMC. As a marathon runner, traveler, favorite dog walker and his passion for history, art, music and reading David enriched the lives of many. Survivors are his wife Ruth, daughters Lisa and Kristin, son-in-law John Oleske and grandson Kestrel.

TAAFFE--William (Bill), Jr, passed at home in Henderson, NV on December 12. Born September 27, 1943 in Queens, NY. Survived by wife, Donna, son, Will, and sister, Joan Engel. Attended Oratory Prep and Seton Hall in New Jersey. Award-winning columnist, esp sports. Staff editor at New York Times sports desk more than seven years. Co-edited New York Times' anthology Sports of the Times. His pioneering TV sports column for Sports Illustrated won National Headliners Award for best national magazine column. Was also a columnist for The Washington Post, The Washington Star, and Las Vegas Review Journal. Co-authored Gimme a Break by sportscaster Warner Wolf, and Stripped with Pastor Jud Wilhite. Chaplain with Marketplace Chaplains. Celebration of Life January 6, 11am, Central Christian Church, 1001 New Beginnings Drive, Henderson, NV. In lieu of flowers, family's favorite charities available upon request.

STRACHAN--John R.,92, a man of notable tenacity, charm, humor, intelligence and generosity moved on to eternal life on December 19, in Loudonville, NY. John was born May 9, 1921 in Mount Vernon, NY to William J. Strachan and Josephine McCormack Strachan of Harlem, NY. He was predeceased by his brother William J. Strachan, Jr. and his beloved wife Frances Marie Weir. John graduated from Mount Saint Michael Academy in the Bronx and was a member of the United States Naval Academy's class of 1944. He served in the Navy during World War II and the Korean War primarily aboard the destroyers USS Kearny and USS Rodman. John attained the rank of Captain. In 1952, John partnered with David Weir to purchase the Pepsi-Cola Albany Bottling Company, adding 17 more franchises in New York, Massachusetts and Connecticut over the next 30 years. John served as President of the Pepsi Cola Bottlers Association in 1972, and led the fight to protect small business against the FTC, which resulted in President Carter signing into law the Soft Drink Interbrand Competition Act of 1980. He was named the Beverage Industry Man of the Year in 1985, and was inducted into the national Soft Drink Hall of Fame in 1987. John is survived by his daughters Mary Strachan (Nick Ward), Patricia O'Keeffe (Tom O'Keeffe), Ellen Pappas (Michael Pappas), and Angela Strachan, and his son John Strachan, Jr. (Janie Strachan) and seventeen grandchildren. A Mass of Christian Burial will be celebrated 9:00am on December 27, at St Mary's Church, 10 Lodge Street, Albany, NY. Interment will be at St. Agnes Cemetery. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be made to the Center for Disability Services Foundation, 314 S Manning Blvd., Albany, NY 12208. To leave a message for the family, obtain directions, or view other helpful services visit McveighFuneralHome.com

STIER--Eleanor, 88, died December 18 at home in Greenwich Village, where she resided more than 55 years. Born in Mount Vernon, NY she earned a BS cum laude at Columbia University and an MSW at Columbia's School of Social Work. An education policy analyst, she worked for 26 years at the Community Service Society and was a charter member of the Educational Priorities Panel, which monitored the NYC Board of Education's spending practices and helped reallocate funds from administration into classroom services. She was the longtime co-chair of the Education Committee of the Women's City Club of NY, which honored her contributions in May 2013. Predeceased by her brothers, Sidney and Joseph L. Stier, and her lifetime partner, Barbara Reach. Survived by her beloved niece and nephew, Audrey Adams-Doppelt (Neil) and Lawrence Stier (Ritann); adored great-nieces, Dr. Sarah Steinberg (Peter) and Dr. Rachel Adams; cherished great-great-nephews, Charles and Henry Steinberg; and many friends.

SPINOGATTI--Mario, on December 20th, 2013. Beloved husband of Tina (Nee) Ruggiero. Cherished brother of Peter Spinogatti and uncle to Michael and Paul Ruggiero and Peter Spinogatti. Viewing will be held in Farenga Bros Funeral Home located at 920 Allerton Avenue, Bronx, NY on Sunday, December 22nd from 2-5pm and 7-9pm. Mass of Christian Burial will take place on Monday, December 23rd, in St. Lucy's Church at 11am. Entombment to follow in Woodlawn Cemetery.

SOTO--Ellen M.,on December 20, 2013 at age 58. Beloved daughter of Marina and the late Victor Soto. Loving sister of Victoria (Harold), Arlene (Gregory) Amelia and Nancy. Also survived by many cherished nieces, nephews, great-niece and great-nephews. Great friend to many. Long time career in jewelry design and manufacturing industries. Mass of Christian burial will be held Monday 11am at Epiphany Church, 22nd St. and 2nd Ave. Interment to follow at Pinelawn Memorial Park, Pinelawn, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to: Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation, www.komen.org.

SILVERMAN--Wallace, age 93, died peacefully at home on December 15, 2013. Loving father of Steven and Nanci. Father-in-law of Fred and Patty, and dear granddad to Jessica, Martin, Barnett, and Abbey. A WWII veteran in the Army Signal Corp he won two bronze medals for decrypting codes. He worked for Simon & Schuster Golden Book Records and was an electrical design engineer at Bunker Ramo Corp; designer of the Nasdaq 100 quotation system. Dedicated husband for 64 years, to the late Martha. His incredible wit and intellect will be deeply missed.
SIEGEL--Irving. Irv, you will be missed dearly. Your zest for life will remain with all of us. Our deepest sympathy to your beloved wife Diane and children. Maxine and Skip Pines

SHEPPARD--Ralph. Born Wolfgang Siegfried Schlesinger in Berlin, Germany on December 2, 1931, died December 17, 2013 in Palm Beach, Florida at the age of 82. Beloved husband of 58 years to Edith, devoted father and father-in-law to Lori Sheppard and Michael Labriola, Gary and Riva Sheppard, Robert and Julie Sheppard, loving cousin to Andrew and Sally Fleming, and adored grandfather of Emily, Cole, Daniel and Luke. Ralph Sheppard was a decorated veteran of the United States Army during the Korean War where he served with distinction, receiving two Purple Hearts and the Bronze Star for Bravery. He was an innovative CEO and founder of one of New York's premier commercial cleaning companies. Throughout his life, he fought for the rights of the oppressed and was a voice of the underdog. Donations can be made in his honor to the ADL or the Disabled American Veterans.

SHAW--Bernard L. Bernard L. Shaw, vice president of corporate security for Hearst Corporation, died December 17 in Garrison, N.Y. after a long illness. He was 68. Shaw joined Hearst Corporation in 1983 and most recently served as vice president of corporate security. "For three decades, Bernie served Hearst Corporation with loyalty and distinction," said Steven R. Swartz, president and CEO, Hearst Corporation. "All of us are grateful for his long tenure and friendship. He will be greatly missed." "Bernie was a dedicated employee, much beloved by his fellow workers, as well as a loving father and husband," said Frank A. Bennack, Jr., executive vice chairman, Hearst Corporation. "Our condolences go out to his immediate family and the entire Hearst family as well." Shaw married Patricia Hearst Shaw, granddaughter of William Randolph Hearst, in 1979. He was born in San Francisco and served as a police officer there for 15 years. He is survived by his wife, Patricia Hearst Shaw; their two daughters, Gillian Hearst Simonds and Lydia Hearst-Shaw; son Thomas Shaw; daughter Heather Shaw; sister Joan Carmignani; and one granddaughter, Harper Randolph Simonds. Final services will be conducted in private. In lieu of flowers, donations may be sent to the San Miguel Academy of Newburgh (http://new burghsanmiguel.org), c/o Cathy Joyce Wooters, Development Director, 245 Renwick Street, Newburgh, NY 12550. Donations may also be made online.

SCHACHTER--Justine Ranson, of Levittown, NY, died on December 17, 2013, 1 day shy of her 86th birthday. Beloved wife of the late Scott Schachter for 51 years. Cherished mother of Linda Wright, the late Barbara Costa, Peter Schachter, and David Schachter. Treasured mother-in-law of Robert Wright, Antonia Schachter, and Scott Hunt. Adored grandmother of Jeffrey and Bryan Wright, and Nicholas and Jonathan Schachter. Dearest sister of Ellen Adams. Loving friend to many. Justine was a talented artist who delighted in traveling the world with her husband and volunteering her time and talents to progressive social causes. Memorial service on Sunday, January 5 at 11am at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, L.I.

RUDER--Betty, 85, died peacefully at home on December 18, 2013, surrounded by love and memories of a life well lived. A lifelong New Yorker, Betty and her late husband, Bill, cherished time in Manhattan, East Hampton, and Ireland and built circles of friends wherever they went. Betty was devoted to her daughter, Jennifer Cott, and a sprawling family. Passionate, generous, smart, and stylish, Betty was a voracious reader, avid traveler, and patient listener who shared her wisdom with gentle candor. She was a public relations executive at Ruder Finn, former VP of public affairs at NYU, an early president of the Women's Forum, and an enthusiastic fan of the arts and all things Frank Sinatra. We will miss Betty's warmth and hearty laugh. Along with Jennifer, Betty leaves Robin (Daniel), Abby (Ellen), Brian (Ginny), Michal (Amy), Eric (Debbie); grandchildren Sarah, Aron, Eliza, Dylan, Aaron (Kirsti), Adam (Amy), David, Jerusha (David), Susannah, Mira, Jesse, Josh, and Ethan; great-granddaughter Maia; ex-husband Ted. The funeral is private; the family will observe Shiva at Betty's home Sunday (December 22) 7:00-9:00pm and Monday 2:00-5:00pm. Memorial contributions may be made to Planned Parenthood, NARAL, or the Tisch MS Research Center of New York.

ROTHMAN--Debbie, age 57, wife of Dr. Ivan Rothman, mother of Arielle Weinberger and Scott Weinberger and sister to Kenneth Wolk, died peacefully on December 20, 2013. A beautiful, brilliant, vibrant woman with a deep and profound love for her family and friends, Debbie will be missed by all who had the privilege of knowing her. Funeral services will be held on Monday, December 23, 2013 at 9:30am at Gutterman's Funeral Home, 8000 Jericho Turnpike, Woodbury, NY.

ROSENBERG--Jeanette, 92, was a caring wife to Robert (deceased). Beloved daughter Barbara, son-in-law Paul, and granddaughters Roxanne and Ariane survive her. Jeanette graduated from Hunter College at age 20 and supervised a computer-processing department in the industry's early years.

ROGERS--Barbara Karstadt, CEO Respiratory Resources and former music producer. Age 66. Died December 7, 2013. Widow of Kinnie Rogers, mother of William, mother-in-law to Stacy, Grandmother of Riley, Brett, and Cami, Sister of Jeff. Patient consultant to medical industry and institutions. Past appointee to the CMS Program Advisory and Oversight Committee. Memorial to be held in San Diego. Contact Billy at wsr212@hotmail.com or 619-259-0359.

NEUWIRTH--Robert S.,80, pioneer in reproductive health, passed away peacefully on December 17th. Born in Floral Park, Long Island, he graduated from Yale College magna cum laude ('55) and Yale School of Medicine ('58). He trained at Columbia Presbyterian Medical Center and served as Chairman of the Department of Obstetrics and Gynecology at St. Luke's Roosevelt from 1971 to 1991, and as the first Babcock Professor of Obstetrics and Gynecology at the College of Physicans and Surgeons of Columbia University from 1977 to 2000. He was known for having introduced laparascopy and hysteroscopy to the United States in the late 1960s, and as the inventor of balloon endometrial ablation, a technique to control menorrhagia and avoid hysterectomy, one of many innovative medical techniques he patented. His family will most remember him for his caring love, generosity and guidance. He is survived by five children Susan, Jessica, Laura (Adam), Michael (Deena) and Alexander (Madalyn), his former wife Gloria, and six grandchildren - Madelyn, Ethan, James, Sarah, Bennett and Juliette. A memorial service will be held December 20 at 10am at Campbell Funeral Chapel, NYC.
McLEOD--E. Webster Jr.,December 17, in Asheville, NC, E. Webster McLeod, Jr., 89, husband of Gail Zabriskie McLeod, father of Andrew Webster McLeod, formerly of Scarborough, NY and Time Inc. retiree.

LICHTBLAU--Charlotte, 1925 2013. Renowned painter Charlotte Lichtblau died December 18th in New York City. Born in Vienna in 1925, Charlotte (Adelberg) Lichtblau came to the United States in 1940 with her parents and sister Doris. She lived and worked in New York City from 1953. Following her emigration to America, she returned repeatedly to her native country, primarily to Vienna and to her childhood summer home in Altaussee, in Austria's Salzkammergut region. Over a career spanning six decades, Lichtblau exhibited in galleries, museums, universities, and churches throughout the US and Austria. For more than four years, she had weekly drawings in America Magazine. Lichtblau was an art critic, as well, writing for The Philadelphia Inquirer, New York Herald Tribune, Arts Magazine, and other publications. Her collected reviews are archived at the Smithsonian Institution. She had two major career retrospective exhibitions in Austria, one at the Palais Palffy in Vienna (1994) and the Pfarrheim Arts Center in Bad Aussee, near Altaussee (2002). A planned career retrospective in 2000 led to the publication of Origin and Transformation: Life and Art of the Painter Charlotte Lichtblau by Albert Lichtblau (no relation). Charlotte Lichtblau's work is represented in museums and private collections across the United States and Europe. She is survived by her husband of 68 years, John (Hans) Lichtblau, daughter Claudia Payne (Robert Roden), sister Doris Orgel (Dr. Shelley Orgel), nieces, nephews and family. Services will be Monday, December 23rd at 10am at Holy Trinity Church, 213 West 82nd St, New York City.
LEWIS--Leonard S. May 11, 1929 - December 17, 2013. Beloved son, husband, son-in-law, father, father-in-law, grandfather and friend. May His Memory be a Blessing Always.

LEOPOLD--Jack, 95. Beloved husband of the late Gladys; brother of Renee Cymes. Loving father of Michael, Larry, and Ilene (Persoff). Proud grandfather of six and great-grandfather of five. Funeral Sunday, December 22, 11am, at Gutterman's, 8000 Jericho Tpke, Woodbury, NY

KOCHMANN--Kurt, passed away at age 98 on December 17 in Greenlawn, NY. Born in Dusseldorf, Germany, he emigrated to the US and fought in WWII. He lived in Port Washington, NY and in Pompano Beach, FL. In the US he leaves his daughters Carol and Jill and three grandchildren. Contributions to Amnesty International are welcome.

KLIROS--Thea. Thea Kliros, a fashion and children's book illustrator, died at home Thursday of lung cancer. She was 78. A strong, engaging spirit, she was generous in sharing her passion for life and art. Thea lived in Manhattan, but also cherished country weekends at her other home near Millbrook, NY. Born Althea Friedberg on August 16, 1935, in Queens, she studied at Bennington College and Yale University. She painted and exhibited, and had a long career as an award-winning illustrator. Successful in publications such as Vogue and Women's Wear Daily, she later turned to creating art grounded in the tradition of the great children's book illustrators of the early 1900s. Her works often featured her grandchildren and her beloved affenpinscher. She illustrated many books, but her rendition of The Wizard of Oz, published in 2010, was a favorite. Husbands Theodore Kliros and David Neuman died before her. She is survived by her companion David Douglas, children Adrian and Hilary Kliros, grandchildren Felix, Lotte, and Fabian, son-in-law Dan Walworth, daughter-in-law Clara Vega Kliros, and her dog Petra.

KAWALLER--Seymour, devoted husband of Jeanette Kawaller and father of Freya Block (Richard), Marsha Sue DeJuan (Jose), and Ira Kawaller (Joanna Knobler), passed away peacefully in Bloomfield, CT on December 16, 2013. He also leaves, a sister Evelyn Phillips and a large extended family. Seymour lived an active, full, and rich life and enjoyed a 75 year marriage to Jeni the love of his life. His warmth and unique personality will be missed by all.

KAUFF--Peter. To our dear friend of over 50 years. We will miss that great sense of humor, which was your signature. You were responsible for our meeting each other, for which we will be eternally grateful. Rest in Peace, my friend. Richard and Kay Sherman

KAMINOW--Ivan Paul, died December 18, 2013 in San Francisco, CA after a prolonged illness. Known as a photonics luminary, Dr. Kaminow's pioneering contributions advanced the field of optical fiber communications for nearly five decades. Born and raised in New Jersey, Dr. Kaminow attended Union College, got a master's degree at UCLA and received a PHD from Harvard University. He worked for over forty years at Bell Labs in Holmdel, NJ until his retirement in 1996. Most recently he was an adjunct professor with the Electrical Engineering and Computer Science Department at the University of California, Berkeley. He is survived by his wife Florence of 61 years, his brother, Alan, his three children, Paula, Leonard and Ellen and seven grandchildren, Sarah, Joseph, Rafael, Nicolas, Gabriel, Sophia and Maura. Services will be held Monday, December 23 at the Jewish Memorial Chapel in Clifton, NJ. For information, jewishmemorialchapel.org

HUGHES--Mike, 65, president and creative chief of The Martin Agency, Richmond, VA passed away at home on Sunday, December 15, 2013. The Board of Directors of The One Club and all its members mourn the loss of a true gentleman who taught us the importance of finding joy in life and work. As a former board member of The One Club, Mike was a stalwart for recognizing creative excellence. He originated the idea for the One Club publication, Best of the Decade 1980-1990, which included his introduction. Mike was the ultimate storyteller and he truly valued work that was entertaining, honest and intelligent. But most of all, he valued his family, friends and the people he worked with. Mike was inducted into the Creative Hall of Fame in 2010. He was a giant in the industry and continued to be an inspiration for many of his peers. Our thoughts are with Ginny, Jason and his family, and all his colleagues, past and present at The Martin Agency.

HEFFNER--Richard. For 60 years his viewers were treated to his "Open Mind." To those of us who loved him, he also opened up his heart. Our deepest sympathy to Elaine, his children and grandchildren. Joan and Sol Wachtler

GOLDEN--Mark Ph.D. of Dania Beach FL. September 22, 1926 - December 13, 2013. Leaves beloved wife Shanti, daughter Cori Ball, sons Paul and John Golden and Paul Wurczel. Memorial Thursday, December 19, 3pm, Lloyd Beach State Park, Dania Beach, FL.

FRIEDMAN--Herbert S. July 10, 1924 - December 17, 2013. Beloved husband of Joanne; loving father of Jillian and Audry (David); devoted grandfather of Jacob. FREAD--Ruth, on December 15, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Bernard. Devoted mother of Cynthia, Richard, Gail, Amy and the late Wendy, and mother-in-law of Stanley, Dorothy and Ileen. Cherished grandmother of Julie, Erica and Warren. Loving great-grandmother of Emily, Brandon, Haley and Fiona.

EIDENBERG--Eugene, who led distinguished careers in public service, academia, business, and philanthropy, died of glioblastoma on December 3, 2013 in Santa Monica, California. He was 74. Gene served as a trusted advisor to the President of the United States, played a pivotal role in remaking the American telecommunications industry, and made significant contributions to the cause of the democratic process around the world. Above all, he will be remembered for the great love he had for his family, who stood with him throughout his battle against brain cancer and were with him at his passing. Gene's wonderful qualities - his ability to analyze complex problems and issues, to recognize the value of relationships in resolving conflict and solving problems, his unerring kindness toward people of all stations, and his wonderful sense of humor played a key role in his success in life. Former President Jimmy Carter paid tribute: "Gene was a delightful and cherished friend and a superbly competent and dedicated public servant." Former Vice President Walter Mondale said: "Gene was a wonderfully gifted and caring leader and friend who lived his life as an inspired public servant, educator and progressive thinker." House Minority Leader Nancy Pelosi: "Gene's life was an example of outstanding public service to his country, creative and innovative management in American business, and a deep devotion to family and friends." Former Secretary of State Madeleine Albright: "Gene loved politics. He did not disparage the practice of politics; rather, he embraced political action as an avenue to represent the views of ordinary citizens and respond to their concerns, hopes and aspirations with tangible results." Gene grew up in Mamaroneck, New York, where he was a high school All-American swimmer. He attended the University of Wisconsin and graduated with a B.A. in Political Science. After completing his Masters and Ph.D. in Political Science from Northwestern University, he taught political science at the University of Minnesota and was then appointed Vice President of Administration for the University of Minnesota system. Gene left his academic career in 1977 to join President Jimmy Carter's administration, first as Deputy Undersecretary of the Department of Health, Education and Welfare; then on the White House Staff as Deputy Secretary to the Cabinet and Deputy Assistant to the President for Intergovernmental Affairs; concluding his service as a member of the President's Senior White House Staff, reporting directly to the President. Following the Carter Administration, Gene became Executive Director of the Democratic National Committee, an extremely challenging job in the wake of the Democrats' loss of the Presidency in 1980. In 1982, William G. McGowan, founder and chairman of MCI Communications, convinced Gene to join MCI as Senior Vice President for Regulatory and Public Policy. During his career with MCI, Gene served as Senior Vice President for Strategic Planning and Corporate Development, President of MCI's Pacific Division in San Francisco, and Executive Vice President and Group Executive for MCI's International Business Operations. After MCI, Gene pursued a highly successful career in the worlds of high tech business and venture capital investment. He served as President and CEO of Macrovision Corp., was a Principal in the San Francisco-based venture capital firm of Hambrecht & Quist, and joined Granite Venture Associates LLC. Gene also served on the board and as chairman of Internap Network Services Corporation (NASDQ; INAP). In recent years, during his "retirement", Gene helped to support and inspire a group on the Hawaiian island of Kauai who were creating Kauai's first renewable energy company, and served until recently as a board member of Pacific Light and Power. Gene was especially passionate about the civil rights of individuals who wish to determine their future through voting. For more than twenty years Gene served on the board and as treasurer of the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs (NDI), a nonprofit, nonpartisan organization working to support and strengthen democratic institutions worldwide. Through his work with NDI, Gene personally supported and participated in election observations and civil rights and democracy education programs in Asia, the Caribbean, South America and the Middle East. When Barack Obama ran for President in 2008, Gene and his wife Anna moved to Southern New Mexico to register voters and work on the campaign. Gene helped to recruit, organize, and train volunteer attorneys from across the country to staff the Democratic Party's Voter Protection Project which reduced incidents of voting rights violations in areas historically known for voter harassment. Gene's first marriage to Susan Zox produced two lovely daughters, Danielle and Elizabeth. Later, he would marry Angenette Martin, who specialized in grassroots organizing and consulting for political campaigns and other social causes. When Angie was later diagnosed with breast cancer, Gene took a leave from work to be with her as she fought the disease that would eventually take her life. In 1999, Gene married former San Francisco news anchor and broadcast journalist Anna Chavez. Gene and Anna were married by his brother David, surrounded by family and friends in their backyard in San Francisco. Eugene Eidenberg is survived by his wife, Anna Chavez; his sister, Dorothea Ellern; his brother, David Eidenberg; his daughters, Danielle Eidenberg-Noppe and Elizabeth Cazenave; and their families Phil Eidenberg-Noppe, Naomi Ariel and Esther Dov Eidenberg Noppe; and Eric Cazenave, Nora Grace and Owen Eli Cazenave. A private memorial service is planned. The family has requested that, in lieu of flowers, memorial remembrances be sent to: The UCLA Brain Cancer Research Fund. C/O Timothy Frances Cloughesy, MD, 710 Westwood Plaza, Suite 1-230 Los Angeles, CA 90095 or The National Democratic Institute for International Affairs 455 Massachusetts Ave., NW, 8th Floor Washington, DC 20001

DUBIN--Frieda, 84, passed on December 16. Beloved mother of Elyse and Marc (Judy), grandmother of Joshua and Jared. Her loving, generous, and youthful spirit will always remain in our hearts. The family deeply mourns the loss of our dear Fredi.

YAEGER--Ruth (nee Hoffman), of Scarsdale, Washington, DC and New York City. Born May 2, 1921. Died December 16, 2013. Ruth lived a rich and full life with her family and the many friends that she made throughout her entire life. She was vital to the end; she volunteered at the Dorot Foundation and even took up a job at Synergos in her 80s. Ruth was a much loved wife, mother, grandmother, and great-grandmother, and we will miss her deeply. She is survived by her daughter Deborah Yaeger, son-in-law John Emshwiller, daughter-in-law Diane Lloyd Yaeger, and her six grandchildren and five great-grandchildren.

WATERS--Sheilah Ross, of Bedford, NY and Nantucket, MA died serenely at home in Bedford on Saturday, December 14. Swathed in her usual brightly-patterned pillowcases and gown, she simply and quietly stopped breathing. She was born April 25, 1928 in New York City. She graduated from The Brearley School in New York City in 1946 and Vassar College in 1950. Mrs. Waters was a successful fashion model from her late teens into her 30s, appearing on the covers of Vogue and Harper's Bazaar. She devoted herself to her two daughters' academic and cultural education and was very much a part of the New York City 1960s political scene. She was proud of her work as a docent at the Metropolitan Museum of Art and of teaching art at New York City public schools. A trained artist, Sheilah presented art programs for the Mount Kisco Day Care Center and the Bedford Library. Sheilah found solace in historical novels and the New York Times crossword. She measured her medical recovery by her ability to finish increasingly difficult crosswords, and a day without the New York Times was not a day. Her tremendous loyalty to her old friends also carried her through. Sheilah took a festive approach to everything in her life: her home was adorned with pattern, color, brightness and humorous detail. One of the keys to her happiness is that she happily anticipated and then savored the small things: a rich dessert, a new book, the TV show MASH, a Porthault washcloth on sale, the bias cut of a dress, the opportunity to be silly. Her wide group of friends always looked forward to her lively and glamorous parties, where she was in her element. She was treated with charm and good manners by everyone she met as she went through her day. It is fitting she died shortly after a day of decorating the tree and wrapping presents. Christmas was her favorite time, because it is all about ornament, festivity and celebration of loyalty and love. All in all, she was what her first husband called, "a classy dame". She is survived by her husband, William Waters; her daughters Amanda Cross and Lisa Pownall-Gray (Dickon); her three granddaughters: Lindsay, Ella and Saskia; her brother Christopher Ross; her cousin Jane Frost; and her favorite niece and 'third daughter' Vickie Green. Her two husbands, Theodore Cross and Regis Gignoux, predeceased her. A memorial service will be held at St. Matthew's Episcopal Church on Saturday, January 11 at 11am (382 Cantitoe St, Bedford NY 10506). A celebration of her life will be held on Nantucket in the summer. Donations in Sheilah's memory may be made to the Bedford Free Library (32 Village Green, Bedford NY 10506), the Artists Association of Nantucket (Box 1104, Nantucket MA 02554) or to a charity of choice.

SCHACHNE--David I. Yeshiva University and the Wurzweiler School of Social Work were extremely saddened to learn of the passing of David I. Schachne, a cherished and beloved University trustee for more than two decades and a most respected and admired long serving Chair of the WSSW Board of Overseers. David was a tireless leader on behalf of Wurzweiler who contributed boundless energy and generous resources. David and his full partner in life, Dorothy, provided significant philanthropic support including the naming of the Wurzweiler deanship and creating scholarship funds. David was a true mensch and everyone at Yeshiva University and the Wurzweiler School of Social Work who knew David will continue to model his values of hard work, kindness, loyalty, and caring for others. We extend our love and deepest condolences to his dear wife Dorothy, his sons Jay (Andrea) and Sydney (Leslie) and to the entire Schachne family.

SOTO--Ellen M.,on December 20, 2013 at age 58. Beloved daughter of Marina and the late Victor Soto. Loving sister of Victoria (Harold), Arlene (Gregory) Amelia and Nancy. Also survived by many cherished nieces, nephews, great-niece and great-nephews. Great friend to many. Long time career in jewelry design and manufacturing industries. Mass of Christian burial will be held Monday 11am at Epiphany Church, 22nd St. and 2nd Ave. Interment to follow at Pinelawn Memorial Park, Pinelawn, NY. Contributions in her memory may be made to: Susan G. Komen Breast Cancer Foundation, www.komen.org.

SCHACHNE--David Irwin, 88, founding partner of Fairfield Properties. David I. Schachne, son of Pauline and Abraham Schachne, died peacefully at his home in Commack today. He is survived by his beloved wife Dorothy of 66 years, sons Sydney and Jay, daughters-in- law Lesly and Andrea, grandchildren Brian, Heather, Seth, lan, and Elana, sister Doris, as well as many nieces, nephews, and cousins. David had a full life. At age 18, he enlisted in the army and fought in the Battle of the Bulge where he was wounded and received a Purple heart. He graduated from NYU with a degree in accounting. After many years as a practicing CPA he developed an interest in real estate, subsequently becoming a founding partner in Fairfield properties where he enjoyed working until his final days. Mr. Schachne's philanthropies extended to Flatbush Park Jewish Center, Yeshiva University where he was bestowed an honorary doctorate of humanities, Wurzweiler school of social work, Brookdale hospital, Gurwin Jewish Geriatric Center, Jinsa, Shaare Zedek hospital In Israel, Jinsa, and Cancer Care. Because he believed In doing what he could to improve the human condition and to relieve pain and suffering of his fellow man he actively served on the boards of these Institutions. Above all, Mr. Schachne embodied the true essence of "Tzadik", a righteous man who loved life, his family and friends. For all who knew him and loved him he will live forever. Shiva will be observed at his home in Commack.

ROONEY--Andrea Sokerka, 70, passed away into light and love peacefully at home December 20, 2013, and is survived by her husband Steve and her sisters Suzanne Elrod and Nancy Railey. Funeral service will be 11:45am Friday, December 27 at Riverside Memorial Chapel, 180 West 76th Street, New York City. Riversidememorialchapel.com

ROGERS--Barbara Karstadt, CEO Respiratory Resources and former music producer. Age 66. Died December 7, 2013. Widow of Kinnie Rogers, mother of William, mother-in-law to Stacy, Grandmother of Riley, Brett, and Cami, Sister of Jeff. Patient consultant to medical industry and institutions. Past appointee to the CMS Program Advisory and Oversight Committee. Memorial to be held in San Diego. Contact Billy at wsr212@hotmail.com or 619-259-0359.

KENNER--Eugene, on December 21 at age 91 in Rye NY. Beloved husband of Barbara (Berg) Kenner. Devoted father of Sharon Heiman, Brian Kenner, Todd Kenner and Andrea Kinnard. Adoring grandfather of ten and a great-grandchild. Loving uncle and great-uncle. Predeceased by late wife Rhoda (Daum) and former wife Elaine (Greenberg). An admired and respected CPA, he retired as a partner from Lipsky, Goodkin. He was a model of generosity and kindness to all who knew him. Service December 23, 12:30pm, Ferncliff Cemetery, Hartsdale.
HEFFNER--Richard D. Sadly a mighty oak has fallen. He will be missed. Dorothy Cooper

GRAFF--Lawrence, of Woodmere, NY died peacefully on December 21st. Beloved husband of Roberta (Nussbaum) Graff, devoted father of Sherry Graff Schreiber and Kathy Graff. Proud father-in-law of Jonathan Schreiber and Benjamin Pinczewski. Adoring grandfather to Kevin, Kimberly and Nicholas. Larry, accomplished, intelligent and thoughtful, was passionately devoted to his wife of 54 years and to his children and grandchildren. A graduate of Cornell and a former member of the American Stock Exchange, he lived a full life of 77 years, enjoying time spent with family and on the golf course. Services will be held at Boulevard Riverside Hewlett, 1450 Broadway, Hewlett, NY on Monday, December 23rd at 12:00pm. Donations may be sent to JCC Therapeutic Nursery 411 East Clinton Ave., Tenafly, NJ 07670.

GIAMBELLI--Mary. We are deeply saddened by the loss of our dear friend, owner of Giambelli's 50th Ristorante with her late husband Francesco. She was generous, kind and loved by all who knew her. May she rest in God's eternal peace. WeiserMazars LLP

GIAMBELLI--Mary, on December 17, 2013. Beloved wife of the late Francesco. Loving sister of Jean Florio, the late Charles Anzalone and the late Lena Garten. Loving aunt of numerous nieces and nephews. Mary and her late husband Francesco were the renowned and respected proprietors of Giambelli 50th Ristaronte for many years. She will be deeply missed by all who knew and loved her. Friends may call Thursday, December 26, from 2-5pm and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st Street. FOX--Jean, a lifelong new Yorker, died at home in Manhattan on December 13th, 2013, two weeks before her 98th birthday. She was a champion of social justice, an advocate for senior tenants rights, and a devoted wife for 66 years to Sidney Fox, predeceased in 2010. Survived by her two sons, Terry and Paul; her daughters-in-law Susan and Franne; her grandchildren, Avra, Aaron, and Sydney; her grandson-in-law Jose; and her great-granddaughter Matilda; along with her caregiver of many years, Leanne Ford.

BRONFMAN--Edgar M.,Sr. The 92nd Street Y Board and Staff mourn with a heavy heart the passing of Edgar M. Bronfman Sr., beloved father of our long standing Board member and former President, Matthew Bronfman. While Edgar's remarkable life and service will long be remembered, the Jewish world has lost a great leader and we have lost a true friend to our institution. His vision of a proud and vibrant Jewish community finds a home at our Bronfman Center for Jewish Life and leaves a lasting and profound impact on the 92nd Street Y and the many lives we serve. We extend our deepest sympathies to the entire Bronfman family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Stuart J. Ellman, President Thomas S. Kaplan, Chairman Henry Timms, Interim Executive Director

BRONFMAN--Edgar. Hebrew Union College-Jewish Institute of Religion mourns the loss of a defender of the Jewish people, advocate of the State of Israel, champion of Holocaust memory, and recipient of our Dr. Bernard Heller Prize. May his beloved wife Jan, his cherished brother Charles and sister Phyllis, and his dear family find comfort in his inspiring legacy. Rabbi David Ellenson Ph.D, President Rabbi Aaron Panken Ph.D, President-Elect Irwin Engelman, Chairman

BRONFMAN--Edgar M. The Andrea and Charles Bronfman Philanthropies (ACBP) and its officers, staff, and network of supported organizations in the United States, Canada and Israel mourn the passing of Edgar M. Bronfman. We extend our deepest sympathies to his wife, Jan Aronson; his brother, Charles R. Bronfman; his sister, Phyllis Lambert; and his entire immediate and extended family. His tireless work and devotion to Israel and the Jewish people will forever be an inspiration. Jeffrey Solomon, President John Hoover Janet Aviad Sharna Goldseker Senior Vice Presidents, ACBP

BRONFMAN--Edgar, SR. AJC is deeply saddened by the passing of Edgar Bronfman Sr., whose contributions to advancing the well-being of the Jewish people were legendary. He met with world leaders and spoke out on behalf of Jews at risk. He insisted on historical accountability and justice. He also strengthened ties between Israel and the U.S., and sought to enhance the identity of younger American Jews. AJC honored him for his lifelong work in 2000. We extend our heartfelt condolences to his son, Matthew, who serves on AJC's Executive Council, his brother, Charles, a cherished friend, and the other members of the grieving family. May the memory of his remarkable life always be an inspiration and blessing. Stanley Bergman, President David Harris, Executive Director

BRONFMAN--Edgar. UJA-Federation of New York mourns the passing of Edgar Bronfman, a philanthropic giant who demonstrated an unparalleled commitment to improving Jewish communal life. His impact on the Jewish community will live on through his beloved family, including his brother, Charles, a longtime supporter and dear friend of UJA-Federation. We extend our condolences to his wife, Jan Aronson; to his seven children, Samuel Bronfman II, Edgar Bronfman Jr., Matthew Bronfman, Holly Bronfman Lev, Adam Bronfman, Sara Igtet and Clare Bronfman; to Charles, and Edgar's sister Phyllis Lambert; and to the entire family. Alisa R. Doctoroff, President Linda Mirels, Chair of Board John S. Ruskay, Exec. VP & CEO

BRONFMAN--Edgar M. CBE Brooklyn mourns the loss of a fierce friend of the Jewish people. Edgar's youthful vision of doing, learning, and pluralism gave new life to our people's duty to serve with justice and hope. We extend our love to the Bronfman family. Edgar's memory is a blessing. Andy Bachman, Rabbi Charles Nathan, President

BRONFMAN--Edgar. The Steinhardt Foundation for Jewish Life mourns the loss of our friend and partner, Edgar Bronfman. Edgar was the great Jew of his generation. He had both courage and integrity. Our deepest condolences to Jan and the entire family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Michael Steinhardt, Chair Robert Aronson, President Rabbi David Gedzelman, Exec. Vice President

BRONFMAN--Edgar. The Abraham Joshua Heschel School community mourns the passing of Edgar Bronfman, a leader and philanthropist in the Jewish community worldwide and a friend and supporter of our school. We extend our sincere condolences to the entire Bronfman family and in particular to his son, Matthew, and grandchildren Tess, Sasha, and Zeke, students of The Heschel School. May the family be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Joel Citron, President Board of Trustees Roanna Shorofsky, Head of School

BRONFMAN--Edgar M. The World Jewish Congress mourns the passing of Edgar M. Bronfman, our President from 1979 to 2007. He was an unwavering Jewish Leader and visionary. He believed that every Jew is responsible for one another, and his legacy will be forever remembered in the annals of the history of the Jewish People. The World Jewish Congress extends it's heartfelt condolences to the Bronfman family. May they be comforted among the mourners of Zion and Jerusalem. Ronald S. Lauder, President Robert Singer, CEO

BAUM--Judith. We mourn the passing of Judith Baum who died of a heart attack on Friday, at 77. She was a beloved parent and grandparent. Born in Brooklyn on January 4, 1936, Judith graduated from Erasmus Hall high school in 1953 and Barnard College in 1957. After her husband's death in 1974, she received a masters degree from Columbia University in Library Science. She dedicated her professional life to advocacy for improvement of public education. In recent years she was known to parents throughout New York City for her "Ask Judy" column on the Inside Schools website. She published her last blog post hours before she died. Judith leaves her long-time companion, Ike Henkoff; two daughters, Erica and Jenny; two grandchildren, Dashiell and Caleb; her sons-in-law, Tim Allen and Henry Sivak; Ike's daughter Lisa Henkoff: her husband Manu Rana; and their daughter Maya. The funeral will be held Monday, December 23rd at the Plaza jewish Community Chapel at 630 Amsterdam Ave.

BASSER-BIGIO--Barbara. June 23, 1954, died December 20, 2013. She was the beloved daughter of Harold Basser, sister of Peter Basser, wife of Jack Bigio, and mother of Zakieh, Rachel and William. Services 11:30am, Sunday, Temple Shaaray Tefila. In lieu of flowers, donations should be sent to Cycle for Survival.

BASSER-BIGIO--Barbara. The Educational Alliance is deeply saddened by the passing of Barbara Basser-Bigio, a former member of our Board. We offer our sincere condolences to her husband Jack, children Zakieh, Rachel and William, and to the entire family.
BASSER-BIGIO--Barbara. The Board of Directors and Shareholders of 40 East 80 Apartment Corp. send our deepest sympathies to the Bigio family on the passing of Barbara, our dear friend and neighbor.

ALLING--Charles Booth Jr.,92, of Exeter, New Hampshire, and Kennebunk, Maine, died peacefully at home on December 19 after a long illness. Before he graduated from Yale University (1947), he flew 27 combat missions, 19 as a lead pilot, and two mercy missions with the Eighth Air Force over Europe earning the Distinguished Flying Cross and the Air Medal with four Oak Leaf Clusters. In New York City, he became a management consultant and later a Partner and Senior Director of SpencerStuart, an executive search firm. He is survived by his wife Gail McMaster Alling; three daughters Charlotte Alling, Elizabeth Alling Hildt, and Abigail Alling; three grandchildren Christopher Cooke, Abigail Alling, and Charles Hildt; and sister, Elizabeth Atwood. A Celebration of his Life will be held at St. Ann's Episcopal Church in Kennebunk, Maine (summer 2014). In lieu of flowers, a contribution in his memory may be made to St. Ann's Episcopal Church, Box 44, Kennebunkport, Maine 04046 or Yale University, Office of Development, 157 Church Street, New Haven, Connecticut 06510-2100. Services are in care of Bibber Memorial Chapel, Kennebunk. bibberfuneral.com.

Television highlights.
David Boudia and Sam Dorman won the men’s 3-meter synchronized title on the final day of the United States Diving Winter Nationals in Austin, Tex.
The two-time N.C.A.A. singles champion Steve Johnson and 18-year-old Sachia Vickery earned wild-card invitations to the Australian Open.
Paul George scored 24 points and Lance Stephenson recorded his third triple-double of the season, leading the Indiana Pacers over the Boston Celtics.
Kyle Lowry scored 22 points and the Toronto Raptors handed the Oklahoma City Thunder their first home loss with a 104-98 victory on Sunday night.
The teenage golf star Lydia Ko has split with the only coach she has had since she took up the sport as a 5-year-old. The coach, Guy Wilson, has worked with Ko for 11 years.
Defenseman Chris Tanev broke a tie in the third period as Vancouver beat the visiting Winnipeg Jets, 2-1, after Canucks goalie Roberto Luongo left early because of an injury.
The track closed for good after the day’s 11 races, ending 75 years of racing that featured such thoroughbred stars as Seabiscuit, Seattle Slew and Zenyatta.
